column2: WASHINGTON, NOV. 24. 1885. The State Department was informed by cable from Madrid to-day that the Spanish Government had consented to extend the time for putting a higher duty on American straw paper until Feb. 1, to give the American manufacturers a chance to show that injustice was being done on the island of Cuba by putting a higher duty on their paper than is imposed on the same paper made in Europe.

That the Duke of Cumberland is in something more than easy circumstances may be gathered from the fact that the gold and silver plate which he has inherited from the late King of Hanover and the Duke of Brunswick weighs upward of eight tons!

RONDOUT, Nov. 24.--The second day of the trial of Louis Willett, alias Charles Crosby, for the murder of a saloon keeper named Kelland, began this morning in the Circuit Court and Court of Oyer and Terminer, at Kingston.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--The United State Supreme Court to-day transacted the following business: No. 73--Herman Presser, plaintiff in error, vs. The People of the State of Illinois.--Argument continued by...

The process of restoring a characteristic old wooden church at Hopperstad, in the Hardes district of Sogne, in Norway, has brought to light an interesting Norwegian mediaeval relic. In a closed niche a book, consisting of six wax tablets, was found, carefully inclosed in a casket of wood and leather.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24.--The dwelling of Jay Cooke, Jr., at Chelton Hills, Montgomery County, was entered by thieves last night and thoroughly ransacked. Diamonds and other jewelry valued at $2,500 were stolen.
Bride (en route for Montreal with first husband)--Now, George, do be careful. We are to do nothing "bridal," you know.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 24.--Many whisky men were interviewed here to-day as to Commissioner Miller's report recommending an unlimited bond period for whisky, and they were all pleased with it.
ALBANY, Nov. 24.--In the Court of Appeals today, the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following business was transacted:

BOSTON, Nov. 24.--Another scene in the Bowdoin-Square Church trouble was enacted to-night, when Parson Downs presided over a meeting of the church organization, and there was much discussion, but no tangible result.

A correspondent writes: "If you want a solution of the question why typhoid fever is so prevalent in Brooklyn, examine the drinking water. Six years ago the city had clear water; no heavy rains then affected its cleanliness. Now after every storm the water is brown with dirt."
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 24.--Edward P. Brown, the Boston lawyer whose disapperance has been followed by disclosures of fraud on his part, was to-day disbarred by the Superior Civil Court.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 24.--The schooner Cricket, from St. John for New-York, was ashore on Ragged Island on the 20th inst. full of water and with her deckload of laths washed off. She will probably be a total loss.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 24.--T.F. Maloney, retail dry goods, has been attached by H.B. Claflin Co. and other Eastern creditors and also by St. Louis houses. The attachments aggregate $41,000. Maloney made an assignment at about noon to-day. He places his assets at $63,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24.--Slosson, Vignaux, and Schaefer played a three-handed exhibition game of 14-inch balk line billiards, 250 points up, at the Calumet Club this evening in the presence of 350 members of the club and ladies invited to attend. Slosson won the game easily in 12 innings, Vignaux scoring 192 and Schaeter 149. Later in the evening the experts gave a wonderful exhibition of fancy playing.

Many ministers of churches in the vicinity of the Heights, in Brooklyn, gathered yesterday in the First Baptist Church, in Pierrepontstreet, for the purpose of considering plans for arousing religious interest, promoting spiritual prosperity in the church, and to obtain the presence at divine worship of those who have kept away.

The fourth concert of the series of Thomas Populars was given at the Academy of Music yesterday evening. The only unfamiliar number on the programme was a new suite by Tschaikowsky, whereof the divisions are entitled, respectively, "Elegie,"...

At a meeting of the Industrial Educational Association yesterday afternoon, at No. 21 University-place, Gen. A.S. Webb, the President, exhibited specimens of the work done by boys in the College of the City of New-York, to show how well they understood the mechanical contrivances which they studied.
Under the advice of Judge Charles Allen, additional bequests from the balance of the estate of Valeria G. Stone, of Malden, have been made as follows:
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 24.--A profound sensation has been caused here by the discovery of immoralities existing between the boys and girls attending the West High and Tremont Schools.
BISMARCK, Dakota, Nov. 24.--A halfbreed hunter who has arrived from the Canadian Northwest reports that an extremely warlike spirit exists among his countrymen in the Northwest Territory.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Charles H. Fisher, for many years Chief Engineer of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, is suffering from softening of the brain.
Mme. Sophie Menter, the famous pianist had, among the many admirers her talent, the well known Baron S., of Russian celebrity.
LABANY, N.Y., Nov. 24.--Excise Commissioners Morris, Mitchell, and Haughton, of NewYork, appeared before Gov.

The marriage of James F.D. Lanier, son of Charles Lanier, banker, to Miss Harriet daughter of Heber R. Bishop, was solemnized at the West Presbyterian Church, in East Fortysecond-street, yesterday afternoon.
The gas monopoly investigation was resumed at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday by the State Senate committee, comprising Senators Glbert, Murphy, and Robinson.

MONTREAL, Nov. 24.--The French Canadians having expended their spare energy in denouncing the Government and the people of Ontario, have now leisure to look after Riel's spiritual welfare, and masses are to be celebrated...
The Dock Commissioners constituted themselves as investigation committee yesterday and examined witnesses under oath regarding the charges made before the Senate committee.

"When doctors differ" in the Department of Vaucluse they set to work to poison each other, and, indeed, a duel by poison in the case of doctors is quite as rational as a duel with swords or pistols in the case of soldiers.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 24.--Thomas A. Doyle was re-elected Mayor to-day by 2,946 majority over Asa Lyman, the Prohibition candidate. The Republicans made no nomination. License was voted by 826 majority. The vote was very light.
OTTAWA, Nov. 24.--Lord Melgund, Secretary to the Marquis of Lansdowne, GovernorGeneral of Canada, has resigned his position and will return to England at once.
Railway companies do not kill and maim as many people as they did 10 years ago. Improved brakepower no doubt has mainly contributed to this very satisfactory result.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 24.--For some time past the Republicans have been suspicious that the Democrats had not given up the idea of defeating John Sherman for re-election to the Senate.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 24.--A letter from Princeton, Ky., written yesterday, says that on Saturday evening that town was thrown into excitement by the announcement that John Verhoeff, of Louisville, a student of Princeton College, was lost in the saltpetre caverns near town.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 24.--Insurance Commissioner Tarbox furnishes the following list of associations which, not having deposited with the State Treasurer the emergency fund, as required...

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 24.--The great local option contest of Fulton County, in which this city is situated, will be closed to-morrow, the polls throughout the county being open at 6 o'clock. The utmost enthusiasm prevails in the city to-night, and both sides are claiming to-morrow's fight.
J.K. Emmet, generally known as Fritz, is in Bellevue Hospital, where he will remain until he has recovered from an attack of delirium tremens.
The Philadelphia Press has just been cast in damages to the amount of $1,200 for libel, and it very justly complains that the Judge's charge to the jury was neither sound law nor common sense.

The second of the series of Musin-Hyllested matinees at Steinway Hall occurred yesterday. The concert opened with Gade's sonata in A, in which both performers were heard, and this number was followed by a long list of solos, conspicuous among which was Corelli's "La...

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 24.--Joseph G. Lilliston, a traveling man from Cincinnati, attempted to commit suicide here this morning by taking morphine. He made two attempts during the day, but failed each time. He will recover. He gives as a reason that he has been twice discharged for drunkenness.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 24.--At an early hour this morning, between Kent and Akron, the engineer of a New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio freight train found the dead bogy of John P. Hopp, an Akron cigar manufacturer, lying on the track.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 24.--Col. Albert Howell, brother of Capt. E.P. Howell, was shot and seriously wounded this morning at 11 o'clock in the right shoulder, in the Union Passenger Station, this city, by D.H. Pope, who is in the hat business here.

The thirty-second annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held yesterday at the American Exchange Bank. The chief business of the meeting was to listen to the annual reports and to select officers.
"Subscriber."--The word is spelled "Binocle." "J.K.M."--The official vote was printed in THE TIMES on Monday last.
The Brooklyn Temperance Union had its first meeting since the State election, in Everett Hall, No. 298 Fulton-street, last evening. Mr. Edwin P. Ide presided.

The story that George Strassner told the Senate investigating committee about Judge John Henry McCarthy making him divide the salary earned as a stenographer in the Fifth District Court was denied by the Judge in a statement made voluntarily to the committee yesterday.
A meeting of the Classis of New-York was held yesterday afternoon at the Collegiate Dutch Church, at Fifth-avenue and Twentyninth-street, the Rev. J.M. Dickson, D.D., President, in the chair.
When the Williamsburg Athletic Club was lately merged into the Brooklyn Athletic Club the new organization made many changes.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 24.--A convention of believers in the faith cure is being held here. The first session was held this morning in the chapel of the Third Preshyterian Church. Addresses were made by Mrs. Baxter, of England: the Rev. A.W. Simpson, of New-York; Dr. John Cookman, of New-York; the Rev. H. W. Brown, of Chicago, and Mrs. S.G. Beck, of Philadelphia. The convention will continue for several days.

LONDON, Nov. 24.--The following results of the Parliamentary elections were received this afternoon. The Right Hon. David R. Plunket, First Commissioner of Works under the Conservative Cabinet, and Mr. Holmes. Attorney-General for Ireland, also under the Conservative Cabinet, have been elected from the Dublin University divisions.

TORONTO, Nov. 24.--The Mail makes the following important announcement on behalf of the Dominion Government to-day: "Sir John Macdonald was summoned to England by urgent business connected with the fishery question.

The Executive Committee of Twentyfive, members of the lately organized Irish Parliamentary Fund Association, met last night in Parlor E of the Hoffman House and formulated an address to the citizens of the United States,...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 24.--It has been a tedious day on the Hudsen because of a severe storm of snow which raged from 1 o'clock this morning unitl 2 o'clock this afternoon. Fully a foot of snow must have fallen, though all of it did not remain.
COPENHAGEN, Nov. 24.--M. Horup, editor, and President of the Folkething, has been sentenced to six months' imprisonment for writing and publishing an article insulting the King.

John Reardon, cattle salesman, was last week proved before the Newport magistrates to have knocked his wife down and held her on the ground by the hair of her head for five minutes while he pommeled her body with his disengaged fist.

There is quite a little romance associated with the large iron ring worn by Prince Bismarck. The ring has the Russian inscription of "Nitschewo," a word much used by the Russians, and expressing much the same meaning as our "no matter."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--Gen. J.B. Stonehouse died at 1:30 o'clock this (Wednesday) morning.

Undertaker Stephen Merritt was shown copies of Western newspapers last night containing statements that his bill for the funeral expenses of Gen. Grant had been refused payment by the War Department accounting officers.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Nov. 24.--The following was issued to-day by General Manager S.B. Whiting, of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, in anticipation of to-morrow's meeting of the Miners' Amalgamated Association.

When John Rae, of No 135 Concordstreet, Brooklyn, went out of his dressing room to take a bath in the gymnasium of the Young Men's Christian Association, Brooklyn, last night, he left inside a watch and $20, and put the key to the door under the mat. When he came back to dress the watch and money were gone.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 24.--A curious criminal libel suit against M.J. Brzezinski, the Waterbury correspondent of the Examiner of this city, the organ of the Knights of Labor in Connecticut, will probably be brought before the courts here.

It was reported at Police Headquarters last night that Messrs. Rogers, Shandley Farrell, the sub-contractors for a portion of the work of excavating for the new Croton Aqueduct tunnel, had been robbed of a large sum of money by safe burglars.
LONDON, Nov. 24.--Mr. Gladstone spoke at Edinburgh to-day. He complained that Lord Salisbury had misinterpreted his recent utterances.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 24.--Mrs. Elizabeth Smallman, wife of William Smallman, a gardener, was burned to death at her home, No. 10 Lafayette-street, in this city, this morning.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24.--Secret Service Officer John S. Bell to-day arrested Theodore Forrest at the Chrome Steel Works, in Brooklyn, on a charge of making counterfeit five, ten, and twenty-five-cent coins.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 24.--Yellow fever rumors were flying about the streets today creating unpleasant forebodings. On the 11th inst. the British steamship Wivenhoe, Clark master, arrived in the outer harbor in ballast from Kingston, Jamaica.
James Farrell, the ship news agent at Sandy Hook, died suddenly of heart disease yesterday morning in his room in the Sandy Hook light tower.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 24.--A well attended meeting of tobacco dealers was held in the Court House, this city, this evening to consider the subject of taking measures to obtain an increased duty on Sumatra tobacco.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 24.--"I am only here to offer myself as a bloodless sacrifice for the benefit of the bondholders and stockholders of the two roads," remarked president Chauncey M. Depew, of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, to a representative of THE TIMES this forenoon.
MONTREAL, Nov. 24.--A prominent French Canadian anti-vaccinationist named Dr. Coderre was to-day prosecuted in the Health Court for neglecting to report a case of smallpox which he was attending.
Pier No. 29 East River is under the Brooklyn Bridge. It was built by the Bridge Trustees, during the construction of the bridge, on property ceded by the city for bridge purposes.

The New-York Vocal Union is an amateur society which has given a number of concerts with varying success. The first concert of this is ninth season was given in Chickering Hall last evening in the presence of a large audience of invited guests.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--The following letter has been received by Secretary Bayard from Lieut. W. H. Schuetze, united States Navy, who was sent to Siberia last Summer to carry the presents and gratuities awarded by Congress to the natives of that country who befriended the survivors of the Jeannette.

Sister Cipriani arrived at Akasha from El Obeid on Friday, the 23d of October. She came attended by a black lay sister and a Greek, probably the man with whom the form of marriage was gone through for the sake of protection.

ALBANY, Nov. 24.--Among the large batch of decisions by the Court of Appeals today were two of more than ordinary interest. The sentence of Frank R. Sherwin was reversed and the indictment against him quashed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 24.--Clement Grausinger, an old resident of Cass County, died on Sunday morning. Six years ago Grausinger startled his neighbors by telling them that his daughter, a girl aged 20, had committed suicide.

It was to be expected that if Tammany carried its points in the recent election it would grow more arrogant than ever. It triumphed in the nomination of HILL for Governor and of course it is in favor with the State administration.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24.--A Coroner's jury today investigated the circumstances surrounding the murder of Emma Smith last Saturday evening, and came to the conclusion that her husband committed the deed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--Late this afternoon the Spanish Minister received a dispatch sent by the Minister of Foreign affairs from Madrid stating that King Alfonso was last night stricken with a violent disorder of the respiratory organs, and was alarmingly ill.

A meeting for the especial benefit of young men was held in Association Hall last night under the auspices of the White Cross Army of the Young Men's Christian Association. About 1,000 persons were present. Ira D. Sankey led in the singing.

"Iwan," described as a picture of Russian life, was the play presented at the Star Theatre last evening. Herr Friedrich Mitterwurzer appeared in the title role, and he was assisted by more than a score of the members of Mr. Amberg's Thalia Theatre company.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Nov. 24.--Last week diphtheria made its appearance in the family of John Gearhardt, of Maintop, a few miles from Mount Carmel, and to-day the seventh death occurred and four others are at the point of death. The family consisted of 16 members, and it is feared that all of them will die.

The general election to Parliament, which began yesterday, is not of great interest or importance. A nation divided between those who admire and those who detest Mr. GLADSTONE may feel the warmest zeal for the success of one or the other set of candidates who stand respectively for this sympathy and this antipathy.

"Don Giovanni" will be sung at the Academy of Music this evening. Fraulein Lilli Lehmann will make her first appearance in America at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening. She will be heard in "Carmen."

BOSTON, Nov. 24.--The New-York and New-England Directors' meeting to-day, notwithstanding the slight indications of a storm, was a quite serene affair, and important business was transacted without the least friction. There was a large attendance, all but one of the 19 members of the board being present.
The stockholders of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company held their annual meeting yesterday, elected their Board of Directors for the ensuing year, and accepted the annual report.

Joseph W. Wheelock, who keeps an oil and gasoline store on the first floor and basement of No. 118 Maiden-lane, was standing near the door of his office at about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, when he was startled by seeing smoke pouring through the floor, and almost instantly tongues of flame shot through the basement door.

MONTREAL, Nov. 24.--A meeting of the creditors of the insolvent firm of C.T. Picard Co., wholesale jewelers, was to have been held to-day, but had to be adjourned, as the principal member of the firm had fled to Chicago.
Judge O'Gorman having refused to dismiss Mrs. Elizabeth Van Antwerp's suit for a limited divorce, William Van Antwerp took the witness stand in his own defense yesterday.
Mr. George H. sterling, the Brooklyn politician who was recently appointed a Port Warden by Gov. Hill, appeared at the office of the Port Wardens, on South-street, at about...

Fur hat manufacturers representing between $2,000,000 and $3,000,000 of capital packed one of the Metropolitan Hotel parlers yesterday and discussed a constitution and by-laws for an organization which they have been endeavoring to effect since Oct. 28.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24.--Leave of absence for six months is granted Capt. Thomas Garvey, First Cavalry.
Florida sent a contribution to the Grant fund yesterday. Judging from the number of persons of the same surname who contributed the amount it may have been a family affair. It came from Daytona.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24.--Herman Presser was indicted in the Criminal Court of Cook County in 1879 for violating Article XI. of the Illinois Military Code, which makes it unlawful for any body of men other than the regular organized volunteer militia of this State and...
The Commissioners of Inland Revenue have ignominiously surrendered to Mr. Winans, who a short time ago forcibly prevented their officers from entering his deer forest in search of illicit stills.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 24.--In the United States District Court in this city this afternoon two indictments were returned against Thomas Saylor and William G. Gage, both former Postmasters of East Saginaw, and both prominent citizens and Republicans.

PORT EADS, La., Nov. 24.--The steamship Carmona is still aground on a mud lump three-quarters of a mile from the jetty channel. Capt. Frances, the President of the Bar Pilots' Association, says the existence of this mud lump was well known, and that it has existed ever since the jetties were constructed.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 24.--John Crawford, died this morning at Holiday's Cove, West Va., from lockjaw superinduced by having run a splinter under his thumbnail a few days ago.

The revival of Maillart's "Dragons de Villars" at the Thalia Theatre last night, under the title of "The Hermit's Bell," was a noteworthy artistic success, which, owing to the inclement weather, was attended by a very scanty audience.

RONDOUT, Nov. 24.--The doorkeeper at the Ulster County courtroom, Kingston, is Samuel Paulding. He is a full-blooded aristocrat. He is a son of the Paulding who, with Van Wart and Williams, captured Major Andre during the Revolutionary war. Mr. Paulding was also a half brother of the late Admiral Paulding.
JACKSONVILLE, Texas, Nov. 24.--A dastardly assassination occurred near here last night, which will probably result in the lynching of four men within the next 48 hours.

Charles Davidson, 61 years age and a mechanic by occupation, walked into the Oakstreet police station on Monday evening, about 11 o'clock, and complained that he had been injured in one of his his by slipping as he got off a train on the elevated railroad at the Franklin-square station.
The memhership roll of the Staten Island Cricket Club was considerably increased this season. There are now nearly 500 active members and 100 juniors.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 24.--David Graves, a machinist, met with a horrible accident at the Knoxville Iron Company's Rolling Mills this morning.
Our Washington dispatches yesterday morning reported the opinion of Senator CAMDEN, of New-Jersey, regarding the prospect of tariff legislation in the next Congress as follows: "I think there will...

Services commemorative of the reopening of the Sisters' House, the Home for the Aged, and the Babies' Shelter, which have been enlarged and improved during the past Summer, were held in the Church of the Holy Communion, corner of Sixth-avenue and Twentiethstreet, yesterday afternoon, the Right Rev.

A well dressed man, accompanied by Detective Dolan, of the Central Office, entered the reception room of Bellevue Hospital late last evening and made inguiries regarding a man who was found unconscious in the Grand Central Station on Tuesday morning.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Nov. 25.--When exVice-President David Davis was told this evening that Mr. Hendricks was dead he paused for a moment and then said: "And so poor Hendricks is dead.

Coroners Kennedy and Messemer settled their difficulty regarding the right to hold the inquest into the deaths of Joseph Baff and Mrs. Mary M. Conn, who were killed by the falling of one of the walls of the burned Empire Plaster Mills, on Bethune-street, on the 19th inst., by the latter gracefully giving way.

The markets presented a lively aspect yesterday afternoon. The buying for Thanksgiving of course began before yesterday, but a large number of people naturally deferred purchasing until the last day in order to have their poultry fresh.

A reception to the Rev. Francis Pigott, who has come over from England to conduct the Advent Mission services in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, was given last night at the house of John H. Glover, No. 531 Madison-avenue.

Justice Kilbreth was engaged for over an hour yesterday afternoon in holding an investigation in the case of William Peck, the young man who was arrested on Monday by Detective Price, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, for having abducted Sadie Gilfoyle, a young girl, from her home at Stamford, Conn.

In the security vault of the American Safe Deposit Co., Fifth-avenue and Forty-secondstreet, one's valuable personal effects are beyond the reach of harm, loss, risk, or interference of any kind and are always accessible to the owner. Private safes from $10 a year upward.--Exchange.

A meeting of the stockholders of the Fifth-Avenue Transportation Company was held at Delmonico's yesterday afternoon for the purpose of adopting by-laws and electing a Board of Directors. Mr. Bradish Johnson, Jr., officiated as Chairman and Mr. Eugene M. Earle as Secretary.
MONTREAL, Nov. 25.--Mr. W.H. Lytell, propreitor of the Montreal Opera House, was arrested late last night on a caplas taken out by Mrs. Bernard for arrears of salary amounting to $79 50.
A peculiar and exceedingly serious accident occurred in St. Mary's Star of the Sea Church Sunday morning, the unfortunate victim being Patrick Cooney, one of the collectors.

KINGSTON, Nov. 25.--In the case of Louis Willett, alias Charles Crosby, the testimony given to-day was strongly against the prisoner, who on the former trial was found guilty of murder and sentenced to be hanged.

Police Justice Charles Welde, the Tammany Hall leader in the Twenty-third Assembly District, gave a a banquet last night to the hundred members of the District General Committee and a few specially invited guests.
A Brooklyn man, J.D. Lloyd, of Company K. Thirteenth Regiment, carried off the laurels at the third game of the Ninth Regiment last evening.
The twenty-first annual report of the Sheltering Arms, Tenth-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth-street, contains some interesting information in regard to the work of the institution.

The high tide at Rockaway Beach on Tuesday night caused considerable damage. About a mile of the New-York, Woodhaven and Rockaway Railroad track was washed away, preventing the running of trains beyond Hammils.
A.S. Flandrau Co., of Broome-street, have been awarded four silver medals for the display of fine carriages made by them at the horse show lately held at the Madison-Square Garden.
GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 25.--State Health Officer Swearingen has arrived in this city from Austin, and visited the yellow fever patient on board the steamship Wivenhoe, now lying at Quarantine.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25.--The Appellate Court here to-day reversed the decision of the lower court in the suit of David Belasco against Manager J.M. Hill. Belasco agreed to write a play, to be named "Lone Pine," for Mr. Hill, and if the latter liked it and pronounced it a success he was to pay $5,000 for it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--The Supreme Court of the United States transacted the following business to-day: No. 75--W.C. Holgate et al., appellants, vs. Rufus I. Eaton, Administrator, continued by James H. Hoyt for the appellee and concluded by W.C. Holgate for the appellants.

Mr. O.B. Potter and several other taxpayers appeared before the Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday to oppose the project to construct the Quaker Bridge Dam. Mr. Potter submitted a protest signed by himself, William H. Webb, Robert L. Darragh, and A.P. Man, in which it was said, in reference to the two plans now before the Commissioners:
Uncle Rufus Hatch is making another effort to regain control of the Yellowstone National Park Improvement Company, now in the hands of Receivers. He alleges gross mismanagement...
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--Gen. N.P. Lane, of Philadelphia, had an interview with President Cleveland this morning, and presented him with the following communication:

LONDON, Nov. 25.--To-night's borough returns swell the tide of Conservative reaction. Unless there is an unexpected change in the current as shown by the returns thus far received the Conservatives are sure to have such a majority as will enable them to hold office.

ROCKLAND LAKE, Nov. 25.--Last night, shortly before midnight, while the storm was raging with frightul severity. Mr. and Mrs. James McNamara, who live in New-Jersey, close to the Rockland County (N.Y.) line, were driving from the northern part of the county to this place, and experienced an accident which they would not like repeated.

Suicide is increasing in Berlin to what may be called a most frightful extent. In one day lately there were no fewer than 10 cases of self-murder and attempted self-murder, while not a single day passes without bringing its repulsive story of suicide in some form or other.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 25.--Reports from Northern Connecticut say that that part of the State has passed through the heaviest November storm on record. Beginning last Sunday, snow fell for four days, and many roads in the towns of Litchfield County are impassable, ...
When the last census was taken in 1881 the following were found to be the numbers of the United Kingdom:
Miss Marie Louise Finch, a daughter of Mrs. L. Finch, was married last evening to Mr. Hurry Standish, the comedian, who made a hit as the Minister of War in the "Queen's Lace Handkerchief."

Senator John Sherman, who is stopping at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, discussed with great freedom last night the actual and possible effect of the death of the Vice-President. He said that he had learned of Mr. Hendricks's demise with sincere personal regret.

The Governors of the Southern States are responding very generally to the invitation of Gov. Perry, of Florida, to send delegates from each of the Congressional districts to the Southern Forestry Congress, which is to meet at De Funlak Springs on Dec. 18. The subject of forestry is one of growing, if not pressing, importance, and should be given as far as possible the attention it deserves.
LONDON, Nov. 25.--4:30 P.M.--A dispatch has just been received at the foreign Office from Madrid stating that King Alfonso died at 9 o'clock this morning of consumption, accelerated by dysentery.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 25.--The Coroner's jury investigating the cause of the recent explosion in Shaft No. 2 of the Delaware and Hudson Coal Company's mine, in Plymouth, whereby several men lost their lives and a number were injured rendered a verdict late this evening.

RONDOUT, Nov. 25.--Luther Krom, of Kripplebush, Ulster County, was crushed to death near that place three days ago. Krom was 16 years of age, and he heroically sacrified his own life to save a little sister.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--The leave of First Lieut. Bainbridge Reynolds, Third Cavalry, is further extended two months. The Superintendent of the General Recruiting Service is ordered to send 58 recruits to the Department of the Platte for the Seventh Infantry; the Superintendent of the Mounted Recruiting Service is ordered to send 84 recruits to the Department of Missouri for the Fifth Cavalry.
The representation of "Carmen" at the Metropotitan Opera House last evening brought together another large and fashionable assemblage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25, 1885. Gen. John Eaton, Commissioner of Education, to-day tendered his resignation, to take effect upon the appointment and qualification of his successor. Gen. Eaton's health is much impaired, and he resigns for the purpose of accepting the Presidency of a college, where his labors will be less exacting.

A statement has been issued by Health Commissioner Raymond, of Brooklyn, in regard to the prevalence of typhoid fever in that city. In answer to questions to physicians he was assured that the prevalence of the disease was not alarming.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 25.--Two million eight hundred and sixteen thousand bushels of barley have been received at this port this season, an increase of about 200,000 bushels over the same period last season.
The election in this city yesterday resulted in the practically unanimous choice of the Hon. Thomas A. Doyle for Mayor for his seventeenth term of service.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 25.--The valuation of the State as reported by the Assessors of cities and towns to the Secretary of State shows a net increase of $25,469,365 over that of the previous year.
Messrs. Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities at auction yesterday at the Liberty-street Real Estate Exchange:
Matinees will be given at all the city theatres to-day except Wallack's, where the stage will be needed for a rehearsal of "Hoodman Blind."

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 25.--Mr. Thomas Flatley, a well known Democratic lawyer and the first Secretary of the Irish National Land League of America, was to-day appointed Deputy Collector of Customs by Collector Saltonstalt.

Samuel Sloan, the controlling spirit, of the Lackawanna Coal and Railroad Companies, and a Director in the Consolidated Gas Company, was the first witness examined by the Senate Gas Commission in the Fitth-Avenue Hotel yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 25.--The Circuit Court to-day passed upon the Senatorial mandamus case, which has been pending since the official count following the October election.

BOSTON, Nov. 25.--The protest in behalf of Cyrus W. Field, Russell, Sage, and others of the New-York syndicate, against the sale of the New-York and New-England bonds by the State, was considered by the Governor and Council to-day.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 25.--After the most exciting election ever held in the State, Fulton County has adopted prohibition by a majority of about 219 out of a poll of 9,000.
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 25.--To-day witnessed the annual parade of the Central Trades and Labor Assembly, and the city has in consequence presented a gale appearance.

The third anniversary banquet of the Society of '83 was held at the Hotel Brunswick last night. The Society of '83 is composed of representatives of New-York in 1837 and the descendants of Revolutionary families.
A brutal murder was discovered yesterday morning in a low Swedish sailors' boarding house in the lower part of the city.

Joseph K. Emmet awoke refreshed and "Fritz again" yesterday morning at Bollevue Hospital, and the doctors thought him well enough to the doctors thought him well the St. James Hotel, patted Clerk Hill on the back, hugged his son, called a cab, and left for Williamsport, Penn., to fulfill an engagement there to-night.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 25.--The Rev. J.G. Smart has resigned the pastorate of the Presbyterian church at Norwood, N.J., just over the Rockland County (N.Y.) border, and accepted a call from the Reformed church at Schoharie.

According to schedules filed in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday, Henry N. Smith, the insolvent speculator, owes $1,350,403 26 and has assets nominally worth $609,118.44, but actually worth only $203,935.82.

ROCK HILL, S.C., Nov. 25.--Bishop J.J. Moore, of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, held special services for the white people in Roddey's Hall, in this place, last night, and told an interesting story of having met a sister from whom he had been separated for 62 years.

Mr. HENDRICKS was a type of the sincere and earnest partisan Democrat, of upright personal character and considerable abilities, whose sympathies were too narrow, whose views too restricted to permit him the place in political history to which he aspired.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 25.--Detective Adams, of New-York, will on Saturday return to NewYork, having in custody Robert Hovan, alias Henry Parker, alias Edward Harrington.

The utterances of the head of the Roman Catholic Church have an increasing interest and importance for the people of this Republic, although hardly more than one-tenth of them profess the faith of Rome.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 25.--The subscriptions for the relief of the sufferers by the recent fire now aggregate $110,000, of which the committee has received $91,600, and disbursed $50,230 among 1,107 applicants for aid.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25.--Capt. Hines, of the steamer Wyoming, from Richmond, reports that he has seen several times recently the heel of a heavy spar, probably bowsprit, sticking about two feet out of the water four or five miles southeast of Hog Island Light, Virginia, in seven fathoms of water. It is in the track of vessels bound up and down the coast.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 25.--The official count of the vote at the November State election is reported by the Exceutive Council as follows.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 25.--Recent reports of the deepening of the channel of Sabine Pass are of a very favorable character. The Government has so far appropriated $500,000 for the work of improvement, and the water on the bar has been increased from six to ten feet, and the channel is constantly deepening.

In order to avoid trial on the indictment hanging over him in the District Attorney's office, Monmouth B. Wilson went before the Senate investigating committee yesterday, and offered to purge himself of contempt of the Senate.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25.--The Metropolitan Hotel, on Seventh and Market streets, was destroyed by fire early this morning.

Gen. Abraham Dally, 90 years old, and Henry Morris, 86, were the only veterans of the war of 1812 able to respond yesterday to Major Louis Hallan's invitation to a dinner at the Tontine Hotel, on Broome-street, to celebrate the one hundred and second anniversary of the British evacuation.
TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 25.--Eastwood Barfoot, lithographers, of Toronto, have failed. Their liabilities are $15,000. A. Wetherell, (dry goods,) of Hamilton, has also failed. Liabilities, $20,000.
In September last Eckford's machine shop, at No. 40 Morris-street, Jersey City, was burned, and two wooden houses adjoining, Nos. 42 and 44, were gutted, the skeletons alone remaining in position.

The police were notified last night to look for Augusta Ming Britton, 12 years old, and a pupil at the West Twelfth-street school. She went there yesterday morning and did not return to her home, No. 138 Clinton-place.

Mr. Louis F. Dommerich, the silk importer of No. 57 Greens-street, who had been living at his country residence at New-Brighton, Staten Island, took possession a month ago of the mansion, No. 25 Gramerey Park, which is owned by the Pryor estate.

Thomas Andrews Hendricks was disposed toward a public career both by nature and by training. His temperament was sanguine and elastic, and he could recover from the knockdown blows of practical politics with a smiling celerity which stood him good service through the ups and downs of a life which became part of public history 40 years ago, and which ended, as Mr. Hendricks intended it should, while he was yet in harness.
PANAMA, Nov. 17.--The revolution in Nicaragua is ended.

CAMBRIDGE, Nov. 25.--The Harvard University catalogue was issued this morning, and, as usual, it gives a great many interesting facts about the college proper and the various schools connected with the university.

It has just been decided that the Cossacks of Terek, Oural, Couban and Astrakhan, who, in time of peace, number 18, and in time of war 53 regiments, shall in the future have the same number of officers as the regular cavalry regiments.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 25.--Indianapolis mourns to-night the death of her foremost citizen as she did eight years ago this same month when Senator Morton expired after a lingering illness.

A spirit of glee pervaded the rooms of the Grant Monument Association yesterday. The faces of visitors who called "to see how the fund was getting along" beamed with satisfaction at the announcement that the stumbling block had been removed and that the treasury of the fund at length contained more than $100,000.
The Yale and Wesleyan College football teams will play a championship game on the Polo Grounds this afternoon. The game will begin at 2:30.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 25.--The completion to-day of the canvass of the vote cast in the election on Nov. 3 for Attorney-General shows that Rufus A. Ayres, Democratic candidate, received 152,375 votes, and Frank S. Blair, Republican, 136,129.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 25.--By the largest single transfer of real estate ever made in Marshall County, the Hon. Stephen B. Packard, of New-Orleans, becomes the owner of 1,240 acres of land in Linn and Marietta Townships, about two miles west of Marshalltown City, comprising what were known as the Allen farms.
BOSTON, Nov. 25--The easterly gale which began on Friday night continues, although the wind has decreased in velocity, with a prospect of blowing itself out before many hours.
LONDON, Nov. 25.--The Government today publishes advertisements soliciting tenders for laying a cable from Halifax to Bermuda and Jamaica under a subsidy from the Government.
There is something of the shrewd humor of the Oriental cazi in the decision of a Russian stipendiary magistrate, a report of which has just reached us from Odessa.
At yesterday's hearing, by Referee Hamilton Cole, in the case of Mr. Holt, the Assignee for Ferdinand Ward, against William S. Warner, Gen. Hubbard resumed the examination of Cashier Spencer.
PALENVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 25.--Andrew Erbacher, a farmer living at Manorville, Greene County, a little hamlet a few miles from this place, is the owner of a full-grown hog that is a great curiosity.

Senator Sherman sat in a private box at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre Last night with Mr. E. A. Bateman, H. Victor Newcomb, and Alfred Hayt. He was quite merry over the first part of "The Mikado," but when the announcement of Vice-President Hendricks's death reached him he appeared deeply worried.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange yesterday adopted the amendment to the by-laws which provides for the substitution of a Moderator and a Chairman for the Chairman and Vice-Chairman at present having charge of the practical workings of the Exchange during business hours.

Judge Hoffman's punishment of the Chinese defendant who stole his way into the country upon a certificate filled out for another is severe. The man is fined $1,000, and goes to prison for five years. The hope may be entertained that this example will check the disposition of the Chinese to treat the Restriction act with contempt.

BOSTON, Nov. 25.--Upon receipt of a dispatch from Chief of Police Campbell, of Brooklyn, N.Y., this morning, Inspectors arrested Herman Brindee, alias Jacob Cox, a fugitive from justice from Brooklyn. Brindee is wanted in Brooklyn for swindling insurance companies. He has been practicing in the same field here to a small extent. He will go to New-York without a requisition.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday distributed $47,498 98 of the excise money to various charitable institutions for the care during August of children committed by Police Justices.
BELGRADE, Nov. 25.--It is officially announced to-day that King Milan has accepted the armistice proposed by the powers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25.--Slosson, Schaefer, and Vignaux to-night signed an agreement to enter into a sweepstakes, 14-inch Balk-line tournament, open to the world, for $500 a corner, 600 points up. The games are to be played in NewYork some time between Dec. 15 and Feb. 15 on a 5x10 carrom table, with 2 3/8-inch balls.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 25.--Dr. J.A. Milno, a leading physician of this place, was to-day fined $250, with the alternative of six months' imprisonment, for contempt of court in refusing to testify in a criminal case. Dr. Milne pleaded as a defense for his refusal that his testimony would involve the disclosure of professional secrets.

In New-York the announcement was received with mingled doubt and surprise. The first intimation to the general public of the Vice-President's death was given unofficially about the hotels by the telegraph operators, but no one was ready to believe it. Later, the intelligence was conveyed from the newspaper offices, and when the "extras" were presented about the hotels and theatres they were eagerly purchased.

A religious mass meeting for working people under the auspices of St.'Mark's parish and in connection with the Advent Mission will be held at Clarendon Hall, Thirteenth-street, between Third and Fourth avenues, on Saturday evening.

ALBANY, Nov. 25.--Attorney-General O'Brien has appointed Tuesday, Dec. 2, at 10 o'clock A.M., to hear arguments in the application made to him by Clarence Seward to begin an action to restrain the laying of horse car rails on Fifth-avenue, New-York City.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25.--The first full and authentic translation into English of Pope Leo's encyclical on the Christian constitution of States shows the letter to be somewhat different from the cable condensations already published. Instead of condemning in any way modern civilization or States as they exist at present, the Pope approves of all real progress and true freodom. Following is the letter in full:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 25.--The striking coal miners of the lower pools have chartered a steamboat and will leave for the fourth pool this evening for the purpose of bringing out the miners who returned to work at the reduced rate.
READING, Penn., Nov. 25.--The firm of Glaser Frame, of this city, extensive manufacturers and jobbers of cigars, are being boycotted by the Knights of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25.--The Secretary of the Interior has received the annual report of Gen. John C. Black, Commissioner of Pensions, for the year ended June 30, 1885. It shows that there were at the close of the year 345,125 pensioners.
MONTREAL, Nov. 25.--A special dispatch from Regina says the reply of the Northwest Council to Lieut-Gov. Dewdney's address was issued late last evening.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 26.--At present a great many separations are being applied for in court here by wives from their husbands. No less than eight cases of this kind have just been entered on the docket of the Superior Court for a hearing. The majority of the applications are against hotel, restaurant, and saloon keepers.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--A dispatch from Sofia states that at 4 o'clock on the morning of Thursday, the 26th inst., Prince Alexander, at the head of 50,000 Bulgarian troops, entered Servia. Great enthusiasm prevails in the army and throughout Bulgaria.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26.--Five barbers were fined by a police magistrate here to-day for profanation of the Sabbath by following their calling on that day. The magistrate said that printers and telegraph operators, unless working for the Government, were liable to a similar penalty.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., Nov. 26.--It is believed that the barge Cornelius Grinnell went down in the gale of Wednesday, and that her crew of three men perished.

LONDON, Ontario, Nov. 26.--Col. Williams, commanding the Seventh Fusileers, who served in the Northwest during the half breed rebellion, has been suspended. The reason assigned is the alleged failure of Col. Williams to report a letter received by him during the campaign.

Adolph Schulze, it Berlin policeman, and a self-taught linguist, has made the most of his leisure hours by translating into German the recent work of Col. A drummer from Waynesborough says that at the late fair in that town about 20 thieves and sharpers were arrested. The citizens took the law into their own hands, and, after stripping off all the clothes from the gang, turned them loose to make their way up North the best they could. The fellows begged some old clothes from negroes and organized themselves into a band of tramps.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 26.--The last boats passed up the Delaware and Hudson Canal Nov. 21, on which date the company ceased issuing permits.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 26.--The game at the Exposition to-day was too one-sided to require a description. Foutz and Bushong did splendid batting work for St. Louis, the New-Yorks getting in only three scattering hits, although none of them struck out.

GRENADA, Miss., Nov. 26.--A difficulty occurred here to-day in which B.T. Wright and his son shot and killed Eugene Melton. The men concerned in the affair were cotton weighers, and the trouble grew out of business rivalry. Reports of the affair are unfavorable to the Wrights, who are now in prison. It is said that they fired several shots at Melton, five of which took effect, while Melton did not fire once.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Nov. 26.--In the case of Frank Palmer, on trial here for the murder of Peter Bernard, committed at Dannemora on the night of Aug. 9, the jury this afternoon brought in a verdict of guilty of murder in the second degree, and Palmer was sentenced to life imprisonment in Clinton Prison. The verdict is looked upon as a compromise one. Palmer belongs in South Royalton, Vt., as did also his victim.

MONTREAL, Nov. 26.--Two barges loaded with wood, one belonging to J.B. Blanchard and the other to Mr. Tate, are reported as having sunk on Lake St. Louis during the recent heavy gale. The barges were in tow at the time. The crews were saved.

The usual special Winter services for Bellevue Hospital will begin on Advent Sunday, Nov. 29, at 3 o'clock P.M., when Assistant Bishop Henry C. Potter will preach and confirm about 25 of the patients. Until May services will be held every Thursday evening, at which the city clergy are expected to preach and several of the city choirs to take part. Interested friends are invited to attend.

There are nine churches of the Mormon faith in Southern Indiana. They belong to the Joseph Smith, or anti-polygamy, wing of the church. There has been a church in Floyd County ever since 1868, and it is said the sect is growing slowly but surely. A conference now in session at Lancaster, Jefferson County, numbers about 50 members. Elder Morris Scott, of Galena, Floyd County, is head of this branch of the church in Indiana.

The audience at the Star Theatre last evening which greeted Herr Friedrich Mitterwurzer was not lacking in numbers or enthusiasm. He made his first appearance as Kean in Schneider's adaptation of the drama of that name.
The report of the Controller of the Currency, the Hon. H.W. CANNON, has been submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury, and an abstract of its provisions will be found in another column.

Charles Cox accompanied Capt. Jewett, of the Tenth Precinct, Brooklyn, when he returned from Boston last night. Cox was an insurance swindler, who had been arrested in Boston and who also had a previous record in Brooklyn.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 26.--It is understood here that Sandford Fleming, George Stephen, and the Hon. D.A. Smith will be knighted for services rendered in connection with the construction of the Canadian Pacific Railroad.

LIMA, Nov. 26, via Galveston.--A great sensation has been caused here by the receipt of a telegram announcing that Gen. Caceres with his entire army had surprised and occupied the town of Chicla on the 23d inst.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 26.--The severe storm that had prevailed on the New-England coast for several days subsided early this afternoon.
BELLEVILLE, Ontario, Nov. 26.--Spurious ten-dollar bills are in circulation here. These bills are made by cutting up genuine bills and pasting the pieces together so as to make additional bills.

The marble memorial altar in memory of the late Rector of St. Gabriel's Church, in East Thirty-seventh-street, the Rev. William H. Clowry, was consecrated yesterday morning by Archbishop M.A., Corrigan.
Harry P. Bell, 22 years of age, a clerk in Benjamin Forshay's grocery at Port Chester, committed suicide in his bedroom yesterday afternoon just after having eaten his Thanksgiving dinner.

William Clark, a fireman on board the steamer St. Laurent, appeared yesterday in the Tombs Police Court and charged Patrick O'Brien and Michael Flannagan, two of the Whyo Gang, with having robbed him the previous evening in Spruce-street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26.--Three hundred men gathered under a red flag at Market and Washington streets this afternoon in response to a call "on Chicago workingmen, tramps, and all others who are despoiled and disfranchised," to attend Thanksgiving services and learn "how turkeys and other nice things may be procured."

The Duke and Duchess of Connaught brought home from India a large collections. Oriental china and other rare and valuable articles, many of which were intended as presents. Unluckily the delicate cargo was carelessly packed, and almost everything has been broken or badly chipped.

The announcement that the Rev. Dr. K. Kohler, at the Temple Beth-El, would give his views upon the declaration of principles recently adopted at Pittsburg by the reform Jewish rabbis, drew a large congregation to the synagogue yesterday morning.

QUEBEC, Quebec, Nov. 26.--The Signal Service reports the steamer Earl of Dufferin, of Halifax, a total wreck on Anticosti Island, at the same place as the steamer Brooklyn was wrecked. The crew reached the shore in safety.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26.--Two hundred and sixty-one members of the First Regiment, Illinois National Guard, were this afternoon instructed in "street riot" drill in the presence of 3,000 people.

The members of the American Athletic Club enjoyed their regular Thanksgiving Day hare and hounds chase yesterday. At an early hour in the morning Pettit's Hotel, in Jamaica, the starting point, was filled with well developed young men.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26.--Two men, giving their names as John Smith and John F. Leonard, were arrested here to-day on suspicion of passing counterfeit money. The mold and metal were found in Smith's coat pocket.

The old-time trotting celebrity, Occident, died in San Francisco on Friday, after a few hours' illness. He had the fastest record to his credit in 1873, (2:16 ,) and raised an excitement over the whole country. He was 22 years old.
MONTREAL, Nov. 26.--Mr. Joseph Tasse, member of Parliament, arrived in this city today from New-York, having returned from a trip to France.

MADRID, Nov. 26.--Senor Canovas went to El Pardo again to-day and presented the resignations of the Cabinet Ministers to the Queen.
Mr. Patrick Henry Roche, a well known Seventh Ward County Democrat and an Assemblyman, has suddenly taken a notion to visit the saline region of the State in and about Syracuse.
QUEBEC, Nov. 26.--Five hundred and eighty seagoing vessels were entered at this port since the opening of navigation. Navigation is now closed.

MONTREAL, NOV. 26.--Savage Lyman, jewelers, of this city, owing to the very great depression in business, have decided to make a judicial abandonment of their estate. Liabilities, $30,000; assets, about $22,000.
An exhibition of homing pigeons will take place at the American Institute Fair on Wednesday and Thursday under the management of the Federation of American Homing Pigeon Fanciers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26.--There was a quiet but general observance of Thanksgiving Day in this city. Business was entirely suspended, and there was a large attendance at the religious services in all the churches.

The new Goethe Society of Weimar promises great things. Its projected activity may be divided into three branches: (1) The preparation of a full and detinitive edition of the poet's works, including notes, sketches, fragments, and preparatory studies.
CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 26, via Galveston. --The Governors of a number of Mexican States are gathering here, and many political rumors are afloat as to the cause.
The civil suit of "Doc" Wilson, of Providence, against P.L. Moen, of this city, for $100,000, is to begin before Judge Carpenter, at the session of the United States court, Post ...

The Chambers last session passed a new excise law relative to the brewing of beer, which will come into operation on the 1st of January next. During the last 10 years the importation of German, especially Munich, beer into this ...
The tugboat C.H. Raymond, which put into port yesterday, reported that she attempted to tow in the dismasted brig Mattie B. Russell, which was spoken on Nov. 24 off Absecom by the bark Conductor.

BUFFALO, Nov. 26.--Senator-elect McMillan denies the statement lately printed in the New-York Tribune that he is pledged to support John W. Vrooman for Clerk of the Senate. He says he is not pledged to any one.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 26.--Estella Beach was a domestic in the family of Martin Hermance at Rhinecliff. She was a modest, handsome girl about 20 years of age, and had the esteem and confidence of her employers.

LONDON, Nov. 26.--The British steamer Aurora, Capt. Ormandy, while leaving Hartlepool for Savannah yesterday, struck a rock in the harbor. She subsequently proceeded, and foundered within two hours. The crew left the vessel in three boats. The first boat, with nine men, and the third, with twelve men, landed safely. The second, in which were nine men, reached shore with only six, the three others having been drowned.
MONTREAL, Nov. 26.--Messrs. Savage Lyman, jewelers, of St. James-street, were obliged to call a meeting of their creditors today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 26.--The indications all are that the funeral of Vice-President Hendricks next Tuesday will be the most memora ble affair of the kind ever seen in the West, except on the occasion of President Garfield's burial.

GREYSTONE, N.Y., Nov. 26.--I am inexpressibly shocked by the surprising and painful intelligence of the sudden closing of the career of your husband. He has fallen with honors thick upon him and in the acme of his popular esteem. In your personal bereavement I deeply sympathize, while, in common with the whole country, I deplore the loss of Mr. Hendricks as a public calamity. SAMUEL J. TILDEN.
On Wednesday afternoon a young and well dressed man applied for a room at the Coleman house. His actions were strange, as though he had been drinking heavily for some time or had been taking opium.

SUSQUEHANNA, Penn., Nov. 26.--For many years J.E. Payne has been one of the most respected and enterprising citizens of Arrarat, a small village in this county, near this place, on the line of the Jefferson branch of the Erie Railway. He is a merchant.

When the steamship Egyptian Monarch, of the Monarch Line, reached her pier in Jersey City yesterday, it was discovered than 31 cases of tin and four cases of mohair cloth, valued at $1,000, had been stolen from the hold.

ATLANTA, Nov. 26.--The excitement in the election of yesterday is unabated. The whole question will unquestionably go into the courts, and the liquor men claim that the result of the election will be overthrown.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 26.--It is reported that the scab has broken out among the sheep in County Yamaska.

A number of Scotchmen, lovers of outdoor sports, assembled on the old ScottishAmerican Athletic Club Grounds yesterday to witness the Caledonian sports that took place there.
A football match was played yesterday afternoon on the Polo Grounds between the Yale and Wesleyan teams. About 4,000 spectators were present and cheered, the contestants in their efforts.

C.H. Upson, the patient who is held as a prisoner at Bellevue Hospital, as state in THE TIMES yesterday, is wanted by the authorities of Brockton, Mass., for embezzlement.

HAWKINSVILLE, Ga., Nov. 27.--Pearce Rose, colored, has been found guilty of the murder of Jerry Cowan, an old man to whose daughter he was engaged in marriage. He enticed the old man into the woods, brained him with a club, and then covered him with loose earth and leaves. Hogs rooting around discovered the dead body.

GALVESTON, Nov. 27.--In the heart of the great burned district, on Church-street, between Eighteenth and Nineteenth streets, was found this morning the body of a handsome young man, with a bullet through his brain.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 27.--The citizens of Indianapolis have entered zealously into the work of arranging for the obsequies of the late Vice-President. Until they are completed and the funeral services are held, business, both public and private, will be practically suspended.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27.--A bunch of casualties is reported in State specials this evening. Charles Filliatreau, a well-to-do farmer and Postmaster at Randolph, was killed yesterday by falling off a tree.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27.--Andrew Paxton, General Agent of the Citizens' League, and David Cory, also an agent of the League, were early this afternoon assaulted and knocked down in Clark-street by some unknown man.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 27.--The report of the Ontario Bureau of Industries for November, just issued, states that Fall wheat shows a large yield, of fine quality, while Spring wheat is a failure, both in quantity and quality.

A lamp exploded in the second hand sewing machine store of Matthews Sandford, at No. 526 Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, late last evening, causing a fire which required several hours of hard work to get under control.

MONTREAL, Nov. 27.--George Le Furgay, the notorious Prince Edward Island forger, has been released on account of ill health from the penitentiary, where he was sent on a life sentence. He has gone to Boston.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--The following officers of the Corps of Engineers, members of the Board of Visitors to the Engineer School of Application, at Willet's Point, N.Y., will proceed to Willet's Point for the purpose of making the semi-annual inspection of the school: Col. James C. Duane, ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 27.--Justice Meech left his seat in the Armory Police Court this morning and bent his head to catch the whispered words of a wasted, white-faced woman who sat in the witness chair propped up with pillows.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27.--Mrs. William Smith was arrested this morning on a charge of attempting to poison her husband, and was held for examination under $1,000 bail. The woman denies the charge, but it is said there is strong circumstantial evidence against her. Her husband is now out of danger. Jealousy is assigned as the cause of the trouble.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--The results of the elections to-day demonstrate that two swallows do not make a Summer. The unexpectedly great majorities for Mr. Gladstone and Lord Hartington, while they delight the Liberals, fail to reassure them.

LONDON, Nov. 28.--Telegrams have been received here from Calcutta announcing the breaking out of a rebellion in Nepaul. The Premier has been murdered and the Maharajah of the province has been taken prisoner. The British Resident is absent from Khatmandu on a tour of inspection.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 27.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20; drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25.

JOLIET, Ill., Nov. 27.--A daring escape was made from the Joliet Penitentiary yesterday afternoon by Daniel McAllister, alias "Peoria Dan," who was sent up from Peoria in 1876 on a life sentence for murder.

A large number of wealthy and influential holders of gas stocks attended the session of the Senate investigating committee at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday. The testimony was listened to with interest by several of the officers of the Consolidated Gas Company. The members of the committee--Senators Gilbert, Murphy, and Robinson--were all present.

Two weeks ago a dapper young man engaged a room at No. 43 Chatham-street and paid a half month's rent. He used to open the room late in the morning and close it early in the afternoon, and sometimes for days the office would remain closed.
The Tammany Society last night resolved to send the full band of 13 sachems, headed by Grand Sachem P. Henry Dugro, to attend the funeral of Vice-President Hendricks at Indianapolis on Tuesday next.
The Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen heard further arguments yesterday upon the proposed horse railroad on St. Nicholas-avenue and One Hundred and Twentysixth-street.
Many of the merchants and manufacturers of New-Hampshire were not in a thankful mood last Thursday, and the coming holiday season will not put them in good humor.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27.--William J. Clinger, the Democratic Clerk of the Armory Police Court, the most important Police Court in the city, is believed to have gotten away with fully $30,000 of the city's good money during the five years he has held his present office.

Coroner Messemer held an inquest yesterday in the case of John Hayes, a 12-year-old boy, of No. 66 Cliff-street, who was run over and killed by a Broadway car on Oct. 7, at Twelfthstreet and Broadway.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27.--Betting men who laid wagers on the result of the billiard tournament are in a good deal of trouble over the way the contest was settled. Riley Co., the pool sellers of this city, have not yet paid a dollar of the money held by them and will not till some trustworthy authority tells them what to do.
"Fra Diavolo" was repeated by Mr. Mapleson's company at the Academy of Music last evening. A large audience was present, and, judging from the applause that was bestowed, found much to approve.

Hector Berlioz wrote a series of interesting and amusing sketches called "Musical Grotesques." It is a great pity, though it could hardly have been expected under any circumstances, that he did not live until to-day.

Edgar Lewis, of No. 255 First-avenue, caught a man sitting astride the fanlight of the tea store of his next-door neighbor, Hugh Anderson, at 11 o'clock Thursday night, passing out boxes of tea to a confederate, who stood on the sidewalk.

MOUNDSVILLE, West Va., Nov. 27.--The fourth fatal shooting in this end of the State during the past week occurred here about 3 o'clock this afternoon. The victim was Grant Lucas, a well known resident.

Michael T. Danaher sued Richard L. Hull on a promissory note for $300 given him by Hull in Washington, D.C., last Spring. According to Hull the note, and several others like it, were given by him while gambling.

DECATUR, Ill., Nov. 27.--There was a cutting affray at Warrensburg, in this county, yesterday, in which five young men were engaged. The parties are Frank and Walter Major and William, Eugene, and Thomas Hoagland.

BATTLEFORD, Northwest Territory, Nov. 27.--The execution of the eight Indians found guilty of murder at Frog Lake and Battleford occurred at 8:27 o'clock this morning. The gallows worked without friction. The day broke dark and cloudy, and with the air frosty.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 27.--A large number of the delegates at the convention of the National Cattle and Horse Growers' Association left for home last evening. Judge Carrol, of Texas, presided over the deliberations of the convention.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 27.--Judge Learned, of the Supreme Court, to-day denied the motion of Winslow Paige, counsel for the New-York Central Railroad, to dissolve the injunction granted by Justice George N. Kennedy, of Syracuse, restraining the New-York Central ...

ATLANTA, Nov. 27.--While the funeral of John Harvey was in progress at West View Cemetery it was noticed that the coffin was very light. This induced the opening of the lid, when it was discovered that the coffin was full of sand. Harvey died in a hospital and the doctors had evidently used his body for the dissecting table.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 27.--The casket for the remains of Vice-President Hendricks, which is being manufactured in this city, will be forwarded to Indianapolis to-morrow.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 27.--Manager McCaull, as is his usual custom, gave a Thanksgiving dinner to his "Black Hussar" Company, at the Russell House, Detroit, last night. Fifty covers were laid. The company has continued its Chicago success, both in Detroit and Toledo, playing to the largest business known in either place for years.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will make the first announcement of the fact that a scheme is on foot, and will probably be carried out, to sell out the Beech Creek Railroad and reorganize the company.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., Nov. 27.--The up freight train, due here at 4:40 P.M., was derailed when drawing over to a side track at the south end of the yard. The accident was caused by the engine drivers climbing the switch rail.
HAVANA, Nov. 27.--The subscription of the Military Club for the purpose of improving the defenses of the island now amounts to $97,361 58 in gold and $15,469 45 in bank bills.

MARIETTA, Ga., Nov. 27.--Judge David Irwin, long a prominent molder of public sentiment in the State, is dead. He was in political life as early as 1840--a Whig. He was a candidate for Elector on the Clay ticket in 1844.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--In the Mincing-lane markets beet sugar is firm. Cane sugar is steady. The prices of refined and other grades are unchanged. Tea is steady. Indian tea is firm. Coffee is dull. Rice is firmer.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 27.--The trouble which was anticipated last night took place this morning at Jordan S. Neil's coal mines, in the fourth pool.

LONDON, Ontario, Nov. 27.--Benjamin Simmonds, who was sentenced to death for the murder of Mary Ann Stokes, his paramour, on the 5th of June last, was hanged in the jail yard here in the presence of about 100 persons this morning.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Nov. 27.--John Hall, of this place, who on the morning of the 21st inst. severely burned his wife about the face with a redhot stove lifter, heated while she slept, was to-day convicted and sentenced to the Albany Penitentiary for one year.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 27.--The Rev. Dr. Smith, President of Trinity College, this afternoon decided to decline the position of Bishop of Easton, Md., to which he was recently elected. His letter giving his reasons for declining will be made public to-morrow.

The discomfited speculators who failed to get the bonds of the New-York and New-England Railroad which the State of Massachusetts had for sale seem to have been astonished by the rebuff administered to them by the Governor and Council of that State.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 27.--Governor-elect Foraker has announced the following appointments, which complete his military staff: Quartermaster-General--A.S. Bushnell, ...

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 27.--Lewis Willett, alias Charles Crosby, is still on trial in this city for murder in the first degree. Many witnesses have been examined, and the testimony against Willett is of a damaging character.
KANKAKEE, Ill., Nov. 27.--A boy, aged 14 years, named Snyder, living near Cabery, was killed and eaten by hogs yesterday while sleeping on a straw stack near his father's house.

ROME, Nov. 27.--The new American Minister to-day presented his credentials to King Humbert.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov. 27.--While duck hunting in the marsh near here yesterday Thomas Duignan, of this city, fell out of his boat, and, being unable to right the craft, crawled upon her bottom and clung to her. This morning his dead body way found, the rigid hands clinging to the drifting boat. He leaves a widow.

Piers C. Doty, an old confidence operator, was arraigned in the Court of General Sessions yesterday on a charge of larceny. Doty several months ago formed the acquaintance of Francis W. Green, of No. 116 Second-place, Brooklyn.

Ever since the sudden closing of races at Brighton Beach two weeks ago, deemed necessary by the attitude assumed by the authorities, there has existed among the "talent" an intense desire to be able by hook or by crook to get even on the season.

Around the camp fire of Alexander Hamilton Post, No. 182, G.A.R., many veterans of the blue and the gray fought their battles over again last night, the rebel yell giving place to the hip, hip hurrah, as the stirring incidents of 25 years ago were recalled.

MONTREAL, Nov. 27.--The flight of Mr. E.C. Picard, the head of the insolvent firm of Picard Co., wholesale jewelers, has given rise to startling developments.

Ex-Coroner Henry Woltman occupies a cot in the insane-pavilion in Bellevue Hospital. Mr. Woltman did a great deal of work during the recent campaign, and the effects of it told heavily on his nervous system.
The Holt-Warner case had another hearing yesterday afternoon by Referee Hamilton Cole, and Mr. Hornblower continued the crossexamination of ex-Cashier Spencer.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27.--A frightful case of hydrophobia was developed in the Ninth Ward this morning, the victim being George Nagelschmidt, a 4-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Nagelschmidt, living at No. 510 Fourteenthstreet.
OTTAWA, Nov. 27.--Thomas Hotchkiss, United States Consul here, has forwarded to the State Department at Washington an elaborate report upon the phosphate of lime industry of this district.
A train on the bridge yesterday morning, due in Brooklyn at 8:30 o'clock, came into collision with an inverted signal post which had been thrown on the track by a train loaded with oil tanks.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 27.--Business Manager Hayes, of the Daily Age, was tried in the City Court to-day charged with violation of the clause of the new Sunday law forbidding newsdealers to sell papers. Judge Sharpe presiding, decided that Mr. Hayes, as agent of the newspaper published, was not a newsdealer and could sell on the street or in his office.
BELGRADE, Nov. 27.--Gen. Leshjanin, of the Servian Army, telegraphs that he is bombarding Widdin, and expects the surrender of the city to-day.
In the Van Antwerp divorce case yesterday William Van Antwerp testified that his wife gave him a power of attorney. He had it prepared and laid it before his wife.

The case of Thomas Maguire, who was placed on trial for a second time yesterday, in Newark, for manslaughter in the killing of young Carroll, at Waverly, last November, was given to the jury yesterday afternoon, and in two minutes they returned with a verdict of not guilty.

HALIFAX, Nov. 27.--Advices from Sydney, Cape Breton, state that only 14 cases of smallpox in all stages now exist there, and several of these are almost recovered and all the others are expected to survive.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 27.--As the result of a canvass that has been in progress only a few weeks the sum of $82,000 has been raised for the erection of a Young Men's Christian Association building in this city. It is expected that $100,000 will be secured. The heaviest givers are Albert Curtis, $25,000; F.B. Knowles, P. L. Moen, and Stephen Salisbury, $5,000 each.

Before Justice Kilbreth, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday afternoon, a charge of disorderly conduct was made by Mrs. Anna L. King, of No. 45 East Twentieth-street, against her husband, Henry M. King, of No. 18 West Twenty-second-street.
BOSTON, Nov. 27.--The Democratic City Convention to-night renominated Hugh O'Brien for Mayor, the vote standing 190 for O'Brien to 43 for Alderman Charles V. Whitten.

The amount of the Thanksgiving Day contributions to the Grant Monument fund will not be known, probably, before Monday. The association has reason to believe that they will increase the fund materially.
William Raeder, who lives at No. 17 Chrystie-street, arrived from Europe yesterday on the steamer Rhein. When he landed two good-looking German girls, both about 20 years old, were with him.
CHATHAM, Mass., Nov. 27.--The most severe storm of the season was supposed to have reached its height Tuesday, and it lulled Wednesday morning and the wind took a sea turn and died out.

READING, Penn., Nov. 27.--The strike in the Western Nail Mills is greatly benefiting mills at Birdsborough, this county, and at Pottstown.

Chief of Police Tuite, of Newark, last night received a dispatch from the Chief of Police of Chester, Penn., requesting him to release Charles A. Williams, the colored man who was arrested yesterday on suspicion of being the Sharpless murderer. Williams was at once given his liberty.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 27.--In the Circuit Court, to-day, Judge Fisher filed an opinion in the case of Day against The Postal Telegraph Company. Judge Fisher passed an order to sell all the property of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 1.--At Enfield this afternoon E. Whitney, aged 24 years, belonging in Lincoln, shot his wife, aged 18 years, twice with a revolver, but not fatally. He then shot himself through the heart, dying instantly They had been married three weeks, and she left him on Monday.

EASTON, Md., Dec. 1.--Commodore Charles Lowndes, United States Navy, aged 86, is said to be dying at his country seat in Talbot County, from an attack of paralysis. He was appointed a midshipman in 1815, and was retired in 1861. He was made Commodore on the retired list in July, 1862.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1.--Off Throgg's Neck last night the steamer Continental, from New-York for New-Haven, was run into by an unknown schooner. The damage to the Continental is not heavy.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec 2.--The Knights of Labor are beginning to create trouble in Georgia. Hitherto union workmen and Knights of Labor have given but little trouble here, the native artisans and mechanics preferring their individual independence.

PANAMA, Dec. 2, via Galveston.--It is said here that Gen. Iglesias surrendered to Caceres at Lima at 2 o'clock this afternoon, and that Senor Eusebio Sanchez has been named Provisional President.
MONTREAL, Dec. 2.--Mgr. Grandin, Bishop of St. Albert, who was reported some days ago as being indisposed, has suddenly become seriously ill. He is now suffering from a severe attack of pleurisy.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 2.--A committee appointed by the Commander of the Grand Commandery of Ohio Knights Templar to investigate charges against the Rev. Henry D. Moore, editor of the Masonic Review, has found him guilty, and sentenced him to indefinite suspension. The charge arose from an article published in the Review, the authorship of which was attributed to the editor. Judge Foraker has given notice of an appeal to the Grand Commandery.
The funeral of the Late John Paine, who died on Saturday at the advanced age of 92 years, was held at his house, No. 3 West Fiftythird-street, yesterday morning.
