WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 2.--The Rev. John J. McAuley, S.J. Professor of Rhetoric at the Holy Cross College, died suddenly of apoplexy this afternoon. He fell through thin ice while skating early in the afternoon, and after changing his clothing was taking a brisk walk. He felt ill on Trambull-street, and entering the house of Dr. O'Callaghan almost immediately expired. He was about 40 years of age.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2.--Young William C. Glenn, 16 years old, son of the Postmaster at Rochelle, was to-day convicted in the United States court of using the mails fraudulently in obtaining money under false pretenses, and of taking $500 from a registered envelope.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2.--E.G. Hewitt, of Cincinnati, this evening filed in the Supreme Court a petition in error to the Circuit Court of Cincinnati in the Senatorial contest, accompanied by a transcript of the docket journal, and entered a bill of exceptions. A motion to take the case up out of its order and set an early day for the hearing will be argued to-morrow morning.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec 2.--The Elmira Daily Advertiser celebrated its thirty-third anniversary to-night. A new Webb perfecting press had been set up and the edition of the paper was run on the machine to-night for the first time. A supplement giving a history of the concern was also printed. The press is of the Potter make, and has the capacity to print both sides, cut, Paste, fold, and count 15,000 copies per hour.

VILLA GARCIA, Nuevo Leon, Dec. 2-- The revolutionists, led by Manuel Rodriguez, reached the vicinity of Villa Garcia Sunday afternoon. Gov. Sepulvedos, fearing capture, made his escape on the approach of Rodriguez and crossed over into the State of Coahuila, where he is safe for the present.

Insurance Superintendent Mccall's report of his investigation into the affairs of the New-York Bowery Fire Insurance Company had been discounted among insurance men, who have known for several weeks that something was wrong with the company and that measures had been taken to correct the wrong.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 2.--The towboat Iron City was blown to pieces this morning at about 2 o'clock while stuck on the bar at the head of Herr's Island, in the Allegheny River. The crew, numbering six, were blown into the river. The engineer, George Ashton, was instantly killed.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 2.--Harris S. Duffield, one of the members of the "Pavements of Paris" company playing here, has been arrested on a court order in a civil case.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 2.--The jury in the case of William and Humphrey Best, charged with the murder of William Bailey, colored, returned a verdict of not guilty, at Lancaster ky., to-night. The father of the Best boys killed seven men and always managed to escape punishment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2.--B. Greenebaum, United States Consul in Samoa, in a letter to the Merchants' Exchange of this city, says that an island never before reported has been thrown up out of the sea about 40 miles off the Tonga Islands, bearing toward the Fiji Islands, in the track of California vessels. The island is two miles long and 250 feet high, and is in latitude 20 28' south, longitude 175 21' west.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 2.--Charlotte Wickliffe, colored, died here to-night, aged 117. She has 15 living children, the oldest nearly a hundred years old, and 60 grandchildren. She claims to leave handed Washington a cup of water at the battle of Yorktown. Her second husband was 112 years old. She was hale and hearty until recently.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 2.--The witness Keith, who acted as agent for the sale of stolen United States bonds, was to-day again before the Grand Jury, and his examination ended in his indictment and arrest for false swearing. ADAMS, Mass., Dec. 2.--A young boy, a member of the Martin family which was stricken with smallpox last week, died yesterday, and four others are ill. Five members of the Field family are sick. Both houses are effectually quarantined, and the health officers think there will be no more cases.

BRIDGEPORT, Ill., Dec. 3.--A prominent physician who was Mr. Hendricks's friend and attendant for a longer period than any other physician says that Mr. Hendricks did not die of heart paralysis. U.S. Grant and the firm of Grant Ward for $22,000 on any property the defendants may have in Cook County. It is not known that Gen. WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--The AdjutantGeneral of the army has received the following telegram from Gen. Schofield, at Chicago: "Gen. Miles telegraphs that Major Summer reports from Fort Reno that instructions regarding Oklahoma have been carried out, and that all the intruders have been removed, and that cattle men with their herds are on the move."

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 5.--The telephone cable to be placed in the Hudson River at Cornwall from Storm King Mountain to Breakneck was received in Newburg to-day and will be laid on Monday. It is 3,000 feet in length, weighs four tons, and is composed of five strands. The laying of this cable will give Newburg and other places in the vicinity the telephone communication which has for some time been much desired.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 5.--The steamer Vincent made her last trip to-day, and navigation has closed on Chautauqua Lake for this year. For a week past the steamer has kept up communication with Mayville through a channel 20 miles long broken in the ice. Soon the frozen surface of the lake will bear a network of sleigh tracks, and be more of a highway than when the steamboats are running.

Last evening a clerical gentleman called at a ticket agency in the city and asked the price of two first class tickets for Halifax. The agent said that the cost would be $15. "Then," said the clergyman, "how far could I travel on a three-dollar ticket?" "To Point du Chene or Memranicook," replied the clerk.

Flushing is excited over the runaway marriage of Louis Masters, the 18-year-old son of David Masters, a wealthy real estate agent of that town, and Mary Jane Maher, a good-looking Irish servant in the family of Mr. Dusenpury. GORDON, Texas, Dec. 5.--At 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning the west-bound passenger train on the Texas and Pacific Railway was wrecked at the trestlework crossing the creek nine miles east of this place. The accident was caused by a broken rail. The first coach jumped the trestle and fell to the bottom of the creek, which was dry, and turned over on its side.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 5.--The officials of the Farmers' National Bank, of Mansfield, have has an interview with Joseph Hosdowitch, the defaulting Teller who fled to Canada. Hosdowitch agrees to return the money and securities, and he will not be prosecuted.

Francis M. Leonard, a civil engineer, 39 years of age, died suddenly last evening at his residence, No. 154 East Thirtieth-street. He had been drinking heavily for several days, and yesterday afternoon became violent and amused himself by smashing the crockery and household effects in the kitchen.

MANDALAY, Dec. 6.--Gen. HAZLETON, Penn., Dec. 6.--The first Hungarian Catholic church edifice erected in this country was dedicated here this morning by the Right Rev. Bishop O'Hara, of the Scranton Diocese, assisted by the Pastor, the Rev. Ignatius Jaskovitz, and a number of local clergy. The crowd of local politicians that filled the quarters of the Senate investigating committee, in the Morton House, yesterday, paid very little attention to the testimony offered there.

Mr. Duryea has just received a letter from Charles Rowell saying that he has made up his mind to visit Australia, and that he would like to stop in New-York on his way there and join in a six days go-as-you-please with Fitzgerald and others.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9.--For many years the grand feast day of the Ohio Democrats was held at Wooster, Wayne County, on Jan. 8, better known in all the rural regions of the State as "St. Jackson's Day." Of late years these gatherings have been held at Columbus, and invitations ...

WELLINGTON, Kan., Dec. 9.--A man named Frank Noyes was enticed from his home in Caldwell, this county, Monday night, and in the morning his body was found hanging to a beam across a high gateway near the stock yards. The cause of the murder is not known. Some think that it was done by parties with whom Noyes was associated in some crime for fear of his turning State's evidence. The Coroner is investigating.

ELMIRA, Dec. 9.--Railroad Commissioner O'Donnell's place on the Railroad Commission will probably be given to a politician, notwithstanding the great efforts put forth by the Conductors' Brotherhood of the State to capture the prize for one of their number.

The American Art Galleries, at Twentythird-street and Broadway, were packed to suffocation last night by well dressed ladies and gentlemen, who crowded into every corner, pushed in front of each other, trod on each other's toes, and in a general way manifested a burning desire to be in the vanguard of intellectual progress.
The Board of Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company issued their quarterly report yesterday for the quarter ending with the end of this month, estimating revenues for December.
Ferdinand Ward has had a change made in his work at Sing Sing Prison, and he is no longer required to pick out, assort, and grind the rough edges off of stove castings.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 9.--A female peddler of fine laces, sealskin sacques, and jewelry, who used to visit this city at frequent intervals selling articles at the homes of the wealthy, was known as Mrs. Mandelbaum, of New-York.

The question of dealing with the Indians appears to be entering upon a new phase. Gen. ATKINS, Commissioner of Indian Affairs: Secretary LAMAR, of the Interior Department, and the President have in the last week presented their views upon the policy which should ...

The committee appointed at the recent Baptist Council in this city to investigate the trouble in the South Baptist Church Society at Tottenville, Staten Island, between Pastor Thomas B. Bott and his following and the Trustees and various other members of ...

READING, Penn., Dec. 9.--The State Liquor League, after outlining its policy of high license yesterday, consumed its morning session to-day fixing the levy per capita of 50 cents per head to pay the expenses of the convention.

The change of bill at Daly's Theatre last evening, the only theatrical event of importance this week, brought together a distinguished audience, and the perfect sympathy existing between Mr. Daly's actors and the frequenters of his handsome playhouse was attested once again.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 9.--William Dwyer, Jr., of Liberty, a rising young lawyer and Special County Judge of Sullivan County, has fled from home to parts unknown to escape prosecution on charges of forgery and embezzlement.
The pedestrian contest between O'Leary and Weston, in Newark, N.J., was witnessed by a large number of city and county officials during the day and night yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9.--Judge Arnold, in Common Pleas Court No. 4, will act as impire at 1 o'clock to-morrow afternoon between the warring baseball managers, and will partially decide whether it was a foul hit when the American Association dropped ...

CHICAGO, Dec. 9.--The first meat contract of the French Government with an American firm has been given the Fairchild Canning Company of this city through the exertions of its President, Mr. Nelson Morris, on the spot. The order calls for 1,000,000 kilograms, which means more than double that number of pounds, and three months' time is given to fill it.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 9.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, Providence and Boston Railroad was held this morning, President Samuel D. Babcock in the chair.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9.--The arguments in the Hamilton County Senatorial cases were concluded in the Supreme Court to-day. These cases are of peculiar interest, for on their decision rests the political complexion of the next Senate of Ohio.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Dec. 9.--A sensational event occurred here this evening, it being the arrest of a bridegroom within a few hours after the marriage ceremony, and while en route on a bridal trip, at the instance of a well known young woman of this city.

The lawyers in the murder trial of Thomas J. Armstrong, the Brooklyn boy who shot his stepfather, Albert R. Herrick, on Aug. 10, were about settling to yesterday's work when the stout figure of a woman, her face shrouded by a heavy veil, stepped within the rail and hurried to the prisoner's side.
The arrangements for extending the Long Island Railroad from Roslyn through Oyster Bay to Huntington are said to be nearly completed.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 9.--When the schooner Fred A. Carle went ashore on Norris Point, near Watch Hill, the mate and two seamen remained on the vessel, preferring to do so to going ashore.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 9.--No little excitement was created this afternoon by rumors on the streets of serious trouble between the police and employes of the Connecting Railway Company at the Benjamin-street crossing in the northern part of the city.

There is another smallpox scare in Long Island City. A child of Thomas Flynn, grocer, of Vernon-avenue, died from the disease on Monday, and two other children suffering from it were sent to the Riverside Hospital. James Hines, residing almost opposite Flynn's store, was taken with the disease yesterday, and was ...

After a great deal of skirmishing and several pitched battles Commissioner Holt's plan for the equalization of the salaries of teachers in the public schools was adopted by the Board of Education last evening, by a vote of 12 to 4.

LONDON, Dec. 9.--Seven Parliamentary seats remain to be declared. The Liberals count upon obtaining three of these seats, which would raise their total to 334, against 336 Conservatives and Nationalists.
The Alumnae Association of the Normal College have long felt the need of a reference library for that institution and have made efforts to secure its establishment.

Richard C. Williams, once a well known hat manufacturer in Orange, N.J., who had pleaded non vult to an indictment charging him with having published a card charging Labor Inspector Fell with being an embezzler, a thief, ...

CHORILLOS, Peru, Dec. 8, via Galveston.-- The new Minister of War, Senor Velarde, arrived yesterday from Lima and disbanded the entire Iglesias force stationed here. The same measures have been taken with those in the capital.

Pall bearers were selected yesterday for William H. Vanderbilt's funeral. They are Samuel F. Barger, Chauncey M. Depew, J. Pierpont Morgan, C.C. Clarke, ex-Judge Charles J. Rapallo, Judge John R. Brady, William Turnbull, William L. Scott, William Bliss, D.O. Mills, ...

Daniel Bertolet, a merchandise broker, sued the firm of Joseph J. O'Donohue Son, in the City Court, to recover brokerage on sales of teas and coffees to one Corbit and to the United States Government.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 9.--The New-York, Fordham and Bronx Railway Company was incorporated to-day, with a capital of $1,000,000, to construct a three-mile elevated railroad in One Hundred and Thirty-eight-street, Lincoln-avenue, ...

The dinner which was to have been given by Mr. Erastus Wiman to Robert Garrett at the Pavilion Hotel, New-Brighton, this evening, has been postponed on account of the death of Mr. Vanderbilt to Wednesday evening next.

Capt. H. Tracey, a wealthy resident of Pearsall's, Long Island, went hunting last Sunday, and in his search for game was traveling over the farm of William Combs, near that place. Farmer Combs ordered Capt. Tracey off the place and forbade him hunting there. Capt. Tracey declined to leave, and when Mr. Combs insisted he assaulted him. Mr. Combs yesterday commenced suit against his assailant for $5,000 as compensation for the injuries received.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 9.--The Hartford Times this evening devotes eight columns to a report of a special investigation into the affairs and management of the internal revenue offices in this State.
DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 9.--Three fishermen, living at Grosse Point, 14 miles above this city, on Lake St. Clair, had a thrilling experience yesterday and the night before.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 9.--It is now known that one of the objects of Sir John Macdonald's mission to England is to make an effort to induce the British Government to take stock in the Canadian Pacific Railway. An argument, or rather threat, will be used that unless the ...

On complaint of Allen C. Redwood, the manager of the Knickerbocker office and apartment house, No. 4 West Fourteenth-street, Police Justice Smith on Tuesday issued a warrant for the arrest of Charles G. Horton, a lumber merchant, who occupies Room 33 in the building as an office and bedroom.
CHESTER, Ill., Dec. 9.--The buildings of the Southern Illinois Penitentiary, at this place, were badly damaged by a cyclone last evening and some of the inmates were very seriously injured.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 9.--F. Baker is a young man who resides in the town of Hardenburg, Ulster County. Yesterday Baker and a Middletown lad named Adee "fooled" with a revolver. They "didn't know it was loaded." The weapon was accidentally discharged, the ball entering Baker's abdomen. The bullet was probed for without success. Baker is in a precarious condition and is likely to die.

Mr. Hamilton Busbey, Mr. William H. Wilson, of Cynthiana, Ky., and other gentlemen who are identified prominently with the trotting turf, in discussing the death of Mr. Vanderbilt yesterday at the Everett House, where the Horse Breeders' Association is ...

Between flattery and envy it fares hard with the very rich. A young man in the position of our late Minister to Rome is apt to suffer as much underestimation arising from ignoble motives of one kind as overestimation from ignoble motives ...
Col. James H. Mapleson yesterday morning walked nonchalantly into the branch of the Court of Common Pleas presided over by Judge Larremore.

Mr. MANNING has found the subject of the collection of duties under the present tariff laws of sufficient importance to submit a special report upon it, which in length and elaboration of treatment is quite equal to the regular Treasury report.

ELMIRA, Dec. 9.--The wreck of Erie train No. 4, St. Louis express, at Scio, 29 miles west of Hornellsville, last Thursday morning, by which Engineer Allen was killed, has been explained by the confession of the telegraph operator, J. Howard.

The New-York Typographical Union No. 6 held its annual election of officers yesterday. There were two tickets in the field, but up to an early hour this morning the count had not proceeded far enough for the result to be ascertained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--First Lieut. John McMartin, Twenty-fifth Infantry, has been relieved from duty at Columbus Barracks and as a member of the general court-martial there and placed on sick leave. First Lieut. John K. Waring, Second Infantry, has been granted six months' leave of absence. Twentyseven recruits have been ordered from Columbus Barracks of Fort Snelling, Minnesota, for the Seventeenth Infantry.
Last evening's representation of "The Prophet" at the Metropolitan Opera House was, as to vocal and dramatic impressiveness, the most noteworthy offered during the current season.
The French steamship Canada sailed for Havre early yesterday morning, having on board four of the six children who were bitten by a mad dog in Newark on Dec. 2.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9.--The Monmouth Na-- tional Bank of Monmouth, Ill., closed its doors on April 8, 1883, and never resumed payment, though its depositors have received 90 per cent. of their claims, and will probably be paid in full.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 9.--The State tax sale will begin to-morrow in the Commissioners' room on the first floor or the Capitol, Washington-avenue side. The counties will be taken up in alphabetical order. The sale will close on Dec. 29.

Capt. Ambrose Snow presided at a meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday whose object was to draw up an address to the National Board of Trade for consideration at the annual meeting of that body next ...

Broker Frothingham had not received a response up to last evening to the questions asked of President Foshay, of the Broadway and Seventh-Avenue Railroad Company, and when asked about the matter he ...
CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 9.--The Sultan has informed Herr von Radowitz, the German Ambassador here, that Turkish troops will invade Eastern Roumelia should Prince Alexander oppose the Turkish commission.

Decorators and florists started work late last night in ornamenting the interior of the Casino with flowers, vines, and tropical plants, and the boxes to be occupied by Gov. Hill and his staff, with flags, banners, and bunting, for this afternoon's entertainment in aid of the Actors' Fund of America.
The election contests in Ireland were closed yesterday. Mr. Parnell has carried every seat in Munster, Leinster, and Connaught with the exception of the two seats for Trinity College.

That no English politician can afford to take the responsibility of forming a Ministry in the coming Parliament is so obvious a corollary from the proposition that no party will have a working majority in that body that it is surprising to hear that ...

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 9.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Boston and Albany Railroad Company was held this morning, at which 21,874 shares were represented. The old Board of Directors were re-elected receiving, with one exception, a unanimous vote.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--That a change of Administration has served to invest the annual message of the President with more than common interest is obvious to every observer. Mr. Cleveland's message has been talked of everywhere to-day, and in such a way as to make it ...

WINFIELD, Kan., Dec. 9.--The Oklahoma "boomers" are being removed by the United States troops from Oklahoma rapidly. The last of them will reach Arkansas City and Caldwell this week. The approach of Winter finds them turned from their promised land, many of them without a dollar to support their families.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 9.--The steamer City of Kingston, of the Cornell Rondout and New-York Line, on her up trip early last evening, when off Fort Washington Point struck a rock. The tide was unusually low at the time, and the vessel was running close to the shore. No damage was done other than the breaking of glass by the shock. The passengers were much frightened, and some were suddenly thrown from their feet.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 9.--There was a packed court room to-day at the commencement of the trial of Theodore A. Boyce for the murder of Frederick W. De Garmo at Dover Plains on the 17th of August last.

The Aqueduct Commissioners devoted several hours yesterday listening to arguments why the Quaker Bridge Dam should not be built. Dexter A. Hawkins made a plea against the building of the proposed dam because of "the unhealthfulness of the water which would be ponded thereby."

Mr. Vanderbilt is best remembered on Staten Island as a farmer. For a banker's clerk, and the son of a wealthy man at that, to go upon a farm with his young wife and not only bring order out of chaos, but make it the best farm on the island, was something which must of necessity go into the history of Richmond County.

WABASH, Ind., Dec. 9.--The 10-year-old daughter of James Dunn, of Xenia, 14 miles southwest of this city, died on Monday evening from trichinosis. A week or more ago she complained of severe pains in her arms and legs, and later became unable to walk.

Genevieve Simpson, a pretty and modest girl, 16 years old, entered the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday with her left eye blackened and swollen and a severe burn across her right cheek. She said that these injuries had been inflicted by her stepfather, Michael Gallagher, ...

There was a shooting affray at cut No. 9 of the new Croton Aqueduct early yesterday morning. John Hickey is a watchman employed by the contractors to protect their houses at night. It is his duty to chase off from the grounds any and all men who have no business ...

PITTSBURG, Dec. 9.--A peculiar and disastrous gas explosion occurred in Canonsburg, within a few miles of this city, early this morning. A large frame residence was blown to pieces, and the occupants of the house--a man, his wife, and two children--were hurled from ...
MONTREAL, Dec. 9.--During the service of the immaculate conception at the Church of Notre Dame de Lourdes last night the drapery of the altar caught fire and in an instant was enveloped in flames.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Dec. 9.--Within the past 10 days three counterfeiters have been arrested in this city. The first arrests were George Haikes and William Norris, about 10 days ago. The arrest was made last evening at about 11 o'clock.

The body of a man that has been lying at the Morgue for two days was last evening identified as that of Joseph Mills, the brother of S.M. Mills, of Mills Co., brokers, at No. 59 Broadway. He was admitted to Beilevue Hospital on Dec. 6 suffering from sickness, and he died the next day.

I have received a letter under date of Dec. 8 inst., signed by C.F. Frothingham, John J. James, and W. Howard Gilder, in which they ask 13 questions on behalf of stockholders who are said to be dissatisfied with the apparent relations between the Broadway and Seventh-Avenue Railroad Company and the Broadway Surface Railroad Company.

An advertisement in a daily paper in September last asked for the services of a young man as Treasurer of the "Mme. Le Mond's Female Mastodon Ministrels." Edward F. Ochs, a young man of No. 2,314 Eighthavenue, who was out of employment, answered the advertisement.

The politicians were talking yesterday about an alliance alleged to have been entered into by the County Democracy and the Republican members of the next Board of Aldermen for the purpose of organization, and perhaps for running the board during the entire year.

Michael Curran died in St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn, on Tuesday morning. The body was taken possession of by Mr. Curran's sister, Mrs. Schmidt, of No. 20 North Portlandavenue. When Mrs. Curran went to visit her husband she found he had died in the morning and that the body had been taken away by an undertaker.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 9.--An explosion occurred at the gas works, situated near the Grand-avenue station, this morning, totally wrecking the building. There were 14 or 15 employes in and about the building at the time of the accident, but they have all been accounted for.

The caucus committee of Republican Senators having in charge the arrangement of the membership of committees had a meeting this afternoon. It is understood that a decision was reached to tender to Senator Sewell the Chairmanship of the joint Library Committee, vacated by Senator Sherman, and to Gen. Logan his old place as Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs, now held by Gen. Sewell.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 9.--At a meeting of the creditors of the Quequeckan Mills, held this morning, the Treasurer presented a statement of the financial standing of the concern.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 9.--Few of the rolling mills of the Mahoning Valley and none of Youngstown are running to their full capacity, and in some of the departments they are running only single term.

BOSTON, Dec. 9.--The Grand Jury has indicted Adrian L. Mellen and Mrs. Coolidge for conspiring to kill amd murder the wife of Adrian L. Mellen in Baltimore. Mrs. Coolidge was held in $5,000 and committed to jail for want of bail. A separate indictment will probably be found against Mrs. Coolidge on a charge of having, in Boston, solicited persons to go to Baltimore and kill young Mrs. Mellen.

The principal event of the dramatic week will be the Actors' Fund benefit given today at the Casino. There has not been recorded in recent years such a rush for tickets of admission to any single entertainment as has developed itself in connection with this Casino performance.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Dec. 9.--The City Council, composed of Mormons, has been investigating for three days the rumors of an uprising of Mormons and bodies of armed men entering the city.

A dozen years ago our sister republic across the Rio Grande appeared to be almost in a chronic state of revolution. Any morning its citizens were liable to find a fresh pronunciamiento from some adventurer proclaiming himself Governor ...

The ship Coringa, Capt. Gibson, which arrived yesterday from London, brought the crew of the Norwegian bark Nora, which was abandoned in a waterlogged condition on Nov. 17 in latitude 43 57' and longitude 33 20'.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--The proceedings in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day were as follows: No. 87--The Northern Pacific Railroad Company, plaintiff in error, vs. Clayton D. Herbert.--Argument concluded by Thomas Wilson for the defendant in error. No. 86--John F. Coyle, appellant, vs. Henry S. Davis et al.--Argued by E.D. Barrett and B.F. Butler for appellant, and by Walter D. Davidge for the defendants.

There was always a strained effort on the part of Jay Gould, Cyrus Field, and their speculating side partners to convince the public of their intimate relations with Mr. Vanderbilt. Illustrations of this were shown in the most marked manner within the past few weeks.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Dec. 9.--A fact in connection with the recent elopement of Frank Haughton from McGrawville, in this county, has just been made public. Haughton is the only son of John Haughton, a wealthy and respected resident of that village.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 9.--A special to the Times says that W.D. Kellett, United States Deputy Marshal of the Northern District of Georgia, was waylaid on Lookout Mountain, 30 miles from Chattanooga, yesterday by five moonshiners and murdered.

The cases of William S. Warner, J. Henry Work, and Edward H. Tobey, indicted for their connection with the financial transactions of Ferdinand Ward, were called yesterday morning, in the criminal part of the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Benedict.
LONDON, Dec. 9.--The Right Hon. William E. Forster, whosuffered a relapse yesterday, is improving to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9.--Franklin B. Gowen was asked to-day what effect the death of Mr. Vanderbilt would have on Reading affairs and how it would be likely to affect his own chances for election as President of the Reading Company in January.

New developments came to the surface yesterday in regard to the peculiar relations of William J. Krueger, or Julius W. Krueger as he styles himself, the painter, of Brooklyn, Eastern District, who made out divorce papers between himself and wife in order that she might marry William Hassenteufel, whom she had met and ...

Mr. Ralph Disraeli is to succeed Sir William Rose as Clerk of Parliaments. The office is worth 3,000 a year. Mr. Disraeli is now clerk assistant, with 2,100 a year, and he will probably be succeeded in that post by Sir Erskine May, who finds his work in the House of Commons too onerous.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 9.--The Faculty of the Vanderbilt University met to-day and took appropriate action regarding the death of William H. Vanderbilt. Resolutions of respect were adopted, and it was decided to suspend exercises at the university to-day and on the day ...

Pew No. 119 in the Fifth-Avenue Presbyterian Church was sold at auction at the Liberty-street Real Estate Exchange yesterday. It belonged to the estate of H.S. Leverich, and brought $4,550. The following securities were also sold at auction:

The new Board of Trustees of the NewYork Press Club was organized yesterday by the election of Col. John A. Cockerill as Chairman and George F. Lyon as Secretary. The meeting was of an agreeable character, and ...

A fire early yesterday morning in the three-story frame building No. 87 South Thirdstreet, Brooklyn, created much smoke and considerable excitement. Ernest A. Worner has a butcher's shop on the first floor and his family lodge over it. They were all abed when the fire broke out, and all got out but Mrs. Worner and her husband.

Dr. Biggs, of the Carnegie Laboratory, sailed for Europe yesterday morning on the Ems. A large number of Beilevue students from the different hospitals and many personal friends were at the dock to wish him a safe voyage.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9.--Bolivar, the largest elephant now in captivity, on Monday afternoon had a terrific encounter with the Nubian lion Prince, at the Winter quarters ...
A holiday sale of fancy articles at low prices began last night in the building in the southeast corner of Fifth-avenue and Twentyfirst-street.

MONTREAL, Dec. 9.--In the early part of last Winter a boy named O'Byrne died at the General Hospital from cancer of the mouth, and when his mother came to receive his body to give it burial it was already inclosed in a coffin.

William W. Ellsworth and Henry L. Ellsworth, twin sons of Oliver Ellsworth, of Windsor, Chief-Justice of the United States, were, in 1826, at the Hartford Bar. They were of different political views, W.W. being a Federalist and Henry L. a Democrat.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Dec. 10.-- While the east-bound freight train on the NewBrunswick Railway was passing over the bridge across the north branch of the Oromocto River to-day the bridge gave way and the engine fell into the river. Fortunately it uncoupled itself and the cars remained on the track, one hanging over the gap.

Mr. Theodore B. Starr, of No. 206 Fifthavenue, does not appear to be exercised about the proposed (and postponed) railway in Fifthavenue. In fact, his whole corps seems to be too busy in this holiday season to think of anything else than business.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10.--Henry O'Connor, an old gray-haired man, shaking from the effects of whisky, went into the Armory Court this morning to testify against Fred Hart, accused of larceny. O'Connor was Attorney-General of Iowa for six years and Assistant United States District Attorney for 14 years.

Wednesday afternoon a man who gave his name as Jules White, and his residence, or place of business, as No. 208 Mercer-street, called at the Bellevue Hospital Morgue and identified the body of a man who died in the hospital on ...

To touch a moment upon personalities, it may be remarked that the three men mentioned above are seldom to be met at receptions nowadays. Dr. Holmes declares that he grows old, although his friends reply that they have only his word for it; Mr. Whipple's health is far from strong, and Mr. Howells is living very quietly out of town.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 10.--This afternoon Mrs. Edward Houghtaling drank an ounce of carbolic acid. Physicians were promptly called, but her recovery is deemed doubtful. Her husband recently deserted her, which caused the attempt on her life. She is young and has no children.
MONTREAL, Dec. 10.--A special dispatch from Regina gives an account of some serious charges made against Lieut.-Gov. Dewdney in the Northwest Council during the debate on the address.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10.--The latest reports from Monterey, Mexico, say that Acting Governor Sepulvida, with 400 troops, and accompanied by a majority of both houses of the State Congress, arrived there last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--Major E.B. Keith, Quartermaster, has been ordered to make an inspection of the national cemeteries at the following places Natchez, Corinth, and Vicksburg. Miss. Port Hudson, Baton Rouge, Alexandria, and Charlotte, La.; Mobile, ...
CHICAGO, Dec. 10.--The strike of the switchmen and other yard employer of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad this evening came suddenly to an end shrouded in mystery.
Miss Lotta will substitute "Nitouche" for "The Old Curiosity Shop" at the Standard Theatre next Monday night.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Dec. 10.--Harry Farrington, aged 44 years, became suddenly insane about noon to-day and appeared on the street perfectly nude, proclaiming himself "God of the World." Armed with a club, he went about knocking on the doors of dwellings and remaining at the door until the knocks were answered.

All day yesterday the house where lay the body of the dead millionaire was the object of curiosity to hundreds of little groups who gathered at the street corners near by or wandered listlessly to and fro on the opposite side of the avenue.

MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 10.--This section was visited by a 30-mile gale Tuesday night, which was distinguished by sudden squalls of great in tensity. Many duck hunters and fishermen were caught out in the bay and barely escaped with their lives.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 10.--An ex parte council composed of delegates from the churches of the Hudson River Central Baptist Association, was held in the First Baptist Church of this city yesterday, pursuant to a resolution adopted by that association at its annual meeting at Sing Sing, Sept. 24, to consider and pass upon the standing of M.L. Ferris in the Christian ministry.

ROME, Dec. 10.--The trial was begun here to-day of a butcher named Tozzi and his wife, son, and daughter, who are charged with the murder of another butcher named Poggi. The motives for the crime were trade jealousy and family disputes. Poggi was entrapped into Tozzi's cellar, where the murder was committed.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 10.--Dr. H.J. McHugh, a veterinary surgeon, ran out of his office on Crown-street this afternoon and told the people whom he met on the street that he had taken 10 grains of morphine.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 10.--This morning on the West Point Railroad, near Long; Cane, Ga., nearly all the cars of a freight train became detached by the breaking of a coupling pin. The engineer stopped his engine, but being on a down grade the detached part came on with terrific force, crushing the engineer, John Knott, to death, and injuring the fireman, Morris.

Herr Friedrich Mitterwilrzer, the German artist that was lately seen at the Star Theatre, has transferred his field of operations to the Thalia, where he came forth last evening in Brachvogel's "Narciss."

THE NEW-YORK TIMES is not only the ablest Republican newspaper in the United States, but it is likewise a real live newspaper. THE TIMES never deals in subterfuge, discusses matters vigorously, sometimes bitterly earnest, but always respectful. There is no paper on that side of the fence that approaches it in dignity and power. All its news columns are especially interesting, and its Sunday edition is profuse with excellent reading matter.

Master in Chancery Isaac S. Romaine sat yesterday to hear the testimony in the proceedings brought against Richard Onslow, constable, by his wife to secure a divorce, on the ground of adultery. Mrs. Onslow and her witnesses and attorneys were in the room when Onslow entered. "Well," he is reported to have said to his wife as he entered, "you old hag, are you here."

A remarkable case of discrimination in railroad freight rates for the benefit of the Standard Oil Company and the destruction of independent shippers and refiners of oil has been discovered in Ohio. The facts are reported by the Marietta Leader of a recent date.

CIYT OF MEXICAO, Dec. 10, Via Galveston. --The bill giving the President authority to treat with the railway companies with regard to the modification of their respective concessions has now passed both houses of Congress and become a law.
FOR WORTH, Texas, Dec. 10.--At the annual meeting of the Fort Worth and Denver Railroad, held in this city on Tuesday last, initiatory steps were fully taken to extend the road clear through the ...
MEADVILLE, Penn., Dec. 10.--W.C. Walker, a student at the Theological Seminary in this city, shot himself dead this morning in his room in the college building.

KENTON, Tenn., Dec. 10.--About 2 o'clock Tuesday morning two clerks in the store of White Boyle were awakened by a suffocating smoke, and discovered that the store was on fire. A thief had entered, stolen some goods, and then set fire to the house.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 10.--Kittie Meyers, a handsome young lady residing at Mansfield, had a quarrel with her lover, and in order to spite him fled to this city and entered a house of ill repute. This so shocked her mother that she dropped dead upon hearing the news of her daughter's flight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10.--Joseph Klenar, alias Sklanar, an insane man, 26 years old, who escaped from the lunatic asylum in Hartburg, Streyermark, Austria, was picked up by the Chicago police while wandering on the streets two weeks ago.
The question of improving the facilities for supplying this city with water was discussed at the monthly meeting of the Union League Club last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10.--The annual meeting of the American Baseball Association, which began at the Continental Hotel yesterday and was nearly through with its work when interrupted by an order of court, has been indefinitely postponed.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 10.--The game between the New-York and Louisville nines was won by the former on a score of 10 to 5. Mullan, of the Louisvilles, did some remarkable pitching, and Foutz and Bushong, of the New-Yorks, finished without an error. Kelly laid off to rest in order to play a brilliant game on Sunday. It was a cold day and the attendance was small.

OTTAWA, Dec.10.--The taking of evidence before the Deputy Minister of Agriculture in the matter of the application of the Telephone Manufacturing Company of Toronto has been concluded. After hearing arguments the Deputy Minister reserved his decision.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 10.--A meeting of the creditors of Davenport Long, boot and shoe manufacturers, Worcester, was held here to-day, but the attendance was so small that no organization was effected. Mr. Davenport stated the liabilities to be about $30,000 and assets about $10,000.

GRENADA, Miss., Dec. 10.--C.L. Austin's gin house and mill at Elliott, Miss., was burned to-day, together with 40 bales of cotton. Engineer John Jones, a Welshman, and William Applewhite, (colored,) who were sleeping in the gin house, were burned to a crisp. The origin of the fire is unknown, but it is believed that it was the work of an incendiary.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10.--The resignation of Robert Garrett as a Director of the Jersey Central Railroad Company was the subject of a great deal of talk in financial circles to-day.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 10.--Four thousand persons attended an Irish mass meeting at Music Hall this evening in aid of the Parliamentary fund.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10.--The detectives are working like beavers to discover the murderer of ex-Mayor Bowman, of East St. Louis, and in their work they have made some startling discoveries.

MONTREAL, Dec. 10.--G.A. Mantel has entered an action against Mayor Beaugrand, as proprietor of La. Patrie, for $10,000 damages for libel. La Patrie charged Mantel with accepting a fourteen-thousand-dollar contract as a bribe to support the Government in the matter of hanging Riel.

BELGRADE, Dec. 10.--It is not believed here that the powers will be able to prevent a decisive battle being fought between the Bulgarians and Servians. The Servians will not admit that they have been conquered.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 10.--Some two Weeks ago the family of Frederick Hausmeyer, a well-to-do German, of Tarentum, Penn., 18 miles from this city, ate heartily of a salad of which raw pork, chopped fine, was one of the principal ingredients.

Edmunds, on behalf of counsel, dismissed per stipulation.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 10.--The entire effects of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company in this city were sold at auction to-day, and realized about $550. The sale included all the telegraph instruments, battery, 10 miles of wire, and 800 messenger call boxes and a horse and buggy. Much of the property was bought by junk dealers. The Bankers and Merchants' is advertised to be sold next week.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 10.--Twenty Sophomores and Freshmen of the State University were indefinitely suspended from that institution yesterday.

SAN ANGELO, Texas, Dec. 10.--Field Marshal Leo von Scharer, of the imperial Austrian Army, has just arrived in this city, and is the guest of Col. William S. Veck. Gen. von Scharer is about 60 years old, hale and hearty, and on the active list yet.

Prices are mostly steady in the cloth department, though sellers are disposed to accept offers which they had previously declined, thus effecting fair sales. LONDON, Dec. 12.--The Times says: "The Easter difficulty may be regarded as virtually settled. The powers have agreed to recognize the union of the Bulgarias. A demarkation commission has been appointed, which insures an armistice of a month, and will hardly fail to secure peace."

OLEAN, N.Y., Dec. 11.--John L. Sullivan, William Muldoon, and Martin Muldoon, who were arrested yesterday charged with committing an assault upon two men, were tried to-day. It was not proved that Sullivan took part in the fracas, and he was discharged. William Muldoon plended guilty to the charge and was fined $50. His brother was also fined $10.

Yesterday Weston lost the advantage he had gained over O'Leary in the walking match in the Newark Skating Rink, and the latter steadily drew ahead, so that at 10:30 o'clock, when they retired for the night, the score stood O'Leary, 240 miles: Weston, 234 miles.

HAZLETON, Penn., Dec. 11.--An acre of the surface over the Harleigh mines of M.S. Kemmerer Co. caved in to-day, causing great damage and throwing 400 miners and laborers out of employment. AUBURN, Dec. 11.--Gus Guerrero, of San Francisco, and A.A. Hoagland, of this city, were matched in a foot race this evening, Guerrero agreeing to run 10 miles while Hoagland walked seven miles square heel and toe. Hoagland completed seven miles in 52:19, defeating Guerrero half a mile. The track was 12 laps to a mile, and nearly exact, lacking only three feet on the entire mile. A large amount of money changed hands.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 11.--Joe Parker, a negro, said to be 125 years old, died at the Poor Farm here yesterday. His last words were: "Wake up, for the great jubilee am come." Parker had been a slave in Alabama, Georgia, and Texas for exactly 100 years of his life. He was the original of "Old Black Joe" in Dan Bryant's famous character song bearing that title.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 12.--An Erie freight brakeman named Course, of Conductor Coykendall's gang, running between Port Jervis and Newsburg, was killed at Greycourt last evening. Dealers in counterfeit silver dollars made a descent on the cars of the Sharp roads on Saturday night and victimized several conductors. At 8 o'clock a rough-looking man boarded the Bleecker-street car of which Louis E. Tiffeau is conductor at Twelfth and Fourth streets and handed him a dollar.

TRENTON, Dec. 13.--When the RockwellWainwright murder trial was ended last Spring at Toms River Counselor Lindaburg, who represented the Attorney-General in the prosecution, put in a bill for $2,000 for his services in behalf of the State, and the official stenographer also submitted his bill.

"Be ye ready for death" was the subject of the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher's sermon in Plymouth Church yesterday. Men largely dreaded death, Mr. Beecher said, because they did not know what was going to happen. All they knew was that the church said there was going to be an awful time.

OLEANA, Penn., Dec. 13.--Hugh Clem, Barney Morgan, and William Gibbs, all employes of the Williams Lumber Company, in Forest County, left the mills a few days ago to walk to their logging camp, five miles back in the woods.

HOHOKUS, N.J., Dec. 13.--After very many years of social sunshine, the residents of this romantic little village are finally to lose the presence of the old actor, Joseph Jefferson, and that of his immediate family.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 13.--The Hon. B. Gratz Brown died at his residence in Kirkwood, a suburb of this city, this morning, of pneumonia, complicatad with heart disease, age 59 years. Mr. Brown was a prominent figure in the politics of this State for a number of years, and also earned a national reputation.

DEMING, New-Mexico, Dec. 13.--A courier arrived at Silver City last night with the information that Capt. Fountain, Troop C. Eighth Cavalry, and his scouts surprised the hostiles on the 9th inst. at Lillie's cabin, three miles southeast of Papinoes. The Indians had murdered Lillie and an old man named Prior, and had just set fire to Lillie's cabin when the troops came upon them.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 13.--John Graham, a special conductor on the Nashville Railway, was caught between two cars and crushed to death to-day. He leaves a widow and children, and had worked for the company seven years.

Capt. Smith, of the bark Star of the South, which is loading for New-Zealand at Pier No. 10 East River, has recently had considerable trouble with his stewards, of whom he has had four during the past month. The first steward decamped with a watch and $80 belonging to the Captain.

Agents Becker and Burlando, of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, arraigned in the Harlem court yesterday the three young children of Peter Glynn, who lives in a shanty at One Hundred and Thirtyeighth-street and Fifth-avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13.--Although the House of Representatives has been in session only four days, it has already received 18 petitions from citizens of 11 States, praying that Congress shall take no action hostile to the silver dollar.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 13.--Contrary to expectation there was no trouble at Bevier, Mo., last night, and to-day all was quiet there.

BOSTON, Dec. 13.--The Rev. W.W. Downs, against whom an indictment was found yesterday by the Grand Jury for adultery, preached to a large audience this evening in Mechanics' Hall.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13.--Bernard Lynch, in the City Court here yesterday, was bound over to the next term of the Superior Court to answer to the charge of murder. Lynch stabbed Daniel Mallay 10 days ago, and the wounded man died from his injuries.

SANTIAGO DE CHILI, Dec. 13, via Galveston.--The Directory of the Liberal and Radical parties publishes a manifesto to-day calling a convention for the 2d of January. The candidate for the Presidency of the Republic, in order to be eligible, must receive the vote of two-thirds of the convention.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 13.--The Commercial Gazette will publish to-morrow a long communication from James Briggs, a miner employed at the Alliquippa mines of Lynn Co., in which he makes the startling statement that as an outcome of last week's riots at Pine Run the working miners have organized for the purpose of defending themselves against future attacks of the strikers.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 9.--Very many people are unaware that the Mormon Church exists outside of Utah. But it is a fact that the Saints' community is having a very rapid growth in New-England, as well as other parts of the country, and is particularly strong here in Massachusetts. Not the Salt Lake polygamous kind, however.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 13.--James Kennedy, a shoemaker, 39 years old, died in the hospital early this morning from the effects of a bullet wound inflicted Friday night by Constable William Voyt, who went to Kennedy's house in connection with a Squire's suit. Kennedy came from Boston.

READING, Penn., Dec. 13.--The mangled remains of an old man, identified as those of William Lotz, of this city, were found on the Philadelphia and Reading north track at 5 o'clock this morning. The body was still warm when discovered. Lotz had been on a spree.
WASHINGTON, Ga., Dec. 13.--Gen. Toombs remains critically ill. He is scarcely able to swallow his accustomed milk punch. He is confined to his bed as helpless as a baby, and is extremely weak.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 13.--The Typographical Union to-day ordered a strike on the Daily Chronicle. The Chronicle this morning publised a supplement, which the proprietor had set and printed in the Chronicle job rooms. The regular compositors on the paper claimed the right to measure and receive pay for the matter in the supplement.

John Staple entered the works of the United States Electric Light Company at Newark last night, and while eating part of the lunch of the men fell down in a stupor. The ambulance was called, when it was found that the man had take laudanum.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 13.--Commissioner C.F. Peck and Chief Clerk Kean, of the State Bureau of Labor Statistics, last night finished a week of taking labor statistics in this city. The special subjects of inquiry were strikes and women labor. Representatives of labor unions and several leading employers gave evidence.

Mrs. Louise De Comeau died at Clifton, Staten Island, yesterday in her seventieth year. She was the widow of Louis De Comeau, who died at the same place in April. Mr. De Comeau left an estate valued at a million dollars to his daughter, who resides in France.

At the Church of St. Joseph, in East Eighty-seventh-street, yesterday, the mass was sung by the Rev. Henry Heidenrich, and the Rev. Herman Blumensatt, S.J., delivered the sermon. The vespers were sung at 4 o'clock, after which Archbishop Corrigan administered the sacrament of confimation to nearly 200 girls and boys.

PEORIA, Ill., Dec. 13.--James H. Rogers, of Dunlap, has been arrested and held in $900 bail on the charge of having aided and abetted in the destruction of the Dunlap elevator, which was destroyed by fire in a mysterious way some time ago.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 13.--The sugar season now drawing to a close has been one of the most remarkable on record, not only in the size of the crop, but in the favorable weather and other circumstances attending its harvesting. Not a day has been lost by bad weather.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 13.--The business transacted by the Customs District of Buffalo Creek for the year ended June 30, 1885, is reported by the Supervising Special Treasury Agent as follows: Vessels entered--Foreign, 880; coastwise, 2.892. George Brockelman committed suicide last night by hanging himself in his room at No. 303 West Twelfth-street. He was a widower, 47 years old, and for four weeks had occupied a small bedroom in the house.

At a meeting of the Atlantic Yacht Club last evening it was decided to change the club measurement. Under the new plan to find the sailing measurement the length of the yacht must be taken at a point above the actual water line a distance equal to 2 per cent. of the length of the yacht at the actual water line.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 14.--Reports from Central Illinois and Southern Wisconsin and Michigan indicate that the heavy snowstorm of Saturday continued up to a late hour Sunday night, from 9 to 14 inches having fallen.
