The Newark Overseer of the Poor took Christian Hilfer, an old man of 80, into Judge Kirkpatrick's court yesterday. He said that he had brought Hilfer from the poorhouse. His family had sent him there, but as they were perfectly able to support him the county should not be burdened with his care.
Annie A. Jenks was arraigned in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, charged with bigamy. In January, 1880, the prisoner was married to James A. Gregory, a steamboat fireman.

Oliver Warren left his wife Margaret and his two children several years ago. He has since been living with another woman, of whose two children he is the father. His wife recently began a suit in the Court of Common Pleas for separation from him and asked the court to award her alimony.

MARTINSBURG, West Va., Dec. 14.--There is much excitement and alarm in this community over the prevalence of what seems to be cerebro spinal meningitis, there having been 35 cases within the past four days. Half a dozen deaths occurred yesterday and to-day.
Mr. Vanderbilt's bequest of $100,000 to the Metropolitan Museum of Art is likely to reawaken interest in the proposition to keep that institution open on Sundays.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Dec. 14.--John Dyson, a small lad, while endeavoring to jump upon a moving train at Finleyville this afternoon fell under the wheels and was ground to pieces.

The prisoner who gave his name as Frank Hilton, who was caught by Mrs. Peters in Jersey City, after he had snatched her pocketbook on Montgomery-street, Sunday, was recognized yesterday as Patrick McCabe, a well known New-York crook.

LONDON, Dec. 14.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade during the past week, says: "Value of wheat have not improved. The sales of English wheat during the weak were 50,864 quarters at 30s. 5d., against 61,240 quarters at 80s. 10d. during the corresponding week last year. The flour trade is dragging.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 14.--Owing to the fact of the probable absence of visitors from the United States on account of the prevalence of smallpox in Canada, the city authorities have decided not to take any part in the promotion of the carnival in this city this Winter. It was intended to hold the festival here this season instead of at Montreal.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14.--Persons who went to the Chestnut-Street Opera House this evening to hear Salvini in "The Outlaw" were confronted by a large sign saying "No performance this evening."

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 14.--The wrecking tug Winslow arrived at Port Huron on Sunday morning with the passengers from the wrecked steamer Oconto and Capt. McGregor. The tug could not get within three miles of the Oconto on account of the ice.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 14.--A special to the Globe-Democrat from Monterey, Mexico, says: Business is recovering from the shock caused by the recent disturbed condition of affairs.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 14.--P.W. Hoyle, a Peters-street stock dealer, was waylaid by highway robbers and relieved of $1,400 about midnight last night.

A friend of Miss Wildey, of South Orange, writes to THE TIMES, making the following statement about the article printed last week with regard to the accusations of cheating in a vote at a fair of the Methodist Episcopal Church of that place: "The basket of paper flowers...

Andrew Hogg, an iron merchant and resident of Greenpoint, complained to the police yesterday morning that he bad been robbed of 50 and an overcoat worth $50 by some unknown persons. He had been drinking in several saloons in Long Island City, and crossed over the creek...
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 14.--The recent advance in raw materials for the manufacture of iron and increased price for pig metal have caused activity about the idle blast furnaces in this vicinity.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14.--The elderly woman who was knocked down by a team on Grand-street yesterday was identified at the New-Haven Hospital to-day as Mrs. Mary S. Pomeroy. She has several children living in this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14.--The President to-day, in response to a Senate resolution, transmitted to that body all the papers and correspondence on file in the Department of State relating to the appointment of A. M. Keiley as Minister to Italy and his subsequent appointment as Minister to Austria.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14.--Benjamin T.O. Hubbard, formerly Cashier of the First National Bank, of Monmouth, Ill., who is charged with embezzling $120,000 of the bank's funds, testified in his own behalf to-day in the United States District Court, declaring that he had not taken any of the funds.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 14.--The State tax sale to-day was given up to lands in Franklin County, sold for arrears of taxes. Seven thousand eight hundred pieces were on the list and they brought from $50 to $100 each on the average.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 14.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following causes were argued: No.371--Alden B. Stockwell, appellant...
An official circular issued by J.D. Layng, General Manager, announces the appointment of J.W. Musson as Traffic Manager of the West Shore Railroad, to take effect yesterday.

John May and his wife, Mary, of Long Island City, were committed for trial yesterday morning by Justice Kavanagh for gross cruelty to the 10-year-old daughter of the husband. Saturday the child ran into a neighbor's house for ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 14.--J.H. Smith, Sr., who was at one time Sheriff of Smith County, a prominent member of the church, and who occupied many positions of trust, has been ordered by the Circuit Court to leave the State forever under penalty of immediate arrest and imprisonment for whisky blockade running.
Mr. George F. Williams, the Secretary of the Metropolitan Baseball Club, was seen yesterday and asked if he had seen the interview with President McKnight published in THE TIMES yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14.--The flood of bills that it was intended to let loose in the House today was not released, and it will probably gain greater volume by the delay of a week that may be expected to be enforced during the debate on the report of the Committee on Rules, which was submitted this morning by Mr. Morrison.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 14.--Benjamin Louth, Sr., the inventor of the process of making nail plate out of old steel rails, has sold the right of his patent to a syndicate of five Eastern firms. Mr. Louth claims that by his process at least $10 per ton can be saved on the manufactured product, as compared with the present methods of production.
Those jolly citizens composing the Society for the Preservation of Game met at Pinard's last night, and partook of the first dinner of the season.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 14.--The Mill Creek Slope of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, situated within a short distance of the Mill Creek station of the Lehigh and Susquehanna Road, was the scene of a terrible explosion of mine gas about 8 o'clock this morning, by which eight men were frightfully burned. The list of the victims is as follows:
As usual Sandy Hook caught the worst of the rainstorm that has been making NewYorkers uncomfortable for two days.

If the women want to know how comfortably the men can dispense with them in congregational singing they should peep into Trinity Church during one of Missioner Aitken's noon services for business men.
Sarah Ann Mallory died in 1884 and is buried in Cypress Hills Cemetery. Her husband, Frederick, died a short time ago and is buried in the White Hills Cemetery, near New-Haven.

ST. JOHNSVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 14.--Earl S. Gillett, aged about 58 years, Cashier of the National Mohawk River Bank of Fonda since its organization in 1856, died at Fonda about 7 o'clock this evening from a dose of aconite, given him by his wife in mistake for the usual medicine.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 14.--Last night officers found Katie E. Delaney, 16 years old, a pretty working girl, lying on the pavement near her home, No. 384 East Third-street, unconscious and bleeding from a severe wound in the neck.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 14.--The FifthAvenue Hotel Company assigned to-day with liabilities of about $10,000, involving local creditors entirely. Louis Strauss, dealer in gentlemen's furnishing goods, also assigned; liabilities, $8,500; assets half that amount.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 14.--In the United States court to-day H.B. Hammond, Receiver of the Indianapolis, Decatur and Springfield Railroad Company, filed a petition asking to be allowed to bring suit against Alphonse Duprat, now a resident of New-York.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 14.--It is rumored that the Hon. Diedrich Willers, Secretary of State from 1873 to 1875, will be Assistant Secretary to Mr. Frederick Cook, who will succeed Gen. Carr.

KINGSTON, Dec. 14.--Louis Willett, the condemned murderer, now employs his time in decorating the cell in which he is confined. It is lined with boiler iron and is painted a yellowish tint. Willett is painting stars all over it in green, blue, and red, so that it has quite an artistic appearance. He appears to be self-possessed, and never speaks of his approaching doom unless spoken to about it.
The chapel of the convent of the Ursuline nuns at Morrisania was filled at 10 o'clock yesterday morning by the relatives and friends of those about to join the community.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 14.--Argument was resumed to-day in the contested election case before Judge McKay, of the United States court.

Thomas J. Armstrong was set free last night on a verdict of acquittal. He had been on trial for a full week in the Brooklyn Court of Sessions for shooting his stepfather, Albert R. Herrick, on Aug. 10. Yesterday was devoted to summing up.
In Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon the Rev. Hugh R. Haweis, of London, lectured on "Wagner and His School" in aid of the library fund of the Alumnae Association of the Normal College.

The New-York Presbytery yesterday granted a request from the Murray Hill Church, of which the Rev. Dr. Burchard was formerly Pastor, for the pastoral services of the Rev. Dr. J. Ford Sutton, of Philadelphia.

Isaac Seligson, who worked for Hansen, Steiner Co., cigarette manufacturers, at No. 356 Pearl-street, was yesterday arraigned at the Tombs Police Court charged by Steiner with having created a disturbance in the shop.

When Patrolman Mahoney, of the Sixth Precinct, reached the end of his post at the junction of the Bowery and Chatham-square at 4:45 yesterday morning he noticed an object in white moving about with the agility of a cat on the trestlework of the elevated railroad at Division-street and the Bowery.
The House has set to work in earnest to revise its rules, and the discussion of the majority and minority reports on that subject will probably occupy the whole of this week.

MEDINA, N.Y., Dec. 14.--No material evidence was brought before the Coroner's jury in the Miles murder case to-day. The jury, after a brief deliberation, rendered a verdict that Amelia Miles came to her death by having her throat cut with a knife or some sharp instrument in the hands of some person unknown.
ST. CLAIR, Penn., Dec. 14.--A meeting of the Town Council has been called for Wednesday night to take action on the dynamite outrage on Saturday morning.
The annual sale of seats in the Central Congressional Church of Brooklyn last evening realized $3,140 in premiums. There are 369 seats, ranging in price from $3 to $150.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 14.--Roswell Hotaling, residing near Margaretville, Delaware County, disappeared three weeks ago. His family have been away visiting for that time.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14.--Mayor Smith to-day received a dilapidated and much patched pair of trousers.

Last evening's performance of "The Queen of Sheba" at the Metropolitan differed in no respect from its predecessors. It reintroduced the familiar artists in familiar roles, Herr Alvary being Assad and Herr Robinson King Solomon, the gorgeous processions...

Mr. Anson Pond's melodrama called "Her Atonement" was presented at the Grand Opera House last night before an audience somewhat smaller than those which usually gather in the popular west side theatre, but still large enough to indicate prosperous business throughout the week.
Col. Ayer, chief of the Special Agents' Bureau at the Custom House, is to be transferred to San Francisco, as is also his assistant, Special Agent Jewell.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14.--The Wabash stubbornly refuses to comply with the demand of the Rock Island and Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroads to have its percentages in the Western Trunk Lines Association (tripartite combination) reduced, and there is likely to be trouble over the matter in the association.

SWANTON, Vt., Dec. 14.--Four persons were drowned in Missisquoi Bay, Lake Champlain, at Phillipsburg, Quebec, on Saturday. Henry Burke and Annie Scroggie, a teacher, while skating, broke through the ice, and the latter only was saved. A blind man named Caderette and two children, while crossing the bay, broke through the ice, and all three were drowned.

Daniel W. McGee, a locomotive engineer employed on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, who lives at No. 591 East One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street, went to Police Headquarters last night and reported...

Samuel Barnett, a puller-in at No. 18 Baxter-street, was yesterday arrested on a warrant and arraigned at the Tombs Police Court. Michael Winn, of No. 350 Classon-avenue, Brooklyn, the complainant, said that on Saturday, while he was walking along Baxter-street...

CHICAGO, Dec. 14.--Vice-Chairman Pierson, of the Trunk Lines Passenger Pool, has requested all the connections of the trunk lines and affiliated roads between the Western terminal of the trunk lines and the Missouri River to settle continuous train tickets for all...

TROY, Dec. 14.--In the fog this morning the steamer Lotta, from Coxsackie for Albany, struck on a dike, crushing in her bow and sinking immediately. No lives were lost. The boat is believed to have been worth $15,000.

Sarah Gilfoyle, a pretty girl of 15, who had been employed as a servant in the family of Mr. Peck, a patent lawyer, residing at Stamford, Conn., eloped from her home with William Peck, the young son of her employer, on Nov. 21, and came to this city.
LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 14.--Hawthorn H. Kennedy, of Paradise, an extra telegraph operator in the Pennsylvania Railroad station, met with a terrible accident this morning that will prove fatal.

The Newark police are troubled over the question of how to kill dogs. Their first attempts were with pistols, but the average Newark policeman is not an accomplished marksman, and the dogs, as a rule, escaped, although some were terribly mutilated before they were at last killed with clubs.

James Russell, the companion of John Barry in the numerous highway robberies committed in the neighborhood of Seventieth-street and Fourth-avenue last week, was again remanded in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 14.--Two suits were filed in the Circuit Court of Summers County to-day which created a perfect whirlwind of gossip and excitement among the people of Hinton and the neighborhood surrounding.
BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 14.--Another link in the chain of circumstancial evidence going to show that the woman found dead in Sharon on Dec. 5 came to her death by violence was discovered yesterday.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 14.--Mr. E.S. Cowles, of the firm of Williams Cowles, of Jersey City, arrived here yesterday for the purpose of settling the affairs of Miss Arabella Field, of Brooklyn, who died suddenly at the Grand Central Hotel, this city, on the 20th of last month.

TALLULAH, Ga., Dec. 14.--A bride and bridegroom were drowned to-day while attempting to cross the Chattanooga River. Ernest Atwood married Miss Stella Wadsworth in Anderson, S.C., yesterday, and started for their new home in Rabun County, Ga. When they reached...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14.--The old Court House was crowded this morning by a class of spectators that don't usually attend trials in the Quarter Sessions. George F. and Samuel Work and Shreve Acklev were put on trial on the charge of conspiracy in the illegal issue and disposal of stock of the People's Passenger Railway Company.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 14.--In l867 a family named Fear, living in Cleveland, Ohio, lost all traces of their daughter Mary, aged 9 years, and finally gave her up for dead.
THOMASTON, Ga., Dec. 14.--Last night Mr. Dave Hayes was killed by Mr. Rains in this county. They had a quarrel over a bottle of whisky, which one claimed was brandy and the other said was whisky.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 14.--For some time past thieves and counterfeiters have been operating in this city, and detectives have been on their tracks without success until to-day, when a part of the combination was broken up by the arrest of two of the number.

MONTREAL, Dec. 14.--Justice Doherty today decided the celebrated case of Melvin Smith against his wife for infidelity and her suit against him on a similar charge, the declaration of which contained many very serious statements.
Eugene F. Buckley, the night watchman employed by the contractor for the buildings erecting at Third-avenue and East Seventyseventh-street, who was arrested on suspicion...

CHICAGO, Dec. 14.--The following figures taken from the official statement of the Board of Trade, to be posted on 'Change to-morrow morning, show, in bushels, the amount of grain in sight in the United States and Canada on...
This evening's programme for the Thomas Popular Concert at the Academy of Music is devoted to Beethoven.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 14.--Labor Commissioner Charles F. Peck arrived in this city today to inquire into the matter of strikes, particularly the recent molder's strike which was of several months' duration.
Margaret Doyle has been twice married, and regrets the fact. According to her own story she has been badly treated by both husbands, and did not regret the death of the first one.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Dec. 14.--This has been an exciting day among those interested in the oil trade. The Gabby Well was torpedoed with a hundred-quart shot.
OTTAWA, Dec. 14.--The sentence of F. Seraglio, the Italian who was to have been hanged on the 28th inst., has been commuted to 10 years' imprisonment in the Provincial Penitentiary.

A new and very pretty ballet was seen for the first time at Niblo's last evening in the second act of "The Ratcatcher," while the ballet in the third act, which as the piece is now arranged follows the Makart procession, was given as before.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14.--Frank Gilbert, an employe in Osborn Cheesman's shops at Shelton, while at work today, caught his arm in a set of brass rollers. By main strength Gilbert succeeded in saving himself from being drawn into the rollers.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 14.--About 7 o'clock this morning E.A. Jones, residing on Ellsworthavenue, Mechanicville, was discovered in his yard acting as though insane.
The will of Rear-Admiral John W. Livingston was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday. All the estate is left to the testator's wife, Mary Augusta Livingston, for her use during her life.
No art is more plastic or elastic than the drama. There is nothing too symmetrical nor too shapeless to be included in its wide domain. The stage is a world of contrasts and delicious uncertainty.

The placid countenance of President Eugene Kelly, of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association, was wreathed in smiles when Richard M. Waiters read the name of Archbishop Corrigan as a contributor of $50 to the fund.
BELGRADE, Dec. 14.--Rumors are current of hard fighting between Pirot and Bela Pelanka, and of Bulgarian attacks on the Servian forces at Widdin and the retiring of Gen. Leshjanin.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 14.--A committee of Hocking Valley coal operators and miners arrived in the city to-day to gather information regarding the railroad coal trade here, to be presented to the Hocking Valley Arbitration Board.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14.--In the Supreme Court of the United States the following decisions were rendered to-day:
The Hon. S.G.W. Benjamin, late United States Minister to Persia, lectured before a crowded meeting of the American Geographical Society in Chickering Hall last evening on Persia and the Persians.

WOOSTER, Ohio, Dec. 14.--The Orrville Farmers' Bank, a private institution run by prominent citizens of Orrville and vicinity, was closed on Saturday. The bank was reported to be shaky some time ago, but was reorganized, and was thought to be solid.

Louis C. Burgess, a clerk in the employ of the Liebig Laboratory and Chemical Company, who was found insensible Sunday morning on the Amboy road, Staten Island, and was thence taken to the Smith Infirmary at Tompkinsville, gave the following account of himself on regaining consciousness:
Mr. VANDERBILT'S bequests to the American Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum of Art will make the maintenance of those institutions considerably easier than it has heretofore been.
Mayor Grace yesterday approved of the following resolutions, passed by the Board of Aldermen on motion of President Sanger:

The annual meeting of the Lehigh and Hudson River Railroad Company was held yesterday at No. 161 Broadway. The election for a Board of Directors resulted as follows: Grinnell Burt, John S. Martin, W.C. Sheldon...
A dispatch to THE TIMES from Danville, Ky., yesterday announced the death of Peter C. Fox, a prominent turfman. Mr. Fox owned Tom Martin, a most promising candidate for cup honors next season.
PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 14.--John S. Clary, a wealthy butcher of this city, has been in the habit of keeping his accounts at the Petersburg Savings and Insurance Company.

LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 14.--The Lancaster Bar Association, at its semi-annual meeting to-day, considered the case of Robert J. Evans, a member of the Bar, who is charged with appropriating to his own use money intrusted to him by Henry Speidel, Executor of...

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 14.--The Typographical Union to-night ordered a strike on the Daily Tribune because the proprietors declined to pay a compositor for a change made in an advertisement by the foreman after the compositor had failed to set it according to orders.

At the annual meeting of the Real Estate Exchange and Auction Room yesterday the annual report was read, showing that the net earnings up to Nov. 15 were $8,539,671, out of which a dividend of 1 per cent. has been declared.
LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 14.--Lancaster presented a lively scene to-day. Every train brought in hundreds of farmers and hundreds came by private conveyance, until the streets were thronged.

Several overdue steamships arrived at this port early yesterday and reported having had very stormy experiences on the ocean. The City of Richmond, of the Inman Line, which was due on Friday last, encountered violent gales, with head seas, during the entire passage from Queenstown.

The Tammany Hall Convention in the Sixth Assembly District, which was convened last night to nominate a candidate for Assembly in place of William Hall, deceased, felt the heavy hand of Richard Croker upon it.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 25 cents. Drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25 cents.

Henry A. Smith was yesterday arraigned in the Tombs Police Court on a charge, made by Andrew Shenkel, of obtaining goods by fraudulent representations. Smith is a rubber broker, is a young man of good appearance, and lives at No. 193 Madison-avenue.
Yesterday the Senate investigating committee adjourned, subject to the call of the Chair on forty-eight hours' notice, which means that its work of inquiry is finished.

Gov. Hill, on Monday, pardoned Ralph Schmidt, a convict in Sing Sing Prison, and he was released yesterday. Schmidt was convicted of stealing six tablecloths, valued at $70, and was sent to prison in June last for two and a half years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--The Chicago Committee of East-bound Freight Traffic to-day discussed for some hours the question of giving Joint Agent T.C. Moore increased powers in investigating charges against the roads forming the committee of violation of rates.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15.--Last night Hart's Opera Company opened a week's engagement at Apgar's Opera House in Moberly, Mo., and as an advertisement gave a free exhibition. The scheme caught well, the house being literally packed up stairs and down.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 15.--The insane man who arrived at Stonington on the steamer Massachusetts Sunday morning has been identified as Dr. William Morrison. He is still in a terribly excited condition and refuses all nourishment.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, Alderman Hall presented a resolution providing that "no person shall drive any railroad cars while carrying passengers in any of the streets of the city, unless he be 21 ...
Della Watson, who manages the "Ceni College Chums Comedy Company," was yesterday arraigned at the Tombs Police Court. She had been there as a defendant upon a similar charge only a few weeks ago.
BOSTON, Dec. 15.--Mayor Hugh O'Brien was re-elected to-day by a majority of 8,580 in a small vote. This is the largest majority that a candidate for Mayor has received in this city for many years.

At the annual meeting of the New-England Society, held last evening at Delmonico's, the following officers were elected to serve for the ensuing year: Horace Russell, President; Cornelius N. Bliss, First Vice-President; ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 15.--In the Court of Sessions this afternoon Hiram B. Everest and Charles M. Everest, of the Rochester Vacuum Oil Company, indicted for conspiracy in endeavoring to ruin the business of the Buffalo Lubricating Oil Company with others, appeared ...

MONTREAL, Dec. 15.--To-day the attorneys of Melvin Smith took out a writ of appeal against the judgement rendered yesterday by Justice Doherty in favor of Mrs. Smith. A return will be made in a day or two by Mrs. Smith for alimony allowance and to secure possession of her four children. It is stated that the annual allowance asked for will be about $4,000.

Jerry P. Thomas, one of the best known of the barkeepers of this city, died in his residence, Sixty-third-street and Ninth-avenue, on Monday afternoon of apoplexy. Soon after noon he left the Hotel Brighton for his home, and within five minutes after reaching it he dropped to the floor dead. He leaves a widow and two children.

Thomas Micklemore, a Canadian solicitor, came to this city from Winnipeg, Manitoba, in October last in search of clients. He brought with him his 8-year-old son, and left his wife and the rest of his family in Winnipeg.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 15.--The amount in litigation between H.B. Hammond, Receiver of the Indianapolis, Decatur and Springfield Railroad, and A. Duprat, the late Treasurer, is $3,800.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--During the Forty-eighth Congress the Senate restaurant was in charge of a colored man who had been a bartender in a well known saloon on Pennsylvania-avenue, and whose ability as the concoctor of certain mixed drinks had made him popular among eminent national legislators who appreciated his artistic works.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15.--The following annual reports were filed to-day:

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 15.--Early this morning clerks discovered that the dry goods store of Westbrook Stoll, at Port Jervis, had been entered by burglars through a skylight and $2,000 worth of goods had been stolen.

The walking match between O'Leary and Weston wns continued in New-Brunswick, N.J., yesterday. Both men seemed to be in good condition, though O'Leary was decidely the fresher. The score at 10:30 this evening, when the men stopped, was: O'Leary, 378 miles; Weston, 371 miles.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 15.--The election of a United States Senator to succeed Gen. Mahone, whose term expires March 4, 1887, took place to-day in the General Assembly.

The steamship Muriel, which arrived from the West Indies yesterday, brought the crew of the schooner Alice Tarlton, which was run down some weeks ago by an unknown vessel. Capt. Cole, of the lost schooner, states that he sailed from Rockport, Me., for Port au Prince on Nov. 12.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Dec. 15.--The engineer of the south-bound passenger train on the Lake shore and Michigan Southern Railway yesterday morning discovered the bleeding body of a man on his hands and knees near the track at NewEra Station, 16 miles north of Fort Wayne.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 15.--William Westlake died after much suffering and a county way relieved of great expense a short time ago. Westlake was an inmate of the Summit County Infirmary, having been a sufferer from acute rheumatism.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15.--One hundred colored men, women, and children passed through the city to-day en route from South Carolina to Arkansas, where they intend to settle.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 15.--A mass meeting of the milk producers of Orange and adjoining counties will be held in the Goshen Court House on Thursday, 24th inst., at 10 A.M., for the formation of a farmers' milk exchange in New-York.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15.--The committee of stockholders having in charge the reorganization of the Beech Creek Railroad Company met this week and prepared a circular, which was sent to each stockholder in the road, asking for an assessment on ...

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 15.--The systematic robbery of freight cars arriving in this city has been carried on for some time past. Late yesterday evening the seal on an Iron Mountain car was discovered to be broken, and on examination three boys--Andrew, Frank, and ...
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 15.--The Mayor of this city, J. Valsin Guillotte, was tried to-day on the charge of extortion in office while Clerk of the Court some years ago.
ALBANY, Dec. 15.--It is now reported that Superintendent of Insurance John A. McCall, Jr., will not accept the Presidency of a New-York insurance company in January, as previously announced.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 15.--The General Term has affirmed the decisions of the Supreme Court in the cases of Julia and George D. Turner against the city of Newburg.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. l5.--The celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the organization of the Maennerchor Singing Society began to-night at Maennerchor Hall, Franklin-street and Fairmount-avenue.

Inspector Byrnes has in his possession all or nearly all the watches, jewelry, and valuables stolen on the night of the 7th inst. from the vault of E.N. Marks's jewelry store, No. 103 Adams-street, Chicago.

The Rev. Joseph R. Duryee was installed as Pastor of the Grace Reformed Church, corner of West Fifty-fourth-street and Seventhavenue, last evening, in the presence of a congregation which filled evey seat in the building.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 15.--The State Dairymen's Association began a three day's convention here to-day. Prominent dairymen are in attendance from all parts of the State. The closing night an entertainment will be given the association by the ladies of Jamestown.
The Calcutta dispatch recording an increased belief that the Government does not intend to annex Burmah may be somewhat due to local impatience over a natural delay.
The justice of the acquittal of ARMSTRONG has already been impugned, but on no good ground that we can see. His story was consistent with itself and with the known facts of the case.

George Sisson, a, grocer, died of consumption last Autumn at No. 165 East Thirtysecond-street, and his widow recently fitted up a a grocery store at No. 203 East Thirty-first-street. Monday she moved there, and at night she, her ...

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 15.--Shortly after the machinery in the spinning room of the Arlington Mills Manufacturing Company was set in motion this morning a heated pulley set fire to some cotton on mules, and the flames spread through the building in an instant, burning it to the ground.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15.--The agents in Tennessee towns of foreign insurance companies have been notified that rates will advance ...

Jacob Knobloch, a well known local worker in Republican ranks, entertained the members of the Yorkville Pig's Head Club at a banquet last night at his place, No. 1,551 Secondavenue, near Eightieth-street.
Antonio Sturma asked the Board of Health yesterday to investigate the death of his sister, Mrs. Anna Stessner, who lived at No. 257 West Thirty-ninth-street, saying that he suspected poisoning.

Mr. John Cryer, an aged business man from London, Canada, came to New-York yesterday for the first time in a quarter of a century. When near the Post Office he was asked by "Pete" Lake, or, as the police know him, "Grand ...

Some one slew a couple of big polar bears recently away up North near where Lieut. Greely and his party were found, and consigned the skins to C.C. Shayne, the furrier, of No. 103 Prince-street. They arrived yesterday, and their appearance made all of Mr. Shayne's business friends jealous.

KINGSTON, Dec. 15.--Three young men of Fox Hollow, Ulster County, named Elvey, Tompkins, and Harlecker, met with an exciting adventure in the woods a few days ago. They tracked a bear to a cave. Elvey, who had a gun with him, fired into the cave and wounded the bear.

The report of Receiver Joel B. Erhardt, of the New-York City and Northern Railroad Company, shows that the earnings of the road from Dec. 1 to 10 were $12,569 59, against $8,530 30 for the same time last year, an increase of $4,039 29.

Two handsomely dressed ladies walked into Recorder Schleicher's court at Union Hill, N.J., yesterday. One of them said she was looking for Herman Harris, her husband, a clerk in a New-York store, who had abandoned her. Some months ago, she said, they had lived on Union Hill.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 15.--It was believed that the Hamilton County returns on the last election had been effectually disposed of. Such, however, was an error.

Charles Kaufman, of Franklin, who was bitten by a dog that is supposed to have been mad, will sail for Paris to be treated by Pasteur to-day. Dr. O'Gorman, of Newark, supplied him with the necessary funds.
NYACK, Dec. 15.--"The recent stormy weather has retardad us some in our work on the park," said one of the men to THE TIMES'S correspondent, "but you can see that we are getting along finely."

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 15.--The crew of a coal train on the Lehigh Valley Railroad had a sensational escape from death at Yatesville this morning. The workings of Fowler's colliery caved in during the night and caused the surface to subside for 200 yards over which the railroad runs.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 15.--Waterbury is enjoying the sensation just now of knowing all about one of the most singular elopements that ever took place, where a married man abandoned his family and hied away with two women and several of their children. The man is Elihu B. Smith, a blacksmith and a Deacon in the Methodist Church.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--The proceedings in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day were as follows: No. 588--Henry C. Brown, appellant, vs. James B. Grant, Governor. , et al.--Argument continued ...

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15.--All that was mortal of the late B. Gratz Brown was laid away in Oak Ridge Cemetery, at Kirkwood, this morning. Among those present at the funeral were Gov. Marmaduke and Adjt.-Gen Jamison.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--A bill was filed in the Circuit Court here to-day by Perry H. Smith, Jr., Ernest H. Smith, and Emma A. Smith, Executors of the estate of Perry H. Smith, against George L. Dunlap, Columbus R. Cummings, W.B. Howard, Jay Gould, ...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 15.--Chris Vonder Ahe, Vice-President of the American Association, arrived home to-day. Speaking about the Metropolitan Club and the throwing of it out of the association, be said:

A meeting was held last evening at the residence of Courtland Palmer, No. 117 EastTwenty-first-street, to further the cause of manual training and to create additional interest in the progress of the Gramercy-Park School and Tool House, No. 104 East Twentiethstreet.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 15.--The river was free of ice in the channel from here to Albany yesterday, but a cold wave has entered the Hudson River Valley and ice is again forming. No boats are running north of Rondout.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 15.--Frederick J. Stanton, formerly Wyoming Territorial Geologist, now notary public and attorney for Baker Johnson, Iver Johnson, of the firm of Baker Johnson, merchants; George D. Hawes, and Abraham Baker, were arrested yesterday on ...
ALBANY, Dec. 15.--The interest in the State tax sale is diminishing. The attendance to-day was small. Lands in Fulton, Genesee, and Greene Counties were sold, about 250 parcels in all.

Edward Banks was arraigned in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, charged with stealing William Holmes's pocketbook. Both are colored men. One witness, in explanation, said that it was only a "nigger fight," and that the prisoner was a good man.

"It never rains but it pours" is an adage that stands in high favor with the Grant Monument Association. For several days the fund had been at a standstill, but yesterday the dollars rolled into the treasury in a shining stream that swelled the fund from $104,004 to $111,000.

The suit of George O. Hovey's heirs against Phelps, Dodge Co., for damages based on alleged misrepresentations of the value of a Chicago store which they sold him in 1875, was continued yesterday before Judge Van Vorst in the Supreme Court.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 15.--The National Convention of Coal Operators and Miners, called for the purpose of arbitrating the difficulties between the employers and employes, and establishing a national scale of wages, together with the cost of miners' supplies, which shall govern the operators and the men all over the United States, opened here this morning.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 15.--The arrangements to attend the banquet to-morrow, given by Mr. Erastus Wiman to Mr. Robert Garrett, are completed, and a large delegation will go from Baltimore by special train.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 15.--Something of a sensation was created yesterday by the finding of the dead body of Frank Duncan, a miner living at East Palestine, near here.

James E. Hoyt, Superintendent of the Poor of Westchester County, is anxious that the Board of Supervisors should accept the offer of the Children's Aid Society of New-York and thereby save the county about $12,000 per year.
MONTREAL, Dec. 15.--An official statement shows that the value of the cattle exported from Montreal from May 1 to Nov. 30 was $4,491,870, and of sheep $274,975.
A bright-eyed young girl, jauntily dressed, clung tenaciously to the arm of a man much older than herself when the steerage passengers of the steamer Egypt were landed yesterday.

HURON, Dakota, Dec. 15.--The "First Legislature of the State of Dakota" assembled at Huron yesterday morning. Under the Constitution it was made the duty of Gen. Hugh J. Campbell, Chairman of the State Executive Committee, to call the House to order and swear in the members.
LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 15.--That dreaded cattle disease, pleuro-pneumonia, has made its appearance in a fine herd of cattle belonging to Henry G. Resh, who resides near West Willow.

Patrick Burns, known through the length and breadth of Yorkville and Harlem and also in that portion of the east side which has been dubbed Mackerelville, died at Bellevue Hospital, yesterday, after a short illness.

Chief-Justice Daly, of the Court of Common Pleas, has made an order reopening the case of Rufus Story against the New-York Elevated Railroad Company so far as to permit the defendant corporation to put in evidence its proceeding in the Supreme Court to acquire title to that portion of Mr. Story's easement, in Frontstreet, which it has usurped.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 15.--At midnight last night on the Georgia Pacific Railroad, 17 miles from this city, the Georgia Pacific train was run into by the East Tennessee train. Ten persons were killed instantly and six seriously wounded.

By a vote taken yesterday in executive session tha Gibbs investigating committee has practically stopped work. In order to make a better appearance, a motion to adjourn subject to the call of the Chair on 48 hours' notice was substituted for a motion for a sine die adjournment, ...

The North German Lloyd Line are having three new steamships built at the yard of John Elder, on the Clyde. The new vessels will probably be ready in the Spring. They are of the same pattern as the Werra, Ems, and other fast vessels of the line.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15.--The town of Birmingham, nine miles from here, has been the scene of a number of unprovoked and mysterious assaults within the past few days. Last night Mrs. Catherine Haggarty, a widow, who works in Joomer's corset shop, started for her home in the northern part of the town.

BUFFALO, Dec. 15.--During the season just closed there entered the port of Tonawanda 1,162 vessels with 498,613,000 feet of lumber, besides 7,652,000 lath 52,004,000 shingles. The duties imposed were $51,015 72. Of the lumber received by lake at Tonawanda this year over seven-tenths, or 355,230,391 feet, went East by canal. The value of the shipments is estimated at $8,467,460.

Mayor's Marshal Byrnes yesterday investigated a peculiar case in which an intelligence office keeper named Fitzpatrick, of No. 32 Greenwich-street, was called upon to explain. Fitzpatrick, it was claimed, had advertised for 125 men to go to Central America for employment.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 15.--At 3 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in Cambridge, N.Y., which resulted in the loss of a life. The property destroyed consisted of the old Fenton Hotel on Main-street, in the village, owned by Albert Herrington and kept by George O'Brien, and the saloon adjoining the hotel, run by a man named Kennedy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15.--The Board of Trustees of Princeton College, last week, at the recommendation of the Faculty, Unanimously conferred the degree of Master of Arts on W. J. Henderson, of the Class of '76. The regular time of meeting for the conferring of degrees is in February, but the Faculty recommended the conferring of this degree at once.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--An attachment was taken out before Justice Hammer to-day by Ben Cirkle to recover $164 from Emma Nevada which is alleged to be due the plaintiff for extra services as advertising agent and assistant advance agent last year.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 15.--Orange County has two county seats, Goshen and Newburg. In Goshen the jail is a building by itself, but in Newburg cells are placed in the Court House for the imprisonment of culprits.

The Rev. Mr. Aitken preached in Trinity Church yesterday noon on "Snares." Passing briefly over the snare of intemperance, into which he thought men were often led by the sociable glass, he devoted the main part of his discourse to the snare of gambling.

WASHINGTON, Ga., Dec. 15.--Gen. Robert Toombs died this morning at 6 o'clock. He was stricken with paralysis about three months ago and had since been confined to his room, during which time his mind had been more or less clouded.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 15.--Miss Arrighi, the New-York girl who was taken from the Pittsburg Female College yesterday by two ministers, is still in this city. She is stopping with the Rev. Dr. C.W. Smith, editor of the Christian Advocate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--First Lieut. Charles C. Morrison, Ordnance Department, has been granted leave of absence for six months on account of sickness. The leave of absence of First Lieut. Nathaniel Wolfe, Second Artillery, has been extended six months on account of sickness.

John Kearney, a well known Irish Nationalist, died suddenly of pnuemonia at his home, No. 65 North Moore-street, late Monday afternoon. Mr. Kenrney was born in Millstreet, County Cork, Ireland, 50 years ago.

Some one sent an anonymous communication to the Board of Health yesterday, giving information that an actress named Sarah S. Cortelyou, or Sadie Cortelyou, as she was known to the stage, had died from the effects of malpractice.
A regular meeting of the Union Card Political League was held last night at No. 141 Eighth-street, near Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--Mr. Hoar addressed the Senate to-day in support of the Presidential Succession bill. He said the bill, in case of a vacancy in the offices of President and Vice-President, devolved the Presidential duties upon the members of the Cabinet in the order of their official seniority, that is to say, in the order in which the various departments were ...

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 15.--The hydrophobia scare in this city was increased to-night by the mangling of the son, 5 years old, of Charles Nichols by a large Newfoundland dog belonging to George Van Riper, of No. 66 Sheffield-street.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 15.--At the meeting of the Harlem syndicate this afternoon Walter H. Shupe, of New-York, Trustee for the syndicate, read his report. He stated that the members resided in about 80 Congressional district, in over 30 States and Territories, and possessed ...
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 15.--A meeting of the Athletic Commitee has been held and the advisability of allowing Harvard to re-enter the Intercollegiate Football League has been discussed.

ALBANY, Dec. 15.--Speaker Erwin was in town to-day to attend a meeting of the Capitol Trustees. With his customary coolness he declared to all with whom he conversed that he was certain of being re-elected Speaker.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 15.--Labor Commissioner Peck has been busy all day examining witnesses. Among them have been a molder, tailor, and printer.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 15.--A man named Smith has been finally found who had the courage to ask that his name be changed. He is a resident of Cleveland, and has placed on file an application to the Common Pleas Court asking that he shall hereafter be known as Edward Smith Worthington, the latter name being that of his grandmother.

TORONTO, Dec. 15.--The Globe's London (England) correspondent interviewed Sir John A. Macdonald on his arrival, who informed him that the main object of his visit to the old country was to gain a short rest.

OTTAWA, Dec. 15.--It is reported that in addition to reimposing duties on tea and coffee, with the view of meeting the deficit in the revenue, the new Minister of Finance will increase the coal tax from 50 cents to $1 per ton.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 15.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following business was transacted:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15.--It is learned on excellent authority that the $200,000 bequeathed to Vanderbilt University by the late William H. Vanderbilt well probably be used in the erection of a fire-proof library building and the purchase of books for the same.

NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico, Dec. 15.--Now that the Federal Government has assumed the management of affairs in the State of Nuevo Leon no further trouble is anticipated at present, and a general feeling of relief is experienced.
A. Foster Higgins presided at yesterday's meeting of the Harbor and Shipping Committee of the Chamber of Commerce, and many influential members of the Chamber were present, ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 15.--The Pioneer Press, in its review of railway operations in the Northwest during the year, says: "There was less new railway track built in the Northwest during the present year than in any year since 1880.

Our esteemed contemporary the Evening Post altogether misapprehends the point and meaning of Secretary BAYARD'S argument with the stiff-necked Austrians in the Keiley case. Mr. BAYARD did not "take the position that the Emperor was bound to receive him [KEILEY] because the reasons he gave for rejecting him were not ...

The incoming vessels continue to report severe weather at sea. The steamship Zeeland, of the Red Star Line, arrived from Antwerp yesterday after a very stormy passage of 17 days. Terrific gales from southwest to northwest prevailed from the Channel to Sandy Hook.
Dr. James B. Taylor, of the Fourth Sanitary Division, was busy yesterday in investigating several cases of smallpox which had been concealed.

"We have notified the Western Union Company twice," said Under Sheriff Aarons yesterday, "that unless the execution held in this office for the State on account of unpaid taxes was satisfied promptly we should proceed to sell its property in satisfaction.

It is now arranged that Senator HOAR'S bill regulating the succession to the duties of the President in case of a vacancy in the office of President and Vice-President and the bill of Mr. EDMUNDS regulating the Electoral Count shall be joined together.

Typesetters poured into the large publishing house of Frank Tousey, in North Moorestreet, for six hours yesterday, to witness a contest between Joseph McCann, of the Herald, and W.C. Barnes, of the World composing rooms. The match took place in the seventh story of the building, and during its progress there was no time that all the available space in the room was not occupied.

Dr. Derby, in a communication to the Board of Health last week, said that contagious ophthalmia among children in public institutions had increased to such an extent that the Academy of Medicine had taken the matter up and the Committee on Ophthalmia had arranged to thoroughly investigate the disease.

A very entertaining fair was held at the Hotel Brunswick yesterday afternoon in aid of the Bethlehem Day Nursery. This nursery, which is situated at No. 248 East Thirty-firststreet, is attended by children whose mothers are working women.

READING, Penn., Dec. 15.--Knup Bergenstrahl, a Swede employed as a draughtsman in the Pottstown Iron Company's Steel Works, met an instantaneous death on the Reading Railroad, a half mile west of Pottstown, this morning.
Rose Miley, well wrapped up in blankets, was taken early Monday evening from a carriage that stopped in front of ChambersStreet Hospital and carried inside.
An advertisement appeared yesterday offering a reward for the return to Ashbel P. Fitch, attorney, No. 93 Nassau-street, of certain papers and property taken from No. 404 Fourthavenue.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15.--Several prominent and wealthy farmers in the neighborhood of Asbury, a quiet hamlet in "The Forks," are very much excited over the receipt of anonymous letters making threats against their lives and property. The letters are postmarked Knoxville, and almost illegible. The following is a copy of one of these epistles:

The programme of the seventh Popular Concert, which was given at the Academy of Music last evening, was devoted to Beethoven's music, as the programme of the preceding Tuesday was devoted to Berlioz's.

Mr. Erastus Wiman and his associates in the Staten Island Railway and other enterprises tendered a dinner of welcome to Mr. Robert Garrett and the executive officers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad last evening.
The motion of counsel for the Rev. David Brainard Ray, Rector of Grace Church, in Harlem, for a bill of particulars in the suit of his former assistant Rector, the Rev. John O. Bache...
BOSTON, Dec. 16.--Dr. C.M. Woodward, Director of the Manual Training School of St. Louis, in response to an invitation extended by a number of leading Bostonians, gave his views...
Herman A. Cook, dealer in provisions at Nos. 977 and 979 First-avenue, made an assignment yesterday to H. Wenning, giving preferences for $13,419, of which $5,100 was to relatives.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 16.--The will of the millionaire vessel owner, Capt. Alva Bradley, who died in this city a few days ago, was probated to-day. It was a voluminous document.

BUFFLO, N.Y., Dec. 16.--The Lake Carriers' Association, representing important United States vessel interests on the great lakes, to-day addressed a letter to President Cleveland, calling his attention to the existing law regarding mutual help by Canadian or United States vessels on the lakes in cases of wreck or distress.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 16.--For several months the Louisville Bride Company has been engaged in the construction of an iron truss bridge across the Cumberland River at this place. Some weeks ago the false work of the channel span of the structure gave way, owing to the stong current and the accumulation of driftwood at the base.

ITHACA, Dec. 16.--The Faculty of Cornell University have adopted a rule by which attendance on lectures and recitations is made voluntary, with certain limitations to guard against neglect on the part of the student.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 16.--The true inwardness of the killing of young Millard Fillmore Parker, at Monroe, La., last Saturday, has just been brought to light. It appears that Parker, together with his brother and a constable, went to the house of George Johnson, a negro, late at night and aroused him from his sleep.
DETROIT, Dec. 16.--Mr. James McMillan, one of the largest capitalists and best known business men here, had a narrow escape from instant death this morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16.--By the provisions of the will of the late Allen C. Lewis, probated in 1877, Chicago is about to come into possession of a public institution resembling in many respects the Cooper Union of New-York and the Polytechnic Schools of Troy and Boston.

LONDON, Dec. 17.--The Standard says: "Mr. Gladstone, on taking office, will be prepared to create an Irish Parliament to manage legislative and administrative affairs, securities being taken for the representation of minorities, the equitable partition of all imperial charges, and the unity of the empire.

The Nassau Athletic Club, of Brooklyn, was incorporated two months ago and now has 257 members in good standing. The officers elected for the ensuing season are: President-- T.L. Woodruff; First Vice-President--G.W. Blair; Second Vice-President--L.V. Strong; ...

The Aldermanic Railroad Committee yesterday heard further arguments for and against the applications of the Citizens and the People's Surface Railway Companies to lay tracks in nearly every street south of Canalstreet.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 16.--The Roman correspondent of the Catholic Mirror writes that no new Cardinals will be created in the December Consistory, despite all reports to the contrary.

Some interesting facts concerning the financial history and condition of the several corporations that comprise the Consolidated Gas Company were given to the Senate Gas Investigating Committee by James Yalden, the expert accountant, yesterday afternoon.

MONTREAL, Dec. 16.--The investigation opened here some time since into the charges against the British-American Bank Note Company of smuggling in here from New-York valuable articles of art produced there, and of...

The suit of the heirs of George O. Hovey against Phelps, Dodge Co., for damages for alleged misrepresentation of the value of property in Chicago sold by the defendants to Mr. Hovey, began to draw toward a close yesterday.

A concert was given at Steinway Hall yesterday evening, in aid of the Gotham Art Students, an organization whose objects were duly set forth in a brief address with which the vocal and instrumental performances were prefaced.
The Excise Commissioners yesterday revoked the license of John Link, a saloon keeper at No. 133 Third-avenue, on a complaint that a room over the saloon had been let out for gaming purposes.

HONESDALE, Penn., Dec. 16.--The usually quiet little village of Starucca, in the northern part of this county, has had an unusual number of startling occurrences to excite it within a fortnight or so.
The Twenty-third Regiment, N.G.S.N. Y., gave a complimentary reception to their bandmaster, Prof. Felix I. Eben, last evening, at their armory on Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 16.--This afternoon W.A. Wight, No. 36 Ontario-street, was washing his baby's clothes with gasoline. He had completed his work and stepped outside to hang up a dress, when, upon turning around, he discovered his home in flames.

OLYMPIA, Washington Territory, Dec. 16.--This morning, at Long Prairie, about eight miles from this place, a deplorable event occurred, news of which was received here tonight. Mrs. Miner, a relative of Mr. David Chambers, has for some time manifested symptoms of...

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Dec. 16.--The Rev. D.D. Gillespie, of this village, is the possessor of an Alderney cow that since April 6 up to Nov. 1, 1885, made 302 pounds of butter. This is remarkable. As near as can be ascertained it is the largest amount of butter made by any one cow, for the same period of time, on record.

The arrival here of S. Wolf, the President of the local branch of the Cigarmakers' International Union in San Francisco, in Search of union workmen for that city has caused a good deal of excitement among tobacconists, and many cigarmakers are preparing to leave the East for the Pacific slope, where higher wages than they get here are promised them.

Under Sheriff Aarons said yesterday in regard to the levy upon the Western Union Telegraph Company that Mr. Goodwin, of the law firm of Vanderpoel, Green Cuming had visited the Sheriff's office during the day, and represented...
The Plain Dealer coined and published a story to the effect that during the war the editor of the Leader fled to Europe in order to escape the draft.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16.--The principal barbed wire manufacturers of the United States met here to-day and agreed to advance the price on all grades of their product cent a pound, such schedule of prices to take effect at once and continue in force until Jan. 14. It is probable that on that date another advance will be made to meet anticipated advance in the price of plain wire.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Dec. 16.--The Arkansas Telegraph Company to-day completed its new line between Littte Rock and this place, and opened the same in connection with the Baltimore and Ohio telegraph system.
Clinton H. Tucker, son of W.H. Tucker, of Newark, aged 15 years, fell out of his boat while rowing on the Passaic yesterday and was drowned. The body has not been recovered.
A stand of flowers stood on the platform of the Westminster Presbyterian Church, Firstplace and Clinton-street, Brooklyn, last evening, and in front were palms and tropical plants.
MONTREAL, Dec. 16.--Forty-one of the flint glass blowers employed at the North American Glass Works of W.D. Yuile Co., have been on strike for the past day or two.

Mr. GLADSTONE'S aggressive benevolence is so well known that there has been nothing improbable in the statement that he was at work on a measure intended to redress all the grievances of the Irish people.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 16--At the Harlem Syndicate meeting this afternoon the report of the Advisory Board was approved.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Dec. 16.--The Protestant Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of Easton was held here to-day, with the Rev. Dr. J.B. Barber, of Washington, D.C., as presiding officer. The convention was called for the purpose of electing a successor to the late Bishop Lay, Dr. G.W. Smith, of Trinity College, having declined. Seven ballots were taken, resulting in the election of the Rev. Dr. Chauncey B. Williams, of Augusta, Ga.

The seventh Thomas Popular matinee may be attended at the Academy of Music this afternoon. A solo for six kettledrums by Mr. G. Gordon Cleather and an oboe solo by M. Felix Bour are among the attractions of the programme.

The Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday received a protest from the Taxpayers' Association of the Tenth, Eleventh, and Seventeenth Wards against the construction of the proposed Quaker Bridge Dam. O.B. Potter also repeated his arguments against the dam.

Capt. Robert R. Drummond, the last of a line of veteran sea Captains, and one of the best known sailing masters in this port, died suddenly of heart disease on Monday night, at his residence in Brooklyn.

TORONTO, Dec. 16.--Oliver Leeming, an escaped convict from the House of Correction at Detroit, was to-day sentenced to four years in the Kingston Penitentiary on two charges of larceny. He has already served a term here for burglary. He beseeched the clemency of the court for the sake of his widowed mother in Detroit, but his pleading was in vain.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 16.--Judge Brown has granted an absolute divorce to James E. Brazee, of Middletown, from his wife, Maria E. Brazee, a young and beautiful woman.

In accordance with the recommendation of the Executive Committee of the trunk lines the Passenger Committee yesterday issued instructions to the various roads forbidding the payment of commissions by or to ticket agents on and after Jan. 1.

RICHMOND, Mo., Dec. 16.--David Whitmer, one of the founders of the Mormon Church, and a resident of this quaint and interesting village for almost a half century, lies at the point of death, and is not expected to live until morning.

William Sohn, Frank Fox, William Manning, and William Can entered the lager beer saloon of Adolph Kruger, at No. 815 Tenth-avenue, on the evening of Nov. 30. The bartender, Frank Kruger, served them with some beer. They said it was stale, and demanded that a new keg be tapped.

OTTAWA, Dec. 16.--Daniel Ardell, aged 20 years, is now being tried here for the murder of Constable Flatters. Flatters was trying to arrest Ardell on a charge of assault and robbery when the latter shot him. A number of persons witnessed the affair. The evidence against the prisoner is very strong.
The following is the statement of the earnings, operating expenses, , of the NewYork Central and Hudson River Railroad Company for the quarter ending Sept. 30:
CHICAGO, Dec. 16.--All the brewers of Chicago and Milwaukee were represented at a private meeting held here to-day to discuss the question of a reduction in the wholesale price of beer.

In direct defiance of the peremptory writ of mandamus served upon the Mayor and Common Council of Rahway, N.J., a majority of the latter on Tuesday night decided to take action that is likely to bring upon them serious consequences.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 16.--The Casinos of Poughkeepsie beat the Crosby Polo Club of Yonkers three straight goals to-night, Time--0:40; 1:00; 1:20.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 16.--Gov. Robinson to-day granted a requisition to Pennsylvania officers to remove Winfield Scott Hayes, who is charged with horse stealing at Lancaster, Penn., May 21, 1884. Hayes is in Charles-Street Jail on the general complaint of being a fugitive from justice.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 16.--The Rev. Father Coyle, Pastor of St. Joseph's Church in this city, to-day forwarded to Rev. Father Reilly, D.D., Treasurer of the Nationalist Fund, a draft for $1,000, the amount subscribed at a meeting held to aid the Parliamentary fund.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 16.--One of the most startling plots for the wholesale assassination of the most prominent men in this city came to light last night. Some time ago the police obtained information of the existence of an organization called the "Socialistic Revolutionary Association," which, it was asserted, was composed of ultra-Socialists.

MONTREAL, Dec. 16.--The management of the Victoria Medical School, after considering the application for reinstatement presented by the students, all of whom left the school because of the expulsion of four of their number, has decided to permit the students, with one exception, to resume their studies.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 16.--Ex-Mayor Thomas J. Stephens and Gustave Tafel have been appointed Trustees to succeed J.B. Mannix, Assignee of the Purcell estate, who has resigned. This action was taken upon the petition of a large number of creditors. The bond of the Trustees is fixed at $600,000. They have accepted the trust.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 16.--One of the worst crimes ever committed in this State, which was followed by swift retribution, is reported from Putnam County.
DETROIT, Dec. 16.--A little hamlet adjacent to Woodmere Cemetery, about three miles below this city, was the scene of a shocking calamity this morning about 2 o'clock.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 16.--A fire broke out in S.B. Hubbard's warehouse on the dock about 10 o'clock to-night and communicated to the store in front, reaching through to Bay-street. The Fire Department has the flames under control, but the adjoining stores are still in danger. It is still impossible as yet to even estimate the loss.

RANGOON, Dec. 16.--Eleven Europeans who were working for the Bombay and Burmah Trading Company and employed in the Chindwin forest, on learning of the rupture between Burmah and the Indian Government, tried to...
NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 16.--A French Canadian named Lebaugh, 58 years of age, employed in a brick yard at Dutchess Junction, last night cut his throat with a razor, completely severing the windpipe.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16.--The compulsory attendance of the students at Harvard College at daily morning prayers has long been a mooted question.
OTTOWA, Dec. 16.--The trial of Louis Dupel for the murder of Patrick Burke was concluded at Aylmer yesterday, the jury returning a verdict of justifiable homicide.

Had the German actor Herr Friedrich Mitterwurzer played during his engagement here a series of roles similar to that of Dr. Wespe, which he assumed in Benedix's comedy of that name at the Thalia Theatre last night, his success both from an artistic and pecuniary standpoint would have been immeasurably greater than it has proved.

A party of gentlemen, assembled at the firing point of the rifle range in the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon, held their hands over their ears while Mr. William Trabue blazed away at the target with his improved magazine rifle.

The ship John Harvey, Capt. Stewart which arrived yesterday from Colombo, brought the crew of the three-masted schooner James T. Morse, which was abandoned in a dismasted and waterlogged condition on Dec. l2 about 250 miles east northeast of Cape Hatteras.

Charles Kaufman, of Franklin Township, N.J., sailed yesterday for France on the steamship Labrador in order to be treated by Pasteur for a bite received from a mad dog on Nov. 21. At least 35 days will have elapsed since the man was bitten before he will be in the hands of Pasteur.
Alderman Jaehne yesterday told Mayor Grace of a curious experience which one of his constituents had had with Excise Inspector Striker.

At a meeting of the Central Labor Union last evening, the German printers of Typographical Union No. 7 reported that they had been unable to make any settlement with the proprietors of the German newspapers, the New-Yorker Zeitung and the Herold.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 16.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day a bill was introduced to establish an import duty on foreign cattle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16.--Another entire day has been consumed by the House in discussion of the report of the Committee on Rules, and it seems probable that the speechmaking will last all day to-morrow and possibly through Friday.

The examination of James Hamel and J. J. Lacneguier, who were arrested for passing counterfeit coins on Bleecker-street cars on Saturday night came up yesterday before United States Commissioner Shields.

An advertisement appeared yesterday requesting the lady who took a male child for adoption from Mrs. Sietz, of East Fifty-thirdstreet, last February, to send her address to M. T. Sharkey, counselor-at-law, No. 335 Broadway.

LEADVILLE, Col., Dec. 16.--The miners are greatly excited over an extensive strike of ore on Carbonate Hill. It is of a grade valued at $20 per ton, and the supply is one of the largest yet found. It is said that ex-Senators Chaffee, James G. Blaine, and Tabor, J.C. Wilson, and D.H. Moffatt are the persons interested in the property.
Jake Walleon, a young boy, was stabbed in the left breast on Tuesday night on Pamrapoavenue, Greenville, N.J., by Antoine Vogel, a crazy fanatic, receiving a wound which may prove fatal.
The trial of the suit instituted by Robert C. Plume against Thomas Potter, a wealthy Jersey City contractor, was begun in Judge Knapp's court room, on Jersey City Heights, yesterday morning.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 16.--Police Officer Dennis Smith was acquitted to-night of the murder of Henry Klein, whom he shot Aug. 29 last while attempting his arrest. When the verdict was announced a shout of joy went up from nearly all of the 500 persons present.
Some days before the opening of the present session of Congress it was announced that a protest against the seating of the Hon. BARCLAY HENLEY would be filed in the House of Representatives.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 16.--A cable message was received to-day at Harvard College Observatory from Lord Crawford, in Aberdeen, Scotland, announcing the discovery of a new star by J.E. Gore, an English astronomer, on...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16.--The following telegram from Gen. Crook, dated Fort Bowie, Dec. 14, and forwarded from Presidio of San Francisco, Cal., by Gen. Pope, has been received at the War Department:

A petition was presented at the meeting of the Board of Park Commissioners yesterday, signed by about 400 property owners in the vicinity of Central Park in, favor of permitting the Madison-Avenue Railroad Company to extend its road through the transverse road of the park at Eighty-sixth-street to Riverside Drive.
JOLIET, Ill., Dec. 16.--Sheriff McGarigle, of Cheyenne, Wyoming Territory, reached this city yesterday, having in charge seven Territorial convicts for the Joliet Prison.
FARGO, Dakota, Dec. 16.--In opening a car of wheat that reached Duluth from Fargo a few days ago the body of a man, bloody and mangled, was found, and in a secret pocket was $475 in bills.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16.--At an early hour this morning a party of 10 men left the Continental Hotel, and, entering carriages, were driven rapidly to the foot of Norris-street, where the William Cramp Son Ship and Engine Building Company have their office and principal ship yard.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16.--It is reported here that there is likely to be in the near future a complete rupture of the relations now existing between the Erie and the Chicago and Atlantic Railroads and a cessation of all interchange of business between them.

BOSTON, Dec. 16.--The Union Pacific statement of the financial operations of the company for the quarter ending Sept. 30, 1885, shows a total income of $3,360,255, and a total surplus income of $934,840, against $1,405,573 for the corresponding period of 1884.

Inspector Thomas J. Brady, of the Bureau of Buildings, was on trial before the Fire Commissioners yesterday, charged with neglecting to report the construction of a wooden fence at One Hundred and Fourth-street and First-avenue, the erection of a frame shed near the same place and in the rear of a building at One Hundred...

The sale of the collection of paintings of the late George Whitney, of Philadelphia, which has been on exhibition at the American Art Galleries since Dec. 8, was begun at Chickering Hall last evening under the management of the American Art Association.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 16.--A Huron (Dakota) special to the Pioneer Press says: "The so-called Legislature yesterday elected Judge Moody and Edgerton United States Senators for the State of South Dakota."

WASHINGTON Dec. 16.--The Hon. A. Boynton, a member of the Democratic Territorial Committee of Dakota, and selected by that body to visit Washington and represent their wishes, had an interview with President...
Funeral services were held over the remains of Mrs. Evelina Shepard Day yesterday morning, at No. 55 East Twenty-fifth-street, and the body was interred at Woodlawn.

It is very difficult to persuade many people that the Creator really did know how to make a horse, and that Divine handiwork cannot very well be improved by man," for to tamper with a horse and to subject him to many unnecessary annoyances is exactly what most of us are always trying to do.

It was members' reception day at the New-York Studio of the Ladies' Art Association, at No. 4 West Fourteenth-street, yesterday, and the rooms were thronged in the afternoon between the hours of 2 and 5 o'clock by members and patrons of the organization.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 16.--A meeting of natives of New-England was held last night to make arrangements for a proper observance of Forefathers' Day at the American Exposition on the 22d inst.

A special committee of the Paterson (N.J.) Board of Trade appointed to find out why manufacturers are leaving that place has reported that the manufacturers are not leaving in any numbers, and that the few who have gone are...
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16.--In the Supreme Court of the United States to-day the following business was transacted; No. 96--The Southwestern Railroad...

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 16.--The Constitution publishes an interview held with Gen. Toombs on his last visit to Atlanta, when his attention was called to the magazine discussion of the "Freedman's Case in Equity" and other articles, and his opinion of the matter was asked.

DUBLIN, Dec. 16.--The trial of William, Sheehan and David Browne for the murder of Catherine, Thomas, and Hannah Sheehan, near Castletownroche, County Cork, eight years ago, was begun on Monday last. The case had been postponed from the Assizes.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Dec. 16.--John B. Mueller, proprietor of a marble yard, attempted suicide to-day in a most extraordinary manner. He was alone in his shop at the time. He drove two stone chisels into his head, one of them going entirely through and protruding upon the other side.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 16.--There was lively bidding at the State tax sale to-day for a parcel of land in Oxbow tract, Hamilton County, containing 320 acres. The taxes, interest, , were $154. The amount cannot be increased under the terms of the sale, but the...

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 16.--John E. Doubleday, aged 63, was struck and killed by an Erie short-cut railroad train this morning at Mountainville. The deceased man was on his way to the station to catch the train which killed him.

Joshua Brierly, an undertaker of Newark, was arrested Tuesday night on complaint of John W. Wells and held in $1,000 bail for trial. Wells claims $5,000 damages on the ground that Brierly has alienated his wife's affections, broken up his family, and destroyed his once happy home.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16.--The President sent to the Senate to-day a large number of nominations of officers appointed during the Congressional recess, but among the number were two new ones, namely, those or the Hon. John Bigelow to be Assistant Treasurer at NewYork and Gen. Franz Sigel to be Pension Agent at New-York.
J. Bleecker Miller read a paper on "Trade and Professional Organizations in Public Affairs" before the Constitution Club, at its rooms, No. 64 Madison-avenue, last evening.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 16.--The State Dairymen's Association held crowded sessions to-day. In the afternoon Gen. E.F. Jones, Lieutenant-Governor-elect, lectured on weights and measures. State Dairy Commissioner Brown, of Albany; B.D. Gilbert, of the Utica Herald, and Prof. Caldwell, of Cornell University, read papers. This evening Gen. Jones addressed a Grand Army fair. The Dairymen's Association closes to-morrow.

It is now decided that the engagement of Miss Margaret Mather in this city shall last until the middle of February. She will play in "Romeo and Juliet" past its hundredth performance, and will then put on "Leah" for four weeks.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 16.--The natural gas problem for Ohio is as yet unsolved. Indications of it are found in some localities, but whether they are the signs of small pockets or of a vast reservior has not yet been decided.

Before sitting down to its annual dinner last night the Medico-Legal Society elected new officers. So many votes were sent by proxy and the tickets were so badly scratched that it was nearly 10:30 o'clock before the tellers finished counting the ballots.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 16.--One of the men, named Beach, who robbed the dry goods store of Westbrook Stoll, of Port Jervis, of $2,000 worth of goods on Monday night, was arrested to-day at Paterson.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 16.--S.W. Tallmadge, of this city, has received from Horace Davis, a statistician of San Francisco, a final report of the wheat yield in that State. The report says: "The crop has yielded nothing like the amount predicted during the Summer.

MONT MOOR, N.Y., Dec. 16.--This place is in a commotion over a bold attempt at burglary made near here at an early hour on Monday morning, in the West Shore Hotel, a public house, kept by ex-Sheriff Charles B. Benson, close to the track of the West Shore Railroad.
There were more vacant seats and fewer persons standing in the passageways of Trinity Church yesterday than at any time since the Rev. Mr. Aitken began to preach noonday sermons there.

The Rev. Antonio Arrighi, the story of whose daughter Aimee's departure from the Pittsburg Female College was related in THE TIMES of yesterday, states that the telegram from Pittsburg giving the alleged facts is altogether incorrect.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 16.--For 19 years the Post Office here has been conducted by the present incumbent or her late husband. When Garret G. Van Dien died little more than a year ago his widow was appointed his successor by the unanimous petition of the populace.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16.--Ex-Senator S. R. Peale, of Lock Haven, General Solicitor of the Beech Creek Railroad Company, and a member of the Board of Directors, was in this city this evening.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 16.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Virginia Midland Railway was held at the office of the company in this city to-day at noon, the Hon. J.S. Barbour in the chair.

ERIE, Penn., Dec. 16.--Papers were filed in the Recorder's office to-day relating to a vast fortune bequeathed to Lorenzo Endy by German relative in Saxony. Endy is a resident of Corry, and is to build a theatre, a free church, and found a national bank.

A meeting of the Anti-Monopoly League was held last evening at the Metropolitan Hotel, to discuss the silver question. Edwards Pierrepont presided, and the room was uncomfortably crowded with gentlemen interested in the subject and one lady.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 16.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.
The convention of the Seventeenth District of Good Templars, comprising all the counties on Long Island, was held yesterday in the Presbyterian church at Freeport.

Charles D. Kellegg, Organizing Secretary of the Charity Organization Society, makes an explanation of the arrest of Thomas Michelmore for vagrancy, as published in THE TIMES of Wednesday, which places the prisoner in the light of an impostor and fraud.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 16.--At the annual meeting of the Boston Baseball Association there was a stormy time, caused by the smaller stockholders, who demanded an accounting of the moneys of the association, it being claimed that President Soden and two others who own a majority of the stock had made no report of the...

A movement having for its object the removal from office of Edward L. Hedden, Collector of the Port of New-York, has just been set on foot by the Veterans' Rights Union of the State of New-York. On Monday, Thomas B. Odell, Chairman of the General Committee...
In November, 1884, the Chicago and Atlantic Railway Company defaulted in the payment of the interest then due on its first mortgage bonds.
