OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 16.--It was learned at a late hour last night that orders have been issued from military headquarters, Department of the Platte, rescinding those of Friday, Dec. 4.

The death of Capt. Hugh J. Golden, Foreman of Engine Company No. 52, which occurred at the quarters of the company at Riverdale, was reported at the headquarters of the Fire Department yesterday afternoon.

Miss Freda Runga, a young German woman who lives with her aunt, Mrs. Abt, at No. 82 North Eighth-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, called at Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning to learn the name of the doctor and the...

O'Leary and Weston continued their weary tramp yesterday at Plainfield, N.J. Weston was stiff when he started this morning, but it seemed to wear off as he warmed to his work. The score at 10:30 last evening was: O'Leary, 426 miles: Weston, 417 miles.

A reception was given Alderman-elect P.F. Ferrigan by the Harlem Democratic Club last evening. Some 200 gentlemen, many of them noted in local political circles, gathered in the spacious parlors of the clubhouse at No. 59 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street.

The proposition to repeal the Tenure of Office act is of itself sufficiently significant. The repeal of the act would be one of the most marked advances toward sound government and away from the narrow and often demoralizing practices of the period immediately succeeding the close of the war that has been taken since that time.
The subscriptions to the Grant Monument fund yesterday amounted to $50. Hugh N. Camp and H.H. Cammann contributed $25 each. The fund is now $111,056.17.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 16.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following causes were argued; No. 872--The People ex rel. Harvey M. Munsell, respondents, vs...

Patrick Fitzpatrick sued Allan Campbell, former Controller of the city, and Thomas F. Devoe, formerly the Superintendent of Markets, for $30,000 damages. He asserted that they had wrongfully conspired to destroy his business.

LIMA, Ohio, Dec. 16.--E.L. Kessler, who murdered his comrade, Lex Harner, by shooting him while they walked together near New-Era, Ind., Monday, was arrested last night near Gomer, this county. He admitted the crime, but says he was disappointed in getting but $6 and a watch and chain. It is alleged that Harner had several hundred dollars in his possession when killed.

As Silas Albertson, a farmer, was passing the residence of Mrs. John Firth, in the town of North Hempstead, Long Island, at about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, he heard cries for help, and running to the house found Mrs. Firth, who is 72 years old, lying on the sitting room floor, bound hand and foot.

Dealers in tobacco read yesterday with much regret a telegram in THE TIMES announcing the death in Cuba of Julian Alvarez. The deceased was known throughout the world of smokers as the manufacturer of the popular "Henry Clay" brand of cigars.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Dec. 16.--The liabilities of James McCarthy, who failed yesterday, will probably exceed $100,000. Prior to the assignment made this morning $45,000 in judgments were filed against him.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 16.--The bark Veronica, of New-Bedford, 409 tons, was lost yesterday on the coast of Madeira. It is supposed she had not much freight on board. The crew were saved. She was built in 1878 and had been employed in freight and passenger business between here and Western Islands and Madeira. She last sailed from New-Bedford Nov. 4. She was valued at $20,000 and insured for $14,000.

A resolution was offered in the Senate yesterday directing the Committee on Territories to inquire and report by what authority a so-called Legislature has been organized in the Territory of Dakota, and whether such organization is not calculated to bring about a conflict of authority prejudicial to good order.
Miss Caroline Rees Seward, a daughter of Mr. Clarence A. Seward, was married yesterday afternoon to Mr. Robert Endicott.

Superintendent Murray on the 12th inst. received a telegram from Chief of Police Stewart, of Philadelphia, asking that search be made in this city for William C. Gatzmer, a man of considerable wealth, who had escaped from a private sanitarium at Tacony, near Philadelphia, and was supposed to have come to this city.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 16.--This village has gone wild over a clairvoyant and fortune teller who recently took rooms at one of the leading hotels here.

An autopsy was made yesterday of the dog that bit Veterinary surgeon L.W. Sattler, in Newark, last Saturday. Prof. Nelson, of this city, and Drs. Herold, Lehlbach, Leemacher, and Guenther, of Newark, conducted the operation. Unmistakable signs of rabies were found. On learning this fact Dr. Sattler expressed a determination to go to Paris for treatment by Pasteur. He will sail by the Trench Line on Saturday.

Thomas St. John Gaffney, a typical dude, who says that he is a law student and boards at No. 42 Irving-place, was the complainant before the Police Commissioners yesterday against Patrolman Patrick Prendergast, of the Grand Central Station squad.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 16.--At the National Convention of Coal Operators and Miners to-day President McBride, of the Ohio Miners' Association, submitted the scale adopted by the Miners' Committee last night.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 16.--Sunday night last Marshals Chapman and McCorkle left this city for the point on Lookout Mountain, where United States Marshal Kellett was murdered by moonshiners.

SOFIA, Dec. 16.--Bulgaria has accepted the proposal of the powers for an international commission of demarcation for the BulgaroServian frontier under certain reservations. She wishes the commission to consider fairly the recent victories of the Bulgarian Army.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Dec. 16.--Joshua Troup, a wealthy farmer living in the Clear Spring district of Washington County, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself through the head with a pistol. Religious excitement is said to have unsettled his mind.
The report that the steamship City of Mexico had been held by the Custom House authorities, on the ground that she was about to start out on a filibustering expedition, proves to be untrue.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 17.--A fatal accident caused by fire occurred at the residence of Mrs. Baker, on Laclede-avenue, yesterday.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 17.--The Grant Eulogy Committee has procured a gold watch, costing $215, with chain to match, which is to be carried to Brooklyn by Councilman Emmons and presented to the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, to take the place of the watch recently stolen from him.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17.--In the City Court this morning Kate Doughan was sentenced to pay a light fine for a breach of the peace.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17.--Henry Cook, a fruit dealer, of No. 157 Goffe-street, this city, was attacked by highwaymen to-night on the Cheshire road.

Francis W. Savin is at the head of the stock brokerage firm of Savin Vanderhoof, of No. 26 New-street, and yesterday he was in trouble. About 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon Collis Levy sent to him, for delivery, 1,100 shares of Northern Pacific preferred stock, and Mr. Savin refused to accept it.

Those who knew Marshal Serrano best declare that he never showed his age, great as it was, until a comparatively short time-ago, when the scandalous statements published by several Republican papers in Spain apropos of his eldest son's marriage had the effect of breaking his health suddenly. From the blow thus received, indeed, he never recovered, and his astonishing energy at length wholly deserted him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--In the Supreme Court of the United States to-day the following business was transacted. No. 106--The County of San Mateo, plaintiff in error, vs. The Southern Pacific Railroad Company.--Motion to dismiss submitted by John W. Ross in support of motion and by A.L. Rhoads in opposition thereto.
The creation of the State of Ireland, sustaining a loosely federal relation to its sister island, seems to be the most probable outcome of Mr. PARNELL'S victory.
People of Orange, N.J., are excited over a romantic marriage and a predicted alternative for the groom of a suit for breach of promise or a horsewhipping.
The scheme of Capt. JAMES B. EADS for constructing a railway across the Isthmus of Tehuantepec over which loaded ships may be taken from one ocean to the other can be regarded only as an experiment.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 17.--Secretary of State-elect Frederick Cook, of this city, to-day tendered the Deputy Secretaryship to Diedrich Willer, Jr., of Seneca County, a former Secretary of State, and the latter accepted the office. All the other appointments in the department must be made under the civil service law.

The Board of Trade of the town of NewLots, or East New-York, as it is generally called, celebrated the completion of the Brooklyn Ele vated Railroad in an expansive manner yesterday afternoon and last night.
I had a lengthy and somewhat remarkable interview to-day with King Theebaw. Along with him were the Queen Soopyalat, her sister, the Queen mother, widow of the late King, and Theebaw's sister.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--Acting Assistant Surgeon W.F. Peabody, now in San Francisco, has been ordered to report to the commanding General, Department of California, for assignment to duty as Attending Surgeon in San Francisco.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--The resignation of the Hon. Barton C. Cook, General Solicitor for the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad Company for 14 years, has been tendered, to take effect at the New Year.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 17.--In pursuance to a call issued by the Republican State Central Committee a gathering of more than 100 prominent and representative members of the party, from all parts of the State, met here to-night to take the preliminary steps toward organizing for the campaign of 1886.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 17.--A general assignment by Arnold A. Levy Co., manufacturers of clothing, was filed to-day. Two law firms are preferred creditors for small amounts.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 17.--A fire which broke out yesterday in Hubbard's warehouses, in Bay-street, spread to the Abell Block, in which were the Herald newspaper, Hazen's billiard parlors, Kurtz Brothers,' and several others.

At the Thalia Theatre last evening Kneisel's new play, "Papageno," was given for the first time in this country. The author is an Austrian comedian of note, and his production bears the evidences of more than ordinary constructive skill.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 17.--The trial of Olaf Granquest for the murder of Asa Dunn, which was begun on Monday in the Middlesex County Court, closed to-day.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17.--An attempt was made to rob the savings bank and Post Office at Guilford last night.

"Is it not true," said Gen. TREMAIN yesterday to JOHN P. KENNEDY, President of the old Mutual Gaslight Company, "that the price of gas furnished to consumers is wholly dependent upon the amount of the dividends to be paid and the amount of capital stock on which the dividends are paid?" "That's the whole story in a nutshell," replied Mr. KENNEDY.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 17.--Henry Weisman, one of the four dynamiters arrested on Tuesday night, was released on $2,000 bail last evening.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 17.--The fire tragedy near Woodmere Cemetery, by which Frank Knoch, his wife, and two children lost their lives yesterday morning, now proves to have been a murder of the most appalling character.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 17.--The Iowa people in town and quite a large party of excursionists had an interesting gathering in Iowa's space at the Exposition today, the occasion being the laying of the cornerstone of a memorial arch...

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 17.--August Burke, John Nwenosky, Anton Delke, Peter Kriet, Peter Lusk, and Jack Grumse are said by the police to be the gang of youthful thieves who have recently been committing depredations on the north side.

Charles J. Everard was arraigned before Judge Gildersleeve in the Court of General Sessions yesterday charged with forging the name of the firm of Baltzer Lichtenstein to a draft on the German-American Bank for $500.

The first Assembly Ball was given last night at Delmonico's. The decorations were very simple, and were marked by a total absence of flowers. Ornamental plants, such as palms, laurels, , were banked in the corners of the halls and parlors, and the windows of the ballroom were hung with lace curtains and pale blue lambrequins.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 17.--It is authoritatively announced that the Albemarle and Raleigh Railroad has passed into the hands and ownership of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad Company, and after this will form a part of the Atlantic Coast Line.
MERIDEN, Conn., Dec. 17.--With reference to the ejection of the negro coachman, Lewis Phillips, from the skating rink here.
Christmas greens begin to be in moderately lively demand, but dealers generally believe that this demand will hardly equal that of previous years.
At Worship-Street Police Court recently Henry James Williams, 40, of Devonshire-place, Mile-end, was charged with stealing a watch, the property of a fellow-lodger in the same house.
A lively contest occurred in the First Ward of Brooklyn last evening over the election of members of the next Kings County Republican General Committee.

George S. Walsh, who shot Mrs. Laura M. Thorpe in the parlor of her residence, No. 206 West Twenty-first-street, on the night of March 28, 1884, yesterday pleaded guilty in the Court of General Sessions to assault in the second degree.

BOSTON, Dec. 17.--A well attended meeting of the Bowdoin-Square Society took place at the church this afternoon.
The Japanese Tea Party, in aid of the Diakonissen fund for the establishment of a training school for nurses, was opened yesterday afternoon at the residence of Mrs. Guernsey, No. 526 Fifth-avenue.

MONONGAHELA CITY, Penn., Dec. 17.--A convention of the river coal miners to consider the situation and advisability of continuing the strike is in session here.

The chapel of the Protestant Half-OrPhan Asylum, at No. 67 West Tenth-street, was well filled with friends of the institution last evening, the occasion being the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the asylum.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 17.--A sensation was created a few weeks ago by John O'Connor, a prominent lawyer, suing Bishop Ireland, of St. Paul, for $1,500 which he alleged the Bishop owed him and refused to pay.
The sale of the second third of the Whitney collection of paintings at Chickering Hall last evening was well attended.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 17.--The Rev. Arthur S. Hoyt, of Oregon, Ill., accepts the Chair of Logic, Rhetoric, and Elocution in Hamilton College, to which he was recently elected, and will enter upon his duties at the opening of the Winter term in January.
YANKTON, Dakota, Dec. 17.--The feeling throughout this district against the rulings of Commissioner Sparks continues intense, and if Congress does not reverse them the people will be heavy sufferers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--Justice Kistler issued an attachment to-day against Manager Hooley, ordering the seizure of whatever money may be due Lillian Russell, the actress, and her husband, Mr. Solomon, as their share of the receipts of his theatre this week.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec 6.--A visit to the State Library in the new Capitol is rewarded now with an opportunity to inspect one of the finest collection of autographs in the United States.

PARIS, Dec. 17.--A sensation was caused here to-day by the collapse of a portion of the Pont Neuf, which connects the Ile de la Cite, on which is situated the Cathedral Church of Notre Dame, with both sides of the river Seine.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 17.--The Louisvilles and New-Yorks played the finest game of baseball seen here this season to-day.

CAMDEN, Me., Dec. 17.--The body of Rufus Carle, who died in Bellevue Hospital, NewYork, last week after having been taken to that institution in a starving condition, reached Camden for burial yesterday.

NYACK, Dec. 17.--The Rockland County Industrial Association--the new and most prosperous agricultural and horticultural society in the county--has decided to hold its next annual fair on Sept. 28, 29, and 30, 1886, and has elected the following officers for the coming year:
Recognition services were tendered to the Rev. Dr. W.C.P. Rhoades, the new pastor of the Marcy-avenue Baptist Church, in Brooklyn, last evening.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--A man with his face bandaged climbed on a west-bound car at Madison and Lasalle streets this afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 17.--The property of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company in Maryland was sold at auction in this city to-day. It included all the wires, poles, and other effects within the limits of the State.

HAZLETON, Penn., Dec. 17.--While John Misko was feeding a pair of rollers at the Derringer coal breaker to-day he lost his balance and fell between the rollers, and before they could be stopped his whole body was drawn through them and crushed to a jelly.

William Gatzmer, the insane son of the Philadelphia millionaire, who was taken to Bellevue Hospital on Wednesday, was taken home to Philadelphia yesterday. He was quiet and obedient to his nurse. HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 17.--The steamer George Shattuck, which left here on Friday last for Anticosti to endeavor to get off the crew of the wrecked steamer Earl Dufferin, returned to-day, having failed to reach the island. READING, Penn., Dec. 20.--Harry Kerlin, aged 13, was struck by a coal car in front of his home in Auburn and almost instantly killed yesterday afternoon. He was playing with a companion around the siding, when from some cause the cars were moved, one of them striking him down and causing fatal internal injuries.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Dec. 20.--A man, believed from papers found on his person to be L.S. Kempell, was arrested last night on the outskirts of the city. He says he is enroute to Washington to kill Cleveland in order to rid the country of Democrats. He was heavily armed and had considerable money. Kempell is believed to be from Sidney, Neb.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 20.--A Charleston, Kanawha County, special says a fatal shooting affray occurred on Friday evening at Eagle, a small town about 20 miles from there.

Mayor Chamberlain and a committee of the Board of Councilmen of Detroit, who were appointed to inspect the new electric railway in this city, are at the Hoffman House. They will return home on Wednesday.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Dec. 20.--On the 10th of December the Camden Consolidated Oil Company, of this city, was advised by the Bank of California that it held for collection a draft on them for $21,435 50, which they had discounted.
There was no unusual excitement at Elizabeth, N.J., yesterday, but the one theme of conversation was the lockout of the Singer sewing machine employes.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 20.--Another day has passed, and the 26 men imprisoned in the mine at Nanticoke have not been rescued.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec, 20.--J.O. Weaver, senior member of the Weaver Organ Manufacturing Company, York, Penn., who became violently deranged here about a week ago, committed suicide yesterday in his room at the St. George's Hotel by cutting his throat from ear to ear.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 20.--A committee of cigar manufacturers from San Francisco is here selecting a corps of cigarmakers, and has secured 200 names to contracts to go there and displace Chinese labor. The party will start about Jan. 1.

EMPORIA, Kan., Dec. 20.--The facts surrounding the death of J. Walkup, of this city, and the subsequent trial of his young widow on the charge of poisoning him, are still fresh in the minds of the public.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--Since the present Session of Congress began 728 bills and Joint resolutious have been introduced in the Senate, and seven, one of which originated in the House, have been passed by that body.

Joseph Schwarzler, a German builder, of Fifth-avenue and Eighty-eighth-street, hasn't as high an opinion of the park policemen as he had before Saturday night. This is the way his change of opinion came about. For several weeks he has been engaged in the construction of a row of houses on the west side.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 20.--The jail at Gurleysville, Ala., 15 miles east of Huntsville, was set on fire at daylight this morning by unknown parties and burned. A man named Phillips, who had been arrested last night and locked up for being drunk, perished in the flames.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20.--The Times will to-morrow print a strange story of the death of George W. Kelpin, a boss painter, of No. 526 North Fifth-street, who died at 6:40 o'clock this morning. Mr. Kelpin had been sick off and on for the past six months.
At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the west side furniture and carpet salesmen said that their employers had promised to close their stores early after the opening of the new year.
Mr. Gus Williams will be seen this week at the Grand Opera House as Major Pottgeiser in Mr. Geand Hoey's play with the following singular title. "Oh, What a Night!"

Robert Bigelow, of No. 119 Chrystiestreet, was before Justice Duffy, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, on a charge of thrashing John Hayes and Thomas Shaw, bakers, of No. 41 Cherry-street, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 20.--George Duhamel, advocate, a French Conservative who has Joined the National Party, delivered a lecture before the Catholic Union this afternoon on "Future Canadian Nationality."

TREATED BY TELEGRAPH. KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 20.--Miss Ora Misner, aged 21 years, daughter of George Misner, a well known farmer residing at Big Indian, a small hamlet a few miles from here took an ounce of laudanum at 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

The convention of the National Guard Association which has just been held in Washington had for its main object the furthering of that legislation by Congress which has been so often promised and as often postponed.

ALBANY, Dec. 20.--Examinations of all of the trust, loan, and mortgage companies of the State have been completed during the present month by direction of Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine, in accordance with the requirements of chapter 824, Laws of 1874.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 20.--Mail advices from Pendleton County say that an epidemic of diphtheria in that sparsely settled district along the Virginia line has caused 60 deaths. The disease is still raging.

Burglars entered the tailor shop of Fisher Finkelstein, No. 97 Prince-street, Newark, at about 5 o'clock yesterday morning, and after poisoning a valuable dogs stole 60 coats. The goods were afterward discovered in some woods on the outskirts of the city by boys. They were turned over to the police.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20.--The National Baseball Club, of ibis city was last Friday formally admitted to membership in the National League. The committee appointed in November to fill vacancies in the National League membership agreed to take the National Club into the fold, and so informed the President and Treasurer of the Nationals.
WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 20.--Five converts to Second Adventism were immersed in the chilly waters of the Naugatuck River at Waterbury to-day.

Exceeding great grief pervaded the ranks of the bookmakers yesterday. A pall of gloom settled over the countenances of those who on Saturday sold pools on the New-Orleans races, and some there were who declared that their confidence in human nature had been cruelly betrayed.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 20.--Judge Brown has granted aa absolute divorce to Mary Catharine Van Amburgh from her husband, Lewis Van Amburgh.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 20.--Lord Dundas arrived here from the South to-day. When here three months ago this young Scotch nobleman cut quite a dash.

The spectacle of the Senators of the United States greeting with derisive laughter and cheap jests a bill punishing office brokerage by fine is not an edifying one. Every Senator, by the direct provision of the Constitutions is made a judge of nominations from the President and is required to decide whether he will advise and consent to them.
The Rev. Dr. Emanuel Greenwald, Pastor of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, at Lancaster, Penn., died at his home in that city yesterday morning.

NANTICOKE, Penn., Dec. 22--Two A.M.-- The fate of the imprisoned men at No. 1 Slope seems now to have been practically determined by the extensive cave-in that occurred last evening at 9 o'clock and drove the force of rescuers before it in a wild and terrible flight for their lives.
NYACK, Dec. 21.--Franklin Weed, who is well known throughout the western portion of Nyack and in Clarkstown, is missing from his home and no clue to his whereabouts has yet been ascertained.
The Christmas exercises of the De La Salle Literary and Musical Union were held in the hall of Manhattan College yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--Maurice Vignaux and George Slosson began to-night the series of tie games to settle the billiard tournament played here a few weeks ago, and Slosson won the first game of the series, scoring his 800 points in 49 innings, stretching over just five hours.

The impression that Quincy, Ill., is a thriftless town is not warranted by the record reported to have been made by one of her favored sons, Oliver P. Burger, a clerk in the Post Office Department at Washington.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 21.--Daniel Ardell, who was tried at Aylmer for the murder of Constable Flatters and found guilty of manslaughter, was to-day sentenced to 14 years' im prisonment in the penitentiary with hard labor. Judge McDougall, in passing sentence, said that the jury should have returned a verdict of murder. Ardell is only 20 years old.
The Grant Monument Association received $7 yesterday from the Methodist Episcopal Church at Rockville Centre, Long Island. The fund is now $111,205.41.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 21.--The New-York Central Railroad has begun civil action against Philo M.L. Shepard, its former cashier in Buffalo, who absconded, was found after a long search in Florida, and brought to Buffalo charged with embezzling $26,000, and admitted to $5,000 bail.
Adolph Belot's dramatization of Alphonse Daudet's "Sappho" was produced in Paris last Friday night. Mlle. Jane Hading in the principal role achieved brilliant success.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 21.--The b.c. Tom Martin, 4 years old, by Longfellow, dam Athalaric, by Gilroy, was purchased to-day by the Dwyer brothers, of Brooklyn, N.Y., from the P. C. Fox estate, Danville, Ky., for $4,500. He has won a number of races during this and last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--Visitors to the Senate to-day were treated to the rather unusual exhibition of a bitter attack on the President and Secretary of the Treasury by a Senator belonging to the same political party as those officers.

It was announced at last night's meeting of the Irish Parliamentary Association in the Hoffman House, that word had been received from Mr. Parnell that, if urgent public affairs on the other side would permit of his attending the Irish convention in Chicago, he would give due notice of his coming over to Eugene Kelly. Mayor Grace was present at the meeting.

PARIS, Dec. 21.--The steamship Canada, which sailed from New-York on Dec. 9 for Havre, having on board Patrick Reynolds, Willie Lane, Patrick Ryan, and Austin Fitzgerald, the Newark boys who had been bitten by a mad dog, arrived off Havre last night, but was unable to enter the harbor until this morning.

DELAWARE, Ontario, Dec. 21.--The schools have been closed on account of the prevalence of diphtheria, and the Sunday school entertainments which were to have been held about Christmas time have been indefinitely postponed.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 21.--Henry Meyer, of Monroe Village, this county, had to kill one of his horses the other day because of an injury it had received.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--The Chicago committee of east-bound passenger traffic sadly concluded, at its meeting to-day, that under the circumstances there was not much use trying to carry out any more agreements regulating east-bound passenger business.

FOREST, Ontario, Dec. 21.--George William Roberts, a Cherokee Indian educated by the United States Government, visited the Indian tribes of this vicinity last week, representing himself to be an agent of the United States Government with authority to settle Indians in the States. It is said he swindled about 200 Indians.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 21.--Gov. Hill returned from New-York at 10 o'clock, and brought a nearly completed list of his staff with him.

Surrogate Rollins listened yesterday to counsel interested in the proceedings instituted by Evan J. Henry to obtain the revocation of the will of his son, James Griffiths Henry, who left the greater portion of an estate of $100,000 to his wife.

It was "sluggers," night at two of the combination theatres last evening. John L. Sullivan, Boston's cultured bruiser, and William Muldoon, a magnificent specimen of physical strength, and who specially prides himself on being the champion Graeco-Roman wrestler, posed for the entertainment of the eastsiders at the Third-Avenue Theatre.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--According to the allegations of the prosecution in the case of the State against Robert Hertel, for fraud and conspiracy, Hertel, in September last, obtained from the Illinois Trust and Savings Bank a loan of $3,000 on property which he did not own.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 21.--The question of adopting a standard target for American riflemen, which has been under discussion by the clubs of this country for many months, was settled to-day and announced from the office of the Rifle, where the votes of the clubs have been received.

Mr. GEORGE Z. ERWIN, of St. Lawrence County, has been for several weeks engaged in an effort to secure pledges from Republican members-elect of the Assembly to support him as a candidate for the Speakership of that body.

Jay Gould ordered his yacht to sail for Charleston yesterday, where, he tells his intimates, he expects to join her for his much advertised Southern cruise. He says he will start for Charleston by rail before New Year's Day.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 21.--The annual meeting of the Yale Alumni Association, of this city, was held this evening.

The suit of the city against John Roach and the estate of the late George Law to recover possession of lands under water at the foot of East Tenth-street is on trial before Judge Van Vorst, in the Supreme Court.

Jose F. De Navarro's office, at No. 71 Broadway, was occupied yesterday by stockholders of the Commercial Warehouse Company, an enterprise that has been out of business for two or three years past because of its bankruptcy.

John Swinton talked to a number of the clergymen of the Reformed Church at their meeting in the Board of Publication rooms yesterday about their duty toward the great class known popularly as "workingmen."
Max Ressler, a buttonhole manufacturer, was a prisoner in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday, and Joseph Blum, of No. 136 Orchardstreet, charged him with felonious assault.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., Dec. 21.--The two hundred and sixty-fifth anniversary of the landing of the Forefathers was observed here by the Pilgrim Society to-day.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 21.--A movement is on foot to re-establish pooling arrangements among the roads west of the Western termini of the trunk lines.
The stage at Harrigan's Park Theatre last evening extended for most of the time clear through the auditorium and away out beyond the lobby.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 21.--Ella Bigelow, aged 19 years, and Hartley Baysinger, aged 22 years, residents of Doylestown, Ohio, a small village near Akron, had been engaged to be married for the past two years.
Eight smallpox patients, a larger number than has been known before for three years, are at present in the Flatbush Hospital.
Workmen were kept busy all Sunday night and until after 4 o'clock yesterday morning splicing new strands into the cable that whirls the cars over the Brooklyn Bridge.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 21.--The schooner E. G. Irwin, Capt. S.H. Dodd, arrived here from New-York to-night with the dead body of a woman on board. Capt. Dodd says it is the body of Miss Eva Gilson, of New-York, and that she took passage with him for Norfolk on Saturday afternoon.

It is considered probable that at least a dozen bills calling for remedial legislation in city affairs will go to the Legislature from the Gibbs investigating committee as a result of fully 3,000 pages of printed testimony affecting tha various departments.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--The Very Rev. P.J. Conway, Vicar-General of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago, to-day swore out a warrant for the arrest of M.J. Cahill, President of the Church Pilot and Home Light Publishing Company, of this city, and editor of the paper, which is an obscure one.

A serious split has occurred in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. A year ago the club was forced to give up its basin and clubhouse site, which it had occupied for several years, between Tompkinsville and Stapleton, Staten Island.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 21.--Several weeks ago George Bachenim, a brother of the Chief of Police of this city, was arrested for an assault with intent to kill an old man named Charles Nisse.

LONDON, Dec. 21.--An interview was had to-day with the Right Hon. Hugh C. Childers, Chancellor of the Exchequer under Mr. Gladstone's administration, on the subject of Irish home rule.
The New-Jersey Supreme Court has, by a decision handed down by Judge Dixon, abolished the office of Director at Large of the Board of Chosen Freeholders.

No one who knows Senator BECK believed that he would long be able to restrain himself from an attack upon the Administration and its views on silver, but it was hardly thought that he would commence hostile operations before some definite measure had come before the Senate.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--Baker Henry Machowitz is an honest, industrious man with one child, a little girl named Helen, 11 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company has tendered a train of parlor coaches to the Senators, Representatives, and newspaper correspondents desiring to visit the New-Orleans Exposition during the holiday recess.
PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 21.--Fred F. Glidhill, whose defalcation from M.N. Rich and the Citizens' Mutual Relief Society was reported yesterday, took about $4,000.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 21.--W.H. Greene, the colored officer of the Signal Service who has been appointed assistant in the Rochester station, assumed charge of his duties to-day.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 21.--The following articles of incorporation were filed with the Secretary of State to-day: The E.L. Llanes Gold Mining Company, of New-York, with a capital of $1,000,000; operations to be carried on in South America.

Several merchants who occupy stores on Fourteenth-street near Sixth-avenue applied to Judge DONOHUE on Saturday last for a mandamus directing the Commissioner of Public Works and the Superintendent of Incumbrances to remove the hucksters who had taken possession of the sidewalk in front of their places of business. The mandamus was granted.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 21.--It is ascertained, upon undoubted authority to-night, that the purchasers of the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad on Dec. 30 will be ex-Gov. Charles Foster, Samuel Thomas, C.S. Brice, and other Eastern capitalists who represent the survivors of the old Seney syndicate of Nickel Plate fame.
The feast of reason enjoyed by the Congregational Club at its December meeting last evening was preceded by a repast of a more material nature.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21.--The Treasurer of the Irish National League of America, in acknowledging a check for $1,000 from the Philadelphia branch to be applied to the Parliamentary fund, says that 15,000 has been sent to Parnell since Oct. 1.
Elizabeth, N.J., earned a bad reputation some years ago, and is engaged in diligently adding to it. It got into trouble and bankruptcy by corrupt extravagance.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec 21.--Armstrong, Phillips Co., who are large owners and operators of oil and gas wells and bituminous coal mines in Pennsylvania, are negotiating with land owners along the Helderberg Mountains, between Knowersville and Kingston, for leases ...
PARIS, Dec. 21.--Seven anarchists have been arrested on a charge of organizing a demonstration against the ball of the Tribunal of Commerce, held last night.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 21.--Superintendent McCall, of the Insurance Department, to-day fixed the fees to be paid to Edward Newcomb, Receiver of the Atlantic Mutual Life Insurance Company, of Albany, pursuant to chapter 902, Laws of 1869.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 21.--The mystery surrounding the advent at the Newburg Almshouse on Thursday last of the fair young woman giving the name of Alice Ellis is gradually being unraveled.

I wonder what Lord Wolseley would have received had the military promenade in Burmah been personally conducted by him? He received a peerage and 40,000 for the absurd "battle" of Tel-el-Kebir, and was suhsequently made a Viscount for helplessly drifting in the direction of Khartoum and arriving too late. Either he got too much, or Gen. Prendergast, who has only been made a K.C.B., gets too little.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 21.--G.A. McFarland, a mulatto, and Fred J. Wade, white, quarreled in a saloon yesterday. McFarland drew a razor and slashed it across Wade's throat, nearly severing the head from the shoulders. He died almost immediately. McFarland was placed under arrest.
At the Theatre Comique, in One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, last night, Gibson and Ryan's company appeared in a play somewhat familiar in this city called "Irish Aristocracy."

Memories of old-time pedestrianism were revived in this city when, yesterday, at the Cosmopolitan Rink, corner of Broadway and Forty-first-street, "Dan" O'Leary and Edward Payson Weston entered upon the third week of their 2,500 miles' walking contest for a purse of $3,000.
LONDON, Dec. 21.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says; "Wheats are inactive, owing to the apprcach of the holidays.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 21.--Jones of Binghamton arrived this afternoon and had a long consultation with the Hon. John W. Vrooman, Clerk of the Senate, about the proceedings of the opening sessions of the body over which he is to preside.

Herr Jean Joseph Bott, who enjoyed considerable renown in Germany many years ago as a composer, kapellmeister, and virtuoso, came forth in the latter capacity yesterday evening at Steinway Hall during the progress of a concert gotten up, apparently, for the express purpose of introducing him to the American public.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 21.--The Pacific Express, west bound, on the Erie Railroad late on Saturday evening struck a team of horses and carriage at Goshen, the latter containing Mr. Philip Brady, his wife, and sister-in-law, Mise Mary Lynch, all of that village.

Mr. J. Hood Wright, of Drexel, Morgan Co., the President of the newly organized West Shore Railroad Company, filed an application with the Stock Exchange yesterday for the listing of $50,000,000 West Shore bonds, bearing 4 per cent. interest, guaranteed by the NewYork Central Railroad Company.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 21.--The general assignment of S. Silverstein Co., wholesale and retail clothing dealers, was filed to-day. Their liabilities are $40,000, with preferences of $20,000, mostly for borrowed money.
The usual Monday meeting of the Baptist pastors yesterday drew an attendance that not only filled the meeting room, but overflowed into the book selling room outside.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 21.--This morning the court appointed J. Oliver Roads, of Pottsville, to succeed John Leonard, ousted from the office of Commissioner on the 1st of the month for bribery.

Judge Donohue rendered decisions yesterday in favor of the Erie Railroad Company in two suits brought against it by the Bradford, Eldred and Cuba Railroad Company and Thomas C. Platt as Receiver and the Tonawanda Valley and Cuba Railroad Company and Bird W. Spencer as Receiver.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 21.--Railroad circles were stirred up here to-day by the hostile movements of the East Tennessee and the Georgia Pacific Roads. For 13 hours the freight trains of the East Tennessee were blocked here by the action of the Georgia Pacific.
A concert was given Sunday evening in Chickering Hall for the purpose of introducing to the public Signorina Adelina Puerari, vocalist and pianist.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 21.--Joseph Krebla, an employe of the Milwaukee Car Shops, was bitten in the calf of the right leg by a dog about 25 days ago, but did not experience any trouble until last Friday, when the premonitory symptoms of hydrophobia seized him.

Miss Rosina Vokes, the charming songstress, dancer, and comedienne, whose triumphs as a member of the famous Vokes Family are so well remembered in New-York, made her first appearance here after a long absence at the Standard Theatre last night accompanied by the troupe of clever young performers who have been traveling with her through the United States since last September.

Mimi Sclanerous, a Greek, was convicted of blackmail in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, and Judge Cowing sent him to Sing Sing for two years. The defendant, who is a confectioner, lived in Albany.

One of the most effective agencies for city mission work is the Gospel Mission to the Tombs, which is now in the ninth year of its existence.
William Lee, who is said to be a man of good character, was charged in the Yorkville Court yesterday with having assaulted a Chinese laundryman named Chung Lee in his shop at No. 497 Third-avenue.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 21.--When Otto Siegar, a clerk for Groceryman John Guyer, stole two Government bonds worth $1,500, which belonged to George Jung, a fellow-clerk, and sped away to parts unknown a few days ago, Jung's chances of recovering his property seemed slight enough.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 21.--Crystal Springs, a favorite resort for invalids, situated about five miles southwest from Dundee, Yates County, was the scene of much excitement last night at about midnight.

A chunk of Plymouth Rock about the size of a big Winter apple, mounted on an ebony base and labeled with letters of glittering gold, was the blarney stone that set scores of NewEnglanders to telling stories about their historic ancestors last night at the sixth annual dinner of the New-England Society in Brooklyn.

Society began the week with the first cotillion ball of the season at Delmonico's last evening, and it was an enjoyable affair. The decorations were simple, consisting of a little holly and Christmas green on the balcony of the ballroom and a few cut flowers in the reception rooms.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 21.--Trebien's distillery, 10 miles east of this city, was completely wrecked to-day by a boiler explosion which occurred shortly after midday. Two men were killed and several others seriously injured.
SCHENECTADY, Dec. 21.--A representative of the Knights of Labor to-day ordered out 37 members from the shops of the Kilmer Manufacturing Company.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 21.--Charles Whitehead, Special United States Examiner of Pensions at this place, to-day recovered his 9-year-old boy, Morrison, who was stolen from him in California two years ago, and whom he had given up all hope of ever seeing again.

Trouble arose at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education of New-Lots. It began when Trustee Kiendl moved that the bill of Weymouth Smith for $1,500 for a heating apparatus be paid. President Anderson and Trustees Sherman, Kiendl, and Meyerborg voted yea, while Trustees Powells, Burrows, Busch, and Cooper voted no.

All day yesterday a group of men stood at the corner of Fourteenth-street and Avenue A discussing the chances of a small strike in which, as molders and clippers in the employ of Hotchkiss, Field Flynn, they were engaged.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 21.--The brig Mayflower, owned by March Sons, Newfoundland, from St. John's to Glace Bay, in ballast, struck on Eastern Rock, Scatary, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 21.--At a late hour last night, at a christening in George Michaeiski's house, Joseph Maller had a dispute with Michaeiski, and stabbed him with a large knife, Michaeiski will die, Maller is under arrest.

Senators Gibert, Murphy, and Robinson, who comprise the special committee appointed to investigate the consolidation of the gas companies in this city, spent the greater part of yesterday in looking over and classifying the great mass of testimony that has been taken during the past month.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 21.--When the will of William S. Stewart, who died in this city last October, came up for probate before Surrogate Cook this morning, notice was given that it would be contested in the interest of Mrs. Maria H. Carnsworth, the testator's daughter and only...

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21.--Private advices by the Steamer Oceanic, which arrived here Saturday from China, state that the German manof-war Nautilus has raised the German flag on the Marshall and Gilbert groups of islands in the Southern Pacific and claimed for the Government a protectorate over them.

The Singer Manufacturing Company's shops at Elizabeth will reopen to-day. Mr. W. F. Proctor, Vice-President of the company, when shown the resolution adopted by the Common Council of Elizabeth last evening, as given below expressed no surprise at its stipulations.
Congressman William C. Maybury, of Detroit, is at the Hoffman House. Albert Lefaivre, French Consul-General at New-York, is at the Clarendon Hotel.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 21.--T.A. Lewis, General Manager of the Erie fast freight lines, has asked to be relieved of the duties which devolve upon this office.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 21.--A memorial is being ciroulated by the American Fishery Union and will be numerously signed all along the coast.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21.--The new Court House was crowded this morning, owing to the announcement that the case of Daniel E. Stanton, charged with the fatal shooting of Federick P. Nash on the night of Oct. 16, 1884, near Germantown Junction, would be called for trial.
ESCANABA, Mich., Dec. 21.--The tug Owen was fitted out yesterday and sailed hence this morning in search of the schooner Orphan Boy. She had on board five-tons of coal and provisions for 20 days.
WOOD'S HOLL, Mass., Dec. 21.--At the United States Fish Commission station at this place great success has been attained in hatching out the eggs of the codfish.
A truck struck Mrs. Salina Schallas, 50 years of age, living at No. 252 Lynch street, Brooklyn, as she was endeavoring to step across the gutter yesterday afternoon and knocked her down.

The question, What is to become of our cooperage industry? is being asked by hundreds of men in the woods of Virginia, Pennsylvania, New-York, and Maine, where most of the material for hogsheads has been obtained for the hitherto large demand from the West India Islands.

"J.M. Walker used to have a one-fifth interest in the bonanza firm," said an old resident yesterday, as he looked at the magnificent mansion in the block bounded by Eleventh, twelfth, Jackson, and Madison streets, Oakland.

In the performance of his duties as Clerk of the Special Term of the Supreme Court, Thomas J. Dunn gave to the counsel for the plaintiff in the suit of Maloy against Duden an extract from the minutes of proceedings in the case.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 21.--The Hon. F.S. Goode, Judge of the District Court of St. Mary and Terrebonne, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself with a shotgun through the head.

The steamship Santiago, which arrived yesterday from Cienfuegos and Nassau, brought the crews of the wrecked schooners Lillian M. and Elsie G. Capt. Walters, of the Lillian M., states that she was wrecked early in the present month at Inagua, where she was taking on a cargo of salt.
LANCASTER, Dec. 21.--Police Officer Speece went down to Providence Township a few days ago to arrest an alleged forger.

Three years ago Mrs. Abbey C. Barker, of Tarrytown, died, leaving property valued at $10,000. Her Executor, Edward B. Cobb, found among her papers a memorandum of a note for $2,500, given by her to the Trustees of a church to help pay off its indebtedness.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 21.--At the State tax sale to-day lands in the counties of Lewis to Niagara, inclusive, were put up at auction. Seven hundred parcels were offered.
An officer brought two big Washington Market women into the Tombs Police Court yesterday. One was Jane Carson, height 6 feet, and weight 250 pounds.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 21.--Superintendent Barnes, of the Kansas Southern Railroad, says that surveyors have been at work for several weeks in the Indian Territory, locating for the extension of that road into the Panhandle of Texas. He is of the opinion that the road is sure to be built.

The hardships which beset the brokers and scalpers in railroad tickets were set forth in THE TIMES of Sunday, and, as if to emphasize the correctness of the facts therein given, the Passenger Agents of the trunk lines yesterday took up the question of the payment of commissions to ticket agents and discussed it in all its bearings.
ELMIRA, Dec. 21.--A mysterious disease has appeared among the hogs in this city and vicinity and other places in the southern tier.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 21.--About six weeks ago the wife of Alfred Krothe, proprietor of the La Pierre House, one of the largest hotels here, eloped with one of her boarders, Charles M. Phoenix, a well known young attorney of this city.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 21.--The appearance of Col. E.C. .Bruffy, the assistant city editor of the Constitution, and Chief of Police Connelly in the Police Court to-day to answer the charge of quarreling in the street developed quite a sensation.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 21.--The Mormon church papers print the names and occupations of the Grand Jurors just discharged "for future reference," that they may be boycotted by Mormons. C.W. Hemenway, editor of the Ogden Herald, a Mormon organ, to-day pleaded guilty of libel. He will be sentenced on Jan. 4.
The Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association held a stated meeting at St. Luke's Hospital last evening, it being the last meeting prior to the general collection on Hospital Sunday.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 21.--It is officially announced by (Governer-General Lansdowne that skating and tobogganing parties will be given at Rideau Hall every Saturday during the months of January and February, though, owing to the recent death of her father, the Duke of Abercorn, Lady Lansdowne will not be able to take part in these amusements.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 21.--"Dr." Dalamata Smith, who was convicted of having caused the death of Carrle Franklin by malpractice, was to-day sentenced to seven years in the penitentiary by Judge McKinney, in the Common Pleas Court. The sentence is the heaviest that could be imposed by law.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 21.--The Dolphin left Newport this morning to go over the compass and measured mile courses.

LANCASTER, Dec. 21.--Felix Baum, Junior of the Theological Seminary, and Frank Schoedler, Junior of the Franklin and Marshall College, have severed their connection with those institutions, and yesterday joined St. Anthony's Catholic Church, making a public profession of faith. Baum was a beneficiary from Lehigh classis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--The Supreme Court of the United States to-day affirmed the decree of the Court of Claims in the case of Hattle A. Burnett, widow of Gen. Ward B. Burnett, against the United States. Mrs. Burnett, subsequent to the death of her husband, filed an application for a widow's pension and was allowed a pension of $30 per month.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 21.--About two months ago Mrs. Gray and her 23-year-old daughter Maggie moved into rooms on the fourth floor of the tenement house at No. 53 Spruce-street, and there last night at about 1 o'clock a reporter saw the dead and horribly bruised body of the daughter lying on the floor wrapped in a shawl, with a pillow beneath the head.
The annual financial statement of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company was issued yesterday. The cost of the road and equipment up to the present date is stated at $146,074,835.80.

ALBANY, Dec. 21.--The Evening Journal announces that Mr. W.J. Arkell, President of the Journal Company, has boon elected President of the Judge Publishing Company of NewYork, and that under his control the Judge will be reorganized throughout all its departments.

Henry N. Beers asked the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday, before it began its work of considering the final estimates for next year, to fix the time when the members of the Council of Reform could be heard regarding the expenses of the departments.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 21.--The excitement over the alleged murder of Benjamin J. Burton by his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Allen Waldorf Dorsey, has been revived and intensified by the removal of Mrs. Dorsey to the county jail at Providence, and by the discovery of certain correspondence which passed between the prisoner and her sister, Emma D. Burton.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21.--First Lieut. Louis P. Brant, First Infantry, will be relieved from duty at Geneva N.Y., on the closing of the rendezvous at that place, and will join his company.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 21.--Miss Alice O'Byrne, daughter of John O'Byrne, late an assistant in the District Attorney's office in NewYork City, was received as a novitiate into the Academy of the Visitation this morning.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 21.--At 3 o'clock last Saturday morning the jail at Rockingham was surrounded by 50 masked men, who forced an entrance and secured a white man named John Lee, who three weeks ago murdered Solomen Welsh. They carried Lee out of town and hanged him to a limb of a tree. Lee murdered Welsh for money.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 21.--At 3 o'clock this afternoon the contested election case, growing ing out of the recent prohibition election, came up in the State court, before Judge Marshall J. Clarke, five or six lawyers appearing on each side.
LONDON, Dec. 21.--Lieut. Greely, of arctic fame, delivered a lecture in this city to-night under the auspices of the Royal Geographical Society.
William Giles, of London, the English wing shot, is anxious to test his skill against that of any wing shot in the country for any amount up to $10,000 a side.
ST. IGNACE, Mich., Dec. 22.--The Mackinaw Lumber Company have given up all hope of finding the schooner Orphan Boy, and have ordered the tug Saugatuck to return here.

We are glad to see that Mr. EDWARD MITCHELL, Chairman of the committee appointed to investigate the charges of treachery on the part of the Republican district leaders, approaches the inquiry with a certain wariness of mind.
Under the auspices of the Union Card Political League a meeting of workingmen was called last evening to protest against the slaughter of laborers in the new aqueduct.

The annual dinner of the New-England Society in the city of New-York took place at Delmonico's last evening. The sons of the pilgrims who live in this city do not agree with those of Brooklyn as to the date on which the pilgrims landed.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Dec. 22.--An un-- known man, thought to be a Polander, was found dead in a stable at Catasauqua to-day. His head was bruised and cut, and it is believed that he was murdered. Four tramps have been arrested on suspicion of having caused the man's death.

Two opposing Presidents testified before the Senate Gas Investigating Committee,in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, yesterday, and each made statements that were listened to with much interest by the committee.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 22.--The following certificates of incorporation were filed to-day: The American Manufacturing and Supply Company, (limited,) of New-York City, capital ...
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22.--Nearly 175 persons sat down to a banquet at the Continental Hotel to-night in celebration of the fifth annual meeting of the New-England Society of Pennsylvania.
Louis Gutman, the young man who shot his fellow-boarder, Max Friedman, at their boarding house on Monday evening, was yesterday arraigned at the Essex Market police Court.
MONTREAL, Dec. 22.--Alderman Donovan has entered action against the Montreal Herald for $10,000 damages.
The General Term of the City Court yesterday handed down a decision in the action commenced by William F.Peverly against Poole Gilmore, affirming a judgment in favor of the defendants.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 22.--Yesterday the noted case of the United States against John T. Chidester and Logan H. Roots came up in the Federal court of this city.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 22.--A petition for the dissolution of the Buffalo Insurance Company was presented to the Superior Court today. An order to show cause why it should not be dissolved was issued, returnable April 2 next.
More than 30 years Epidemus Irving has spent in the City Lunatic Asylum and the almshouse on Ward's Island. He became demented while pursuing investigations in chemistry.

DETROIT, Dec. 22.--The developments of the last two days have brought no new light to the solution of the mystery still hanging around the terrible quadruple murder of last week. They have only added to its horrors.
GLASGOW, Dec. 22.--The first of the three new steamers built by John Elder Co., of this city, for the North German Lloyd steamship Company, has been successfully launched to-day.
NANTICOKE, Penn., Dec. 22.--The early morning consultation of the officials of the Susquehanna Coal Company with some of its most practical and skilled miners, and the conclusion ...

OSWEGO, N.Y., Dec. 22.--A sensation was caused here to-day by the arrival of E. Fellows Jenkins, of New-York, agent of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, accompanied by two detectives, with a warrant for the arrest of Dr. J.A, Milne, a prominent physician, and John Navagh, charging them with kidnaping Eugenia Mehan, a small child.

ALBANY, Dec. 22.--An attempt was made in the Railroad Commission to-day by Commissioner O'Donnell to secure an investigation of the alleged corruption in connection with the Broadway Surface Railroad in New-York. He offered the following resolution:
RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 22.--The West Shore Railroad Commission's work at Marlborough, on the property of Mr. Yonng, was closed yesterday. The commission adjourned to meet in New-York to-morrow.
"Dan" O'Leary and Edward Payson Weston resumed their walk at the Cosmopolitan Rink yesterday noon.
The Pilot Commissioners have sent to Albany their annual report. There are in active service 132 pilots.

PARIS, Dec. 22.--The four children from Newark who were inoculated last evening by M. Pasteur's medical assistant are to-day doing well. They are staying at the Hotel Sarbonne, and will undergo a regular course or treatment. No opinion can yet be formed regarding the ultimate development of the virus.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 22.--A catch-ascatch-can wrestling match between Evan Lewis, the young Welsh champion of Wisconsin, and Tom Cannon, of San Francisco, took place here last night, and was won by Lewis after a severe tussle.
Produce Exchange brokers already have Christmas in their bones, and yesterday they had a chance to show how frisky they could be when anxious to make a record.
The whistles of the Singer Manufacturing Company's shops, at Elizabeth, called all hands to work yesterday morning. Later the Committee of Workingmen appointed ...

The Polygamy bill reported from the Senate Judiciary Committee by Mr. EDMUNDS is almost an exact copy of the bill reported from that committee nearly two years ago and passed by the Senate on June 18, 1884, by a vote of 33 to 15.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 22.--By a decree of Judge Holliday, of the Chancery Court of Richmond, in the cause of Pelouze against the Richmond Whig Publishing Company, the publication of the Whig is suspended after this date until further order of the court.

The suit for libel brought by Robert C. Plume against Thomas Potter, the Jersey City contractor, went on yesterday before Judge Knapp, in the Hudson County Court Horse. It drew a large attendance, as on other days.

Austin, Nichols Co., wholesale grocers, of No. 59 Hudson-street, caused the arrest at Yonkers on Monday evening of J.V. Alexander, a former clerk, whom they charged with appropriating to his own use a check for $267.

LONDON, Nov. 5.--Although but an infant in the matter of years, the Institute of Painters in Oil Colors has already assumed an important position in the world of art, and its annual Winter exhibition of the works of modern painters is the largest and most prominet of the season.

NYACK, Dec. 22.--A number of the Republicans of this section of Rockland County assembled in the old clubroom in this village last night for the purpose of taking preliminary measures toward the reorganization of the Young Men's Republican Club, which conducted the campaign here last Fall.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 22.--Jacob A. Stivers, a farmer at Beemerville, Sussex County, N.J., fell yesterday afternoon while climbing over a fence and broke his neck. He and his son had been to a mountain wood lot two miles away. At 4 o'clock he started to walk home.

ALBANY, Dec. 22.--The New-York insurance companies have made such tempting offers to Superintendent of Insurance John H. McCall, Jr., that he has finally consented to give up his present office and remove to the metropolis about Jan. 1.

Influential members of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association, which is now actively engaged in devising ways and means to aid Mr. Parnell, complained yesterday that the real objects sought to be attained had been erroneously stated and consequently misunderstood. One of them said:

WASHINGTON. Dec. 22.--A Democratic Senator who could cope with Mr. Beck or any other Western silver advocate, and who could bravely, clearly, and persistently reply to such fulminations as that indulged in by Mr. Beck on Monday would be a very comforting friend to the Administration at this time and during the present session.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22.--David A. Gage, who years ago was one of Chicago's foremost citizens, is lying dangerously ill in this city.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 22.--In the United States court to-day Walter Stanton, a NewYork broker, began suit against the bondsmen of eight Indiana township Trustees, who engaged with Pollard in issuing township school warrants for fictitious purchases.
Argument was heard by Judge Beach, in Supreme Court, Special Term, yesterday, on the motion of Samuel Untermyer, counsel for the plaintiff, for the confirmation of the report ...

CHICAGO, Dec. 22.--Maurice Vignaux won to-night the second of the series of tie games in the 14-inch balk line billiard tournament, scoring 800 points at the rate of 22 8-36 an inning, and running out with a lead of 114 over Schaefer, his opponent.
I wonder if any defeated candidate has been consoled by the article last week in the Times telling him the pleasures that are still oven to him.

ALBANY, N,Y., Dec. 22.--Notice of the discovery of a vein of gold and silver on the land of Charles La Duce, in the town of Theresa, Jefferson County, was filed with the Secretary of State to-day by Charles Hordie and Liberty E. Robertson.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 22.--Dow, Short Co., bankers, suspended to-day with direct liabilities of $60,000, of which $40,000 is due to depositors, and contingent liabilities amounting to $100,000 for indorsement of notes rediscounted, the value of which is not now apparent.
MADRID, Dec. 22.--It is reported that a conspiracy to establish a republic has been discovered at Tarragona. The details of the movement are withheld by the Government.

GREENBAY, Wis., Dec. 22.--The funeral of the late Bishop F.X. Krautbauer was held from St. Francis Xavier Cathedral this afternoon, the remains being interred in a vault under the main aisle of the cathedral.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 22.--An inquest was held this morning over the dead body of the woman Eva Gilson, which was brought here last night on the schooner E.G. Irwin, Capt. Dodd, from New-York.

A very nice young man spent most of the hot days of last August at a wind-swept retreat in the Atlantic Highlands of New-Jersey. Atlantic Highlands, after the Summer has gone away, is a tired little village of 500 souls.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Dec. 22.--In Madison County Mrs. Goslin left her husband and went to live with a man named Norton. A few days since the two men met and had an altercation.

Joseph Walsh, 50 years of age, living at No. 18 Hamilton-street, New-York, and employed on the dock at the foot of South Secondstreet, Brooklyn, Eastern District, went into the Brooklyn Sugar House, near the dock, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and while looking ...

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 22.--Parties arrived here this evening from Silver City, New-Mexico, bringing additional particulars of the disastrous surprise of regular troops near Alma. New-Mexico, last Saturday, by a band of Apache guerillas.
RONDOUT, Dec. 22.--Stephen Maynard, of Stamford, Delaware County, raised on his farm the past season a potato that weighs three pounds and six ounces.
BROCKTON, Mass., Dec. 22.--The 42 factories which have been silent for so long a time opened their doors for work this morning.
BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 22.--The organization of the Boston Post is now completed, and it is announced that the new company has a strong financial backing.
Mr. Vanderbilt would have been just as happy without his money. Edgar Poe might have done something with it, and so might Mrs. Fry.
ALABNY, N.Y. Dec. 22.--Ex-Gov. Horatic Seymour was one of purchasers at the State tax sale to-day, and he secured several parcels in Oneida County through his agent.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 22.--There was an outbreak at the old Eagle Mines in the third pool, near Elkhorn, yesterday morning. At an early hour about 20 masked men made an attack upon two Germans when about three-quarters of a mile from the pit.

ELLICOTT CITY, Md., Dec. 22.--A mortgage has been left at the Clerk's office here for record from the United Lines Telegraph Company to the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New-York, to secure an indebtedness of $1,200,000 to various persons, the said telegraph company having issued 1,200 one-thousand-dollar bonds, payable on the 1st day of July, 1905.
ATLANTA, Dec. 22.--"Yes, my name is Thomas Clements, and I am wanted in Alexandria, La., for killing a man. There is a reward of $1,000 for my arrest, and I was under $10,000 bonds when I skipped."

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 22.--The Congregational church is this beautiful little spot on the Sound to-day stole a march on all the sister churches in the State by celebrating its two hundred and fiftieth anniversary and proclaimin itself the mother of all the churches in the State.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 22.--At the Exposition to-day New-England Day was celebrated with music, songs, and speeches, and to-night New-England's sons and daughters sat down to a banquet.

Much information of a cheerful and interesting sort may be found in places unsuspected. No one, however, would pick up that modest volume entitled, "Annual Report of the Hon. Anson G. McCook, Secretary United States Senate," without expecting to be instructed and morally improved by a perusal of its contents.

CANTON, Ga., Dec. 22.--Capt. John Smith, a well known merchant, committed suicide last night by hanging. When his wife awoke she found him hanging dead from the door post, Inability to make collections was the cause.

Sub-committees of Tammany Hall and Irving Hall met yesterday afternoon to agree upon the disposition of some of the patronage that will soon be at the disposal of Sheriff-elect Grant and County Clerk-elect James A. Flack.

A large vault in the crypt of Great Witley Church is being prepared as a mausoleum for the late Lord Dudley, who was temporarily buried in the former family vault of the Foleys, in another part of the church.

The eighth of the Thomas Popular Concerts took place at the Academy of Music yesterday evening. The programme was brief but interesting, although it included no number that had not been made familiar by repeated performance.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 22.--This afternoon a body, supposed to be that of James McGrath, of this city, was found floating in the Hudson near here.
The artist who made the record opened 2,500 bivalves in 2h. 37m. This record was beaten out of sight at Turn Hall last night by John Gillen, of this city, and Frank Barrett, of Norfolk, Va.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 22.--The citizens of Alliance were greatly incensed this morning by an attempt of the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad employes to lay a side track along Front-street, a much used thoroughfare.
A strong effort is being made, it is said, to adjust the differences that have arisen in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.
SCHENECTADY, Dec. 22.--Trouble is anticipated between the Knights of Labor and the Kilmer Manufacturing Company, of this city. Last night the firm appealed to the police for protection.
LONDON, Dec. 12.--In the obituary notices which the death of the Duke of Somerset called forth last week a curious diversity in the spelling of the family name was noticeable.

Nearly 100 artists of New-York and vicinity assembled last evening in the building of the National Academy of Design to consider the question of forming an organization to protect their property in pictures when on exhibition.
A special meeting of New-York Yacht Club was held last evening to consider the challlenge of the Galatea for the America's cup and other matters.
A ragpicker in Hagen, Rhine Prussia, owns a donkey, which, it is safe to say, has not its equal in the world.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 22.--The trial of Policeman Hampton, for conspiracy to entrap non-Mormon officials into disreputable houses, is in progress in the District Court here.

LONDON, Dec. 22.--The recent visit to Ireland of Ford Richard Grosvenor, who was a Government official under the administration of Mr. Gladstone, gave rise to a rumor that his object was to consult with Irish leaders on behalf of Mr. Gladstone.

The thorough drubbing administered in the courts to the American Association by the Metropolitan Baseball Club probably accounts for the credit given to a rumor that a conference was to be held between the two bodies yesterday afternoon.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 22.--The jury in the case of Susan Lee, colored, against William Douglas to-day rendered a sealed verdict in the City Court in favor of the plaintiff for $1,000 damages.
The great question of the sinfulness of raffles at bazaars is not to be permitted to rest-- at all events in Scotland.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 22.--The Hon. Allen G. Thurman was selected to-night as umpire before the Mining Arbitration Board. The Judge was suggested by the miners and readily accepted by the operators. The committee appointed to wait on him report that he will accent.

A quite largely attended meeting of the Republican Association of the Seventeenth Assembly District was held last evening at its rooms, No. 341 West Forty-seventh-street, for the purpose of a arranging for the primary election to be held on Thursday of next week. Police Commissioner John McClave presided.

The sacrifice of life by the caving in of a mine at Nanticoke seems to have been needless. The story of this accident has not been told so clearly or in such detail as to make it entirely intelligible.

CLINTON, Wis., Dec. 22.--William Graham, a bachelor living five miles south of here, was confronted by a masked man last night who compelled him at the point of a pistol to deliver up $4,000 which he had in the house. Henry Lawson, a neighbor, has been arrested, charged with being the robber.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 22.--In Chattooga County, Northern Georgia, yesterday, James Starling was killing hogs and used a half-buried hogshead as a scalding caldron, which was filled with boiling water.
ATLANTA, Dec. 22.--The Superior Court was engaged all day in listening to argument in the proceedings for an injunction against the declaration of the result in the prohibition election.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22.--Samuel Sampson Goldberg is a young man, with large eyes and feet, a prominent nose, and the occupation of "Secretary of the Western Detective and Collection Association."

READING, Penn., Dec. 22.--An eccentirc character named Michael Renninger, aged 65 years, who had been missing since Saturday last, was found handing to a rafter in his garret, at his house, near Shanesville.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 22.--The Pennsylvania Coal Company at Pittston has closed for an indefinite period Shafts Nos. 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, and 11, No. 1 tunnel, and No. 2 slope.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22.--J.H. Hanlenbeek, formerly proprietor of Godey's Lady's Book,and who recently made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors, was arrested this afternoon on a charge of obtaining by false pretences papers to the value of $6,000 from A.G. Elliott Co., and goods to the value of $1,800 from W.H. Butler. He was held in $1,800 bail for further hearing.

VINCENNES, Ind., Dec. 22.--Late last night Mayor Wilhelm and a committee of the Council made a tour of the city to see bow the police force were attending to their duties.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 22.--Connecticut's Legislature will assembly at Hartford on Jan. 6. The chances are that its deliberations will be confined to matters that are unimportant so far as the State at large is concerned.

MADRID, Dec. 22.-- Mr. Curry, the Amercan Minister, presented his credentials to the Queen Regent to-day, when the subject of the commercial relations between the United States Government and Spain was discussed at some length.
Mr. Mapleson will this evening produce Massenet's "Manon," with Mme. Hauk in the principal role, at the Academy.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 22.--A terrible tragedy is reported from Madison County, on the Big Laurel. It appears that James Gunter and his son were drinking together and got into an altercation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 22.--The following was entered in the Court of Appeals to-day: Ordered, That a term of this court be held in the Capitol in the city of Albany on Monday, the 18th day of January, 1886, at 10 A.M.
PIQUA, Ohio, Dec. 22.--O' Farrell Smith, manufacturers of agricultural implements, have made an assignment to M. H. Jones. Their liabilities are $30,000, and the assets about the same.

MONTREAL, Dec. 22.--The priests in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Montreal have received a letter from Bishop Fabre, forbidding them to meddle with politics in any shape or form, and directing them not to use the pulpit to disseminate their views when political questions are on the tapis, and not even to speak in private on political matters.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 22.--A representative of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company passed through here to-day and announced that that company had purchased the Jamesville and Washington Railroad, which is in running order from these two places a distance of 22 miles.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 22.--The whaling bark Amethyst is supposed to have been lost. She was last seen in the Arctic Ocean about Oct. 7, bound out, with five whales.

Prussing, whose testimony was of vital importance in the case of the State against Robert Hertel for conspiracy and fraud, was to-day permitted to take the statutory oath, including the swearing "by the living God," though he said he considered the oath binding only because it is prescribed by the law and statutes.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 23.--No coal will be transported over the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad on Friday and Saturday. It is estimated that this will reduce the tonnage of the road nearly 80,000 tons.
VENICE, Dec. 23.--The Mayor of Venice has sent a circular to all Italian newspapers, in which he protests that the reports of the prevalence of cholera here are greatly exaggerated.

Some friends of the late Miss Helen Prideaux wish to found a memorial to her memory. We are not fond of memorials, and rarely mention them, but Miss Prideaux deserved one.

Morten I. Christensen lives in a modest little dwelling at No. 273 Second-street, Woodlawn Heights, owned by himself and his sister. The street in front of the house is, he claims, in a wretched condition.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 23.--The case of John Greeb, charged with manslaughter in killing James C. Ackley, was brought to an unexpected close to-day. Several witnesses had been sworn and ex-Judge Clute was summing up for the plaintiff, when the Justice called District Attorney Herrick for consultation.

MONTREAL, Dec. 23.--In connection with the outbreak of smallpox at Longue Pointe Asylum Dr. Henry Howard, the Government Medical Superintendent, states when the smallpox became epidemic in September last, and again on the 2d of December, he wrote to the house physicians requesting them to vaccinate all the patients in the institution, but without effect.

Sixth-avenue, Fourteenth-street, Grandstreet, and the other streets and avenues devoted to retail trade, were crowded last evening until well towards midnight by a throng of an entirely different character from that which usually appears there in the evening.
TORONTO, Dec. 23.--A cable dispatch to the Globe says that Sir John Macdonald, George Stephen, and Donald A. Smith will sail for Canada Jan. 9.

LONDON, Dec. 23.--Sir T. D. Acland, member of Parliament, who has just returned from a visit to Mr. Gladstone at Hawarden, addressed the electors of Somerset to-day. In the course of his speech he referred to the various statements in the newspapers concerning Mr. Gladstone's intentions in regard to home rule for Ireland, and advised his hearers not to put any faith in these published reports, which he affirmed were utterly untrustworthy.

In the suit for libel brought by Robert C. Plume against Thomas Potter, in the Hudson County (N.J.) Court, the lawyers consumed all of yesterday in closing arguments. The last of them was not finished at adjournment. Neither Mrs. Plume, the plaintiff's mother, nor Mr. Potter was in court. The attendance was large, however, as usual.

Mr. E. Fellows Jenkins, the Superintendent of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, returned to this city yesterday from Oswego, where he had been endeavoring to gain the custody of Eugenia Meehan under an order from Judge Donchue, of the Supreme Court. Eugenia was born in July 9, 1882.

Viceroy Li, of China, has contributed $300 to the Grant Monument fund, and his example has been followed by the Chinese Minister at Washington, who has subscribed $200 toward the same object.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 23.--A.S. Powell, a widower, of Robertson County, Tenn., has entered suit in the Circuit Court at Russellville, Ky., against Miss Maggie Flowers, an orphan girl, for $10,000 damages for alleged breach of promise of marriage.
