Grace Church, on Brooklyn Heights, was the scene of a fashionable wedding on Tuesday, when Miss Beulah Augusta Benham, daughter of Mr. James M. Benham, was married to Mr. George Ide Malcom, of this city.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 23.--A few weeks ago the city granted a franchise to the Dorsett Underground Service Company to establish an extensive system of conduits, and the initiative steps were taken for putting in a five-hundredthousand-dollar plant.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 23.--The Controller, City Counselor, and the attorney of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company appeared in court to-day and disposed of the case of the city against the railroad company for the recovery of a judgment of $100,000 in connection with a loan made to the Missouri Pacific Company in 1865.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 23.--Intelligence reached the police authorities last night of a brutal assault which was committed yesterday morning on an old woman named Mary Sommers, aged 65 years, who lives alone in a small house near Cummings.
The last will and testament of William Sharon, the late millionaire, was filed for probate yesterday afternoon by Francis G. Newlands and Frederick W. Sharon, the Executors appointed by the deceased.

After the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher had delivered his eulogy on Gen. Grant in Boston on Oct. 22, a committee of the Common Council waited upon him to inquire if he would accept a money equivalent for his services.
An ambulance was sent to Scott's Hotel, No. 96 Sixth-avenue, last evening for a woman who was supposed to be suffering from malpractice.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23.--The town of Lakeview, adjoining Chicago on the north, is in a terrible plight for lack of drinking water.

The New-York Harmonic Society, a new choral organization, gave its first concert last evening at Chickering Hall. The audience was not very large, and the applause evoked by the singing of the new society was not of the warmest possible character.

READING, Penn., Dec. 23.--Five foreigners, with large packs on their backs, came tramping along the Reading Railroad to this city last evening. One who could talk intelligibly said they were part of a band of exiles from Poland who had been ordered to quit Russia for political offenses.

At the recent caucus of the Democrats of the Virginia Legislature, when nominations were declared in order for the office of Superintendent of Public Printing, Mr. Hoffman, of Craig, in a dramatic speech, nominated Rush U. Derr, of Roanoke.

Detective John T. Cuff, of the Nineteenth Precinct, arraigned before Justice Gorman at the Yorkville Police Court yesterday afternoon a nervous old Englishman, who appeared solicitous about the skirts of a cumbersome overcoat, in which he was muffled to the ears.

The trial to determine the damages to be paid to Isaac Marks for the disabling of one of his legs in the collision between Long Island Railroad trains at Hunter's Point on Aug. 11. 1883, was closed, before Judge Larremore and a jury, yesterday.

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., Dec. 23.--Strenuous efforts are being made by the First National Bank, of this city, to get at the bottom of the matter of the alleged forged acceptances on the Camden Consolidated Oil Company, of Parkersburg, West Va.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 23.--The famous trotting mare Early Dawn, whose record is 2:21 , the property of W.L. Simmons, of this city, died to-day, and an autopsy made by veterinarians disclosed the fact that she had been dosed with arsenic, presumably at St. Louis at the fair, where she first gave evidence of being sick previous to starting in a race.

Bartley Campbell entered Berlin without a word of German to bless himself or curse the cab drivers with, yet before two months he made a speech to the Berliners from the stage of the great theatre there, when the "Galley Slave" proved such a success.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23.--In common with all the other business of Congress, except the preparation of the committee list of the House of Representatives by Speaker Carlisle, the 1,200 or 1,500 nominations sent to the Senate by the President will be at a standstill during the holiday recess.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 23.--Charles Wruck and Bernard Lynch, two New-Haven boys, aged 13 and 15 respectively, "borrowed" some firearms and $235 of a friend's money, and started out to kill Indians the other day.

It is too soon to be alarmed about gold shipments from this country. The condition of the elements entering into the rate of exchange does not warrant any shipments of considerable amount at present, and they are likely, if they occur at all, to be limited, both as to amount and the time for which they continue.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23.--By order of Chief of Police Stewart, Samuel Johnson, the negro who is accused of the murder of John Sharpless, was taken from his cell at the Thirtieth District Station House this afternoon, and securely handcuffed.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 23.--Superintendent of Insurance McCall some days ago asked the opinion of the Attorney-General on the question as to whether or not the Live Stock Dealers' Mutual Benefit Association of New-York could, under the State incorporate laws, issue policies of insurance.

G.W. Tyler has not yet given over hope of securing something from the Sharon estate for his client, Sarah Althea Hill, and in an interview yesterday he said that he could take no steps toward pressing his claims until a personal representative of Mr. Sharon is appointed.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23.--Negotiations are pending for the sale of a controlling interest in the mills of the Calumet Iron and Steel Company, of this city to Dan P. Eells, of Cleveland.

The shipments of gold ordered by the foreign bankers gave rise to considerable comment on Wall-street yesterday, the general opinion being that at present the dangers from the apprehended efflux of gold are largely overestimated.

MILTON, Ontario, Dec. 23.--Early this morning burglars broke into the jewelry store of Ramsay Co. and carried off a cartload of jewelry, silverware, money, The store was cleaned out. The stolen goods were worth thousands of dollars.

An entertainment consisting of vocal and instrumental music, recitations, and calesthenic exercises, was given at Steinway Hall yesterday afternoon by students of the Christian Brothers of De Le Salle Institute, St. Patrick's, St. Bridget's, St. Nicholas's, and the Immaculate Conception Institutes.

The conclusion by France of a peace with Madagascar shows that the lesson of the late elections has been well learned. The further report that the treaty gives France a protectorate over the whole of the island may perhaps be taken with some reserve, until it is known in what sense the word protectorate is used.

When the menagerie in Central Park was opened, 18 years ago, there wasn't a building on Fifth-avenue above Fifty-fourth-street. Now the avenue is lined on the east side with handsome residences as far north as Seventiethstreet, and the occupants of many of them make an annual complaint against the menagerie on several grounds.
SILVERTON, Col., Dec. 23.--A snow slide came down the mountain into Minnesota Gulch yesterday afternoon, sweeping everything before it.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23.--The fire insurance men of Chicago have lately suffered some heavy losses in local fires, and are considerably disturbed thereby.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 23.--A great crowd attended the Hampton conspiracy trial to-day. Many witnesses were examined, including the members of the Grand Jury who indicted Hampton.
The Chinese Sunday school scholars of Jersey City presented each of their teachers with a large Chinese sacred lantern yesterday as a Christmas box.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 23.--Mrs. Lizzie Brown, a young widow residing in Wells-street, has for some time been annoyed by the persistent attentions of John Oakley, a barber. She tried in various ways to rid herself of him, but without success, and on Saturday she had him arrested on a charge of disorderly conduct. The case was continued to Thursday and Oakley gave bail.

DETROIT, Dec. 23.--The Holmes Lumber Company of this city, made an assignment today. It was involved in the troubles of M.C. Huyett Co., to whom it had sold a large amount of lumber, taking therefor notes for $23,000, which had been discounted.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 23.--While the boilers at the Lochiel Rolling Mill were being tested this morning prior to starting up the works, which have been idle for years, one of them exploded and scattered steam and debris in every direction.

St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, at Fifth-avenue and Fifty-third-street, was the scene of a pleasant wedding last evening, when Miss Florence Victoire Rodrigue was married to Prof. Fitz Gerald Tisdall, of the College of the City of New-York. The church was well filled.

Beethoven Hall, on Fifth-street, was well filled last evening in response to a call for a mass meeting of taxpayers to oppose the construction of Quaker Bridge Dam, and to indorse the project for the Sodom Dam at Brewster's Station. The meeting was composed largely of Germans.

HAVANA, Dec. 23.--Col. Beriben, the officer who recently attempted to incite a rebellion in the Manicaragua district, has been condemned to death. The Bishop of the diocese is soliciting the authorities to pardon the man.
Manhattan Lodge, No. 62.--Master--Louis P. Warth; Senior Warden--James W. Wilson; Junior Warden--John Whelan; Treasurer--John H. Russell; Secretary--Thomas McKeever; Trustee--John Stewart.
LAREDO, Texas, Dec. 23.--About midnight last night Senor Fernando Montalbo, editor of a Spanish paper called the Horizonte, was shot and killed by a young Mexican named Vincente Martinez.

Branch No. 157 of the Irish National League, at a meeting at its headquarters, No. 415 West Forty-fourth-street, last evening, arranged for a public meeting at Holy Cross Church on the second Sunday in January next.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23.--A decision was given a few days ago by Judge Gresham in the three cases of Gilbert Millspaugh against the Pullman Palace Car Company, the Allen Paper Car Wheel Company, and the Trustees of the Pullman Land Association, which were bills filed to recover a half interest in 160 acres of land on which part of the town of Pullman is situated.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 23.--A.J. Flood, dry goods dealer, made an assignment yesterday to John Carey. His total liabilities are estimated at $15,000. The assets consist of stock and accounts. He has a number of creditors in NewYork and Philadelphia.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 23.--A peculiar and romantic case has just been decided by the Court of Appeals. It is the divorce case of James J. O'Dea against Mary O'Dea. The defendant was first married in 1844 to Walter G. Kollmyer at Lewiston, this State, with whom ...
A policeman found a man sittiug on the front steps of the building in which O'Donovan Rossa's office is located, at 5:30 o'clock last evening. The man seemed to be badly hurt.

MERIDEN, Dec. 23.--Carl Dreyer, a Norwegian, living in Meriden, became despondent to-day and threw himself under the wheels of an express train on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad.

The Tammany Hall men of the Sixth Assembly District nominated Philip Kiernan for Assemblyman last evening, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of William Hall, Kiernan is the present Warden of Ludlow-Street Jail.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 23.--Aaron Shaw and his wife lived together for many years at a small place called Crane's Nest, about eight miles from Owego. During the past few years much unpleasantness existed between the couple, and on Oct. 2 last Mrs. Shaw left her ...

To the student of ethnology few things are more interesting than the different views held by the Eastern and the Western worlds on the subject of corpulence. In China corpulence is considered to be one of the most important qualifications for the holding of any public office.
Charles Koeble, a letter carrier in Jersey City, was bitten in the leg by a Siberian bloodhound in a liquor saloon yesterday. He immediately went to a physician and had the wound cauterized.

MICHAEL DAVITT is not so shrewd a politician as some other Irishmen, but there is no other Irishman who by singleminded devotion to the cause of his country has better earned the right to speak for Ireland.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec 23.--The case against Edward McGhee, of Concordia, Miss., who shot and killed Miss Jessie Clark at McKenzie last week, has been dismissed, and McGhee has returned home.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23.--Charles Hare, a wood carver, 19 years old, met a couple of friends in the street this evening, and, showing them a revolver, said that he was after blood.
LEARY, Ga., Dec. 23.--The case against the colored Kuklux, Allen Yancey and Abe Blocker, has resulted in the conviction of both for murder and their sentence to lifelong imprisonment.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 23.--Mrs. E.E. Riley, the woman who a few years ago made herself famous by visiting all the large cities in America looking for the Grand Duke Alexis, whom she claimed to be her husband, died today at New-Castle, Ky.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 23.--A meeting of stockholders in the Sampson Mine, located at Silverton, Col., was held in this city to-day for the purpose of devising some plan of getting the mine out of its present financial straits.
The President will spend Christmas Day quietly at the White House. He will have no company, but will eat his Christmas dinner with Miss Cleveland.

There is a society in this city known for its good works. It has well paid agents. Some of them are very well paid. A few years ago one of this class was regarded as almost useless, and there was talk of discharging him.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23.--Mr. James C. Flood to-day made a Christmas donation of $6,000 to the various charitable institutions of this city.
MONTREAL, Dec. 23.--The coopers employed at the barrel and keg factory of D. Campbell Son have struck work on account of a dispute as to the introduction of a new system of regulating wages.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 23.--Ten days ago George V. Korell, a carriage manufacturer of No. 92 York-street, this city, and his two children began to eat from a raw ham.

PARIS, Dec. 9.--It is without any attempt at analysis and with still less pretension to criticism that I shall endeavor to give some idea of the final rehearsal, the repetition generale of Sardou's latest creation, "Georgette."

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec 23.--Charles Palmer, of Middletown, a West Shore brakeman, while attempting to board the caboose of a freight train at Amsterdam this morning, slipped from the steps, and, falling on his head, was instantly killed. He was 30 years old and unmarried.

GREENVILLE, Ga., Dec. 23.--Chuck McLendon shot and killed his father-in-law, Rufus Johnson, to-day. McLendon had been living with Johnson and was preparing to move away when Johnson accused him of having stolen something from him.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23.--The news that Fred Dunlap, the king pin of second basemen, had been released from the St. Louis League team to the Philadelphia League club, created a genuine sensation here to-day.

Christmas greens and bunting decorated the main assembly room of the Primary Department of Grammar School No. 76, at Lexingtonavenue and Sixty-eighth-street, yesterday morning.

The unavowed motive of those Republican Senators--we trust they are few in number--who are opposed to the confirmation of Mr. EATON'S nomination as Civil Service Commissioner may be easily conjectured, and it is a motive which does no credit to their honesty or their patriotism.

The lobbies in the Post Office were crowded yesterday with persons sending away Christmas packages. Superintendent Richards, of the City Delivery Department, made a tour of the branch stations in the morning, and found them all crowded with work.

Two hundred olive-skinned children from 10 to 15 years of age, whose nativity could not be a matter of doubt, sat in rows in a long room at the West Side Italian School, No. 24 Sullivan-street, last evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23.--Major R.S. Vickey, Surgeon, has been relieved from duty in the Department of the Columbia and ordered to repair to Washington and report to the Surgeon-General for duty in connection with the Army and Navy Hospital at Hot Springs, Ark.

The struggle for existence which not infrequently brings out a man's best qualities and makes him rise to a position which, under ordinary circumstances, he would never have reached, offers also a splendid opportunity to rogues and rascals to make use of their distinguishing qualities and to display, in their peculiar way, their savoir vivre.

The Young Men's Republican Club met last evening, and after considerable debate passed, by a vote of 36 to 13, a constitutional amendment raising the yearly dues from $5 to $25. Fifteen new members were elected.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 23.--Peter Yager, who was detained in jail here as a witness in a trifling criminal case, was found unconscious this morning and died shortly after. Death was caused by an overdose of morphine, taken as a remedy for the evil effects resulting from the excessive use of liquor.
COSHOCTON, Ohio, Dec. 23.--The Coshocton Iron and Steel Works have shut down, throwing about 100 men out of employment. The cause given is the inability to do work at the prevailing prices.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23.--A great deal of interest is manifested in this city in the coming annual election of the Reading Railroad Company. It is generally believed that Mr. Gowan will succeed in his canvass for the Presidency, but it is not so patent that he will be appointed a Receiver of the company.
Mr. Kellar has passed his hundreth night at the Comedy Theatre, and his entertainments still hold the public favor.

John M. Young clipped two articles from daily newspapers in this city implying that his reappraisement of L. Lehmann's Bohemian glassware was not honorable and equitable, and sent them to Secretary Manning, with a request for an investigation.

Officer Michael J. Connell, of the Fourth Police Precinct, yesterday afternoon arraigned John Fricke, of No. 421 West Sixteenth-street, the driver of a soda water wagon, in the Tombs Police Court, and charged him with having run over and killed a woman at Oliver and Cherry streets.
HILLSBORO, Ill., Dec. 23.--Wolves have appeared in this vicinity in large numbers and are playing havoc with the sheep.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 23.--This evening a cave-in occurred at Fairmount Colliery, near Pittston, operated by A. Norris Co. An area of about an acre was affected, settling a distance of several feet.

OTTAWA, Dec. 23.--The Government has wired instructions to all Inspectors and Commissioners under the Dominion license act to cease all attempts to enforce the act as it is now a dead letter. The Provincial Government alone now issue liquor licenses.
LONDON, Dec. 12.--It is propably unprecedented in the Parliamentary history of any country that five brothers, all under 50 years of age, should simultaneously sit among its lawmakers.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 23.--Representatives of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad were bidders at the State tax sale to-day for lands in Richmond County.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23.--Slosson and Schaefer played balk line billiards at Central Music Hall this evening, in what was termed the last of the scheduled tie games, to decide the tournament held here a few weeks ago. That Schaefer won the game excited no particular surprise, and that the series is to be continued on three nights longer excites none.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22.--Sam Jones and Sam Small, the evangelists, closed their campaign here this morning. It would be superfluous to speculate as to whether Jones's work here was a failure or not. He has admitted that it was repeatedly in the last 10 days, and those who know the man know that he would not make such a confession unless he believed it.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 23.--At 9 o'clock this morning about 75 masked strikers appeared at W.H. Brown Sons' Old Eagle Mines, near Monongahela City, halted the workmen as they approached the mines, and compelled them under fire to retreat. The rioters seemed more desperate than on any previous occasion.

Augustus Watts, mate of the ship Alfred Watts, now lying off Erie Basin, was arrested in in Brooklyn, yesterday, by United States Deputy Marshalls Biggart and Bradley on complaint of two sailors named Thorstein and Svansen, who charged him with assault on the high seas.

READING, Penn., Dec. 23.--At an early hour this morning Daniel and Jacob W. Himes, masons, with Frank Lessig, a helper, were driving along the Reading Turnpike, one mile west of Pottstown, on their way to work.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Dec. 23.--A tramp yesterday stole a ride on a freight train near this place, and had in his possession a good revolver. While fooling with the weapon it was accidentally discharged, and the man was seriously wounded in the stomach.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24.--Among the diplomatic dispatches recently sent to Congress by the President was one from Mr. Charles B. Trail, Secretary of Legation at Rio de Janeiro, giving a brief history of the emancipation movement in Brazil and a statement of the work accomplished and of the present aspect of the slavery question.

DUBLIN, Dec. 24.--William Sheehan, who was convicted on the 19th inst. of having murdered his mother, his brother Thomas, and his sister Mary, at Castletownroche, near Cork, in 1877, has made a full confession of his crime.

PANAMA, Dec. 16.--Rafael Aizpuru, the leader in the recent revolutionary movement in Panama, has been tried and convicted by a court martial at Bogota, the capital of the republic, and sentenced to be exiled for 10 years, to pay the expenses of the court, to be deprived of all political rights during the period of his exile and to make compensation for the losses and damages sustained during the revolution.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 24.--A special from Springer, New-Mexico, to the Republican says: "Six masked men rode into Springer last night, and, after taking the keys of the jail from the jailer, took therefrom Theodore Baker, charged with murdering Frauk Unruh, a wealthy ranchman, with whose wife Baker is supposed to have been intimate, and handed him to a telegraph pole near the jail.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24.--In the game of balk line billiards this evening between Schaefer and Vignaux the former ran his points in 3 hours and 45 minutes, coming out 129 points ahead of the Frenchman. Only about 300 persons gathered at the hall to see the contest.

SACO, Me., Dec. 27.--The schooner Silver Spray, of Rockland, Capt. F.E. Robinson, lies near Biddeford Pool with her cargo of lime on fire. She has been cleared of rigging and deckload, and the crew are at work trying to save the cargo, but the flames will probably break through the vessel's sides, and she will then be a total loss. Negligence is reported on the part of the employes of the life-saving station.

DES MOINES, Dec. 27.--William West, chief distributing clerk in the Des Moines Post Office, was arrested here to-day. Early in November two registered letters containing large sums of money were rifled and their contents abstracted.

Burglars entered the house of Thomas Gallagher, No. 9 Crittenden-street, Newark, N. J., Saturday night, and stole diamonds and other jewelry valued at $700. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 27.--Mrs. James Hunt, of Ridgefield, Conn., has been visiting in this city for some days. To-night she went with a friend to Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church. As she entered the building she complained of feeling unwell, and died before a doctor could be summoned. Heart disease caused her death. She was 50 years old.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27.--At the Convent of the Sacred Heart the solemn ceremonies attendant upon the admission of 13 young ladies to that institution were performed to-day. Of this number three took the last solemn vows, from which they can never be released, four took the first vows, and six were admitted as novices.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27.--John Davis, an old duck hunter, attempted to cross the frozen surface of the Calumet River, near Hammond, Ind., last Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27, 1885. Mr. Bigelow's letter to the President declining to accept the office of Assistant United States Treasurer at New-York will not be given out for publication at present. Col. Lamont said to-night: "Mr. Bigelow's declination is solely because of his disinclination to assume the great responsibilities of the office and its duties being not congenial to his tastes."

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27.--A number of the holders of the first mortgage land grant bonds of the Texas and St. Louis Railroad held a conference here yesterday afternoon to devise means to have certain land certificates extended beyond the time specified on their face.

The steamship City of Savannah, of the Savannah Line, which was due here on Saturday, did not arrive until yesterday afternoon. Capt. Daggett reported that while coming up the coast he encountered the severest weather which he has seen in years.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 27.--John N. Barker, of the Soldiers' Home, late of the Third Iowa Artillery, was found dead at a saloon in the western part of the city to-day. When he came to the city he had about $200 in his possession. Only 50 cents was found on his person. The neighborhood is full of low dives, and it is supposed that he was first robbed and then dosed with poisoned whisky.

The body of James Shields, aged 46, was found yesterday in Newtown Creek, near the Blissville Bridge. Shields lived with his wife and three children on First-street, near North Tenth, Williamsburg.

The mail express train out of Boston known as the "owl train," due in this city at 6:25 o'clock yesterday morning, was running at a high rate of speed when it approached Pelhamville Station, 15 miles out from New-York, on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 27.--Last Summer the Western Steel Company, composed of Youngstown and Cleveland capitalists, leased the Vulcan Steel Works at St. Louis, paying an annual rent of $50,000. The mill had been idle a long time, and the purpose of the new company was ...
Mrs. James Brown Potter and Mr. E.F. Coward will join with other New-York amateurs in giving a comedy called "The Old Love and the New," in the Brooklyn Athenaeum on Jan. 22.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 27.--The first cremation in Buffalo took place this morning at the new temple of the cremation company. The furnace is of the Veinni pattern, the first one of its kind ever erected in this country. The body used was that of a woman weighing 98 pounds.

HARPER'S FERRY, West Va., Dec. 27.-- Active preparations are being made by the syndicate which lately purchased the old Government gun factory and armory at this point to erect large manufacturing establishments as soon as Spring opens.

BLOOMING GROVE, Dec. 27.--In the Winter of 1825 Pliny Shaffer, who lived in the Drinker Beech, near the headwaters of a branch of the Lehigh River, went home one night after being at a shooting match all day. He had been drinking.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27.--The report of an explosion was heard early this morning by the officer doing duty at the lower end of Broadway, and though he was unable to determine whence it proceeded he soon after saw three men moving through an alley in a suspicious manner.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 27.--The one hundredth anniversary of Lodge No. 45, Free and Accepted Masons, the oldest body of the fraternity west of the mountains, was celebrated to-day with religious services at Trinity Episcopal Church.

WABASH, Ind., Dec. 27.--The Rev. E.E. Green, of the Lutheran Church at New-Manchester, has received intelligence that he is one of the heirs of the Mercer estate in New-York City, and will obtain as his portion $500,000.

The funeral services over the body of Capt. John Sampson, the veteran watchman and detective of the Stock Exchange, who died on Thursday, were held yesterday afternoon at his residence, No. 312 East Twenty-sixth-street, preparatory to the interment at Goshen, N.Y.

Much enthusiasm and an abundance of good nature prevailed at the meeting of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Subcommittee on Subscriptions which was held in the Hoffman House last night.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 28.--A.C. J.C. March, engaged in the saddle and harness business, made an assignment to-day for the benefit of their creditors. No schedule of their liabilities and assets was filed. They have creditors in New-York, Louisville, and Philadelphia.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 28.--Thomas R. Earl, a prominent merchant of Turner's, on Saturday evening while walking alongside of his horse and wagon was thrown from his feet by getting entangled in the lines, and was dragged along the ground for some distance.

Santa Claus came late this year to the 700 little inmates of the New-York Foundling Asylum, but when he presented himself at the Christmas festival yesterday afternoon he was more richly laden than usual with the gifts most precious to children.

The saloons in the Sixth Assembly District did a thriving-business last evening, and all on account of the special election that is to take place to-day in the district to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Assemblyman-elect William Hall.

BULLVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 28.--Two men named McCarty were taking up a water pipe leading from a spring on the Mills farm, near here, a few days ago, and found two small subterranean chambers, in one of which were 35 black, milk, and garter snakes, and in the other 30 more. They were rolled and twisted together in big bunches, and were torpid.

ASHFORD, N.Y., Dec. 28.--One Saturday some railroad laborers while in the woods a few miles from this place split a large hollow log to get some dry kindling. As the log fell apart the skeleton of a man was revealed lying in the hollow.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 28.--The Buckeye Glass Works at Martin's Ferry, Ohio, which has been idle since last Summer on account of the strike, to-day accepted a modified proposition concerning the basis of wages offered by the employes, and preparations for starting were begun at once.
The Westchester County Grand Jury reconvened yesterday at White Plains, and the first business was to take up the charges of forgery against J.F.D. Crane, the missing County Clerk.

The will of Jonas Strauss has been filed for probate in the Surrogate's office. According to its provisions the sum of $500,000 is given to the Executors to invest in United States securities for the use of his wife, Sophia, during her life.

Sheriff-elect Hugh J. Grant told a TIMES reporter yesterday that he would announce the list of appointments in his office either to-day or to-morrow. Although he did not see fit to make the formal announcement, it was no secret....

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 28.--Frank Neel presided at the miners' meeting at Alliquippa to-day. The meeting numbered about 400 miners. A.C. Rankin, formerly Master Workman of the Knights of Labor for the Pittsburg district, addressed the miners in a neutral speech.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 28.--Affairs in the polish quarter of the city have greatly quieted down since Saturday night. A strong force of police actively patrolled the region all day yesterday. Thousands of people flocked thither from all parts of the city.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--On Sunday night, Dec. 20, unknown thieves entered St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church, at State and Fortyfirst streets, and stripped the place of its contents.
The tie game between the Continental and Riverside Football Clubs was played off in the Olympian Rink last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--Mrs. Della Benner, the widow of the gallant officer who sacrificed his life while endeavoring to relieve the yellow fever sufferers of the lower Mississippi River several years ago, was to-day appointed Postmaster of the village of Rodger's Park, in the township of Evanston, this county, where she has resided ever since the death of her husband.
LONDON, Dec. 28.--The Government is preparing an important scheme of local government for the whole kingdom.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28.--A shocking case of supposed child murder was brought to light to-day. The police were yesterday morning informed of the mysterious death of an infant at No. 142 West York-street.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 28.--Peter B. Howell, supervising architect at the Reformatory, was killed this afternoon while riding on the freight elevator. He had reached the top floor and attempted to step off before the elevator had stopped, when he was caught between the floor and the carriage. His body was cut almost in two and dropped 40 feet. Mr. Howell was widely known as an architect and builder.

We are requested by Lord Tennyson to inform his correspondents, through the Times, that he is wholly unable to answer the innumerable letters which he daily receives, nor can he undertake to return or criticise the manuscripts sent to him.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--The attention of O. W. Potter, President of the North Chicago Rolling Mills, was called to-day to the following paragaph from a recent issue in the Manchester (England) Guardian, which has been going the rounds of the press:

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--The 125 men and boys employed in the box department of Maxwell Brothers's large factory in Loomis-street went out on a strike this morning. The cause of the strike is the introduction of six new nailing machines in the box factory.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 28.--A Chinese baby, the first ever born in Philadelphia, has been added to the Chinese colony of this city. It all happened last night, and Joe James, the Chinese merchant on Eleventh-street, near Walnut, is the happy father.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 28.--The employes of both of the glass works here received orders from President Cline, of the National Glass Blowers' Association, on Saturday, to discontinue work at the end of the blowing to-day because of a misunderstanding between the association and the manufacturers relative to rates. The order was obeyed. One hundred and fifty men are deprived of employment here.

George N. Bliss sued in the Court of Common Pleas for an absolute divorce from Hattle W. Bliss. She denied his allegations and made a countercharge of infidelity against him. At the Chambers of the court she got an order allowing her $100 a month as alimony and a counsel fee of $250.
The audience in the Criterion Theatre in Brooklyn, where Miss Minnie Maddern is playing in "In Spite of All," was somewhat startled last evening.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--The Illinois Central Railroad Company to-day filed a bill in the United States Circuit Court here against the Chicago, Burlington and Northern Railroad Company, in which it seeks an injunction to restrain the latter company from prosecuting certain condemnation proceedings begun in the Jo Daviess County Court.

LONDON, Dec. 29.--Miss Minnie Palmer opened an engagement at the Strand Theatre last evening, appearing in "My Sweetheart." The verdict of the critics is that she has improved. The novelties introduced in the play were successful.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 28.--A few years ago the Hon. Adam "Crooks, who died to-day in a private insane asylum at Hartford, Conn., held the position of Minister of Education in the Ontario Government, and had before him, probably, the brightest career of any politician in Canada.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 28.--Both branches of the City Councils to-day adopted resolutions directing the chief of the Electrical Department to suspend action until further orders from Councils on the ordinance instructing him to take down on Jan. 1 all overhead telegraph and telphone wires.
ARIEL, Penn., Dec. 28.--It is very rare that a raccoon falls a victim to the hunter after cold weather has set in, for it is a hibernating animal, and stows itself away on the approach of Winter.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--The following figures taken from a statement compiled by the Secretary of the Board of Trade, to be posted on Change to-morrow, show the amount of grain...

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 28.--A scheme for transferring the Indians of the Canadian Northwest back to the control of the Hudson's Bay Company, by whom they were governed previous to the purchase of the Territory by Canada, has been submitted to the Dominion Government.

PARIS, Dec. 28.--Francois Jules P. Grevy was re-elected President of the French Republic at Versailles to-day by the joint vote of the Senate and Chamber of Deputies acting as a National Assembly. The balloting was carried on amid great excitement. Only five members of the Right cast ballots.

The Board of Coroners met yesterday and organized for the ensuing year. On Saturday last they held a meeting and failed to do anything for the reason that both Coroners Levy and Messomer wanted to be elected Chairman. As each had a follower in the board the result was a deadlock.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28.--The committees of the Lehigh and Schuylkill Coal Exchanges met to-day and decided to make no changes in the present line and city and harbor prices of coal during January.

The steamship Gellert, from Hamburg, arrived off the bar at 9:30 o'clock last night with 207 passengers. She reported having met with much fog in the North Sea and English Channel and variable winds to the Banks of Newfoundland, followed by heavy gales and high seas. At 11 o'clock on Sunday morning she fell in with the schooner Ivanhoe, of Gloucester, in distress, and rescued 117 men who were on board that vessel.

The feeling among the members of the Chamber of Commerce in regard to the probable closing of the Nautical School is growing, and to-day's hearing before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment will probably be enlivened by some very vigorous speeches by the delegation from the Chamber against the reduction of the appropriation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28.--Mr. Lawrence Barrett produced at the Chestnut-Street Opera House to-night an English version of Victor Hugo's famous romantic tragedy called "Hernani," acting in it himself the character of the Spanish outlaw.
ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Dec. 28.--A dispatch from Flagg's Cove, Grand Manan, gives the particulars of the disasters in Saturday's storm.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 28.--Around the Christmas tree in John Dimmerling's house there was a quantity of cotton batting. One of the children, while playing with matches to-day, ignited the cotton, and in a moment the tree was in a blaze. Mrs. Dimmerling, in attempting to save the children and extinguish the flames, set fire to her clothing and was seriously, if not fatally, burned.
When the little pine shutter of the American opera box office in the Academy of Music was opened by the ticket seller at 9 o'clock yesterday morning there was a waiting line of about 50 persons.

PARIS, Dec. 28.--In the cases of the four Nowark children who are under treatment by M. Pasteur things are not going with all the smoothness that could be desired. Dr. Billings has moved three of the lads from their lodgings, near M. Pasteur's laboratory, to his own hotel,...
James Moore was found dead in his bed at his boarding house, No. 153 Mulberrystreet, Newark, yesterday afternoon. He went home drunk Sunday morning and locked himself in his room.

Valentine Dreisch had lived for some time at No. 597 Courtlandt-avenue, Harlem, with his wife and daughter. Six months ago he was taken sick. Prior to that time he worked as a laborer at Mott's foundry.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 28.--John Murray, a young man 19 years old, an employe in Thomas Cody's brick yard, at Montowese, a town five miles from this city, committed suicide to-day. He was found hanging in a barn this afternoon, and had evidently been dead for some hours. Disappointed love is supposed to have caused the act.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 28.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20 cents. Drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25 cents.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--The General Managers of the lines in the Colorado Railway Association have directed their General Passenger and Ticket Agents to issue a circular, calling the attention of their eastern connections to the demoralization resulting from paying commissions to ticket brokers, and asking that in the territory of the association.
At the annual meeting of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad Company, yesterday, over two-thirds of the entire capital stock was represented.
At its meeting in Hartford, Conn., in May last, the American Congress of Churches received an invitation to hold its next annual meeting--that of the Spring of 1886--in St. Louis.

Watson and McDowell and their company of comedians entered upon a week's engagement at the Harlem Theatre Comique last evening, and were seen in their musical absurdity entitled "Wrinkles." For two hours and a half the merriment was almost continuous.

To judge by the appearance of the French papers for the last few weeks an election of President of the republic is of less public interest than the injury to the Pont Neuf or the production of DAUDET'S indescribable play of "Sapho."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 28.--A man named Kelley, a weaver in the Hebronville mills, was found frozen to death this morning beside a stone wall in what is known as the "Read and Ide" neighborhood, Attleborough. He had been discharged from the Taunton jail on Saturday, having served a sentence for drunkenness.

An advertisement in a New-York paper yesterday offered a reward of $1,500 for the recovery of three bonds of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company, Denver Extension, numbered, respectively, 1,806, 2,249, 3,058.

The body of the man who shot himself in a gunshop on York-street, Jersey City, Saturday night, was identified yesterday as that of Daniel H. Hunt a native of Manitoba. Just before he killed himself he set a pawn ticket ablaze and threw it on the floor.

The steamship Merrimack, of the Brazilian Mail Line, which arrived yesterday from Rio Janeiro, had a very stormy experience, in which she sustained some damage. On the night of Dec. 20, a few hours after the Merrimack...
Assistant Corporation Counsel Francis M. Scott closed his case in the Excise Board investigation yesterday.
The advertised sale of the personal property of the Western Union Telegraph Company to satisfy the State's claim for unpaid taxes did not take place yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 28.--It is stated here that Russia and Austria are secretly arming, and that both countries have sent orders to England for large quantities of stores for their respective armies.

Pilot boat Edward Cooper, No. 20, reports having boarded the Danish steamship Island, from Copenhagen, for New-York, 40 miles south by east from Sandy Hook. The steamer was disabled, having lost her rudder during heavy weather in longitude 68 . Two tugs have been sent to her assistance.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 28.--While suffering from an attack of mental aberration, caused by anxiety about her mother's sickness, Mrs. Lizzie Sheppard drowned herself in the North Plainfield Creek between 6 and 7 o'clock this morning.

Mr. Gus Williams appeared at the Grand Opera House last evening in the new farcical piece with which he has lately delighted rural audiences. "Oh! What a Night!" is the title of the play, and its author is Mr. George Hoey.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 28.--It is rumored that Mr. S.N.D. North, managing editor of the Utica Herald, will succeed Prof. Lewis Boss as editor of the morning Express on Jan. 1. Prof. Boss, who is Director of the Dudley Observatory, will continue in charge of the Sunday edition of the Express.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Dec. 28.--Another bloody affray occurred in the Cherokee Nation yesterday, in which George Hiles was brutally murdered by Dave Mize and Joe Hunter.

Mrs. Cornelia M. Stewart, widow of A. T. Stewart, has been sued by her former architect connected with the Garden City Cathedral, who wishes to recover $95,732 12 with interest, money claimed to be due him for professional...

MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 28.--On Friday week, at Gainstown, Clark County, a young lady named Carrie Boyer, 17 years old, was waylaid while on her way home from a neighbor's. She was found dying with a bullet hole in the back of her neck and with her skull crushed in.

Bernard Schrendek walked into the Fourth Precinct Station House, Brooklyn, last evening and told the Sergeant that he had just stabbed a man, and wanted to surrender himself. When questioned he said he was 30 years of age, and lived with his wife and family on the second floor of No. 26 Flushing-avenue.
H.B. McKay, United States Consul at Teneriffe, sent $25 to the Grant Monument Association yesterday. In a letter in which the contribution was inclosed he wrote:

WAY CROSS, Ga., Dec. 28.--Edward Brown, in Clinch County, danced himself to death Christmas night. Beginning at 8 o'clock in the evening he danced in every set until o'clock next morning, when he was carried of the floor in a de flitated condition. He died from the effects yesterday.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 28.--The AdjutantGeneral of Ilinois to-day issued an order consolidating the Fifth, Seventh, Eighth, and Ninth Regiments of the Illinois National Guard into two regiments of 12 companies, or three battalions, in accordance with the amended State Military Code.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Dec. 28.--At Shamokin last nigth two large houses were destroyed by a fire caused by the explosion of a kerosene lamp in the hands of Mrs. John Bernaski, a tenant, who was fatally burned.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28.--The leave of Post Chaplain George W. Simpson, United States Army, has been further extended one month for disability.
BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 28.--The trial of H. K. Goodwin, of Lawrence, for the murder of Albert D. Swan in the latter's office in August last, was begun in Salem to-day.

Charles B. Ransom, one of the last of what may be termed the old school of sporting men, died yesterday at 9:20 A.M. at his residence, No. 11 West Twenty-fifth-street, of lung disease and diabetes.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 28.--Controller Chapin is playing a pretty fine point in politics for himself. The bids for the State printing were recently opened by the Controller and Secretary of State Carr, and it was found that the lowest bidders on the entire list were Weed, Parsons Co., of this city.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 28.--The State tax sale will be concluded to-morrow, when lands in all the counties between St. Lawrence and Yates will be sold. St. Lawrence, Seneca, and Saratoga were under the hammer to-day.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Dec. 28.--Martin Reynolds, a boy 12 years old, living in Girard, Ala., was horribly burned by the explosion of a kerosene can yesterday.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 28.--The Boston Chamber of Commerce to-day adopted resolutions favoring the appointment of Commissioners, both for the settlement of fishing rights and for the negotiation of an equitable treaty of reciprocity with the Dominion of Canada and the Province of Newfoundland to the end that profitable trade relations may be established,...

There was no little rejoicing at the office of the Morgan Railway yesterday upon the announcement being made that the steamship El Dorado, of the Morgan Line, just arrived, had beaten the Louisiana's fast time, made between New-York and this city in November last.

Police Justice Maurice J. Power had gone through many cases, in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, when an attractive little lady dressed in black walked up to the bar and tremulously asked for a warrant of arrest against Alfred Wotton.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 28.--A general impression prevailed hereabout that when the Susquehanna Coal Company gave up the idea of sinking a shaft over No. 2 slope at Nanticoke no further attempt would be made to look for the bodies of the victims of the recent disaster.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 28.--The special train containing the party of journalistic excursionists from Washington and Chicago arrived over the Illinois Central Railroad this morning. Four Pullman sleepers were occupied by the prrty.

A committee of stockholders of the Beech Creek Railroad Company, which was appointed to conduct the reorganization of that company, met in the offices of the New-York Central Railroad, in the Grand Central Station, yesterday.
John Post and John Churchill, both residents of Pamrapo, N.J., were driving down Fulton-street toward the East River yesterday afternoon.

MILL VILLAGE, Penn., Dec. 28.--Martin McKay, of this village, was passing some workmen who were digging a ditch along the railroad just as one of them threw a shovelful of earth and stones from the excavation from a depth of 6 feet.

Dr. John C. Peters reported to the County Medical Society last evening the conclusions of the Committee of Hygiene upon the conferences lately held with the Taxpayers' Associations in regard to the Quaker Bridge Dam project.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 28.--Morehead (Ky.) had another tragedy this afternoon, Moses Little, one of the notorious Little brothers, shooting and killing John Marlow, a resident of that place. The quarrel was about an old grudge. Both had been drinking.
The returns from Sunday's hospital collection in the churches warrant the conclusion that it was an unusual success.
LONDON, Dec. 29.--The Daily News publishes a letter from Antananarivo, the capital of Madagascar, giving an account of a French attack upon the Hovas on Sept. 10 outside of Tamatav.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Dec. 28.--Gas from a main pipe gained access to the cellars on Princess-street, last night, through an old drain, and many persons were seriously affected. A man named Sharpe and his wife were unconscious all day. The man died to-night, and the woman is in a critical condition. Others who were affected are out of danger.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--The Congregational ministers invited August Spies, a local Socialist, to attend their weekly meeting to-day and tell them in a few words what Socialists believed. Spies was present and among other things said that it was natural that Socialism should break with Christianity for it was based on a materialistic foundation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28.--Erastus Wiman, who purchased the franchise of the Metroplitan Baseball Club of New-York, clinched his recent victory in the courts over the American Association to-night. The Mets were admitted to full membership with all the rights and privileges appertaining thereto.
For some years the office of Sheriff of this county has been in the hands of a politician of the Irving Hall variety.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 28.--While passing through a piece of woods Sunday in the township of Yankee Springs, Barry County; in the western part of the State, a resident of the neighborhood found the badly decomposed body of a man lying on the ground.
The New-York City Church Extension and Missionary Society held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the Methodist Book Concern, No. 805 Broadway. Gen. Clinton B. Fisk presided.

BOSTON, Dec. 23.--Edwin Booth opened his engagement to-night at the Boston Museum with the first production for many years of John Howard Payne's drama, "Brutus," before in enthusiastic audience of moderate size.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28.--The jury to-day in the Circuit Court, in the suit of Frank Springman, brought by his father and next friend, James Springman, against the Baltimore and Potomac Railroad Company, gave the plaintiff a verdict for $12,000. The boy was struck by a railroad car in July, 1883, and made a cripple for life. The amount of damages originally claimed was $50,000.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 28.--The office of Superintendent of Insurance was formally vacated to-night. A new Superintendent was appointed by Gov. Hill, a new Deputy was chosen, and the two men will be sworn in tomorrow, and will begin the discharge of their duties on the 1st day of January. Superintendent McCall, in his letter of resignation, explains the cause of his action. Here is the letter:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28.--The few misguided persons who still imagine that President Cleveland is not in sympathy with the friends of civil service reform, and the many disgruntled office seekers who wish the Administration was hostile to the merit system, will derive little satisfaction in a number of modifications of the civil service rules which have been approved and promulgated by Mr. Cleveland.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 28.--Benjamin Kaye Heaton, a graduate of Yale College in the Class of '85 and a member of the Junior Class of the Yale Law School, died in his room in the old laboratory, on the college campus, this morning. His physicians attribute his death to overwork.

A physician informed Dr. James B. Taylor, of the Health Department, yesterday, that he had been called to attend a case of smallpox in the tenement house No. 898 Third-avenue. Dr. Conant made an investigation, and discovered two cases in the same family, which had been concealed from the health authorities.

The grounds of the Staten Island Athletic Club, at West New-Brighton, have been put thoroughly in order at an expense of about $5,000. Next season a cricket eleven will be put in the field and a baseball nine organized. Many members of the Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club are joining the Athletic Club.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 28.--A crash of glass, which attracted the attention of pedestrians, at about 11:30 o'clock this morning, to the Tracy Block, on the public square, was quickly followed by the sight of a woman's body shooting downward from a third-story window to the pavement, 60 feet below.
HARRISONBURG, Va., Dec. 28.--The County Court to-day accepted the resignation of Samuel R. Sterling, the defaulting Treasurer. His successor will be appointed on Wednesday.
Dr. George Drury, of No. 195 Adamsstreet, Brooklyn, yesterday requested Coroner Menninger to make an investigation into the death of George De Milt, which occurred on Sunday night.

MR. Warren G. Abbott, of No. 222 West Twenty-third-street, the proprietor of a brewery at Meserole and Scholes streets and Bushwickavenue, Brooklyn, left his horse and light wagon standing untied in front of No. 33 South Fifthavenue at 7 o'clock last evening while he went into a saloon at that number.

Park Policeman Matthew McInerey and John J. McDonald, formerly holding the same position, claimed a private examination yesterday upon the charge of assaulting Joseph Schwarzler on the evening of Dec. 19.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 28.--W.J. Jones, one of the best known ranchmen in Arizona, arrived here on Sunday from the vicinity of the recent Indian massacres. In an interview Mr. Jones says that the situation in Western NewMexico and Eastern Arizona is really much worse than has been reported by the newspapers.

The Congressional party which goes to Boston this week as the guests of the Boston Merchants' Association includes Senators Edmunds, Evarts, Allison, Morgan, and Voorhees, and Representatives Randall, Holman, Tucker, Butterworth, Reagan, McKinley, Findlay, Willis, Hepburn, and Goff, Speaker Carlisle....

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--There is likely to be a serious conflict among the roads running east from this city regarding the differential rate made by the Chicago and Grand Trunk on passenger traffic to Boston by way of Montreal.

A letter written in German, and dated Dec. 27, was received by mail at the Police Central Office yesterday morning. It was simply directed "Police Headquarters, New-York," and signed "Peter Dollwet, of No. 1,434 North Fourteenth-street, St. Louis, Mo."

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 28.--The first meeting of the Southern Passenger Agents' Association, which succeeds the old organization, met here this morning at 9 o'clock and again at 3 this afternoon, and, lacking a ...
There were a good many visitors yesterday to the scene of the railroad accident at Pelhamville, on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, on Sunday morning.
A member of the editorial staff of the Springfield Republican who has been traveling in Mexico sends the following letter to his paper:
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 28.--Theodore H. Boyce, who was sentenced to Sing Sing State Prison for life for killing Frederick W. De Garmo, of Dover Plains, was conveyed thither to-day.
BOSTON, Dec. 28.--The comet announced last night as discovered by Prof. Brooks was independently discovered by Prof. Barnard at Nashville.

One of the self-dumping scows belonging to the New-York Street-Cleaning Department, which, together with another making up the tow of the tug Desury, was lost at sea during the storm of Saturday, was towed into the Atlantic Dock, Brooklyn, on Sunday evening by the tug Luther C. Ward, Capt. Chase.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 28.--Pursuant to instructions from the Secretary of War, orders were issued yesterday to troops A and K, Second Cavalry, to proceed to Arizona.
The Guild of St. Elizabeth, a society organized for charitable work in Bellevue Hospital and on Blackwell's, Ward's, and Hart's Islands, has submitted its annual report.
The trial of George H. Disque for the murder of his wife at their home, in Hoboken, on the evening of Oct. 6, was begun in Judge Knapp's court, on Jersey City Heights, yesterday morning.

The army's failure to capture or exterminate the marauding Chiricahua Apaches, or even to prevent the murder of settlers by these savages, has almost depopulated Southeastern Arizona and Southwestern New-Mexico.

The counsel to the Gibbs investigating Committee were to have been heard by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on the departmental estimates yesterday, but Mayor Grace announced that they would not appear until to-day.

The African Methodist Episcopal Church of this city issues an appeal for $10,000, to enable it to carry on its work in New-York State, and, through its Bishop and Presiding Elders, it has authorized the Rev. T.T.B. Reed, B.A., to act as its agent in soliciting subscriptions.
CORINTH, Ky., Dec. 28.--Particulars of a fatal shooting affray, which occurred at NewColumbia Saturday evening, have just been received here.

The Board of Police Justices held their annual meeting for the assignment of Justices for the ensuing year at the Jefferson Market Police Court last evening. Justice Smith was re-elected President of the board.
Among the passengers of the Cunard steamship Servia, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, were Lord Charles Fitzmaurice, Lord Kerry, Elliott F. Shepard and family, Arthur ...

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 28.--The guilt of the murder of Richard Nelson Lawton is securely fastened on Samuel F. Besse by the discovery that George West, who had known him several months, saw him in New-Bedford at 8:45 o'clock in the morning after the murder.

There was a slight fire soon after 6 o'clock last evening on the second floor of the three-story frame tenament No. 790 East One Hundred and Forty-fifth-street, occupied by Mrs. Muller, causing a loss of $100.

GLEN ROSE, Mo., Dec., 28.--While John McClellan and Bud Stroop were playing billiards in a saloon here Thomas Cochran came in and dashed his hat on the table, thus interfering with the game and annoying the players.

The Senate gas investigation committee was engaged yesterday morning in executive session, during which it took the testimony of Gustav Kobbe in regard to editorial articles that were written for distribution among country papers through an advertising agent.

The carpenter on the Bermuda, one of the vessels of the Quebec Steamship Company, on Dec. 28, 1883, left the bars which guarded the opening on the side of the vessel resting upon, instead of being inserted in, the eyes fixed to the stanchions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--A fortnight ago a man named Wolf, who claims to be the President of the Cigarmakers' Union of San Francisco, appeared here in search of cigarmakers to go to the Pacific coast city, there to take the place of Chinese workmen.

Ralph Modjeski, the son of Mme. Modjeska and Miss Felice Benda, the niece of that lady, were married yesterday in the little Polish church of St. Stanislaus, at Stanton and Forsyth streets. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H. Klimscki, the Rector, who was assisted by Archbishop Corrigan.

Articles of incorporation of the NewYork District Railway Company were filed with the Secretary of State in Albany yesterday. The company's projectors think they have at last found a practical solution of the rapid transit problem, and their plans certainly have on their ...

OXFORD, Md., Dec. 28.--Yesterday, at the Oxford Military Academy, Richard O. Reinhard, of Indiana, was accidentally shot and killed by Patrick Gavagan, of Michigan. The boys were playing with a revolver from which Gavagan had overlooked one. The deceased was a son of Judge Reinhard, of Indiana.
A well dressed and gray-bearded old man was found wandering aimlessly in Canal-street last night.

As Mary Farrell, a girl of 17, was returning to her home, at No. 262 Water-street, Brooklyn, at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, from a ball, she was attacked by three young men at Adams and Water streets, and thrown to the ground.
PARIS, Texas, Dec. 29.--On Sunday afternoon, at a settlement known as Stockleye Prairie, 12 miles northeast of Paris, Deputy Sheriff Clay Davis was killed by a man named Garrett.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 29.--A special from Fremont, Ohio, referring to the statement recently made by a member of the Fisk University Jubilee Singers (colored) that they had been subjected to gross indignities at Fremont, the home of ex-President Hayes, says the statement is utterly false.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 29.--Mrs. Atchison, who lives west of this place, had a lively encounter with a traveling agent yesterday. Shortly after 3 P.M., while she was alone in her house, there was a knock at her door, and before opening it she asked who was there.

There was a continual rush of visitors at the headquarters of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association, in Nassau-street, yesterday, and before the closing hour came nearly $1,000 additional had been subscribed.

Hudson Kitchell, a carpenter, bought a carpet of George Beck, a furniture dealer, for $38 75, on the installment plan. After delivering the carpet, Beck sent a chattel mortgage to Kitchell to be signed, and in his absence from home it was signed by his daughter without his authority.

LONDON, Dec. 29.--In Irish affairs and in the affairs of Parliament in general big things are on foot. Lord Randolph Churchill is in Dublin to-day with Lord Justice Fitzgibbon consulting with the Orange Tories, whom six months ago he was denouncing as obstacles to the party.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 29.--Late last night two men named James Bone and William Brindley became involved in a terrible fight at Rush Run, a station on the Cleveland and Pittsburg Railroad, about eight miles north of this city. The trouble originated over the ownership of a wagonload of corn. Finally Bone seized half of a fence rail and struck Brindley on the head, killing him almost instantly.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 29.--Secretary Lamar is confined to his rooms at the Peabody Hotel, in this city, by a slight indisposition, which compels him to remain in doors, but causes him no other inconvenience.

ERIE, Penn., Dec. 29.--This city rejected the application of the Standard Oil Company for permission to bring gas here in competition with the local company. The Councils unanimously decided that the monopoly should have no further hold on Erie, as it had already inflicted great damage by shutting the 32 oil refining works which Erie had.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29.--The State tax sale which began on Dec. 10 was concluded today by the sale of lands in Warren, Westchester, and Wyoming Counties.

The following correspondence between the United Lines Telegraph Company and the Western Union throws some light upon the latter company's action in cutting down and carting away the United Lines wires on Christmas Day:

Coroner Eidman has appointed as his deputy Dr. Gustave Scholer, a graduate of the University of New-York, Medical Department, and now the chief of the Surgical Department of the West Side Dispensary. Dr. Scholer, although not an active politician, has always been a consistent Republican.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 29.--The rumor from Albany that S.N.D. North, President of the State Associated Press and managing editor of the Utica Herald, is about to become editor and one of the proprietors of the Albany Morning Express, is verified here. Mr. North takes leave of the Herald this week, and assumes the management of the Express on Monday next.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 29.--Sidney Barber and Miss Katie Woolford, daughter of Con gressman Frank Woolford, were married at Jeffersonville, Ind., to-night. The young couple ran away from their home, at Columbia, Ky., and rode 49 miles in a buggy, to Lebanon, Ky., were they took the train for Louisville. The young lady is about 19 years old.

James Rogers, watchman of the building of the Fruit and Flower Mission, opposite Bellevue Hospital, was discharged recently. Early yesterday morning he paid 15 cents for a lodging at the South Fifth-Avenue Hotel, at Bleecker-street and South Fifth-avenue, and...

The steamship Gellert, of the Hamburg Line, which arrived at Quarantine late Monday night with the rescued crew of the wrecked schooner Ivanhoe on board, came up to her dock in Hoboken yesterday morning. The shipwrecked fishermen came over to this city, and were given...
CHICAGO, Dec. 29.--A little more than two weeks ago Mr. and Mrs. Frank Westerfield, of Willmette, a suburban village, ate of pork tenderloin.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 29.--The steamer Linn O'Dee, from Boston, which arrived here this afternoon, encountered Sunday's storm, which raged with great severity, in the Bay of Fundy.

READING, Penn., Dec. 29.--At 4:30 o'clock this morning a freight engine, with a train attached, struck a bumper block lying across the rails on the Philadelphia and Reading's track, above Spruce-street.

A German saloon keeper on Third-street has a dog that is a most dissipated canine. The dog is slowly but surely drinking himself to death. He not only looks on the beer when it is amber, but risks a sight when it is stale and flat.

The drumhead of the boiler in the tugboat Niagara, belonging to Cornelius Johnson and Thomas Farrell, of No. 22 South-street, and lying at the foot of Bonne-street, Atlantic Dock, Brooklyn, was blown out by an explosion early this morning.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Dec. 29.--The inhabitants of this city were alarmed last night by an earthquake shock, the noise accompanying it resembling closely that made by the firing of artillery. No damage was done to property, although the force of the shock was distinctly felt in several large buildings.
At last there is a prospect that an honorable settlement of the dispute arising out of the disgraceful conduct of the old Venezuela Claims Commission will soon be reached.

The body of a male child was found in an outhouse at No.147 Cherry-street yesterday, and as Catherine Chesnut, a girl of 18, a tobacco stripper living on the top floor of the house with Mrs. Gill, her sister, had become suddenly ill, an investigation was ordered. The girl admitted that the child was hers, but said it had died a natural death. She was arrested and sent to Bellevue Hospital.

Many Russian ironmasters are just now making great efforts to obtain an increase of the already excessive duties which protect their industry. The Metallurgical Congress, which is at present assembled here, has resolved by a large majority to propose the absolute prohibition of foreign iron, or an enormous increase in the duty. The delegates elected a committee, to which these proposals have been submitted.
To aid the newly established babies' ward of the Postgraduate Hospital of this city a concert was given at Chickering Hall last evening.
The Treasury Department bought no silver bullion to-day, the price asked being regarded as too high.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29.--A freight train on the Chester Creek branch of the Central division of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad left the track near Lenni this morning. The engineer was killed, one brakeman was badly injured, and another brakeman and the fireman were slightly injured. The cause of the accident is believed to have been a broken rail.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--Last evening Senator Voorhees received the following letter from the President:
TRENTON, Dec. 29.--The eleventh annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Horticultural Society was begun in the Assembly Chamber at the State House at noon to-day.

HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., Dec. 29.--In a drunken brawl last night Capt. A.R. Perkins shot Col. L.A. Syphert, an ex-army officer and prominent lawyer. Both men were considerably under the influence of liquor. A dispute arose, when Syphert knocked Perkins down, whereupon the latter drew his pistol and fired, the bullet penetrating the thigh of Syphert, producing a painful wound. Perkins was held to ball in $1,000.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29.--William H. Upson, Master Commissioner of the Cleveland, Akron and Columbus Railroad, is authority for the statement that a meeting will be held in Cleveland before Friday night for the purpose of reorganizing the railroad, which, by a recent decision of the Supreme Court, has been taken out...
The sale of seats for Mme. Modjeska's peformances at the Star Theatre will begin tomorrow morning.
The programme arranged for the ninth popular concert, which took place at the Academy of Music last evening, included Mendelssohn's A major symphony, No. 4; Beethoven's...
CASTLETON, N.Y., Dec. 29.--The Hudson River is closed from Germantown Landing to Albany. It is the worst close up, icemen state, in 10 years.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 29.--Arrangements are being made in this city to amalgamate the Flint Glassworkers', the Window Glassworkers', and the Bottleblowers' Unions, Committees from the associations are now holding a series of meetings for the purpose of perfecting a basis of consolidation. It is expected that the plan will be completed within three weeks.

CHATHAM, Ill., Dec. 29.--A verdict was given in a sensational school trial at Auburn, Ill., last evening. Miss Eunice Christopher, daughter of J. M. Christopher, a farmer, has been teaching what is known as the Finley School, a short distance east of Auburn.

Dissensions of a serious nature have broken out among the congregation of St. John's German Lutheran Church, on Fairview-avenue, Jersey City Heights. Those principally concerned in the affair are the Pastor, the Rev. Gottlieb Andreas, and the members of the volunteer choir.

The art of puffing, like many other arts, is in need of the sacred poet. The advertising agents are an imitative race, like monkeys and Chinamen, and expend their energies in repeating the procedures of their predecessors.
PARIS, Dec. 29.--M. Pasteur to-day inoculated Charles Kaufmann, of Franklin, N.J., who was bitten by a supposed mad dog on Nov. 21 and sailed from New-York on the steamer Labrador on Dec. 16.
The following business was transacted at the Exchange and Auction Room yesterday Tuesday, Dec. 29:
At 1 o'clock this morning, John Harrington, of No. 135 Washington-street, struck his wife Ellen in the head with a hatchet, killing her instantly. She was 43 years old.

The Sunday school of the First Reformed Episcopal Church, at Madison-avenue and Fifty-fifth-street, held its Christmas festival last night.
READING, Penn., Dec. 29.--An eloping couple--R.G. Haight and Ida Reese--were captured at Allentown last evening, and brought to this city this morning.

BOSTON, Dec. 29.--Insanity was the plea put in to-day by the defense in the Swan murder trial Col. Sweeney, counsel for Goodwin, the accused man, gave a sketch of the life of the prisoner, in which he said that Goodwin went...
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29.--A largely attended meeting was held in the Controller's once to-day to consider the letting of contracts for legislative printing.

The police are falling into line with those who are trying to get up a hydrophobia scare. Yesterday reports were received at Police Headquarters of the killing of "mad dogs" at Forty-fourth-street and Fifth-avenue, No. 145 Cedar-street; and No. 647 Green wich-street.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 29.--A distressing accident occurred late last night at Saunders Ferry, 23 miles south of this place. James Saunders, with his wife and two small children, attempted to cross the Kentucky River in their ferry boat, and when in the middle of the stream their light blew out.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29.--A review of the iron trade of 1885 has just been prepared by James M. Swank, General Manager of the American Iron and Steel Association. The beginning of the year was marked, he says, by a continuation of the depression of 1884.

Steamship St. Laurent, (Fr.,) de Jousselin, Havre 10 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Louis de Bebian. Steamship Philadelphia, Hess, Porto Cabello, Curacoa and La Guayra 11 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Boulton, Bliss Dallott.

PHELPS, N.Y., Dec. 29.--The new comet discovered by Prof. Brooks, of Red House Observatory, on the 26th inst., was observed by Prof. Barnard, of Nashville, the following evening. The comet is now quite bright, and is visible in moderate sized telescopes.

Mrs. Mary Cordick, of No. 9 Harrisonstreet, Hoboken, has lodged a complaint with the Police Board of that city against Officer Daniel Egan. Some time ago she had a warrant issued for the arrest of her husband on the charge of abusing her.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 29.--The Democratic City Committee have adopted resolutions which are to be transmitted to the State and National Democratic Headquarters excommunicating Postmaster Nicholas Hathaway,...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--Senator Manderson and Congressmen Springer and Laird called upon the Secretary of War this morning to discuss with him the situation in Southern NewMexico in relation to the Apache troubles.
Miss Eva Moody, the eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Moody, was married last evening at the residence of her parents, No. 15...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 29.--The Hon. James E. Bailey, ex-United States Senator, died at 7:50 o'clock this morning at his home in Clarksville, Tenn., of tumor of the stomach, with which he had suffered several years.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 29.--At about 8 last evening, Mrs. Emma Tickens, residing on Camelia-street, attempted to throw herself and her two children into a well containing four feet of water. One of the children is a girl, 6 years old, and the other a boy, 4 years old.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29.--The owners of the schooner Orphan Boy long ago abandoned all hope of ever finding the missing vessel, but for the sake of the half frantic families of the crew they kept up the search.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--Major F. W. Benteen, Ninth Cavalry, is at his own request transferred to the Seventh Cavalry, vice Major Lewis Merrill, transferred from the Seventh to the Ninth Cavalry. Major Benteen will report to the commanding General of Dakota for assignment to a station.

Said one of the Western Union telegraph receivers yesterday: "Do you know that few people outside the doctors and the telegraph receivers realize how many babies are born in the world? Why, there isn't a day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--The Pension Bureau is in receipt of thousands of letters from all parts of the country indicating the existence of widespread but erroneous impression that the recent decision of the Supreme Court in the case of Mrs. Hattle A. Burnett against the United States would bring about an almost total change in the rates of pension allowed to widows of soldiers of the late war.

KINGSTON, Dec. 29.--The Kingston Building Company, which was organized about 20 years ago, decided last night to dissolve.
No fewer than 24 special trains, laden with cattle for the Christmas market, left Perth for London on Thursday and Friday, there being upward of 30 trucks to each train.

The theatrical business is unusually profitable just now in Philadelphia, although some of the theatres have not been making all the money their managers would like to make. Besides the large audience at the ChestnutStreet Opera House on Monday night to see...

Michael Harrington, a fruit vendor, of No. 80 Mulberry-street, was complainant at the Tombs Police Court yesterday against Officer John Leissner, of the Sixth Precinct, who had been arrested by his commanding officer, Capt. John McCullagh, and arraigned before Superintendent Murray, to whom the prisoner tendered...
CHICAGO, Dec. 29.--The striking boxmakers of Maxwell Brothers' factory made no demonstration of any consequence to-day, although they gathered in considerable numbers about the place.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 29.--Deputy Sheriff T.F. Wheeler, of Southford, Conn., has reported at Poughkeepsie that Charles J. Johnson, who is said to be a noted horse thief and confidence operator, has been arrested and is in jail at New-Haven.
The managers of the Produce Exchange New Year's Eve festivities propose to make the occasion a memorable one.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 29.--An Italian organ grinder came in contact with a drooping electric light wire 7 o'clock this evening of Chartres-street and was instantly killed. This is the third recent death of this character.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 29.--There appeared to be no change to-day in the situation at No. 1 Slope in Nanticoke.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 29.--Henry G. Luke and wife, James Kingman, and Charles Luch, who have been doing business here under the firm name of S. Milliman, were arrested this afternoon charged with grand larceny...
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 29.--The particulars reached this city last night of the robbery of the mail carrier between Magnolia, Columbia County, Ark., and Linden, La., early yesterday morning.

M. Gomot, the Minister of Agriculture, is so well satisfied with his visit to M. Pasteur's laboratory that he will ask the Chambers to enable him to practice inoculation against rabies on a large scale, and to treat human beings suffering from that malady in a special hospital. About 40 persons were under treatment when M. Gomot was at M. Pasteur's.
Chicago Winter horse cars are made two feet wider than those used in Summer time. The addition is to admit overshoes.--Yonkers Statesman.
