PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29.--Referring to his canvass for the Presidency of the Reading Railroad, Franklin B. Gowen said to-day: "I am confident of my election, and have been so since I entered the canvass.
It was decided by Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday that the employes of the Aqueduct Commissioners are subject to the rules of the Civil Service Commission of the city.

ALBANY, Dec. 29.--Gen. Husted is expected here to-morrow, not for the purpose of opening his headquarters, but to complete some necessary preparations for occupying the Columbia-street residence in which be and several others will reside during the session. Mr. Erwin is expected the day after.
Washington Tailor (taking measure for trousers)--Thirty-eight--twelve--nine a quarter --seven a half--welt on side--spring bottoms--one hip pocket--there you are, Sir. What name, please?
Sheriff-elect Hugh J. Grant yesterday announced the appointment of his subordinates, substantially as printed in yesterday's TIMES.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 29.--Fred Stieg and John Fisher were arrested yesterday afternoon at a place called Seven Mile, near Hamilton, and taken to New-Baltimore, charged with the killing of Philip Lewis in Erven's saloon last Saturday.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 29.--It became known here yesterday that a bold attempt was made on the night of the 23d inst. to blow up the bridge of the Southern Pacific Railroad across the Rio Grande River, several miles above the city.
VINCENNES, Ind., Dec. 29.--Joseph C. Litzelman, a Newton (Ill.) contractor, has disappeared between two days, leaving behind him scores of victims, who hold nothing but his forged paper.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 29.--Gov. Rusk has granted a full pardon to George Wilson, formerly of Troy, N.Y., who, in 1865, was sent to State prison for life for the alleged murder of John Riley, a barkeeper in J.K. Groves's saloon at Milwaukee.

The annual kneip festival of Campany E, of the Seventh Regiment, was held at Thirdavenue and Sixty-fifth-street last evening. Capt. George B. Rhoads presided as Rex, and C.G. Howard took the part of the Jester.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29.--Joseph Peithiewicz, the Pole caught masquerading as a woman and shop-lifting in a State-street store yesterday, was before Justice Meech to-day.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 29.--The break in the gas mains in Kingston was much more disastrous than was at first reported. The break, when reported to the gas company, was underestimated, and no immediate steps were taken to repair it.

SHARON, Penn., Dec. 29.--The old Sharpsville furnace has just been "blown in" after lying idle for two years. The Joliet Steel Company has made a contract to take all the iron the furnace can produce, and this means a long and steady run. The Douglas furnace, in the same place, has also been put in blast.

ROME, Dec. 29.--The Pope gave audience to-day to the Bishop of Davenport, Iowa. BERLIN, Dec. 29.--Mr. Pendleton, the United States Minister, and Mrs. Pendleton gave their first reception here this evening.
THE STATE SHALL REMAIN THE OWNER. The subject of improving the Erie Canal was discussed before a well attended meeting of canal boatmen at No. 12 South-street, yesterday afternoon.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 29.--The Principals of the academies, high schools, and union schools of this State met in convention here today.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 29.--Harry Thener, aged 1 years, died at the residence of his parents yesterday. He was playing on the floor at his home on Christmas Day, and in the same room, near an open grate, was Tillie Myerstein, a servant of the family. By some means the girls clothing became ignited and she started for the door.

At a meeting of the passenger agents of the roads forming the New-York Emigrant Pool yesterday arrangements were perfected for the reconstruction of the pool.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 29.--The visiting journalists spent the forenoon in examining points of interest about the city. In the afternoon they visited the Exposition, in the art gallery of which a concert was given in their honor. In the evening they accepted Manager Bid well's invitation to his theatre. To-morrow morning they will take a trip to the jetties, and they intend to leave for home on Thursday evening.

BOSTON, Dec. 29.--Senator Dawes delivered an address this evening in Sanders's Theatre, Cambridge, before the Cambridge Indian Rights Association on the Indian question.

The annual election of the New-York Mercantile Exchange took place yesterday. There was a close contest, two tickets being in the field.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 29.--Charles Herman was to-day found guilty of murder in the first degree, the jury having been out 20 hours. He cut his wife'e throat a few weeks ago, and slept in the bed with the corpse for two nights before his discovery and arrest. He will be sentenced on Thursday.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 29.--About three weeks ago the three-masted schooner William H. Jordan, Capt. Thrasher, arrived at Somerset laden with coal. During her trip the Jordan damaged one of her bowers, and the Captain sent it away for repairs.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29.--The St. Louis League Baseball Club signed Fred Dunlap to-day. The team now includes McKinnan, (signed yesterday,) Denney and Glasscock, who were signed last week, and Dunlap. Cliff Carroll, of the Providence Club, is in St. Louis, and he will probably be signed to play at left field.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 30.--The census of Charleston City, completed to-day, shows a total population of 60,145, against 49,984 in 1880, an increase of over 20 per cent. The white population is 27,605, and the colored 32,540. The colored surplus consists mainly of children.

VIENNA, Dec. 30.--A shock of earthquake was felt here to-day, lasting seven seconds. No damage was done.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 30.--Information was received to-day of the death at Beasley's Bend of a young son of Ephriam Beasley from injuries accidentally inflicted by his father. The incoming steamships report having encountered severe weather on the ocean. The San Marcos, from Galveston, had a very stormy experience after leaving the Gulf of Mexico. Violent northwesterly gales were met, and heavy seas frequently swept over the decks.

LIMA, Dec. 30, Via Galveston, Texas.--El Commercio says that reports from the Provinces are to the effect that much enthusiasm has been evoked by Gen. NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 30.--Lieut. James M. Jones, of the Tenth United States Artillery, committed suicide by shooting, in his quarters at Fort Adams, at 9 o'clock this morning. He had been granted a week's leave some two weeks ago and did not return until last night, thereby stopping over his leave. It is supposed that he feared being tried by court-martial.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30.--Two freight trains came into collision on the Wabash line near Kinder Station, six miles out from East St. Louis, this morning, and Conductor Meredith was killed. Trains No. 1 and No. 2 were running in the same direction.

CLINTON, Mass., Jan. 1.--The Lancaster National Bank of this place closed its doors last night after a searching examination of the books by the Directors. President W.H. McNeil is missing. BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 1.--The Young Men's Christian Association of this city gave an elaborate reception to-day at their handsome building. This afternoon, while performing in the gymnasium before many visitors, Michael Friedel, aged 17, burst a blood vessel and died instantly.

A careful review of the tabulated returns made to the various Exchanges indicates that, although there is a vastly improved feeling in most business circles, the volume of trade, both in actual and speculative transactions, was less in the your dust past than during 1884.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Jan. 1.--R.H. Harris, a prominent citizen of Lee County, Ala., and a member of the Alabama Legislature in 1880, committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself. Financial trouble caused the act.

GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 1.--A collision occurred yesterday morning on the Houston and Texas Central Railway at Garrett Station, by which a passenger engine and caboose and three freight cars were damaged and set on fire. The caboose was full of passengers, most of whom sustained injuries. W.H. McGraw and the 5-year-old son of Mr. Darby, both of Dallas, were seriously hurt. The passengers were taken to Dallas, where the injured were cared for.

All the new officials of Queens County quietly took possession of their offices yesterday with the exception of A.N. Weller, who was elected last November, as supposed, to succeed Surrogate Charles De Kay Townsend.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 1.--Henry Christianson, a sailor, was taken to the New-Haven Hospital to-night, suffering from a fractured skull and concussion of the brain. His injuries were received by falling from the rigging of a schooner lying at the docks. He will probably die.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 1.--At the Exposition to-day was celebrated the anniversary of the emancipation proclamation of President Lincoln, and about 10,000 colored people participated in the exercises.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 1.--An inquest on the death of Addie Davis, of Sarnia, a beautiful young girl who committed suicide in a commercial traveler's room here last evening, was held to-day.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 1.--At Davidson College to-day a street encounter occurred between J.D. Hood, a merchant, and J.W. Summers, a lawyer, in which Hood was shot, and it is supposed fatally wounded. Hood and Summers are brothers-in-law, and quareled about the settlement of of an estate. Hood was attacking Summers with a hatchet when the latter used his pistol.

PERTH, Ontario, Jan. 1.--A man over 90 years old, named Nallen, and his aged wife, both of them helpless, were burned to death to-day in the hovel where they lived. A few bones, which were the only remains found after the fire, were removed to the lockup to await proper burial.

PALMYRA, Wis., Jan. 1.--Thomas Green, who began abstaining from food because of religious views on Dec. 16, continues fasting.

LONDON, Jan. 1.--Mr. Thomas M. Waller, the United States Consul General, gave a brilliant New Year reception at the rooms of the St. George's Club, in Hanover-square, to-day. The rooms were beautifully decorated with flags. Nearly 1,000 Americans and many society leaders attended.

A committee had been at work for several days collecting money, and $460 was subscribed. Of this $200 was distributed among various charity institutions and the remainder was reserved to defray the expenses of the "blow-out."

NASHVILLE, Jan. 1.--The Hon. John M. Langston, ex-Minister to Hayti, addressed a large audience at the emancipation jubillee in the Colored Exposition Building to-night. The address, which was on the status of the negro, past and present, was long, well considered, and warmly applauded.

Miss Elizabeth B. Van Vorst, a wealthy lady, met with a shocking death yesterday morning at her residence, No. 58 West Fortysixth-street. Her clothing ignited from a fire in an open grate in her sitting room on the second floor of her house, and before the accident was discovered she was so terribly burned that death followed soon after.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 1.--The most destructive fire that has occurred in this city in a score of years broke out this morning in the seed store and warehouse of D.M. Ferry Co., which occupied one-half the block, bounded by Croghan and Lafayette streets, east of Randolph.

DUBLIN, Jan. 1.--David Browne, who was charged with complicity in the Sneehan murders, has been acquitted at the Munster Assizes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 2.--The arrival to-day of the 200 Eastern cigarmakers was made the occasion of quite an imposing demonstration. They were met at the ferry by delegations from several labor unions, who escorted them through the city. The Eastern men made an excellent impression. SHARON SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 2.--Jacob J. Anthony, formerly proprietor of the United States Hotel here, was killed at about noon today in his water wheel house, where he was at work on a large band wheel. BONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 2.--The icemen say that the ice in the main channel in the Hudson River above Catskill averages four inches in thickness. Navigation is still open to Rondout, though there is a great deal of running ice to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 2.--Henry Zorn, who lives in Hallock-street, this city, grew weary of life last night and took two ounces of laudanum. The excessive dose saved his life, and today be was removed to the almshouse for safe keeping. Sickness and family troubles caused the act.

In a sermon yesterday upon the conflict of virtuous purpose with vicious tendencies, the Rev. R. Heber Newton spoke of the antagonisms of human nature as typified in Raphael's picture, in the Louvre, of the youth and the monster, the artist's interpretation of the poet's vision.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 3.--For some time a gang of young roughs has been infesting the western part of the city. Complaints have been frequently made to the police, but all efforts to break up the gang have been unsuccessful. To-night half a dozen officers were detailed to make a raid.

Nobody ever pays the smallest attention to the "authorized" fictions which are circulated whenever a royal personage is ill. It is the invariable custom to assure inquirers that very little is amiss with the patient, who is always reported to be "going on favorably," although at the very time he is known to be going straight to his grave.

Japan having been opened to the nations of the West by the peaceful persuasions of the United States, the virtual opening of Corea to the readers of English books by an American is strictly in order. Corea is not merely geographically the first stepping stone on the Asian mainland in the...

The Rev. Andrew Grey, the Presbyterian clergyman from Millerton, N.Y., whose relations with Miss Rachel Nicholson, of Fox Harbor, Nova Scotia, were described in THE TIMES yesterday, went to the Paisley House, on Twenty-eighth-street and Sixth-avenue, when he was released from custody by Capt. Williams Saturday night.

The members of Typographical Union No. 6 poured into Clarendon Hall yesterday afternoon to the number of over four hundred. They met to install the officers who were elected on Dec. 9 to serve for a year.

--Charles Scribner's Sons will publish this month Lieut. Greely's narrative of the Lady Franklin Bay expedition simultaneously with the appearance of an English edition. The book makes two large octavo volumes and is entitled "Three Years of Arctic Service." It contains over 100 engravings, maps, and charts.

The examination of Joseph Meyer on a charge of abandoning his wife, Yette, was finished in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning. Meyer was arrested on Thursday and remanded until Saturday, when his wife produced 12 witnesses to prove that he had abandoned her four months ago.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 3.--It has leaked out that four or five days ago Naval Cadets Welch, J.J. Waters, Gillespie, and Steber went into the room of Cadet Lewis Driggs, for hazing whom Cadet Wiley was recently dismissed, and gave him a good thrashing. Driggs made a statement of the affair to Capt. Ramsay, and the...

The officers of the Board of Health dismissed a score or more of inspectors, sanitary engineers, and clerks on Saturday, and to-day they will notify their other employes of reductions in salaries ranging from 10 to 20 per cent.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 3.--The Record will make the announcement in the morning that ex-Mayor T.V. Powderly, of Scranton, Master Workman of the Knights of Labor in this county, will probably be the regular Democratic candidate for Congress to succeed J.A. Scranton, Republican.

Few ecclesiastics in any age of the church have been more active or achieved more through the combined use of tongue and pen than Mgr. Dupanloup, who passed away in October, 1878, in his seventy-seventh year. He was born, of poor parents, in the village of Saint-Felix, near Aix, in the Province of Savoy...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 3.--The piping of natural gas into Cleveland from regions of Eastern Ohio and Western Pennsylvania will doubtless be accomplished, but a hard fight will have to be carried to a bitter end against local manufactured gas companies that have for years had their own way in Cleveland.

I should like to know why Gen. Prendergast, K.C.B., declined to use the cartridges supplied to him from England and Egypt and took only those manufactured at the Indian Army arsenal at Dum-Dum? Was it because the...
A Paris correspondent telegraphs that one of the heroes of the Franco-German war has just died, Gen. Bonnemains, who commanded the Cuirassiers in the famous cavalry charge at Reichsofen.

GENTLEMEN: Mr. James G. Batterson, President of the Travelers Insurance Company of this city, called at my house last evening, on the arrival of the train from New-York, whither he said he had been called the Day before by an urgent dispatch signed by two of you; that he had had a conference with you, and that, at your joint request he was the bearer of certain propositions.

LONDON, Jan. 3.--Lord Randolph Churchill has submitted to the Cabinet a proposition for the reform of the Administration of the Government in Ireland. The scheme is supported by the Earl of Carnarvon, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and by Baron Ashbourne, the Lord Chancellor.

The Rev. William J. Daly celebrated his first solemn high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, attended by the Rev. M.J. Mulhern as deacon, the Rev. E.F. Slattery as subdeacon, and the Rev. James W. Kelly as master of ceremonies. Archbishop Corrigan, the Rev. Dr. Denis J. O'Connell, Rector of the American College at Rome, and the Rev. Dr. Charles E. McDonnell were seated in the sanctuary.

The frequenters of Koster Bial's have their favorites, with whom the closest kind of familiarity never engenders contempt. Several of them took part in last evening's performance and were received with quite as much fervor as if they had just returned from a prolonged visit to Europe, instead of a brief excursion as far as the east side.

BERLIN, Jan. 3.--The twenty-fifth anniversary of the accession of Emperor William to the throne of Prussia was observed quietly today. The Emperor held a reception, which was attended by all the foreign ambassadors and diplomats in the city.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 3.--The Matamoras (Mexico) correspondent of the Globe-Democrat telegraphs as follows under yesterday's date: "Yesterday was the date fixed by law for the installation of the new board of city officers.

To be a healthy and happy people we have got to take care of our diet. What he eats and what he drinks should be the most important subject of a man's consideration; for, if his digestion is in good condition his morals are the same.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 3.--Considerable excitement has been aroused here by the report that William Weis, foreman in the Monumental Works, has eloped with a young and handsome widow named Kate Kirscher.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 3.--The attorneys for the prosecution have discovered some startling evidence in the now famous MaxwellBrooks-Preller murder. They have circled the whole world in their efforts to obtain evidence calculated to convict the defendant. From HongKong, China, they will bring as a witness a girl named Grace, whom Maxwell knew in San Francisco.

The Queen did a kindly act last week when, as she was driving through Windsor, she observed a cab horse fall down. An outrider was sent to make inquiries, and, on learning the nature of the accident, her Majesty caused an intimation to be conveyed to the lamenting owner that he should be presented with another horse from the royal stables.

Special evangelistic services will occupy the attention of the Presbyterian churches during this month. The present week has been set aside as a week of prayer. Services will be held daily in the Madison-Square Church and in the Central Church, on Fifty-seventh-street, near Broadway.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Jan. 3.--Yesterday Edward Gearighty and Charles Paustian, of Phillipsburg, were taken to the penitentiary to serve a sentence of one year at hard labor for an attempt to break jail last Tuesday. The method they used to accomplish their end was a novel one.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3.--Chester has seen hard times since the Roaches suspended," said one of the great shipbuilders' old workmen yesterday, "and although there's plenty of work in all other branches of business, the depression caused by the comparative idleness at the ship yard is very seriously felt by all classes.

Lewis H. Court, a tall, thin man, of dark complexion, 60 years of age, who lived at No. 611 Warren-street, Brooklyn, has disappeared from his home. He was a carriage builder doing business on Atlantic-avenue, but had recently become financially involved. This depressed him greatly, and his friends are afraid he has committed suicide.
OAKLAND, Jan. 3.--The day before New Year's James Shaftley--one of the Shaftley family of hunters and trappers--caused no little commotion in this backwoods village by the news he brought in.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--Visitors to the White House who enjoy the privilege which every American citizen regards himself entitled to of inspecting the great East Room, the Green Room and its portrait of Mr. Hayes, the Robin's Ege Blue Room and its gilded furniture, and the Red Room that is the parlor of the President's family, never get any...

Several sailing vessels which arrived yesterday bore evidences of having been severely used in the recent storms. The ship E.J. Spicer, Capt. Spicer, from Antwerp, which anchored off Quarantine, had been partially dismasted. Capt. Spicer reports that he sailed from Antwerp 40 days ago.

BOSTON, Jan. 3.--A meeting of dissatisfied stockholders of the Boston Baseball Association was held yesterday, at which it was decided to proceed at once to assert their rights as members of the corporation.
"How is your sister this morning, Bobby?" inquired young Featherly.

ANDOVER, Mass., Jan. 3.--While several young men were engaged at play on the Shawsheen River, at Ballardvale, to-day, Thomas Lynch, aged 17, fell through the ice and was drowned. Edward Scott, in attempting to rescue him, was also drowned.
"My dear Sir," said a clerical looking gentleman to the passenger in the seat ahead, "have you found grace?"

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 3.--A number of safes have been opened by burglers in this section recently in a manner that police officials pronounce to be the work of the most expert cracksmen in the country.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 3.--Lieut. James M. Jones, Fourth United Status Artillery, whose attempted suicide on Wednesday caused such deep sorrow at Fort Adams, where he was stationed, died this morning, having been unconscious since the shooting. After funeral services with military honors, the body will be conveyed to Cincinnati, Ohio, from which State he was appointed to the army.

Coroner Messemer last evening took the deposition of George F. Monarque, aged 20 years, who was reported to lie in a precarious condition at his residence, No. 239 East One Hundred and Twelfth-street.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 3.--The curious story of the pranks of a mad bull comes in from the lower end of the county. Mr. Tul Patrick had a fine Jersey which, being vicious, was kept in a pen.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 3.--Among various bequests for religious and educational purposes made by the late Mrs. Sophronia Morehouse, of Liverpool, N.Y., was one of $30,000 to Syracuse University. Of this sum $5,000 is for the special use of indigent students. This bequest was paid to the university some time before the death of the devisor, she receiving interest during her lifetime. The university now enters into full possession of the bequest.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3.--Mary McKown and her daughter, 5 years old, bound for Joliet, where the woman's husband resides, arrived on a train on the Pennsylvania Railroad on Friday, and were transferred in a bus to the Rock Island station.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 3.--At midnight last night an alarm of fire was caused by the burning of a large tobacco warehouse, situated at the eastern extremity of Orange-street, just within the city limits, and owned and occupied by David G. Hirsch, dealer in leaf tobacco and cigars.
The first volume of the posthumous works of Victor Hugo, the publication of which has been delayed owing to various causes, will probably appear in February next.

The County Democracy and Republican members of the new Board of Aldermen have practically completed the division of places on committees and of patronage in the organization of the board for 1886. The old board will meet for the last time at 11 A.M. to-day and the new board will meet for the first time at noon.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Jan. 3.--The Rev. Mr. Long, Pastor of the Presbyterian church at Kennedyville, has been asked to resign. The trouble in the church that caused the request commenced some two years ago, when the temperance people of the congregation, headed by the Pastor, commenced a crusade against William Carpenter, an Elder of the church, and two of...

Jacob W. Henkell's cigar box factory, Nos. 293, 295, and 297 Monroe-street, was destroyed by fire early this morning. The factory consisted of a four-story brick building, 75 feet front and 75 feet deep. The fire broke out at midnight in the third story of the building.

Patrolman Ketchale, of the Sixteenth Precinct, arraigned Terence F. Cassidy, who keeps a liquor store at No. 202 West Twentyfirst-street, before Justice Power, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, and charged him with violating the excise law in having his place open.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 3.--The stand taken by the Supreme Court of Ohio in opposition to rebates from railroad companies to the Standard Oil Company on shipments of oil promises to bear a great deal of fruit in favor of outside refiners.

Exclusive of personal expenses and the Returning Officer's charges the election at Northampton cost me the modest sum of 39. The electors of Northampton have had hard things said of them; but no one can say of them that they convert an election into a means of pecuniary profit to themselves.
"I intend to hold the fort," said the Rev. T. Heinle yesterday morning, and a minute after he ascended the pulpit steps in the Second Reformed Church, at Flatbush.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 3.--Miss Eugenia Gallettes, a charming young lady and highly esteemed in the creole circles of New-Orleans society, fell dead while dancing at a party in the residence of Mrs. Hanpy, No. 46 St. Claudsstreet, in the Third District, at midnight last night.
Mr. Gladstone's election expenses amounted to 640. Mr. Gladstone was returned free of expense to himself.

Much comment has been indulged in throughout the city, especially in medical circles, over the sweeping reductions made in the appropriation for the current year for the Health Department. Last year the amount appropriated was $469,758, and this year, although $487,516 was applied for, only $319,800 was allowed by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

RED WING, Minn., Jan. 3.--A short time ago rumors were afloat that the First National Bank, of Lake City, was not in a sound condition financially. This started a run on the bank and it was closed. The Directors promise that all depositors will be paid.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 3.--Capt. Jeffrey Gerroir, of the schooner Racer, whose wreck off Cape Elizabeth last Monday has been reported, was arrested in Gloucester early yesterday morning and brought to this city by United States Deputy Marshal Galloupe, where he was arraigned before Commissioner Hallett, charged with attempting to destroy his vessel by scuttling her.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 3.--A Commercial Gazette special says: 'A desperate attempt to burn down the town of Tarentum, Penn., was made at an early hour this morning. The fire was first discovered in Essler's livery stable on Gaines-street.

Gov. HILL'S inaugural address on New Year's Day was a laborious effort to elevate himself to the pinnacle of statesmanship by magnifying the office which he has succeeded in attaining by the craft of the politician. He referred at length to the careers of the illustrious Governors of New-York and bestowed his unqualified approval upon the entire line.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 3.--Every effort is still being made to recover the bodies of the 26 men in Slope No. 1 at Nanticoke. The Susquehanna Coal Company are doing all in their power to get to them.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 3.--One of the men arrested here yesterday in connection with swindling operations by a bogus news agency is a detective named Benson, who was recently released from penal servitude, to which he had been sentenced for turf frauds.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 3.--John Carter, colored, residing in the Sixth District, was brought to the city to-day and placed in jail to await trial for incendiarism. Yesterday morning Thomas Harris, a merchant and farmer, discovered that his large barn was on fire, and reached it just in time to save 10 horses from perishing in the flames.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 3.--This city has escaped disaster from ill-constructed buildings-- Buddensiekeries, as they are called--until to-day. This morning at about 6 o'clock a fire broke out in the four-story brick building corner of Carondelet and Julia streets, known as the Southern Hotel.

Here is a good story apropos of dueling. Rather less than three years ago two frequenters of the principal cafe at Aries quarreled, with the result that two friends of the one who considered himself the affronted party waited on the other, a corn merchant in the town.

An old man of 65, John Downing, of No. 550 West Thirty-fifth-street, accidentally fell down the basement steps at No. 301 West Thirtysixth-street yesterday afternoon, and was so badly injured that he died before the arrival of an ambulance.

There was a party at No. 140 Cook-street, Brooklyn, which was not over at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. Two young men--Fred Brenner, of No. 160 Cook-street, and James Leddy, of No. 79 Cook-street--had been having a good time, when the latter proposed they have some beer. He then wanted to borrow a dollar from Brenner, who refused him.
Charles Phillips, a lapidary of No. 250 Second-street, has been missing since New Year's Eve. He was last seen in a saloon at Avenue A and Fifth-street.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 3.--On Dec. 18 last the safe in the Southern Express Company's office at Brinkley, Ark., was blown open and a package containing $2,900 in money and two gold watches were stolen from it. To-day intelligence reached hare that detectives who have been working up the case had arrested one of the burglars at Galeshurg, Ill., and recovered $1,100 of the stolen money and both watches.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3.--The closing half of Mr. Florence's fortnight engagement at McVicker's has been the most enjoyable thing at the Chicago theatres during the week. The houses have been rather larger than last week, and the engagement has been a fairly successful one.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 3.--No lives were lost at the fire in the Essex County Lunatic Asylum last night, and but one patient, who is harmless, escaped. He has not yet been found. There are 369 patients in the asylum. Watchman Patrick Gavin was to-day assaulted by a lunatic, who tried to escape. The Building Committee of the Essex County Freeholders have been in session all day investigating the cause of the fire.

There is a very bad epidemic of smallpox in Vienna at present. It began about a month ago and shows no signs of abatement. Orders have been given for the vaccination of soldiers in barracks, and the municipal authorities have issued urgent appeals to proprietors of schools, workshops, and employers generally to have the children, servants, or working people under their charge, vaccinated.

Mrs. Catherine Hamell, a young woman of 26, residing at No. 1,221 Third-avenue, was accidently shot and dangerously wounded by her brother, Christian Rush, yesterday afternoon. Rush boards with his sister, and yesterday afternoon, while in the sitting room talking to her, he started to take a loaded revolver out of his pocket, intending to put it away.

APPLETON, Wis., Jan. 3.--Peter Armstrong, 15 years old, stood talking with his brother, three years older, and Frank Davis, another boy, in front of the latter's home in this city last evening. While they were talking Julia Giskie, housekeeper for Davis's father, came to the head of the hall stairs and cried: "Who is there?"

FORT GAINES, Ga., Jan. 3.--While the steamer W.D. Chipley was trying to make her landing at Stark's Clay, 10 miles north of this place, on the Chattahoochee River, last night, between 7 and 8 o'clock, she struck a protruding rock. A cry of alarm went up and a moment later it was evident that the vessel was sinking.

Smoke issuing from the store of J.G. Hyman, dealer in boot and shoe uppers, at No. 9 Spruce-street, brought fire engines to Printing House-square at midnight last night. When the firemen broke into the store the smoke rushed out. Search for its cause was unavailing and in 15 minutes the insurance patrol concluded that the smoke came from a back draught down the chimney.

Two or three hundred well dressed men and women, sympathizers and the regenerated, attended the anniversary meeting of Jerry McAuley's Cremorne Mission, yesterday afternoon. Gen. Clinton B. Fisk, the Rev. Drs. R.S. MacArthur and R.R. Booth, the Rev. Lindsay Parker, and Mrs. Maria McAuley occupied the platform and made brief addresses.
At a meeting last evening, under the auspices of the Fordham branch of the Irish National League, in Tammany Hall, Fordham, the sum of $83 was contributed to the Parnell Parliamentary fund.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union delegates from the Brassworkers' Union were admitted to membership. A committee was appointed to consider the advisability of publishing an official journal of the proceedings of the Central Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3.--In response to a request for additional information explanatory of the recommendations of his last annual report in regard to the Indian question, Lieut.Gen. Sheridan has written the following statement:

The works for Pere Lachaise Cemetery, recently given out to M. Godet, contractor, at a rabate of 35f. 30c. per cent. on his bid of 193,497f., comprise three crematory apparatuses, to be constructed after the plans of M. Formige, City Architect.

A Singular accident occurred at 1 o'clock yesterday morning on the Philadelphia and Reading Road. A long freight train was passing the station at Centreville, N.J., when there was an explosion and the forward car of the train was enveloped in a cloud-of steam. When it had blown away it was discovered that the water grate of the locomotive had exploded.

The recent movement among Episcopalians in New-York City is something so unusual as to claim notice outside of strictly religious circles. The Episcopal churches here are greater in number than those of any other Protestant body and also than those of the Roman Catholics, and many of...
PARIS, Jan. 3.--Before the departure of the Newark children for Havre, whence they sailed on the steamer Canada yesterday for New-York, they were carefully examined by M. Pasteur.

Services commemorative of the fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of the German Evangelical congregation were held in the church building on East Houston-street, near Forsyth, last night. A very large congregation was present, and several score of voices formed the choir.

The elevated railroad engineers who are trying to get Manager Hain to accede to their proposition to make eight hours a working day, suspended agitation of the subject yesterday. They expect C.M. Arthur, the Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, here today from Cleveland to confer with Mr. Hain. Further action by the engineers will depend upon the result of that conference.

The fourth annual tennis tournament (open) of the clubs playing in the tennis building, No. 212 West Forty-first-street, will take place on the 22d inst. Only doubles will be played. Twenty different clubs use the building.

It was communion Sunday at Plymouth Church yesterday and there was the usual large attendance. Mr. Beecher gave notice that there would be a daily prayer meeting in the lecture room of the church at 8 A.M during the week. It would last for an hour. Next Tuesday night the annual rental of the pews of the church will take place.

"I don't suppose you care if Hattie and I elope?" said young Charles Smith, of Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, when he left the home of Miss Hattie Forker, on Thursday evening last. Miss Hattie was a pretty little lady, young and pleasing, and she had completely captivated Mr. Smith. She is a daughter of John Forker, a well-to-do merchant living at Flatbush.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 3.--An Indian Territory special says that an attempt is being made by a number of leading Cherokees to set aside the lease of a tract of land, known as the Cherokee outlet, to a syndicate of cattlemen. The land embraces more than 6,000,000 acres and includes all unoccupied lands of the Cherokee Nation lying west of the Arkansas River.

Services commemorative of the fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of the German Evangelical congregation were held in the church building on East Houston-street, near Forsyth, last night. A very large congregation was present, and several score of voices formed the choir.

The elevated railroad engineers who are trying to get Manager Hain to accede to their proposition to make eight hours a working day, suspended agitation of the subject yesterday. They expect C.M. Arthur, the Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, here today from Cleveland to confer with Mr. Hain. Further action by the engineers will depend upon the result of that conference.

The fourth annual tennis tournament (open) of the clubs playing in the tennis building, No. 212 West Forty-first-street, will take place on the 22d inst. Only doubles will be played. Twenty different clubs use the building.

ALBANY, Jan. 3.--The fight is practically ended. Platt's three candidates have been bowled out. The anti-Platt combination has won. Senator Edmund L. Pitts will be the next President pro tem. of the Senate, and the Senate's committees will be made up in the interest of decent legislation.

The Sportsman publishes the following report of a fight for the championship of England and 200: "The most important fistic encounter that has taken place in the old country for years, and which revives the time-honored-- but supposed to be defunct--title of Champion of England, was successfully brought off yesterday, (Wednesday.)

The hat works of R.L. Dunlap Co., Nos. 70 to 88 Nostrand-avenue, Brooklyn, a fourstory brick building, caught fire in the office at 10 o'clock this morning. The fire was caused by a dog upsetting a lamp. The flames extended to the felt department, and at 2 o'clock the entire building was threatened. The loss is estimated at $150,000, with insurance not sufficient to cover the loss.

--A Handbook to the National Museum at the Smithsonial Institution, Washington, New-York: Brentano Brothers.--Mr. Ernest Ingersoll for the text, and Mr. F.H. Taylor for the illustrations, associated with Mr. Ainsworth, have made a handbook, which will be found serviceable to those who visit the National Museum at Washington.

The Hon. FRANK LAWLER, of Chicago, who is beginning his first term in Congress, has introduced a bill (H.R. 303) whose provisions prove that the genial philanthropist of the Senate now has an ambitious and formidable rival in the House.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 3.--Late Saturday afternoon the body of a man was found in the woods five miles east of Columbus, Ind. The head was horribly beaten, one eye and part of the nose gone, and there were five or six bullet holes through different parts of the body.

Early yesterday morning a fire broke out in the grocery store at No. 17 Carmine-street, kept by John B. Quinlan. It was discovered by a Park policeman who was going home, and his ringing at the door aroused the janitor, John Toney.
The Secretary of State has received and sent to Mr. Ericsson, the distinguished inventor, the Grand Cross of the Order of Naval Merit recently conferred on that gentleman by the late King of Spain.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4.--Notwithstanding the terrible rainstorm McCaull's Opera House to-night was packed with the elite of the city, and "The Black Hussar" proved himself a worthy successor to "The Mikado." The scenery, designed by W.H. Day, of New-York, is the most realistic ever seen on any stage.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 4.--The case of Shillaber against George E. Fairbanks, of this city, was begun in the Superior Civil Court here to-day. The plaintiff asserts that the defendant's clerk and agent put up corrosive sublimate instead of hydrate of chloral in a prescription, causing her husband's death.

"Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg," a three-act opera composed by Richard Wagner, was represented at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening for the first time in this country. The performance was witnessed by an audience of unwonted brilliancy, and every seat and foot of standing room was occupied.
PARIS, Jan. 4.--M. de Freycinet has concluded to form a new Cabinet and is now engaged in the task of selecting the members. Several members of the late Ministry will accept portfolios.

BOSTON, Jan. 4.--The opening of the Mapleson Opera Company's engagement at the Boston Theatre to-night was most successful, the experiment of a reduction in prices meeting with popular favor. "Carmen" was presented, Del Puente, Mmes. Hauk and Dotti, Ravelli and the other artists being warmly received. The advance sale of tickets indicates a highly successful engagement.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 4.--Thomas W. Keene, the actor, was stricken with paralysis at a reception tendered him last night by the local lodge of the Order of Elks. He is lying in bed at his hotel this morning attended by able physicians and a host of friends.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 4.--Warren Stone, a boy 19 years old, is lying in a critical condition at his home, in North Madison. His father a well-to-do farmer, has been preparing his two sons for Yale College. The boys are about equally advanced in their studies, and the rivalry between them was keen.

It is generally assumed, especially among the protectionists, that the tariff will not be touched at this session of Congress, if for no other reason because the Republican majority in the Senate will not permit it.

Although the undertaking of American opera was begun last night under circumstances in some respects most auspicious, it would be more than usually unjust to judge its promise by its first performance. Readers of newspapers have of late ...

Mrs. Mary Gibson reported to Chief of Police Murphy, of Jersey City, yesterday, that her husband, Joseph Gibson, who was employed as expert gasmaker at a salary of $3,000 at the Standard Oil Works at Constable Hook, had disappeared.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 4.--At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company of Massachusetts, held in this city to-day, the following Board of Directors was elected for the ensuing year: D. H. Bates, E.A. Leslie, E.C.M. Bunce, and C.F. Hutchinson. Mr. D.H. Bates was re-elected President and Mr. E.A. Leslie Vice-President.
HOWELL, Mich., Jan. 4.--There is liable to be trouble here over the railroad war between the Toledo, Ann Arbor and Northern Michigan and Detroit, Lansing and Northern Railroads.

The Rev. Charles A. Tibbals has resigned the Rectorship of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn. Trouble in the church has been brewing for some time on account of the low church views of Mr. Tibbals.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 4.--The report comes from Louisville on good authority that on March 1, John Scott, formerly President and General Manager of the Queen and Crescent route, will succeed J.Q. Hanrahan as General Manager of its great rival, the Louisville and Nashville system.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 4.--About 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon Brainard Harmon was discovered lying on a platform in the cellar of his home in Spencerport, with blood streaming from an ugly gash in his throat. Near by were two razors covered with blood.

TAUNTON, Mass., Jan. 4.--The Rev. T.G. Millstead, Pastor of the Unitarian Church here, has accepted a call to the Church of the Unity, Chicago, of which the Rev. Robert Collyer, now of New-York, was formerly Pastor, and will enter upon his new duties on Feb. 1. Mr. Millstead did not announce his determination until this morning.

Much of the mystery which surrounded the death of Henry D. Smith, chief salesman for the Hamilton Rubber Company, of Trenton, N. J., has been cleared up by Inspector Byrnes. Smith, early on the morning of Dec. 26, was found unconscious from a fractured skull at the area gate of a disorderly house, No. 103 West ...

William F. Johnson, formerly counsel of John McCullough; M.W. Canning, of Philadelphia, and Capt. William M. Conner, of NewYork, the committee which has legal charge of the dead actor's estate under appointment of the Pennsylvania courts, conferred yesterday over the location of a monument.

Surrounded by many lights of the theatrical firmament Lilian Spencer, the actress, sat before Judge Truax and a jury in the Superior Court yesterday. She was plaintiff in a suit against Lucas R. Williams and James K. Tillottson, claiming large damages for an alleged breach of a contract made with her.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4.--George W. Tyler, leading counsel for Sarah Althea Hill in her suit for divorce against the late ex-Senator Sharon, was indicted to-day by the county Grand Jury for felony.

ALBANY, Jan. 4.--A murderer was discovered among the inmates at the penitentiary to-day. He is a young man 22 years old, who was arrested on Aug. 6, during the Grant obsequies, while in the act of picking an old man's pocket near the Capitol. He gave the name of Edward Childs and Philadelphia as his residence.

James S. Gratz in May last made arrangements with Grundling Schmidt, wholesale jewelers in Chicago, whereby he succeeded that concern in the trade, under the firm name of James S. Gratz Co., the "Co." being Mr. Schmidt, of the original firm.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 4.--Lenox Decue have been for some time the general agents of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company in this city. Decue, the older member of the firm, who came here from Cincinnati, ...

TRENTON, Jan. 4.--Henry Ford and his brother discovered in the river just west of Factory-street early to-day the body of Lizzie G. Baldwin, the young woman who was supposed to have committed suicide yesterday. County Physician Taylor had the body removed to the Morgue, where an examination confirmed the suicide theory and a burial permit was granted.

Coroner Messemer held an inquest yesterday in the case of Edward J. Thompson, a driver of a grocery wagon, who was killed by his wagon being struck by a train on the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad at Central Morrisania on Dec. 12. The jury rendered a verdict censuring the railroad company for not providing safeguards against dangers of this kind.

BUFFALO, Jan. 4.--The Hon. Philip Becker, the newly elected Mayor, entered office to-day. His message is the most elaborate showing of Buffalo's affairs ever made in such a paper. The city's indebtedness on Jan. 1 was $8,050,735.93, and its resources over liabilities $1,935,134.41. The credit of the city is first class.
The following subscriptions were received by the Grant Monument Association yesterday:

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 4.--Among the articles of incorporation filed with the Secretary of State to-day was that of the American Pasteur Institute of New-York City. The objects of the institute are: The gratuitous care and treatment by the Pasteur system of inoculation, or such variations thereof and improvements thereon as ...

The Orthopaedic Hospital is likely to receive substantial benefit from the theatrical performances to be given in its behalf on Saturday and Monday evenings at the University Club Theatre. No tickets for Saturday's performance remain unsold, but tickets for Monday's entertainment can be procured from Mrs. James A. Burden, No. 139 Fifth-avenue; Mrs. J.K. Gracie, No. 12 West Nineteenth-street, and Mrs. W.M. Bliss. No. 29 West Twenty-fourth-street.

OTTAWA, Jan. 4.--Another effort will be made at the approaching meeting of Parliament to obtain charters authorizing the construction of railways crossing the United States boundary west of Lake Superior.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 4.--The election of a Mayor to-day excited greater interest than any previous political contest ever created here. The candidates were Mayor Manning, a millionaire brewer, who was up for re-election, and W. H. Howland, a commission merchant, who is well known in the New-York and Chicago grain markets.

CLINTON, Mass., Jan. 4.--The notes taken by absconding President McNeil from the Lancaster National Bank on the night of his departure, and which aggregate about $24,000 face value, are now said to be notes discounted by the bank, and on which money had been obtained.

ALBANY, Jan. 4.--The reports that have been published about typhus fever raging in the penitentiary here are calculated to excite unnecessary alarm. Since the dread disease first appeared in the latter part of November the physicians at the institution and Health Officer of the city, Dr. Lewis Balch, have preserved ...

At the meeting of the Trustees of Columbia College yesterday the Library Committee reported that although 20,000 volumes had been added in the last two years there was urgent need of more books to meet the demands of the Professors and students in the various departments of the university, especially in the graduate courses.
CORK, Jan. 4.--The coal porters who have been boycotting the Cork Steam Packet Company have abandoned the strike and resumed work.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 4.--Adolph Schoenleber, an old resident and retired furniture dealer, who for nearly 30 years was owner of the Pioneer Furniture House, Nos. 291 and 293 Third-street, was arrested by Sheriff Paschen shortly before midnight Saturday on a charge of criminal libel, preferred by Christian Ritter, a Second Ward furniture dealer, who brought suit for $10,000 damages.

The decision of the General Term in the case of the National Exchange Bank against the elevated roads is in a line with all the judicial opinions that have hitherto been taken on the subject. Relying upon the authorization of the Legislature ...

HAZLEHURST, Miss., Jan. 4.--Levy Brown, colored, living near Rockport, Copiah County, was shot and killed while standing at his door last night, 10 buckshot going entirely through his body. Joe James, an escaped convict, is supposed to be the murderer. Some months ago Brown was in a posse that made an unsuccessful attempt to capture James and return him to Jackson.

The steamship Saratoga, of the Ward Line, which arrived from Havana yesterday, brought Capt. Rapetto and 12 seamen who were wrecked on the Columbian Reefs on Dec. 15. They belonged to the Italian bark Francesco Padre, which sailed from Cape Town for Pensacola in ballast on Oct. 21.

CLINTON, N.C., Jan. 4.--A strange reunion has just taken place here. In 1861 the venerable Rev. H.S. Spivey parted from his son, John G. Spivey, at Goldsborough. The latter, then a youth, left behind him his loved ones to link his fate to that of the South.

BOSTON, Jan. 4.--George F. Jelly, a distinguished specialist in mental and nervous diseases, who for eight years was Superintendent of the McLane Insane Asylum, gave testimony to-day in the Swan murder trial at Salem. He had visited the prisoner, Henry K. Goodwin, in his cell, and remained with him for two hours.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 4.--At an early hour this morning the officials of the Air Line Railroad sought the aid of the Federal authorities to enable them to resume the running of trains between this city and Chicago.

The annual "statement" of the Mayor of this city to the Board of Aldermen is a rather unusual document. It is made "in accordance with the requirements of law and custom," and it may be that its character is due mainly to the fact that there is very little that the Mayor can usefully lay before the Board of Aldermen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--The Supreme Court of the United States to-day rendered decisions in the following cases:

A very curious state of affairs has arisen concerning the race horse Tom Martin, who was purchased recently by the Dwyers for $4,500. Tom Martin was bred by Frank Harper, who owns his sire, Longfellow, at Midway, Ky., and bought when a yearling by Peter C. Fox, of Louisville, for $220.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 4.--There was a general resumption of work in the river coal mines to-day, at the reduced rate. A further reduction of wages is probable in the Spring. Leading operators assert that during the four months of the strike Pittsburg lost her prestige in the lower markets, and can only regain it by underbidding all competitors.

T.W. Carrinder was arrested in Philadelphia on Thursday last by Detective H.C. Mintzhouzer, of that city, for offering watches and other jewelry for sale at prices apparently far below their market value. The arrest was made upon complaint of a man to whom some ...

SYRACUSE, Jan. 4.--The Church of the Assumption in this city is attended by Franciscan Fathers of the Order of Minor Conventuals. It is the largest place of worship for German Catholics in Central New-York. Attached to it is a college, a parochial school, a monastery, and a convent, the whole property aggregating hundreds of thousands of dollars in value.
Jay Cooke, of Philadelphia, is at the Brevoort House.

ELMIRA, Jan. 4.--A few miles south of the Pennsylvania State line, in Bradford County, is the Talcot farm. Ezra Talcot, its owner, is a rich widower, his wife having died two years ago. Soon after her death he rented the farm to William Williams.

LONDON, Jan. 4.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade during the past week, says: "The land is very wet. The growing crops appear remarkably well. The year 1886 opens very promisingly.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 4.--Pleuro-pneumonia is on the increase in this county. Yesterday A.S. Frey, of Manor Township, discovered that about one-third of his herd of 100 cattle were sick and summoned two veterinary surgeons, who pronounced the disease pleuropneumonia.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 4.--Alexander McKinsley, one of the pioneers of this city, died last September, leaving a will in which the bulk of his property, amounting to about $60,000, was bequeathed to his daughter, Mrs. Florence Hackett, who lives at No. 216 St. Mark's-avenue, Brooklyn.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 4.--Jack Neal, one of the oldest and wealthiest citizens of Atlanta, died to-day, aged 91. He was born in Pike County when it was inhabited by Indians. He had amassed a fortune of $300,000 in cash by 1856, when he settled in Atlanta.

A notice has been placarded in the stations of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad for the past few days, announcing that "On and after Jan. 4, 1886, trains will not stop at the Halseystreet, Chauncey-street, Manhattan Beach Junction, and Van Siclen-avenue stations after 8 o'clock P.M.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 4.--Millie Eddy was booked to appear to-night at the American Theatre in a variety performance and to make a "leap for life." She appeared when her number of the programme came, and, with her mate, began to perform on a trapeze, suspended above an ordinary net.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--The boycotting committee of the Trade and Labor Assembly recommended yesterday that the screws be applied to-morrow to the Calumet Iron and Steel Company's forge at Cummings for employing non-union men, who refused to work at the wages offered them, and the report was adopted.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 4.--The school book war has broken out again in a new form. Today, in the United States Circuit Court, Messrs. Ivison, Blakeman, Taylor Co., school book publishers of New-York, filed a bill in equity against Ulric Bettison, Superintendent of City Schools, and the City School Board, and all citizens of the State of Louisiana, alleging that ...

Stalwart Capt. Williams, of the Twentyninth Precinct, walked into the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon with two notorious "bunko steerers" as prisoners--Henry Miller, alias "Kid" Miller, who has a national reputation in the peculiar branch of industry which he follows so persistently, and Henry ...

There was a good attendance at the meeting of the Executive Committe of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association at the Hoffman House last evening, and those who braved the storm to get there were well repaid for the trouble. From the beginning the interest in what was said was warm and hearty, and enthusiasm developed as the meeting went on.

Michael Condon tells a pitiful tale of outrage done upon him and his children by his wife, Eliza, whom he married 20 years ago, and from whom he now seeks a divorce in the Superior Court. He says that she is a common drunkard; that she has assaulted him with teapots, stove lids, broom handles, and bad language; ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 4.--The Hon. Charles E. Fitch, editor of the Democrat and Chronicle, is dangerously ill at his residence in this city. He was attacked with erysipelas, which affected his brain, and his mind has wandered for about a week.

NEWBURG, Jan. 4.--Yesterday noon Alexander Dumond, an Erie brakeman on Conductor Cosses's train, while pulling a pin as he was about to make a flying switch at Turner's, lost his hold on the car and fell lengthwise on the track. A car passed over his body, horribly mangling and instantly killing him. Dumond was 35 years old and had a wife at Port Jervis.

So intricate is the story of the marital relations of Laura Houghton, as she calls herself, and William W. Houghton, and so apparent is it that there has been perjury committed in the course of the proceedings before a Referee that Judge Andrews, in Supreme Court Chambers, has decided not to ratify the Referee's report in favor of sustaining a decree annulling ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 4.--Dr. Moriarty, Pastor of St. John the Evangelist's Church, in this city, is at sword's points with his Curate, Father Reilly, the immediate cause of trouble being a disagreement in the matter of holding funeral services over the remains of Rufus B. Bush, who died last Friday.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 4.--A daring and unique robbery took place on the Harrison Pike, just outside the city limits, early yesterday morning. The robbers were mere boys. They wore masks and conducted themselves in regular dime novel style.

The New-York City Club of Yale College held its first annual dinner at Delmonico's last evening. Many graduates were present, including Walter Jennings, Julian W. Curtiss, Richard Peabody, and Emile J. Schultze. F.J. Winston presided, and George Griswold Haven and Edwin Parsons were in charge of the supper. The object of the club is to stimulate the Yale feeling in the city, and to direct young men toward Yale College. Covers were laid for 75.

During all the time that Thomas C. Acton was in charge of the Sub-Treasury he never was behindhand a single hour at the beginning of business in the morning. Spending his Sundays regularly up at Saybrook, Conn., Mr. Acton has been usually the first man up in that town every Monday morning.

TRENTON, Jan. 4.--A little terrier dog belonging to Mrs. William West, of No. 94 Springstreet, exhibited symptoms of madness last Saturday evening. He frothed at the mouth, snapped at every one who went near him, and frightened a score of people more or less.

ALBANY, Jan. 4.--The resolution of the Common Council adopting the report of the Special Water Commission, in favor of the introduction of the system of gang wells in the flats north of the city as a new source of water supply, was vetoed by Mayor Banks to-night.

The position of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in reference to the reduction in the estimates of the Board of Health was stated last evening by James Gallatin, President of the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

HAMMOND, Ind., Jan. 4.--Mayor Towle, of this city, was arrested to-day by United Staten Marshal Hawkins for obstructing the mail. The Mayor owns a piece of land upon which the Louisville and New-Albany Railroad swings the draw of its bridge crossing the Calumet River.

For some time the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company has been running through trains over its entire line to the terminus at East New-York. The establishment of rapid transit in the region served by the eastern part of the line was regarded with great satisfaction by the people, and the extension of the road to that region was the main cause of the erection of hundreds of dwellings there.

GALENA, Ill., Jan. 4.--Richard Magoon, of Scales Mound, in this county, was committed to jail on Saturday last at Farmington, Wis., on the charge of having forced the Hon. Henry T. Magoon, ex-Congressman of the Third Wisconsin District, at the point of a pistol, to sign a note payable to the order of the former for $15,000.

LONDON, Jan. 4.--The local Government measure to be laid before Parliament by the Government, as drafted, gives to Ireland a household franchise for electing County Boards and for electing a Central Council. The proposition that the Crown should have the right to nominate a part of the Council was abandoned.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 4.--The fight between the Allegheny and Baltimore Baseball Clubs for the services of Sam Barkley was settled to-day. The Alleghenys signed him and President McKnight approved the contract. Von der Ahe, of St. Louis, was offered $1,000 by each club for Barkley's release and gave him the choice.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--Acting upon the suggestion of Patrick Egan, President of the National Land League, the original Committee of Arrangements for the proposed convention here this month, voted to-night to postpone the convention until after the February meeting of Parliament, when it is hoped Parnell will attend.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 4.--John E. Owens, the comedian, was to-day brought from Aigburth Vale, his country seat, to his residence in Baltimore. There is little change in his physical condition.

The message of Mayor Grace sent to the new Board of Aldermen yesterday opens with the statement that he understands the Senate investigating committee has in hand the preparation of bills to be introduced in the Legislature during the coming session, the object of which will be to remedy "such abuses as may have been discovered."

The members of the Cigarmakers' International Union went yesterday to their various shops, and wherever the reduced rates of wages were enforced the men did not resist, but temporarily accepted the terms under protest until the majority of the local unions throughout the country shall have decided what action should be taken.

The first of a series of meetings, which will be continued through the week of prayer at Plymouth Church, nas held in the lecture room at 8 o'clock yesterday morning. About 50 persons were scattered around the room when Mr. Beecher opened the meeting by requesting the pianist to "give us a Moody and Sankey, and a good loud one."
The following additional sums were received yesterday on behalf of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Collection by Mr. Charles Lanier, the general Treasurer, No. 26 Nassaustreet:

BOSTON, Jan. 4.--The inauguration of the new City Government to-day attracted special attention because of the re-election last December of a Democratic Mayor by Republican votes, and the fact that the coming year will be the first in which the new charter legislation, giving extensive powers to the Mayor, will have full trial.

Col. Ayer, who was transferred by Secretary Manning, a few weeks ago, from the post of Chief of the Special Treasury Service in this city to that of chief in the same service at San Francisco, is in the hands of the doctors at the Brooklyn Homeopathic Hospital.

What THE TIMES said some weeks ago-- that the Board of Aldermen for 1886 would be organized by the votes of the County Democracy and Republican members--came to pass yesterday. The old board held its last meeting at 11:30 o'clock and, after passing the usual complimentary resolutions to President Sanger, the clerks and reporters, adjourned sine die.
"I.C.L."--Easter Sunday fell on March 28 in 1869. Clerk of the Common Council Twomey has reappointed Richard E. Mott as his Deputy.

The story published yesterday of the rescue of Dr. Hawes's three children from a burning room at No. 745 Lexington-avenue on Sunday was said by Dr. Hawes yesterday to be somewhat at variance with the facts. Dr. Hawes said that the curtain of the window caught fire, but that before the flames made any headway they were extinguished by a lady in the house, who also removed the children to an adjoining room.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 4.--Much excitement was caused here last night by the escape of five prisoners from the county jail. When Dick Wyatt, the night guard, went into the jail to lock the prisoners in their cells one of them knocked him down.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 4.--Relative to the effort of the Gas Fuel Company to obtain the right of way to the Cleveland streets a member of the Board of Improvements said to-day that a substitute will be submitted to the Board of Aldermen at the meeting next Monday evening for the ordinance then to be returned to that body.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 4.--By a decision of Judge Clarke to-day prohibition in Atlanta is sustained and the law will go into force. Upon the hearing of the mandamus to-day Judge Clarke granted a demurrer to the prohibition party's counsel, on the ground that the whisky ...
The storm which broke over this city in full force yesterday originated somewhere in the interior of Kansas on Saturday, traveled up the Mississippi Valley, and gradually worked its way eastward.

P.M. Arthur, head of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, reached the city yesterday in response to the invitation of the committee of elevated railroad engineers, who laid their grievances before General Manager Hain on Thursday and requested that they be redressed.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 4.--A morning train from Ansonia to New-Haven on the NewHaven and Derby Railroad had a narrow escape to-day. As it was rounding a curve near Birmingham a telegraph pole fell across the track. In falling the pole struck the locomotive's headlight, but was thrown to one side by the speed of the train. The passengers felt a slight shock.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--A young man named Edward Palson endeavored to get a good seat in the upper gallery at the Standard Theatre last night by climbing over the backs of the chairs during a performance of a "Buffalo Bill" combination. He missed his footing, and tumbled head over heels over the rail into the parquet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--In response to a request from Senator Harrison, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Territories, Gov. Zulick, of Arizona, has furnished a statement of the Territorial debt, how incurred, The Territory has outstanding warrants amounting to $120,948, upon which it pays interest at the rate of 10 per cent. per annum.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--The following figures, taken from the official statement of the Board of Trade to be posted on 'Change to-morrow, show in bushels the amount of grain in sight in the United States and Canada on Saturday, Jan. 2, and the amount of decrease or increase over the preceding week:

PETERSBURG, Va., Jan. 4.--The fast mail train on the Atlantic Coast Line, which arrives here from the South at 10 A.M., narrowly escaped being wrecked this morning, and was only saved from destruction by the coolness and heroism of the engineer, William McMillan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--A very pretty and elegantly dressed young woman was arrested today in a Chinese laundry in Desplaines-street while enjoying an opium smoke. At the police station she gave her name as May Heineman, and said her father was a police officer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--Land Commissioner Sparks's enemies among the land grabbers, whose schemes to steal such of the public lands as are worth anything have been checked since last April, are trying hard to make it appear that the Commissioner's action in holding up final action on land entries is working great hardship to the honest settlers who cannot get patents for their homesteads.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 3.--The boatmen of the Erie Canal are raising a fund to erect a monument over the grave of Peter Cummings, the driver that drove the first boat that made the trip from Buffalo over the canal, in 1825. De Witt Clinton stood at the bow of the boat and gave the word to start.
DAWSON, Penn., Jan. 4.--About 10 o'clock this morning, during the prevalence of a heavy wind storm, the roof, the gable ends, and chimneys of the Tyrone schoolhouse were blown down.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 4.--John Bower, Frederick Whittlesey, and J.C. O'Brien, who constitute a committee of the Municipal Reform League to draw up a revised city charter, have reported that their labors are finished. The new charter is modeled after that of Brooklyn. It is now ready for presentation to the Legislature.

ALBANY, Jan. 4.--The inevitable has occurred at last. The combination of political forces represented by Senator Miller, Congressman Hiscock, ex-President Arthur, and a few friends of ex-Gov. Cornell has succeeded in defeating the desperate determination of Thomas C. Platt and his sympathizers to organize this Republican Legislature.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 4.--Another outbreak was expected yesterday morning among the members of St. Prokop's Polish Catholic Church, who were in rebellion last Spring against an objectionable priest. Quite a number of rebellious members were excommunicated at that time.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 4.--The annual election of officers of the Toledo Produce Exchange to-day, while of itself a dull and spiritless affair, will have an importance in the grain markets of the country, because it is liable to divide the Toledo association into two organizations-- the present Produce Exchange and a Board of Trade.

Articles of incorporation for the organization of the Croton Valley Railway Company have been filed in the Westchester County Clerk's office. It is proposed to start from the Hudson River at the mouth of the Croton River, in Cortlandtown, and thence run along the north bank of the Croton to a station on the line of the New-York City and Northern Railroad, known as Croton Lake North, being a distance of eight miles.

Official notice of the sudden death at Cairo, Egypt, on Nov. 29, 1885, of Ali-Mahmoud Pasha El Falaki, Grand Shareef Al Muhazzi of the Cairo Temple of the Ancient Arabic Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine, has been received by the Imperial Council of the order in the United States, and Imperial Potentate Dr. Walter M. Flaming has issued, on behalf of the ...

Judge Andrews decided yesterday to continue the injunction obtained by John M. Otter, manager of the Metropolitan Hotel, restraining the Excise Commissioners from annulling his liquor license because he kept open a doorway between the vestibule of Niblo's Garden Theatre and a passageway leading to the bar and billiard rooms of the hotel.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 4.--W.H. Whyte, counsel for A.L. Mellen, filed with Police Justice Cashmyer, of the Central Station, this morning, a motion to quash the warrant for Mellen's arrest which was issued on Nov. 10 on the oath of Marshal Frey, based on information and belief.

CRESTLINE, Ohio, Jan. 4.--A dining room girl employed at a hotel here gave birth to a child on Saturday afternoon, unattended, and threw it into a red-hot stove. The odor of burning flesh disclosed the horrible deed. The girl is lying at the point of death. The Coroner from Bucyrus came here yesterday, but has not taken any action in the case. No arrests have yet been made.

Two Paterson lawyers went out the other day to Preakness to try an important case before a country Justice. The defendant in the case had slandered the plaintiff's horse, so that the owner could not sell him to advantage.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4.--Col. John A. McCaull's "Mikado" company began an engagement here to-night with the biggest house, with one exception, that the new Opera House has seen since it was opened. Every seat in the lower part of the house was taken, all the boxes were occupied, and the foyer was crowded with people standing.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4.--The Supreme Court made an important decision in criminal law to-day in an opinion by the Chief-Justice concerning the case of Hyland, who was indicted in the Criminal Court of Mercer County for murder in the first degree.

Trustee Ferdinand T. Hopkins, of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church, was as suave and smiling as ever last evening at the meeting of the Trustees, and said there was no disagreement between himself and Dr. Ranney. "We are friends and visit each other," he said.

HORNELLSVILLE, Jan. 4.--George Bostwick, of Pulaski, Penn., was awakened late Saturday night by feeling something cold touch his face. He threw up his hand and caught hold of stick, which was instantly given a jerk by some one who had hold of the other end.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--The leaves of absence granted Capt. Charles Porter, Eighth Infantry, and Capt. Thomas Wilhelm, Eighth Infantry, have been extended two months.

LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 4.--The Democrats of the Common Council to-day withdrew from the Council, refusing to take part in its deliberations, because, as they claim, Enright, their candidate for President, was not fairly defeated. Sawyer, the Republican candidate, received 12 ...

LONDON, Jan. 5.--A torpedo has broken loose from its moorings on the coast of Tripoli and is now floating about somewhere in the Mediterranean Sea. The Government of Tripoli has been guarding the coast with torpedoes in view of the possibility of an Italian invasion.

At an early hour yesterday morning fire was discovered in the hat factory of Robert Dunlap Co., at Nostrand and Park avenues, Brooklyn, Eastern District. Michael Sullivan, the night watchman, was walking in one of the halls with a lighted lamp in his right hand when a large Newfoundland dog ran against an oil can in his left hand, causing some of the oil to flow over the lamp.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 4.--A snowstorm, which railway men say is the worst ever encountered in this State, has prevailed since Saturday morning. The weather is clearing and warmer this evening. The worst effects of the storm are near Omaha, along the St. Paul Road northward.
NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 4.--James A. Brown, Jr., fruit and produce dealer, and C.F.D. Fayerweather, blacksmith, are reported as having failed. Edmund Bricketmaier, barber, has also suspended business.

The new Brooklyn Board of Aldermen was organized yesterday. Alderman McCarthy took the Chair temporarily, and Alderman Theophilus Olena was re-elected President. After a brief speech he ordered the roll called on the vote for clerk, and John Shanley was re-elected to that position, 18 votes being cast for him. John M. Gray was chosen messenger.

The framework of six unfinished threestory wooden houses at the corner of Gerrystreet and Throop-avenue, Brooklyn, fell with a loud crash late on Monday night. The floor beams were not injured by the fall. The trouble seemed to be with the layer of bricks on top of the cellar walls, which were held together by white sand only.

The merits of the question of wages at issue between the elevated railroad company and its engineers can be fairly determined only on a careful examination of the facts and a balancing of the assertions put forth on both sides.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The following business was transacted in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day: No. 886--The Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians, appellants, vs. The United States and the Cherokee Nation. Argument continued by J.M. Wilson for appellants and by S.S. Burdett and W.A. Phillips for the appellees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The leave of absence of Capt. Cass Durham, Eighteenth infantry, has been further extended four months on Surgeon's certificate of disability; that of First Lieut. O.F. Long, Fifth Infantry, further extended two months, and that of Second Lieut. A.L.O Brien, Second Cavalry, further extended six months on Surgeon's certificate of disability.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 5.--Dr. Robert Ramsay, one of the most prominent Masons in America, died in Toronto, Ontario, last night. His home was in Orillia, Ontario. He broke one of his legs in Toronto and was taken to the hospital, where he died of heart disease.

At the annual meeting of the New-York Mercantile Exchange yesterday the report of the Free Canal Union was submitted, and it was decided that the Exchange's committee should be empowered to act for it in the distribution of the balance of the funds now in the hands of the union.

Mrs. Joicy Murray, the young woman who charged her husband, Gerald Murray, with attempting to shoot her, withdrew her complaint by permission of District Attorney Martine yesterday on promise that she would return to England, where her parents reside.

The trial of Charles G. Am Ende, the Hoboken druggist, who was accused of having, in August last, poisoned Marguerite and Ella Holtz with morphine compounded in mistake for quinine, was brought to a close in Judge McGill's court, Jersey City, yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 5.--At a special meeting of the Directors of the Academy of Music to-night, it was resolved that, as Samuel W. Fort had forfeited the confidence of the Board of Directors, he be at once discharged from his position as manager of the Academy, and that Mr. Harry J. Conway be at once appointed his successor.

Yesterday, for the fourth or fifth time, the lumber dealers and traders of the city made an abortive attempt to start a Lumber Exchange. An anonymous call was issued for a meeting at the Grand Central Hotel, and with so little result that when the time for the assembly arrived the attendance was confined to 10 lumbermen and 7 reporters.

An audience of the wonted size and comeliness attended yesterday's orchestral matinee at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The programme included nothing that had not been heard before, but it embraced no music that would not bear repetition, and all the numbers were characterized by tunefulness and tonal splendor.
It is gratifying to receive still another magazine during the month in which it is dated. The North American is now to be added to a list which includes, among others, the Century and Lippincott.

OWEGO, N.Y., Jan. 5.--At Candor, N. Y., last night Fred Schaller, aged between 55 and 60, was shot and probably fatally hurt by one George Johnson. Schaller's son was married on New Year's night last to a Miss Whitmarsh, of Catatonk, N.Y. When the couple returned to Candor a gang of ruffians gave them a serenade upon instruments intended to produce anything but harmony.

Wall-street has lately heard a good deal about a project which C.P. Huntington has on foot, likely to be of importance in railway matters. To an inquirer Mr. Huntington summarized his purpose briefly yesterday as follows:

CLEVELAND, Jan. 5.--The discontent felt among Ohio Democrats over the local appointments brought about by the influence of Senator H.B. Payne has been greatly magnified by men whose personal disappointments gave made them sore and unjust.
