NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 5.--New-Haven Italians are greatly exercised to-night over circumstances attending the burial to-day of Michael Dileone, a compatriot, who died at the New-Haven Hospital.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 5.--The County Court of Rutherford County has declared the office of Sheriff vacant, and elected a successor to fill the unexpired term of Benjamin Batey, the missing Sheriff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--Mr. Cutcheon, of Michigan, introduced in the House to-day a bill to reform the civil service and to preserve the constitutional distinction between legislative and executive duties by the organization of a bureau of civil appointments.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 5.--A small steel box containing the money stolen from the Ames Plow Company's safe last night was found unopened this afternoon in the attic over their warerooms. It is supposed that the robbers were concealed in the attic while the firemen were engaged in extinguishing the fire caused by the blowing open of the safe, and that they made their escape after the excitement had subsided.

Bark La Fiducla, (Ital.,) Facola, Smyrna 90 ds., with licorice root to order--vessel to Seager Bros., Limited. Bark Linden, (of Halifax, N.S.,) Crowe, Rotterdam 29 ds., with barrels to order--vessel to Snow Burgess.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 5.--At Pulaski to-day the Hon. Benton McMillin, member of Congress from the Fourth District, was married to Miss Marie Brown, daughter of Gov. John C. Brown. The ceremony occurred at high noon in the family homestead, Bishop Quintard performing the service.

The New-York Philharmonic Club gave its second concert of the present season at Chickering Hall last evening. The soloists of the occasion were Mrs. Richard Arnold, pianist, and Mrs. Blanche Stone Barton, soprano. The programme was an interesting one, consisting, in addition to Mrs. Barton's songs, of SaintSaens's trio in F major, Bach's suite in B minor, and Beethoven's E flat quarter.

WATERVILLE, Me., Jan. 5.--While several men were working in a ledge pit an overbanging rock, loosened by the severe storm, fell upon them. James Freeman was instantly killed, and two others were badly wounded. The deceased was from Winslow and 40 years of age.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 5.--Near Uhrichsville, Ohio, yesterday, James Parker, a farmer, took a load of grain to Kail's mill. There being no one but Mrs. Kail on the premises, she went out to show Parker where to put the grain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: John J. Higgins, Collector of Customs, District of Natchez, ...

CLIFTON SPRINGS, Jan. 5.--John Kelly was quite benefited by the treatment received while at Clifton Springs, but owing to his interest in Tammany Hall he has allowed his physician's advice to go unheeded, and is now again suffering from insomnia and nervous prostration.

A suit in equity has been begun in the United States Circuit Court by George Bowman, of Red Bank, N.J., against William R. Grace, Charles Coudert, Frederic R. Coudert, Charles D. Adams, and Thomas H. Rodman, to recover certain farm lands situated at Northfield, Staten Island.
LONDON, Jan. 5.--Mr. Ruskin writes to the Pall Mall Gazette on the Irish question the following characteristic letter:

The tenth of the current series of Thomas popular Concerts was given at the Academy of Music yesterday evening. The novelty of the programme was a suite for stringed orchestra by Grieg, recorded as opus 40, and connected as to significance, in the opinion of some of the composer's commentators, with the spirit of Ludwig Holberg's period.
The absurd verdict of the military court before which Gen. SWAIM was tried has served to direct attention to a decision of the Supreme Court which is said to have caused some uneasiness in the army.

The statement of grievances and the accompanying letter were given to Col. Hain, who laid them before the Board of Directors, after making an appointment with the committee for 11 o'clock this morning. On Saturday the committee informed P.M. Arthur, Grand Chief Engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, of the situation here, and requested him ...

The case of Warner and Work, indicted for aiding and abetting Ferdinand Ward in defrauding the Marine Bank and Gen. Grant, came up yesterday before Judge Benedict, in the criminal branch of the United States Circuit ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 5.--It is reported to-day that the Knights of Labor have decided to boycott the Fairbanks Canning Company's beef because that company has given a contract for the making of a large number of packing boxes to Soper Co., boxmakers, who employ 10 nonunion men.
HAVRE, Jan. 5.--The Gascogne, the fourth of the new steamers built for the General Transatlantic Company, has been successfully launched.

Many members of the Parliamentary Fund Association accompanied T.P. Gill, member of the English Parliament from South Louth, on board of the Arizona, on which he sailed for England yesterday afternoon.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 5.--Good weather today aided materially in raising the snow blockade. The Union Pacific main line is clear. The Kansas Division, and all branches in Kansas and Nebraska are in very bad condition. Those in Nebraska are practically abandoned for the present.

Mr. J.S. MOORE, in another column, suggests a compromise on the silver question, the chief objection to which is that it comes from the wrong side. Were it proposed by some one as devoted to the silver coinage as Mr. MOORE is to sound currency, it would be well worth considering.

ALBANY, Jan. 5.--Below is given abstracts of the official quarterly reports of all of the banks of discount and deposit operated under the State laws made to the Superintendent of the Banking Department for Dec. 26, 1885.

BOSTON, Jan.5.--The court room at Salem was crowded to-day by people who were eager to listen to the argument of Gen. Butler counsel for the accused, Henry K. Goodwin, in the Swan murder trial. The General, in beginning his address, placed particular stress on the tendency to insanity which had been shown to exist in the family of the prisoner.

LONDON, Jan. 5.--Mr. Gladstone has sum moned the Liberal members of Parliament to a meeting on the 16th inst. He privately promises them that he will then make a frank statement of the principles upon which he proposes to settle the Irish question.
MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Jan. 5.--This morning at sunrise the Hon. W.D. Lester, of Jones County, committed suicide by shooting himself in the left side with a gun. Mental depression caused the act.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 5.--George H. Ellis, publisher of the Daily Advertiser and the Evening Record, has resigned. It is stated that Henry Cabot Lodge will take his place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The Collector of Customs at New-York has been authorized to allow free entry of a solid silver communion service imported by Miss Catherine E. Wolfe, and intended for the sole use of Grace Church, New-York, the Rev. W.R. Huntington, Rector. The articles are to be classified as regalia specially imported for a religious society.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5.--The Receivers of the Reading Railroad Company have decided to retain $10,000 per day from the earnings of the Jersey Central Railroad with which to pay the disputed taxes to the State of New-Jersey, provided that the courts shall order the Reading Railroad to pay them. The amount in dispute is about $270,000.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Jan. 5.--Lorenzo Snow, one of the 12 Apostles of the Mormon Church, was convicted twice today in Ogden on separate indictments charging him with unlawful cohabitation. The defense was on the line that Snow had lived with one--the third and youngest wife exclusively ...
The Ladies' Health Protective Association met for the first time in its new quarters, No. 139 East Fifty-ninth-street, yesterday afternoon. in the absence of the President, Mrs. A.M. Sparks presided.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 5.--The warlike spirit that manifested itself in the Democratic caucus last night has materially disappeared, as also the threats made by Senator Hopple to the effect that in the event the Hamilton County members of the House were unseated, it was the duty of the Senate to withdraw from the chamber ...

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 5.--The Common Council of 1886 organized to-night by the selection of Franklin Murphy as President. Almost the first business transacted was the passage of a resolution, offered by George S. Smith, providing for the opening of a dog pound and the appointment of keepers and dog catchers.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5.--Julia Rosa Newberry, daughter of Walter L. Newberry, who left half of his fortune for the founding of a public library in Chicago, inherited under her father's will $120,000.

BOSTON, Jan. 5.--The Atchison Directors at their meeting this afternoon declared the usual dividend and issued a circular announcing that the rapid growth of Kansas during the last two years had rendered desirable the construction of new roads in that section so situated as to add to the earnings of the company and at the same time to protect its present property.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 5.--The destruction by the storm of yesterday and last night of telegraph and telephone lines is being repaired to-day, and to-night all the railroads are in working order. The passengers on a train on the Lehigh Valley Road were compelled to spend last night in the cars on account of a washout.

MADISON, Ind., Jan. 5.--After an exciting preliminary trial of over two weeks of the now famous gold brick suit of the National Branch Bank against Wolf and Briggs, alias Dan Brown, for conspiracy, Magistrate Cravens this evening at 5 o'clock rendered a long decision acquitting the defendants. The court was crowded and many spectators cheered. Grand Jury indictments are expected to follow.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 5.--Jacob Loewenstein Co., wholesale clothiers, of this city, have suspended business. The cause of the failure was hard times, slow collections, and the inability of the firm to meet its obligations at the specified time.

WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 5.--The large brass factory of Brown Brothers was closed up last night on the serving of an attachment by the Shoe and Leather Bank of New-York for $30,000. Philo Brown was one of the early brothers, and in his life the establishment obtained its reputation and wealth.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 5.--This city has been free from labor troubles for a long time but now a strike has been inaugurated by the employes in the cigar manufactories which doubtless will involve a thousand men and a large number of women.

For years the engineers and firemen employed on the elevated roads had not been satisfied with their lot. They entered the employ of the company under an agreement that eight hours should constitute a day and that for a day's labor an engineer should receive $3.50. Little by little they found their time encroached upon.
The Rev. M.E. Karlsson and James W. Ash and family arrived here yesterday from Liverpool by the steamer Abyssinia.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Jan. 5.--A sad case of dementia was developed in this city last night. Mr. Joseph Degnan, a prominent business man of Tunkhannock, Wyoming County, Penn., was accosted on the street by a merchant of this city, who had known him intimately several years ago.
Roscoe Conkling contributed $50 to the Grant Monument fund yesterday. It was forwarded to the association through S.L.M. Barlow Arthur M. Dodge contributed $100. The fund amounts to $113,556.98.

Among the many delegations that visited Mayor Whitney, of Brooklyn, yesterday in the interest of some candidate for a political position was one composed of lager-beer brewers, who wished to see Peter P. Huberty occupy the Chair of Excise Commissioner instead of John ...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5.--The ticket for a Board of Managers to serve with Mr. Gowen is announced to be I.V. Williamson, John Wannamaker, Peter C. Hollis, Dr. Hostetter, and Mark W. Watson. The two last named gentlemen live in Pittsburg.
ALBANY, Jan. 5.--The Legislature of 1886 formally organized at noon to-day. Clerk Charles A. Chickering called the Assembly to order, and prayer was offered by the Rev. Dr. Smart, of this city.

It was reported yesterday in a dispatch describing the epidemic of typhus fever in the Albany Penitentiary that the first prisoner attacked was supposed to have caught the disease in the Kings County Penitentiary.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 5.--Final decrees were entered in the United States Circuit Court to-day in the suits of the American Bell Telephone Company and others against the Baxter Overland Telephone and Telegraph Company, Penn Overland Telephone and Telegraph Company, and the Overland Telephone Company and others.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 5.--Pension Agent Errett yesterday issued to Alexander Gilchrist of Indiana, Penn., the largest pension ever paid to a private soldier. His back pay aggregated $12,151, and the money came to a blind, decrepit old man, who has been an inmate of the noorhouse for 12 years.

Henry, or "Kid," Miller and his ally, Henry Mallon, who were arrested as bunko steerers by Capt. Williams on Monday in Unionsquare, avoided commitment as vagrants yesterday by the trick known in police vernacular as "showing up the boodle." When they were rearraigned before Justice Ford, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, Col. Charles S. Spencer asked them if they were vagrants.
The following additional sums were received yesterday from the Hospital Saturday and Sunday collection by the General Treasurer, Mr. Charles Lanier, No. 26 Nassau-street:
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5.--Mrs. Lilian Conway Camblos will go to New-York to-morrow to consult with one of the theatrical managers there relative to a position on the operatic stage.

ALBANY, Jan. 5.--The report of Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine was submitted to the Legislature to-day. Six State banks were organized during the year ending Oct. 1, with an aggregate capital of $525,000. The Genesee County Bank, at Batavia, was converted from a national bank. The Herkimer Bank and the Union Bank of Rochester had been private banks.

C. Amory Stevens, of Woodburg, Long Island, who is a Trustee of the Stevens estate, was yesterday arrested at his office at No. 58 Broad-street, on complaint of George H. Richardson, a fruit dealer, of No. 228 Greenwichstreet, and who lives at the Barrett House, who charges him with conspiracy.

In grace and beauty Mme. Modjeska's embodiment of Mary Stuart surpasses that of any actress who has been seen in Shiller's noble drama in this city of late years. The character has had several representatives whose dramatic powers have elevated them among their contemporaries. The Mary Stuart of Janauschek is to-day a performance of wonderful force and symmetry.

DEAR SIR: The correspondence between Messrs. Greene and Batterson, published yesterday and to-day, and the important interests to which it is collateral, induce me to write to you and to the other Directors of the Connecticut Mutual. I am advised by those who think they know, that I miscalculate your power in the premises, that Mr. Greene holds the proxies, ...
A well dressed man engaged rooms at the Manhattan Hotel, Broadway and Canalstreet, yesterday. He acted very strangely, and the clerk came to the conclusion that his guest was insane.
Mr. Milnes Levick is ill at his home with rheumatism. His place in Mr. Hill's company at the Union-Square will be filled temporarily by Mr. Frank Tannahill.

"This is the only night in the year and the only assemblage in which I am tempted to think of my congregation in the line of money," said Mr. Beecher last night in his brief remarks preliminary to the annual renting of the pews and seats in Plymouth Church. "I don't think very much on that subject even on this night, ...

Between 500 and 600 engineers, firemen, and hostlers employed on the elevates roads met in a hall at Third-avenue and Eighty-sixthstreet last evening. The object of the meeting was to explain to such of them ...

BOSTON, Jan. 5.--A meeting of business men of Haverhill was held to-day to consider the feasibility of constructing a railroad from Haverhill to Lawrence. A committee was appointed to take into consideration the project and to confer with the Boston and Lowell and the Boston and Maine Railroads.

James G. Batterson, Esq.: DEAR SIR: I see in this evening's papers an open letter from you referring to my letter to Messrs. McCurdy, Hyde, and Beers, in which you charge me first, with breach of confidence; second, with incorrect statement.
ALBANY, Jan. 5.--The message of Gov. Hill, presented to the Legislature to-day, is a long document, embracing 36 printed pages, and covering a variety of subjects of more or less interest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 5.--The City Council last night passed to print an order introduced by Supervisor Farwell, author of the work, "Chinese at Home and Abroad," making it a misdemeanor, with a heavy penalty attached, to continue holding "sand lot" meetings, which ...

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Jan. 5.--Judge Furst heard argument here to-day on the rule granted at the regular session last month to show cause why the executions on which the property and corporate rights of the South Pennsylvania Railroad were levied upon should not be stayed and the judgments opened.

General Manager F.K. Hain was seen at his residence last night, and when asked what reasons had determined the company to take the initiative and order the withdrawal of the Second and Ninth avenue trains he replied:

PORT JERVIS, Jan. 5.--J.M. Snook, conductor, and Peter Garrabrant, flagman, two old and experienced employes of the Erie Railway, have been discharged by the company, the authorities having decided that they were responsible for the serious and costly accident at ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 5.--In the course of the exciting election of officers of the Board of Trade, which began yesterday, Robert Lindblom, one of the candidates for the Vice-Presidency, saw fit to issue a circular reflecting severely on the way in which Director John Bryant, another candidate for the same office, was nominated. Among the expressions used in the circular were "sneak thief" and "false prefenses."
Burglars took advantage of the severe storm of wind and rain that prevailed on Monday night to make a general raid on the business places in the town of Bedford, Westchester County.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5.--J.S. Gratz, the Chicago jeweler, doing business under the name of J.S. Gratz Co., who sold out his business here on Dec. 31, leaving a number of creditors in New-York in the lurch, departed from this city for some point in Texas on Jan. 1. As he sent his wife to Texas two months ago, it is supposed he had been planning the sale for some time.

ALBANY, Jan. 5.--Ex-State Treasurer Nathan D. Wendell died suddenly of heart disease this afternoon. He went to the Merchants' National Bank at the usual time this morning, and shortly before 11 o'clock remarked that he was not feeling well, and complained of a pain in the chest.

Inquiries were made at Police Headquarters last night for James Taylor, 19 years old, who was unaccountably absent from his home. Young Taylor lived with his parents at No. 478 West Twenty-second-street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--Speaker Carlisle went to the House this morning with his list of committees prepared for submission as soon as the Chaplain had finished his prayer and the Journal had been read. He and Mr. Morrison and Mr. Willis looked as if they had had a hard night of it, and they had, having been busy up to 2 o'clock this morning.

The General Passenger Agents have determined to put a stop to the difficulties and annoyances growing out of the abuse of the free pass system. At a meeting yesterday it was agreed not to issue passes to the employes of the connecting roads except upon the written request of the General Passenger Agent.

Gov. HILL'S annual message to the Legislature bears evidence of having been very carefully prepared, and there is much in it to commend. It is not only far in advance of that submitted last year, but is in many respects a clear and able document.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 5.--This morning about 11 o'clock John McGinne and his sister were seated in a spring wagon drawn by one horse. When they reached the village of Plains and were on top of a hill, the earth gave way under them. McGinne called to his sister to jump, and both leaped from the wagon.

Association Hall was filled last evening with clergymen and others, members of the Evangelical Alliance of the United States, who had assembled to honor the memory of the late Rev. Dr. S. Irenaeus Prime. An oil portrait of Dr. Prime occupied a prominent place on the platform. William E. Dodge, Jr., presided.

There was a large gathering of friends and relatives of the late James Arnold Hearn at the funeral service held last evening at the family residence, No. 2,086 Fifth-avenue. Friends came from Philadelphia and Boston. Many employes of the firm of which Mr. Hearn was a member were present.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 5.--The creditors of the George W. Miles Fish Company, of Milford, met in this city to-day to consult with George W. Gunn, Trustee on the insolvent estate, and decide upon some plan of action to bring about a settlement of their claims.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 5.--Mrs. Lucht, who was attacked with hydrophobia on Saturday night, died last evening in great agony.

The Democratic politician has been circulating among down-town "business men" in a lively way for the past week or more laying pipe for that Delmonico dinner to Gov. Hill, which is set down for next Friday night.
Stockholders of the old Boston, Hartford and Erie Railroad Company held a meeting down town yesterday and discussed a proposal made to them for the practical wiping out of their stock.

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 5.--The charges preferred against the Rev. George R. Bristor, Pastor of the Spring Valley Methodist Episcopal Church, or criminal intimacy with Ida Downs, a young girl employed as a domestic in his family, were investigated to-day.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 5.--The condition of Keene, the actor, is materially improved to-day, and he is progressing satisfactorily toward recovery.

WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 5.--The greatest excitement prevailed here to-day when it was announced that the police had been called out to support the Street Inspector and his men in a fight over the Burnham-street crossing with the New-York and New-England Railroad men.

When Mr. George F. Williams was asked yesterday about the progress of negotiations between the Metropolitan and Brooklyn Baseball Clubs regarding the possession of Orr and Roseman, the Mets' Secretary laughed and said:

There were few vacant seats in the old John-Street Methodist Church at the business men's meeting yesterday noon. Old and middle-aged men formed the greater part of the gathering, though there was a fair sprinkling of younger men and even a few ladies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--Mr. Wilson, of Iowa, called up in the Senate to-day the resolution heretofore offered by him, calling on the Secretary of the Interior for a copy of each report made by the Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad, from ...

Mrs. SARAH A. KELLEY, of Honesdale, Penn., cherishes a large and laudable ambition. She wishes to be the Bard of the Nation. Her petition to Congress sets forth that her claims to this uncreated office are that she has contributed to the perpetuation of the Union, directly or indirectly, a husband, a father, two brothers, and a brother-in-law, and that she has a family to support.

A sailor named Richard Walleny hanged himself last night in the cellar of No. 101 Bloomfield-street, Hoboken. Life was extinct when the body was cut down. The suicide was 35 years old, and was apparently happy when last seen alive last evening.

The last trains on the Second-avenue division of the elevated railways left the termini at 7:30 P.M., and the last on the Ninth-avenue division at 7:57 P.M., yesterday, in accordance with the usual schedule. Then the announcement was sent out that no trains would ...

The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company is going vigorously to work to make good its recent assurances that the continuance of its line through New-Jersey to Staten Island will be pushed with all possible speed.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5.--A person calling himself "Dr." Charles Bartholdy was arraigned before Justice Hammer to-day on two charges--for failing to report cases of contagious diseases to the health authorities and practicing medicine without a license.

The whitmore Nicoll Company, a corporation organized to manufacture leather, was placed yesterday in the hands of a Receiver. The proceedings were instituted by John Campbell Co. on a judmnent for $100 obtained in the Supreme Court yesterday.

Miss Mather's first performance of Leah, given at the Union-Square Theatre last evening, resulted in a personal triumph much more definite than that which accompanied her first appearance, in the same house, as Juliet.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 5.--J.M. Ashley, Jr., Superintendent of the Toledo and Ann Arbor Road, was arrested last night on the charge of obstructing United States mails, for which offense the United States statutes provide a penalty not to exceed $100 fine.

During the storm that closed its wild career yesterday morning 1.56 inches of rain fell in this city. Calculated in another way, this means that 156 tons, or 43,680 gallons, of water fell on each acre of ground on Manhattan Island.

MATAMORAS, Texas, Jan. 5.--A telegraphic order was received here Saturday night from President Diaz directing that Senor Yturria, the candidate approved by the State Legislature, be immediately seated as Mayor.
A special meeting of the Seawanhaka Yacht Club was held last night at Delmonico's. The object was to consider the differences between the Trustees of the club and Vice-Commodore ...

Jay Gould, if his own declarations go for anything, starts this morning for Charleston, to board his yacht for that much advertised trip in Southern waters. He drops all sorts of mysterious hints as to how long he intends to remain away from Wall-street, and the average man who has listened to his confidences is sadly in doubt whether the vacation is to be for a fortnight or for 40 years.
The call of States for the introduction of bills was continued to-day in the House, 790 measures being introduced. The call was not completed.

The committee in charge of John McCullough's estate, consisting of William F. Johnson and M.W. Canning, of Philadelphia, and Capt. William M. Conner, of New-York, had a conference at the Hoffman House yesterday with the dead actor's friend, John W. Mackay, about the erection of a suitable monument.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 6.--A storm of unusual violence prevails in the mountains. The blockades on the railroad are the worst known for years. The Signal Service officer here says the storm originated in the Rocky Mountains four days ago.
The following additional sums were received from the Hospital Saturday and Sunday collection yesterday by Mr. Charles Lanier, General Treasurer, No. 26 Nassau-street:

BUFFALO, Jan. 6.--About 40 leading grocers and other milk and butter dealers in Buffalo were lately arrested charged with selling impure milk and oleomargarine as butter. Assistant State Dairy Commissioner Perry made the complaint. The Erie County Board of Supervisors to-day directed the District Attorney to prosecute all persons indicted on these charges, and to make strenuous efforts to have them punished to the full extent of the law.

At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, Brooklyn, and Seashore Railroad Company yesterday the following persons were elected Directors for the ensuing year: William Strauss, Samuel Lawrence, Moritz Meyier, Charles F. MacLean, George W. Smith, Moses Rappaport, and Charles F. Estwick.

The paintings and marbles shown at the Academy of Design which belonged to the late Hon. Edwin D. Morgan have very great disparity in merit, and represent many years of collecting, during which the taste of the collector changed much.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6.--Dispatches from Pittsburg, Penn., state that the Supreme Court of that State has denied a new trial to Milton Weston, formerly of this city, who was convicted in Pennsylvania some years ago of manslaughter. This announcement was accompanied by a rumor that Weston proposed to jump his bail and leave the country.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 6.--Dr. Francis Bridge, of Philadelphia, State Veterinary Surgeon, came here yesterday, and, accompanied by Surgeon Weber, Inspector of Lancaster County, visited the farm of A.S. Fry, at Masonville, where a herd of 100 cattle are affected with pieuro-pneumonia, ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 6.--A new and most interesting point in the great prohibition fight here turned up to-day in the shape of a new contest. The law says that within 20 days from the announcement of the result of the election by...

The car drivers of the Third-Avenue Railroad reported yesterday that their committee called upon Mr. Lyon, President of the road, and asked him for an answer to their request to shorten their hours of labor to 12 hours. Mr. Lyon asked the committee for more time, until Monday, because he said that a meeting of the Board of Trustees could not be held until Saturday at the earliest.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 6.--Moses Koch was held for a hearing this afternoon for assaulting Mrs. Louisa V. Lamb. Mrs. Lamb owed Koch a balance of $1 on last month's rent of a room which she hired from him. This morning he went to her room while she was dressing, and being refused admittance kicked in the door, which, in opening, struck Mrs. Lamb on the...

Officers of Gen. James McQuade Post, No. 557, were installed at their headquarters, No. 234 Spring-street, last evening, by Commander William McEntee, of Dahlgren Post, No. 113, as follows: Commander--Alexander Francisco;

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Gov. Hill this morning gave a hearing in the case of Giuseppe Giudici, the Brooklyn murderer, sentenced to be hanged on the 22d of this month. Ex-Assemblyman John G. Loghe, of Brooklyn, and the Hon. N.C. Moak, of this city,

John Pell, the aged proprietor of a leather and finding store at No.148 Market-street, Newark, was busy in his store at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, when a man nearly 6 feet high walked in and asked for a strip of leather.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 6.--The regulations admitting American cattle for Northwest ranches free of duty, which expired on Jan. 1, have been extended until Sept. 1, by an order in Council.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 6.--There was a decidedly lively time in the Senate this afternoon over the adoption of the new rules to govern that body. The propositions which were adopted make Clerk Caliandigham the autocrat of the Senate.

The committee appointed by the Republican County Committee to investigate the cause of the discrepancy between the votes for the Republican candidates for Governor and for Sheriff of this county at the late election have been called together several times...

BOSTON, Jan. 6.--On the arrival at this port of the Allan steamer Carthagenia, from Glasgow, a number of cattlemen who had sailed from Montreal were landed here and turned adrift without any money to pay either their board or their passage back to Montreal. They were in a destitute condition.

BUCHANAN, Ga., Jan. 6.--The murder of J.W. Holland by Bud Hughes has created a great sensation here, where both men were well known. Both were prosperous farmers, and were members of the same Baptist church. Some time ago Hughes contracted a debt with Holland, in satisfation for which he proposed to give notes to cover the new year.

Arthur E. Marsh, a foreman in the employ of Koch, Sons Co., stationers, was arraigned in Part I, of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Recorder Smyth, for larceny from his employers. Marsh had charge of gold leaf used in the manufacture of some of the stationery articles, and on May 29 stole $1,200 worth and disappeared.
Mr. JAY GOULD and his associates of the Manhattan Railway Company discovered yesterday that there are powers in the community which even they may not safely defy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6.--Citizens of Dakota recently formally organized a State Government, needing but the sanction of Congress to give it life, and elected a set of State officers and State Representatives to the National Legislature at Washington. Of the officers thus chosen Senators A.J. Edgerton and G.C. Moody, Congressman D. Kanause, and Gov. A.C. Mallette, together with Col. J.H. Drake and the Rev. J.S. Ward, ...

As Emil Luther, a German cabinetmaker, was entering the doorway of his residence, No. 259 West Twenty-sixth-street, at 6:30 o'clock last evening, he was attacked by four men, who dragged him out on the sidewalk and rubbed him of 6 cents and a pocket handkerchief, all he had about him.

Surprise has been expressed in Newark, N.J., over the kind of nominations Mayor Haynes has made for members of the Police and Fire Boards in Newark. The control of the two departments has been heretofore in the hands of the Common Council.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 6.--George Lamoreaux is said to be the only Democrat in Highland Mills. Once upon a time there was another, but he joined the Prohibitionists. Not long ago Lamoreaux's wife presented him with a handsome boy baby.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 6.--The Ninth National Bank of New-York yesterday filed a suit in the United States Circuit Court against Rails County on 14 bonds issued by the county in July, 1870, payable 10 years after date. The bonds were a part of a subscription of $275,000 by the county to the capital stock of the St. Louis and Keokuk Railroad Company. The bonds and coupons sued on aggregate nearly $17,000.

Steamship Picqua. (Br.,) Prowse, Catania, Nov. 24, Messina 27th, Palermo 29th. Mulaga Dec. 17, and Gibraitar 22d, with fruit, , to Phelps Bros. Co. Arr. at the Bar at 7:30 P.M. had easterly winds and fine weather the entire passage.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6.--Franklin B. Gowen was at his office in the Forrest Building today. He declined to state whom he would put upon his ticket for manager in the place of the late J.B. Lippincott on the ground that it would be indelicate to talk of the matter until after the funeral, which is announced for Friday.

LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 6.--The suits of the Erie Telegraph and Telephone Company against the old local telephone syndicate--William A. Ingham, Charles J. Glidden, Loren W. Downs, William H. Bent, and Alonzo A. Coburn--was settled to-day.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 6.--The creditors of the old banking house of Charles H. Sweet Co., having been paid the principal in full, were notified to-day that the interest due on their claims will be paid on or before the 20th inst. The firm failed about three years ago for $380,000.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 6.--An inquest which was concluded here late to-night on the body of Willie Crowe, the 15-months-old infant of John Crowe and Susan Barton, disclosed a terrible tale of inhumanity on the part of the little one's parents, who are a worthless, degraded couple.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6.--Richard Bailey, who had lived 18 months in Chicago, died yesterday morning at the county hospital. It was he who first produced Gilbert and Sullivan's operetta "Patience" on the American stage. His wife, Amy Goodrich, appeared in the title role. Mr. Bailey's habits were somewhat intemperate during the last few months of his life.

The amendments to the rules of the Assembly submitted yesterday by the Speaker and adopted by that body do not go so far as Mr. HUSTED'S speech of the day before would have led one to expect. Brief as that speech was, the programme laid down in it was sufficiently ambitious.

The cold wave that inhabitants of the city have expected and wondered at its non-appearance got here all right last night, and made itself felt to the pedestrians who had occasion to be out. The mercury hovered around 32 and 85 all the morning, and at 3:30 in the afternoon stood at 33 .

The statistics of the Supreme Court work during 1885 show that at Chambers 7,680 contested motions were heard and disposed of, nearly one-third of them having been before Judge Donohue, next to whom was Judge Andrews in the amount of work done in that branch of the court. Judge Andrews spent 81 days in Chambers and Judge Donohue 68. The remainder of the work done there was by Judges Barrett, Lawrence, and Van Brunt.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the cabinetmakers complained that the New-York Woodworking Company was discharging its union workmen, and that when any man applied for work he was asked whether he belonged to a union, and if he replied in the affirmative he was refused employment.

Josiah B. Richardson having obtained a preliminary injunction restraining the NewEngland Iron Company from prosecuting its suit against the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company, argument on a motion for the continuance of the restrictive order was heard by Judge Freedman, in the Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday.

Justice Ford held an examination yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court in the case of Harry M. Wright and his wife, Kitty, of No. 107 Clinton-place, who were arrested on Tuesday afternoon on suspicion of having abducted and detained from her home Minnie Baker, otherwise known as Minnie Vancaeyseele, the 13-year-old stepdaughter of Louis Vancaeyzeele, a Belgian waiter at the Hotel Normandie.
PARIS, Jan. 6.--Advices from Madagascar report the arrival at Tananarivo, the capital, of M. Sequier, the French Consul.

Before the conclusion of the call of States today the House adjourned. There were 882 bills introduced. Only two States and the Territories remain to be called, but the recognition of members who were absent upon the recent bill days may occupy a couple of hours.

Sir Richard Sutton, of Genesta fame, is engaged to the daughter of Sir Vincent Rowland Corbet, of Reynald Hall, Shropshire. Miss Corbet was last season a provincial belle. The union will connect two very old families. Sir Richard is directly descended from Kina George III.'s Under Secretary of State, who held office at the commencement of the Revolutionary war.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 6.--Herbert S. Graham, a lawyer of Nanticoke, was arrested by a United States Marshal last night on a charge of acting as a United States detective without authority. He was held in $500 bail for a hearing on Friday next.

Mr. and Mrs. Ziba H. Kitchen celebrated their golden wedding last night at their residence, No. 448 West Twenty-third-street. They were married 50 years ago at Newark, N.J., at the residence of Mrs. Kitchen's father, Moses Ward.

MONTREAL, Jan. 6.--In the case of the absconding jeweler, Picard, who left the city about two months ago, the Trustees and guardians of the estate have discovered that for three years he had been carrying on a swindle upon the customs here, and that he had succeeded in defrauding the revenue out of 150,000f.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6.--The members of the House filled the chamber again this morning at prayer time, not so much to hear the orotund phrases of the Chaplain as to learn the disposition that had been made of the membership of the standing committees.

It now transpires that Richard Woolley, the sailor who strangled himself in Hoboken, N.J., Tuesday night, was moved by jealousy. In the trunk on which he sat to end his life was found a letter signed Gretchen, making an appointment with him.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 6.--A very interesting episode has just come to light illustrating the evils arising from corresponding with strangers. A beautiful and intelligent young lady stepped from a train at Canisteo yesterday, inquired the way to the residence of George Benjamin, ...

The steamship Advance, of the United States and Brazil Mail Line, which arrived yesterday from Rio Janeiro, brought six men belonging to the whaling schooner Mary E. Simmons. They were rescued on Dec. 1 in an exhausted condition, after having passed two days in an open boat without food or water.

The reception and ball tendered to Henry E. Dixey by his friends and admirers is to take place at the Metropolitan Opera House to-night. It will commemorate the five hundredth representation of "Adonis," and promises to be a great success.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6.--Senator Van Wyck today offered in the Senate the petition of the National Labor League praying that Lieut.-Gen. Philip H. Sheridan he made a full General. He asked that it be printed in the Record, and also be referred to the Committee on Military Affairs. It was so ordered.

Wo Kee, a Chinese merchant of Mottstreet, had three of his countrymen arrested yesterday and taken before the bar of the Tombs Police Court, where he charged them with having flourished pistols and knives and threatened to murder him in his own house.

The annual meeting of the Society for Instruction in Frst Aid to the Injured, at No. 21 University-place, yesterday afternoon, was well attended. John Jay, President of the society, in his opening address stated that upward of 5,000 pupils had been given instruction, and 200 cases of relief of suffering had been reported.

The Rosalind of Modjeska is an almost faultless piece of comedy acting. If English were the artist's native tongue the single blemish that it has would not exist. The slight foreign accent which is plainly noticeable in the delivery of blank verse we have all grown to like, however, and it serves now only to remind us that Modjeska, a Polish woman...

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 6.--The Hon. Daniel H. Day, one of the most respected citizens and business men of Atlanta, was run over and killed in the heart of the city by the 10:30 Central Railroad train to-day. Mr. Day, who was 76 years old and somewhat deaf, had just turned off the Whitehall-street crossing, when he saw a train in front of him.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 6.--Prior to the adjournment of the National Council of the Cherokee Nation, held recently at Tahlequah, there was a quarrel between the Senate and Chief Bushyhead over the appointment of two delegates to represent the Cherokee interests at Washington.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6.--The contract for the current printing of the Legislature was to-day awarded to John L. Murphy, of the State Gazette, in this place. Other bidders were McCrellish Quigley, of Trenton; Sinnickson, Chew, of Camden, and the Camden Courier Publishing Company, that has done the work for the past two years.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 6.--Judgments were taken in the United States Circuit Court to-day against United States Senator Dwight M. Sabin, for an aggregate sum of over $85,000. The claims were all for money due on promissory notes drawn by the Northwestern Car and Manufacturing Company, Seymour Sabin ...

LONDON, Jan. 6.--A number of unofficial Liberal members of Parliament have been making overtures to the Parnellites for the co-operation of the latter in raising a question as to home rule during the debate on the address in reply to the Queen's speech.

GALESBURG, Ill., Jan. 6.--An important session of the Board of Trustees of the Brotherhood of Railway Brakemen has just closed here. The most important matter was the consideration of a proposition to receive into the brotherhood the members of the Conductors and Brakemen's Benevolent Association of Canada, enrolling 8,000 names, the amalgamation to be...

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 6.--A very distressing accident occurred last evening at Tusculum College, Greenville. William Kennedy, a student, was in the dormitory with a number of companions, when one of them picked up an old army pistol from his trunk and began flourishing it, supposing it was not loaded. It was accidentally discharged, whereupon Kennedy clasped his hands to his breast, crying, "I'm shot!" and fell dead.

John Ericsson was as busy at work yesterday as he ever was in his life. Capt. Ericsson is happy in the thought and knowledge that he has passed the Good ripe old age of fourscore years and two, and will, if his good health continues, celebrate his eighty-third birthday July...

The Lower Rio Grande has for some time been the scene of outrages on the part of the desperadoes who infest it and impartially plunder the people of either bank. Hidalgo County, Texas, has been specially subject to these depredations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6.--Mr. Gray called up in the Senate to-day Mr. Beck's resolution of inquiry regarding the payment of customs duties in coin and the application of that coin to the purposes of the sinking fund. The resolution having been read. Mr. Gray said he would vote for it, but for reasons very different from those which actuated Mr. Beck and those who thought with him.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 6.--In the weekly review of the flour production for its issue of Jan. 8 the Northwestern Miller will say: "The milling situation seems to grow worse rather than to improve despite the former prediction of the millers to the contrary.

Gen. Shaler met the Sanitary Inspectors of the First and Second Divisions at Sanitary Headquarters yesterday and urged them to do their whole duty although their salaries and numbers had been reduced.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 6.--John Stone, of Beamsville village, went to the house of his sister, in the same place, yesterday and asked Maud Hodge, his niece, to shoot him with his revolver. The girl refused and Stone fired two shots at her.

Evervthing goes on swimmingly in swelling the Irish Parliamentary fund, and the committees, which have been at work during the past two days, report a growth of enthusiasm and a hearty desire to co-operate in the work far in excess of even the most sanguine expectations of the leaders.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 6.--Frank X. Pfaffinger, a young Bavarian physician of this city, has been relieved of an exceedingly embarrassing social relation. He was the especial bone of contention between two women-- his wife and a woman named Mary Epp.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6.--The proceedings in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day were as follows: No. 985--The United States, appellant, vs. ...

By direction of the Archbishop of NewYork the six priests recently ordained at St. Joseph's Provincial Seminary at Troy have received letters of assignment. The Rev. Dennis F. Coyle commences his mission at St. Patrick's Church, in Mott-street, as an assistant to the Rector, the Rev. John F. Kearney.
It was generally assumed when Mr. BECK made his violent assault on the Administration's policy regarding silver coinage that he would not be answered from the Democratic side of the Senate.

Adolph Goldsmith, wholesale dealer in jewelry at No. 38 Maiden-lane, who made an assignment Tuesday, has liabilities of about $130,000, and the nominal value of the assets is placed at about $100,000. Poor trade, slow collections, and depreciation are ascribed as the causes of the failure.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Jan. 6.--State detectives passed through here early this morning with a prisoner arrested at Rutland, Vt., for complicity with McNeil, the absconding President of the Lancaster National Bank. The prisoner gave the name of John Willard, but the officers state that it is not his right name.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 6.--To-day the body of Lewis H. Barker was taken to Oppenham, N.Y., for burial. Barker was a bookkeeper for a leading glove factory and had accumulated considerable property. On Cristmas Day he went to call on a Miss Maggie Norton, and was taken ill suddenly.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., Jan. 6.--The damage here by the freshet is greater than has been reported. At 1 o'clock this morning the employes of Leuckel's livery stable were awakened to rescue the drowning horses in the stalls. By 4 O'clock the Lehigh River and the creek that...
"American."--It is a star. "J.B."--The seating capacity of the Metropolitan Opera House is about 3,000.

The citizens of Middletown, Conn., sent in a handsome contribution to the Grant Monument fund yesterday, and set an example which the committee hope and believe will be imitated by hundreds of small towns near New-York. The Executive Committee will meet to-day, and some action is expected upon the plan for the memorial.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 6.--There had been for several days a good deal of anxiety mong the Republican managers of the State concerning the organization of the Legislature, in which a variety of conflicting elements was known to exist. The Republican majority in the House over the Democrats is only 11, ...

Persons who transact a great deal of business through that mails will find the new Local Official Postal Guide a valuable aid. The first number of this publication was issued on Monday, and its 60 pages contain information of every conceivable description relating to the sending or receiving of mail matter. This guide, which is designed especially for the cities of...

The stockholders of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company held their annual meeting yesterday at No. 49 Fulton-street, Brooklyn. President Henry W. Putnam presented his first annual report, showing that the company owns about 7 miles of double track, ...

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Word was received here this afternoon that the body of a woman about 50 years of age was found floating in the Harlem River to-day. From the description it is believed to be that of Mrs. Jane Lovelett, of Newburg.

A memorial tablet in honor of the late Rev. Lot Jones, D.D., was unveiled in the Church of the Epiphany, in Forty-seventh-street, near Lexington-avenue, last evening. The Rev. Mr. Jones was the first Rector of the old Epiphany, now the Church of the Reformation, in Stanton...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 6.--The street car dynamiters, Pinkerton, Kennen, Withers, Byrns, and Withrow, were placed on trial here to-day. Withrow surprised the others by turning State's evidence, whereupon the attorney for the defendants objected to his testimony on the ground that a criminal charge was then resting against him.

HOMER, N.Y., Jan. 6.--It was expected by the three large wagon manufacturing firms in Homer--Brockway Co., Gage, Hitchcock Co., and the Homer Wagon Company--employing nearly 500 men, that they would be able to start their works with a full force on Monday, and that all of their old employes would return.

John W. Morgan, who keeps a boarding house for sailors and immigrants at No. 125 Charlton-street, was accused before Justice Ford, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, by his wife, Elizabeth, of having abandoned her and having failed for two years to contribute to her support.

Mayor Whitney, of Brooklyn, announced his most important appointments at noon yesterday. He stated privately that he had not intended to make known his choice of officials for several days to come, but the unpleasant interview with Mr. Scharmann on Tuesday and the far from agreeable talks to which he has listened from other persons led him to settle the matter at once. The appointments will date from Feb. 1 and are as follows:
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 6.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20. Drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 6.--The Executive Committee of the Trustees of Cornell University, at a meeting this afternoon, appointed Dr. J.G. Schurman to the new Chair of Ethics and Philosophy endowed in memory of the wife of Henry W. Sage with $50,000 cash and a new ten-thousand-dollar house to be built on the campus. Dr. Schurman is at present Professor of Philosophy and Ethics in Dalhousie College, at Halifax, Nova Scotia.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 6.--Brayley McClung, wholesale milliners, have failed, with liabilities estimated at $100,000, and assets of $110,000. T.E. Epstein, dealer in gentlemen's furnishing goods, has also failed, with liabilities of $50,000.

MALDEN, Mass., Jan. 6.--The Boston Rubber Shoe Company's factory at Edgeworth started on three-quarter time this morning. The weather for the past two months has been very unfavorable for the rubber trade. The resumption of work at this factory affects about 5,000 persons.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6.--"Peggy" Frank, a one-legged trump, paid 10 cents for a bed in a cheap lodging house in South Clark-street last night and went to sleep. Gustave Reiber, the clerk, saw that he was drunk and put him out. Frank returned to the house this morning and demanded his dime.

The Hotelkeepers' Association met at the Grand Central Hotel yesterday to consider the garbage question, Mr. E.L. Merrifield, of the Continental Hotel, presiding in the absence of the regular Chairman, Mr. Hitchcock, of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel.

The regular monthly meeting and annual election of officers of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, of this city, was held on Tuesday evening at the clubrooms. One Hundred and Thirtieth-street and Third-avenue.
QUEENSTOWN, Jan. 6.--The steamer Alaska, before reported off Fastnet, arrived here at 5 P.M.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Dr. Henry S. Dimock, for several years a physician at Grove Springs, a fashionable Summer resort on Keuka Lake, who for some time has been the medical adviser at Crystal Springs, and who will be remembered by many people of New-York, as well as those of Western cities, has become violently insane, and this evening was taken to Willard Asylum.

BUFFALO, Jan. 6.--A convention of the National Tobacco Growers' Association was held to-day at the Tifft House. There were present representatives of the principal leafgrowing districts in the country, including Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Wisconsin, and the Big Flats and Onondaga district, New-York. E. N. Phelps, of Connecticut, presided.

LEWES, Del., Jan. 6.--The contract between the quarrymen and the Government for furnishing stone for filling in the entrance to the Delaware Breakwater expired last week, and work has been suspended for the present. Col. Swazey, who has superintended the work, says over 30,000 tons of stone have been dumped there, and that the water is still from five to seven fathoms deep. He thinks it will take three more years to finish the work.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 6.--The talk going on is Columbus of late about some Republican being elected United States Senator by Democratic votes with the aid of anti-Sherman Republicans recalls an episode in the lives of Garfield and Hayes, when either might have been Senator by similar means but could never have been President.

If it be true, as is claimed, that the condition of the iron trade is the pulse of the business of the country, it is safe to say, basing the assertion upon the outlook in the iron business, that the coming year will be one in which business generally will be much better than it was last year.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 6.--A queer freak in prohibition is reported from Lawrenceville, the county seat of Gwinnett, one of the most prominent towns in the State. One of the members of the retiring Town Council was a whisky dealer, white the Council to come in to-day would be composed exclusively of prohibitionists.

ALBANY, Jan. 6.--The report of Superintendent of State Prisons Isaac V. Baker, Jr. for the year ending Sept. 30 last discusses at length various methods of employing convict labor. The Legislature of 1884 abolished contract labor and appropriated $500,000, which sum, together with an unexpended balance of $81,341,69,...

The first bout in the encounter between the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company and its engineers was won by the letter with the aid of an element which neither the company nor the men had taken into consideration.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 6.--At a meeting of the cigarmakers to-day it was resolved to make the strike general unless all of the manufacturers concede to the request of the union that all non-union men be discharged. The Cigarmakers' Union say that the order for their action came from the International Union, and that a similar order will be sent out generally through the State.

ALBANY, Jan. 6.--Speaker Husted submitted to the Assembly to-day his proposed amendments to the rules. Calling Mr. McClelland, of Westchester, to the chair, he came down into the well and read his amendments, explaining each as he went along. "They do not," he said, "trench upon the rights of the minority.

The young girl, Mary Moore, who was found nearly dead from suffocation in her sleeping apartment in the Grand View Hotel, where she is employed, told her story in the Yorkville Court yesterday morning.

The relatives of James Stevenson, the builder, whose mysterious disappearance on Dec. 5 last has been described in THE TIMES, published an advertisement yesterday offering a reward of $500 for the "recovery of his body, dead or alive." Mrs. Stevenson said last night at her home, No. 243 West Fifty-fifth-street, ...

Preceding the business men's meeting at the John-street Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday there was a praise service conducted by Mr. Stebbins, which was well attended. Mr. Stebbins sang a number of hymns, the audience joining in the chorus, and afterward several prayers were offered. At the service following the church was nearly filled with business men, minister, workingmen, ladies, and children.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 6.--In 1879 Justice Barnard sent John Gill, an insane criminal, from here to the insane asylum at Auburn. It has just been ascertained that Gill belonged to Suffolk County.

A sneak thief entered Speaker Husted's room Sunday night and carried off his valise. The rascal, instead of finding it full of money, found only a night shirt and some minor ar ticles. The General that night lay down to rest for an hour or two only, keeping his clothes on, and in that way saved his diamond studs and pocketbook.

FOND DU LAC, Wis., Jan. 6.--There has been not a little interest manifested in this vicinity in reports concerning the alleged Lawrence-Townley estate in England, numerous families within a radius of 20 or 30 miles having it made appear possible, or having had it presented to them by interested agents as possible, that they were heirs to a share of the great estate.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 6.--The attorneys and all parties interested in the Wabash case agreed this morning upon the form of the decree and submitted the same to the United States court. A recess was taken at 1 o'clock this afternoon until 2:30.
Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities at auction at the Liberty-street Real Estate Exchange yesterday:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 6.--John Bodes, a madman, committed suicide in a horrible manner yesterday. While walking on the street he drew a clasp knife, and plunging the blade into the side of his neck tried to behead himself. He did not succeed, and main thrust the blade into the other side of his neck and drew it around under his chin, severing his windpipe, ...

The Superintendent of State Prisons, in his annual report just submitted to the Legislature, is driven by the situation in which he has been left by recent legislation to discuss anew the methods of employing convict labor.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 6.--A brilliant wedding took place this afternoon at the Hotel Rennert, where Miss Kate Bautz Davis, daughter of exSenator H.G. Davis, of West Virginia, was married to Lieut. Robert M.G. Brown, United States Navy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6.--Adolph Pler, the Austrian who, while feigning to be a deaf-mute, was engaged in systematically robbing his employers, A.L. Singer Co., is still languishing in the county jail. The officials say that Pler is the most unique character in the jail. He holds himself aloof from the other prisoners, but today he was in a communicative mood for the...

Mr. Oscar Wilde, much to the chagrin of his more thoroughgoing followers, still persists in wearing his hair out short. Both in look and costume indeed he is so altered for the better that the name--prematurely given him by a satiric journal--of Oscar Tame would now fit him like a glove.

MONTREAL, Jan. 6.--Two Americans, composing the firm of Clark Co., dealers in oysters and canned goods, have disappeared from this city. They came from Chicago, they alleged, last Spring, and had done a good business ever since, receiving large consignments of goods from Baltimore and Philadelphia almost daily.

A table of Receiverships during 1885 shows that 44 railroad companies, having 8,386 miles of lines, with a bonded debt of $198,432,900, and representing capital stock amounting to $187,027,200 or an aggregate apparent investment of nearly $385,500,000, have failed to meet their obligations and have been taken possession of by the courts for the benefit of their credtors.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 6.--Henry Guernsey, a Bethany farmer, was brought to this city to-night under arrest for an act which has seriously injured the bologna sausage trade of New-Haven.

The annual report of the doings of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals during the twentieth year of its existence was presented at a meeting of the Executive Committee yesterday. The membership roll at present contains 514 names, and there are 279 agents in different parts of the State.
LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 6.--Trouble has arisen in the congregation of St. John's German Reformed Church, of this city, which may result is a split in the church.

Three complaints of larceny were made at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday against Rose Hutchinson, a middle-aged woman, who claims to live at No.120 East Eighty-secondstreet, and who was caught shoplifting at the store of Simpson, Crawford Simpson, in Sixthavenue, on Tuesday afternoon.
The Union League Club Waiters held their second annual reception at Lyric Hall, on Sixth-avenue, below Forty-second-street, last evening.

Nicholas Becker, of Belleville, N.J., visited this city on Dec. 16 to see the sights. While doing this he formed the acquaintance of Michael Donnelly, a colored man, and a Cuban named Alexander Barbara. The latter held a handkerchief over Becker's mouth while the colored man rifled his pockets and stole therefrom $20 and a silver watch.

It is singular that Gen. John C. Fremont, who is still living in quiet retirement on Staten Island, should have lived to see the birth and rapid growth of the Republican Party, of which he was the first standard bearer--its triumphant carrying through to the end of the greatest civil war that the world ever knew, ...

The course of discussion over Senator Evarts and the silver question has brought out some novel facts about the great orator. When he went abroad as a member of the International Monetary Conference his associates were ex-Senators Timothy O. Howe, of Iowa, and Allen G. Thurman, of Ohio.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Jan. 6.--In the wind and rain storm which prevailed throughout Somerset County Monday night three colored men were drowned near Rock Creek, in Tangier Sound, while trying to make shore in a small skiff from their vessel, which was anchored a few hundred yards from shore.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Jan. 6.--A well whose capacity is from 500 to 700 barrels of oil per day, is that on the smith farm, two miles northeast of Washington. It has been worked as a mystery, and until the 600-barrel tank with which connection was made Monday night was full, nothing reliable concerning it could be obtained.

When W.J. Phillips, the flour merchant, disappeared several years ago, he left in the possession of the Manhattan Company a large number of forced warehouse receipts, on which it had advanced him about $50,000. The company sued Phillips's partner, Richard H. Laimbeer, for the amount of the advances.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 6.--In the walking match to-day Weston made 42 miles 2 laps, and O'Leary 47 miles 9 laps. The score at the close to-night stood: O'Leary, 1,247 miles 13 laps: Weston, 1,228 miles 14 laps.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 6.--There is universal satisfaction among the students of Harvard College over the following notice, which was first made public this afternoon: "Whereas, the Committee on Athletics has advised the Faculty that the game of football has been much improved during the past season;

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 6.--The appearance of Tuesday's TIMES here to-day with an account or the threatened division among grain firms caused considerable of a commotion on 'Change, as the local papers had failed to note the sentiment.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6.--The murder on Tuesday afternoon of Thomas Moran, the Pennsylvania Railroad track walker, near Bordentown, is arousing a great deal of public interest, since no motive for the crime can be detected. It was evident that the victim struggled for his life. His slayer chose the loneliest spot along the whole length of the road to kill him.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Jan. 6.--On Jan. 20 last nearly or all the peach buds in Southern Ulster were killed by the severe cold weather of that date. The buds on all the trees thus far are secure, but should the mild weather of the past few days be renewed no doubt they will be forced out, and then, if cold weather follows, fruit growers may again be caught.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6.--John. G. Stevens, President of the United New-Jersey Railroad and Canal Company, killed himself here this afternoon. He had been at his office in the Pennsylvania Railroad building all day in company with Secretary Leroy H. Anderson, of the United Companies, and had been attending to business affairs as usual.

Judge Wallace, of the United States Circuit Court, yesterday dismissed the suit of the Liverpool, New-York and Philadelphia Steamship Company against the Commissioners of Emigration of the State of New-York for the recovery of $1,100,000, amounting, with interest, to nearly $2,000,000.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Black Rock Cut, on the Erie Railway, is three miles east of this place. The walls of the cut are 50 feet high. A day or two ago, as the engine of an east-bound freight train was entering the cut, Aaron Merritt, the engineer, saw two immense rocks start from the top of one wall and roll down the steep side immediately ahead of his engine.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 6.--In the City Councils to-night, it was decided to authorize the Mayor and the Presidents of the Councils to offer inducements to the Singer Sewing Machine Company to locate its shops in this city if they are removed from Elizabeth, N.J.

As we said last week, the legislative investigations into the public service of the city and State ought to be extended to the quarantine establishment. Enormous fees and selaries always tend to corruption, and the source of the notorious venality of what is called municipal...

CHICAGO, Jan. 6.--There are 924 policemen in the city of Chicago, but the strikers at the Maxwell box factory and the hoodlums sympathizing with them have no difficulty to speak of in brutally beating the handful of men who are willing to work in a factory where improved machinery is used.

MONTREAL, Jan. 6.--A number of speculators and brokers here have been badly victimized by purchasing land scrip, granted to the volunteers who served in the Northwest rebellion. Some of the claims have been sold several times over. One volunteer is credited with having sold his claim to nine different persons.

The theatrical entertainments to be given for the benefit of the Orthopedic Hospital at the University Club Theatre on Saturday and Monday evenings give promise of being brilliant successes socially as well as financially. The treasury of the hospital is likely to be very much helped by the proceeds.

NORWICH, Conn., Jan. 6.--The weavers of the Shetucket Mills are on strike for an advance of 10 per cent, in wages. This morning the mills shut down, throwing 500 operatives out of employment. The weavers held a meeting to-day and voted not to resume work until their demand is complied with.

Hollins was made Chairman of a committee on reorganization, it being proposed, according to the road's friends, to take it at once out of the hands of the Receiver.

Charles R. Doane Post, No. 499, G.A.R., had an installation of officers last evening at its rooms at DeKalb and Bedford avenues, Brooklyn. Comrade John A. McKane was re-elected Commander, and all the other officers were also to-elected. Department Commander Gen. H. Clay Hall and staff performed the ceremonies according to the ritual of the Grand Army. Three recruits were also mustered in.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 7.--The score in the O'Leary-Weston walking match at 10:30 o'clock to-night stood as follows: O'Leary, 1,292 miles, 9 laps; Weston, 1,260 miles, 5 laps. Weston was seized with an attack of vertigo today and rested for two hours. The walk will be resumed at Lockport to-morrow.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Jan. 7.--A cave-in occurred at Boston Run, near Mahanoy City, today, and a block of houses went down out of sight. The families living in them made a narrow escape. The surface is still caving, and five more blocks are expected to go down.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7.--Last Summer, when there was a strike at the McCormick Reaper Works, an omnibus full of Pinkerton men went out to protest the factory. They were stopped by the strikers, and one of the detectives fired his revolver, striking George Roth in the groin. Yesterday Roth sued the McCormick Company for $10,000 damages, taking the around that the Pinkerton men were the company's agents.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 7.--The scare in regard to the prevalence of contagious diseases at Harvard College, which has existed for the last few days, is rapidly subsiding.

ASHLAND, Penn., Jan. 7.--All the mules in the Preston No. 3 colliery, numbering 36, were drowned this morning. The water gained on the pumps so rapidly that the animals could not be rescued. They were valued at $120 each.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 7.--Contributions to the Nanticoke relief fund are coming in from various sources. Great interest is being taken in the widows and orphans of the victims all over the country.

SHELBY, N.C., Jan. 7.--Sheriff Hamrick, of Cleveland County, while attempting to arrest Berry Carpenter, was compelled to shoot him dead. Carpenter was a negro desperado, who had committed several burglaries around this place.

MONTREAL, Jan. 7.--J. Clinskill, a merchant of Battleford, Northwest Territory, has left here for Ottawa, to impress upon the authorities there the necessity of taking proper precautions to prevent an Indian uprising. Mr. Clinskill fears an uprising if precautions are not taken. He says the Indians are enraged because of the execution of eight murderers in November last, and are making all sorts of threats.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7.--Mrs. Frank Westerfield, of Wilmette, the unhappy victim of trichiniasis, was worse to-day than at any time since her affliction.

TRENTON, Jan. 7.--Chancellor Runyon decided a case to-day which is or unusual interest on account of the peculiar relief sought from the court. The court is asked to restrain a man from divulging a secret.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7.--President Jewett, of the Chicago and Atlantic Railroad, recently said that his road would co-operate with the others running East from Chicago in establishing the new east-bound pools based upon the recent trunk line agreement.

WABASH, Ind., Jan. 7.--A farmer who has recently traversed this county thoroughly says that fully 800 hogs have died in Wabash County since November from hog cholera. The heaviest loses occurred in Liberty Township. The cholera still prevails in the eastern portion of the county, but its ravages have been checked, and no fears of its spreading are entertained.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 7.--A conference committee of the Knights of Labor and the owners of the Geneva woolen mill have agreed that the striking weavers shall return to work tomorrow morning, on the promise that the case of Simms, the weaver discharged for profanity, and for whose reinstatement the weavers struck, will be inquired into further. Simms is not restored to work.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 7.--J.C. Fenton, appointed Postmaster of High Grove, Ky., by ex-President Arthur, was arrested and brought here to-night. It is charged that Fenton refused to turn over the Post Office to his successor. W. F. McCormack, who was recently appointed by President Cleveland. Fenton will be tried tomorrow in the United States court.

The locomotive engineers in the employ of the Manhattan Railway Company were happy last evening; so were the managers of the company. The cause of the happiness was the settlement of the difficulties which have disturbed the two for some days on an amicable basis.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 7.--A national convention of bakers will be held in this city on the 13th inst. The purpose of the convention is to make an attempt to reduce the number of working hours of journeymen bakers and to devise some means of compelling employers to provide suitable working quarters for their men. Nearly 200 delegates are expected, representing about a dozen different States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7.--Not until after 2 o'clock to-day and after 534 bills had been added to the 2,500 already introduced did Speaker Carlisle submit his list of standing and select committees. The reading of the names proved interesting to floor and galleries, but it brought no surprises.

A strike of a somewhat unusual character is in progress at the Cuban cigar factory of Lozano, Pendas Co., at No, 209 Pearl-street. Upon quitting work Wednesday evening about 120 of the firm's employes gave notice that they would not return until a change was made in the sanitary condition of the factory.

Jacob W. Windecker resides at No. 1,378 Washington-avenue and collects money for John Eichler, Morrisania's big brewer. In October last, Mr. Windecker's wife desiring a servant, he concluded to seek one as fresh from the old country as possible, and pretty Dora Schmidt, who was found is a German boarding house in Greenwich-street, was hired.

CAMDEN, Jan. 7.--Henry W. Maitland, a drug clerk in the employ of Dr. E.R. Smiley, committed suicide this morning by taking an ounce of prussic acid. The young man is well connected. No cause is assigned for the act.

Preparations are now going forward for a children's industrial exhibition, to be given in this city during the last week in March, and, if the affair is carried out according to the programme outlined, it ought to be very interesting. The management of the exhibition is in...

The terms of the resolution under which the Senate investigating committee of which Frederick S. Gibbs is Chairman was appointed last year required that the report of the committee should be submitted to the Legislature not later than the second Tuesday in January, 1886. Ex-Senator Gibbs said yesterday that he ...

WHEELING, West Va., Jan. 7.--John R. Dunlap, business manager of the Louisville Commercial, and Miss Isadora, daughter of Mr. Mortimer Pollack, a wealthy resident of this city, were married here this evening. The Rev. Dr. Leftwich, of New-Jerusalem Church, Cincinnati, officiated. The wedding was the most elegant seen here for several years. The bridal party go East on a speical can.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 7.--The Republicans met in joint caucus to-night, and with open doors nominated the Hon. John Sherman as their candidate for the United States Senate.

It may be taken as a settled fact that the problem of rapid transit for this city has not been solved by the elevated railroads and that those structures cannot be permitted to remain permanently in the streets.
ALBANY, Jan. 7.--There was another death from typhus fever at the penitentiary today, making 15 in all since the disease broke out.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 7.--Through the defalcations of a trusted employe the dry goods jobbing firm of Painter, Tongue Co. was obliged to suspend to-day.

Frederick Schluter, a young German, committed suicide yesterday afternoon, in his bedroom on the top floor of the flat house No. 445 East Eighty-fourth-street, by taking poison. He was the son of Ernest Schluter, a wealthy produce merchant doing business at...

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 7.--The State Department of Agriculture has compiled a statement of the number and value of live stock owned in Georgia for the purpose of forwarding official information upon this subject to Washington. Capt. Redding has completed his work, and forwarded his statement, which bears date Jan. 1, 1886.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7.--The non-union men employed in Maxwell's box factory were directed by the police last night to assemble at the Twelfth-street station at 7:15 o'clock this morning, traveling to this point through Halstedstreet, which is thickly picketed with patrolmen, and an escort would be furnished to take them to the factory.

Mme. Janauschek's engagement at the Grand Opera House, which began on Monday and will end to-morrow night, has been very prosperous. The audiences have been large and kindly disposed. Last night, when Schiller's "Mary Stuart" was the play, the house was...
The annual meeting of the Society of Plymouth Church was held last evening in the lecture room of the church. Deacon Henry L. Pratt presided. The following Trustees, whose...

The Park police will establish a substation in Riverside Park to-day in the basement of the Claremont Hotel and occupy it with 12 officers and 2 mounted patrolmen. During the day one policeman will be on guard at the Grant tomb and two policemen and a patrolman will be stationed on the drives. At night the same force, less the patrolman, will be on duty.

Amory Stevens, of No. 58 Broad-street, who was arrested on a charge of having entered into a conspiracy with Edward Tompkins, a private detective, and a young woman named Nellie Lyons, to procure evidence by which Mr. Stevens's sister, the wife of George H. RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 7.--At about 1 o'clock this morning there appeared in the northern heavens a display of aurora borealis which in brilliancy and splendor has seldom, if ever, been equaled in this latitude.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 7.--At a meeting of the Kingston City Board of Health yesterday afternoon the members discussed Gov. Hill's proclamation concerning the State Board of Health. They were unanimous in disapproving Gov. Hill's policy. Some of them suggested that if a saving of money were necessary it would be better to abolish the Legislature as the least useful and important body of the two.

Grand Central Pete, the notorious bunko steerer, whom Dr. Frank E. Seely, of Bridgeport, Conn., had arrested last week on a charge of having been engaged in a plot to swindle and rob him, was again arraigned yesterday in the Tombs Police Court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7.--In the Supreme Court of the United States to-day the following business was transacted: No. 1,221--Asbel H. Barney et al appeliants, vs. The Winona and St. Peter Railroad...

STOCKTON, Cal., Jan. 7.--David S. Terry, ex-Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court of California, and Miss Sarah Althea Hill, who claims to be the widow of ex-Senator Sharon, of Nevada, were married shortly before 10 o'clock this morning in the parsonage of the Catholic church.

The new steamer Mascotte left Tampa, Fla., yesterday, and will leave there every Wednesday on the arrival of the South Florida Railroad train from Sandford with United States mails for Key West and Havana. On Saturdays, either the Whitney or the Hutchinson will leave on like service, and, in connection with the Atlantic Coast Line, will form a through passenger route to Cuba.

LONDON, Jan. 7.--At a meeting of the Irish Loyal and Patriotic Union to-day Major E. J. Saunderson, Loyalist member of Parliament for the North Division of Armagh, made a speech in which he said he feared that the Radicals would concede home rule to the Nationalists.
