As Officer James Dooley was standing near the entrance to the bridge, on the NewYork side, about 11 o'clock yesterday morning he noticed a poorly dressed man, with pinched features, as though he had been suffering from want, approach the gate leading to the footpath. Very few people, except the very poor and visitors from the country, cross on foot on cold days ...

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 8.--The Richmond Whig, which suspended publication on Dec. 22, was sold to-day for $5,000, the purchaser being Abner Anderson, formerly of the Danville (Va.) Register, and Judge A.W.C. Nowlin, of Washington. The paper will be Democratic in principle. The sale has been confirmed by the court.

HANNIBAL, Mo., Jan. 8.--Lottie Griffin, a colored woman, who claimed to be over 120 years of age, died yesterday. She has a daughter here over 80 years of age. Several old citizens place her age at from 110 to 120.

ALBANY, Jan. 8.--Judge-Advocate-General Young, of Gen. Hancock's staff, visited the penitentiary to-day with Health Officer Balch, to make an official examination of the health of the United States prisoners, and ascertain what...

Judge Donohue's decision that the questions put to James R. Keene in supplementary proceedings must not relate to his acts anterior to the appointment of a Receiver on July 20, 1885, will prevent Mr. Edward Gebhard, attorney for Julius R. Gimbernat from continuing the examination.

E.O. Hill, who recently resigned his position as Superintendent of the Eastern Division of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company, has issued a circular to his old employes which has pleased them greatly. In it be thanks them for the hearty support they...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Lieut. Gen. Sheridan in conversation to-day remarked with reference to his recent visit to Arizona and the late news concerning the Apaches: "I have reason to believe that Gen. Crook's operations will result in the destruction of Geronimo's band and the restoration of quiet in the region of the Apache depredations, but the work cannot be accomplished in a day.
BISMARCK, Dakota, Jan. 8.--A fire at Standing Rock Agency this morning destroyed three dwellings belonging to Supply Agent H. S. Parkin, and for a time threatened to wipe out the entire agency.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 8.--In reference to Senator Van Wyck's remarks concerning the extravagance of the Utah Commission, ex-Gov. Ramsay, Chairman of the commission, says that the Senator is mistaken.
The principal store in the village of Glen Cove, Long Island, is known as the "Protective Union," and is owned by the Duryea Brothers, who are also the main owners of the Glen Cove Starch Works.

Grand Chief Engineer Arthur was sure of his ground when he told the engineers and firemen, to whom he gave so much good advice on Thursday night, that the men who had been engaged by the Manhattan Railway company to fill their places in case of a strike would not be needed on the elevated roads.

UTICA, Jan. 8.--The Tompkins mathematical prizes al Hamilton College, founded by H.B. Tompkins, of New-York, were awarded to the following members of the Junior Class today: First prize--Edward S. King, of Liverpool; second--Ward H. Goodenough, of Pierrepont Manor. A medal was awarded to C.S. Fenn, of Pittston, Penn.

The Attorney-General of the United States of Colombia has begun a suit in the Supreme Court of Colombia for a forfeiture of the charter of the Panama Railroad Company, basing his action upon the fact, as he claims, that the railroad company has violated its contract with the Government in having disposed of its property to the de Lesseps canal company.

RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 8.--Dr. E.M. Nelson President of the West Rutland Marble Company, was arrested while in bed this morning by the Chief of Police on suspicion of complicity in the Lancaster Bank embezzlement.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 8.--Late this afternoon, during the heavy snowstorm, the front and middle part of the large four-story warehouse occupied by H.P. Forwood Co., Trabue Co., and J.B. Balmforth Co., all cotton and commission merchants, fell, and an overturned stove started a destructive fire.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8.--Vicar-General P.J. Conway appeared in Justice Brayton's court today to prosecute his charge of libel against M. J. Cahill, editor of the Pilot, a local Roman Catholic paper.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 8.--The interest in the Ann Freeborn case at Fox Lake, Wis., has been revived by a report from Prof. Haynes, of Chicago, who has examined the viscera of the dead woman and found marked traces of poison, as is charged by some of her relatives. Miss Freeborn died suddenly in October, having, a short time previously, changed her will so...

The annual meeting of the Staten Island Diet Kitchen Association will be held to-day at 12 o'clock, at the residence of Mrs. W.W. MacFarland. At 4:15 o'clock the laying of the cornerstone of the new building, Grant and Vanduyee streets, will take place. A stage at Tompkinsville will meet the 3:40 boat from the city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--The Senate to-day passed the Edmunds Anti-Polygamy bill. Only a few of the Republican Senators were present to take part in the closing debate.
The dinner given at Mazzetti's last Wednesday evening by the Sixth Company of Seventh Regiment veterans was a great success. Capt. Frederick Goodwin presided.
FORT VALLEY, Ga., Jan. 8.--The down freight from Macon, which arrived here at 12 o'clock, brought a prisoner captured up the road about six miles. He was charged with an attempt to wreck that train.

The annual meeting of the subscribers to the Northern Dispensary was held last evening at Christopher-street and Waverley-place. Mr. James W. Gerard, who was called to take the chair, made a pleasant address upon the dispensary,

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--The proceedings in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day were as follows: No. 300--Christian F. Liebke et al., plaintiffs in error, vs. William Thomas; No 635--Christian F. Liebke...

BOSTON, Jan, 8.--The anniversary of Jackson's victory at New-Orleans is always commemorated by Massachusetts Democrats by the election of the new officers for the State Committee and a jolly dinner party. At the meeting to-day Congressman Collins was re-elected Chairman of the State Committee, Col. J.W. Coveney, Secretary, and Col. C.D. Lewis, Treasurer.

The statement was published yesterday that the New-York Steam Heating Company has so divided the work at its Greenwich-street station that the night engineer is on duty from 5 o'clock in the evening to 7 o'clock the next morning, and that to relieve him as much as possible the company has allowed him to sleep during part of the night.
Thomas Walsh, the policeman who shot Michael Ruth on Jan. 2, told his story to Justice Gorman, in the Harlem court, yesterday. Inspector Dilks listened to the main portion of the testimony.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 8.--The religious excitement at Palmyra, Wis., is slowly subsiding. The little Methodist church is still crowded at every service, but the score of people who have been fasting for some time past are gradually resuming their natural method of sustenance.

So far as human happiness lies in the exercise of those faculties which constitute man's physical differentia, the study of natural science affords its students the amplest, the most varied, and the most unalloyed enjoyment of existence.
ALBANY, Jan. 8.--The Wilbur Opera Company has been singing "The Mikado" to crowded houses at Jacobs Proctor's Museum this week.

The General Term of the Supreme Court has affirmed the conviction in the Court of General Sessions of David H. Crowley, the Police Sergeant, who is now in State prison under a sentence to hard labor for 17 years.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8.--In November last Charles Gallagher, 35 years of age, who became infatuated with the 18-year-old daughter of James H. Cochran, a dry goods merchant, residing at 1,323 South Broad-street, and had persistently annoyed her for 15 months, was committed to the Norristown Hospital for the Insane.

RONDOUT, Jan. 8.--One stormy night last Fall Charles Mayer, a messenger boy for the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company in Rondout, while returning home after having delivered a message, fell off a dock into the Rondout Creek and was drowned. Since that time the boy's mother has slowly wasted away, and last night she died of a broken heart.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8.--The St. Lawrence River continues to rise rapidly, and a flood is feared. Cellars in St. Paul and Commissioner streets are now flooded, but in most cases the merchants anticipated it and removed their goods. The water is above the main floors of some of the farmhouses on the south shore of the river.

Probably the best appointed and furnished room in the Capitol is that occupied by the President of the Senate and known as "The Vice-President's Room." It adjoins the celebrated Marble Room, in which visitors to Senators are received, and is intended as the private office and retiring room of the Vice-President.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 4.--A feeble ray of hope has of late found its way through the blank cloud of shame, amazement, and disgust which overcame Russian society at the unexpected stand taken by that Government in face of the disturbances on the Balkan Peninsula.

EL PASO, Texas, Jan. 8.--The merchants of this and other American towns on the Rio Grande are circulating petitions, which will be sent to Washington, requesting the United States Government to abolish the free zone between this country and Mexico.

The public rehearsal prefatory to this evening's Philharmonic concert at the Academy of Music was very largely attended. The most important number on the programme was Dvorak's new symphony in D minor,
The following additional sums from the Hospital Saturday and Sunday collection were received yesterday by the General Treasurer, Mr. Charles Lanier, No. 26 Nassau-street:

Railroad Commissioner O'Donnell's friends gave him a boom yesterday in order to assist him to secure the reappointment, his term of office expiring on the 29th inst. The boom was carried into the rooms of Gov. David B. Hill at the Hoffman House during the afternoon by a committee of 30 gentlemen, with...
CHICAGO, Jan. 8.--To-day was about the quietest day around Maxwell's box factory since the strike began. The 75 extra policemen in citizens' clothes were here, there, and everywhere.

NASHVILLE, Jan. 8.--J.W. Blanchard, of Council Bluffs, Iowa, arrived to-day to take active measures looking toward the building of the Nashville and Knoxville Railroad, of which he has the general management.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 8.--Norman B. Harwood, who died six or eight months ago in Florida, from injuries caused by falling off a house, left his family $200,000 in insurance policies on his life.
Rocco, a 2-year-old son of Naido Menzi, died in convulsions on Wednesday morning at No. 281 Mulberry-street.

The events of the past two or three days have compelled the attention of the public to the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, and the attention thus attracted has been entirely creditable to the body which was the object of it.
The employes of the American Express Company will hold their annual ball at Irving Hall on next Friday evening.

ATLANATA, Ga., Jan. 8.--The case of George T. Jackson, late President of the Enterprise Cotton Mills of Augusta, who was convicted last Summer of a defalcation of $150,000, is now before the Supreme Court for review.

Gas escaped last evening in the store of Davis Ziegel, No. 277 Sixth-avenue, and a plumber was sent for. He was investigating the source of the escape in the cellar when the gas exploded, and inflammable goods in the rear of the store caught fire.

The Anti-Mormon bill recently reported from the Senate Judiciary Committee was passed in the Senate yesterday by a vote of 38 to 7. This is substantially a copy of the bill prepared two years ago by Mr. EDMUNDS and passed by the Senate on June 18, 1884, by a vote of 33 to 15.

The committee appointed by the Republican County Committee to find some explanation of the peculiar manner in which the party vote for county officers at the last election varied from the vote for State officers has made very slow progress.

The wind suddenly veered around to the northeast as darkness came on last evening, and by 9 o'clock it began to blow hard. The wind gradually increased to a gale. Soon after 10 o'clock flakes of line snow were whirling in the air, making everybody obliged to be out doors uncomfortable. The thermometer registered 28 .

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 8.--G.W. Simmons, who was arrested at Ashland City for the murder of H.B. Adams, whose throat he cut after a quarrel, was brought here this evening and lodged in jail for safekeeping. Simmons confeesed his guilt, and as there was a strong likelihood of his being mobbed it was deemed best to remove him here.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 8.--While Jacob Diamond and Aaron Pannemoir, two Hebrew peddlers, were crossing Lafleur's Bay, above Golden Lake, Monday evening, their horses and sleighs went through the ice.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 8.--The Savannah Cotton Exchange to-day appointed a committee to petition Congress to discontinue the coinage of silver.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 8.--A brisk and brief correspondence has recently been concluded between President Cleveland and his nephew, Charles Cleveland, of this city, showing somewhat how the former feels on the question of placing members of his family in once. The President has two nephews here.

It was decided by the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday that the Title Guarantee and Trust Company was entitled to a mandamus to compel Register Reilly to permit its employer, to such a number as he thinks, in the exercise of an unbiased judgement, can work in his office without restricting the rights of other persons, to consult the records in his care and make extracts from them.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 8.--In Walton County live two respectable widows, Mrs. A.J. Johnson, the mother of two sons, and Mrs. Buchanan, the mother of three.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 8.--About 50 men, under the direction of J.H. Hutchinson, of Montreal, are engaged in laying the foundations of the ice castle, the ice for which is being hauled by 10 teams.

The main banquet hall in the Hotel Brunswick presented a gay and curious scene last night when the members of the Holland Society, with their friends, assembled for the first banquet since the organization of the society, in April last. Henry E. Reddish, of No. 350 McDonough-street, Brooklyn, told yesterday how Burton T. Beach, the young lawyer who created quite a sensation by his disappearance a year or so ago, had swindled him out of $11,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8.--State's Attorney Grinnell to-day wrote a letter to the Governor, at the instance of the attorney of Frank Mulkowsky, the murderer of Mrs. Kleidzieck, advocating the granting of a reprieve on legal grounds.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 8.--At 2 o'clock this morning the St. James Hotel, the leading hotel in town, a large four-story brick building containing 80 rooms, was discovered to be in flames. The fire had started from a pipe from the furnace which ran to the roof alongside an elevator shaft, and had broken out and spread almost simultaneously on all the floors.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 8.--There is a report current in educational circles that Prof. John M. Coulter, the noted botanist of Wabash College, Crawfordsville, will soon succeed the venerable...

Prof. T. Sterry Hunt, the eminent chemist, now resident in Canada, who is making a short visit in the city, was last evening a guest at a dinner given him at Seighortner's by a number of members of the American Chemical Society.
Gov. Hill and some of his friends will attend the performance of "Hoodman Blind" at Wallack's Theatre this afternoon. Mr. Moss has set apart two proscenium boxes for the use of the party.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 8.--John Ford, engineer at the Thomaston colliery, while oiling the pumping machinery at 4 o'clock this morning, fell from a greasy rod into the slope, which was full of water, and sank to the bottom, about 60 feet. His body was recovered to-night. He was 35 years of age, and leaves a wife and two children.

Judge Moody, recently chosen United States Senator by the Legislature which met in Huron, Dakota, a few days ago, was at the capital to-day, and Judge Edgerton, his colleague, is expected to arrive here to-night. It is probable that a resolution will be introduced in the Senate when it next meets admitting them to the floor as a matter of courtesty.

Custom House Inspectors boarded the ship Samara, from the Philippine Islands, at Prentiss's stores yesterday and seized $1,000 worth of dutiable goods.
Congressman R.W. Townshend, of Illinois, is at the Gilsey House.

The sound of the drum and fife was heard at the Germania Assembly Rooms, in the Bowery, last evening, and men in military costume marched up the stairs.
The committee of the Real estate Exchange appointed to examine into the merits of the lot and block system of indexing conveyances, met in the board room of the Exchange yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8.--The members of the Managers' Committee of the Chicago east-bound freight traffic were very angry this morning when they saw the details of their meeting yesterday in cold type, and promptly discharged an inoffensive stenographer...
At a meeting of the Tammany General Committee last night it was decided to make a united effort in the organization to give Parnell pecuniary help in his plans for home rule.

Henrietta Rothengass, 74 years old, of No. 902 Charlotte-street, Philadelphia, fell down stairs at No. 269 Third-avenue, yesterday, where she was visiting her sister, Mrs. Louisa Neb. She received cerebral injury, from which she died soon afterward at the New-York Hospital.
Dr. Justo P. Martinez was a Cuban, 66 years old and a specialist in midwifery. He lived at No. 246 East Twenty-seventh-street. He was summoned to No. 137 East Forty-eighth-street,

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 8.--In cutting through a gorge of the Blue Ridge Mountains, near the Buncombo County line, recently, a party of convicts, in charge of Capt. W.C. Troy, at work on the Asheville and Spartanburg...
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 8.--There now seems to be a possibility that the long strike of the employes of the Derby Silver Company, of Shelton, may be amicably settled.
Among the tramps that are every morning arraigned at the Essex Market Police Court Justice Duffy yesterday found several whom he regretted had been arrested.
Capt. Charles Holbrook, of the threemasted schooner Fanny Milliken, is sick with pneumonia, but not too sick to shoot at a river thief.
BUFFALO, Jan. 8.--A meeting of the holders of first and second mortgage bonds of the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia was held in this city to-day.
NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 8.--William B. Tatro, a resident of Hartford, ran to catch the limited express on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, which left New-York at 4:30 this afternoon.
Elbridge Kingsley lectured before the Groller Club last night at No. 64 Madison-avenue on modern wood engraving. The lecturer was introduced by Robert Hoe, President of the club.
LONDON, Jan. 9.--The News says that a rumor is again current that Queen Victoria will open Parliament in person.
READING, Penn., Jan. 8.--The court this morning granted an injunction restraining the Reading and Pottsville Railroad Company, controlled by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company,
ATLANTA, Jan. 8.--The proposed East Georgia and Florida Road from Jacksonville, Fla., via St. Mary's to Jesup, Ga., has been placed on an assured basis, and is immediately to be constructed.

Hamilton Pryor, a young man living at No. 24 West Forty-ninth-street, who claims to be a nephew of Gen. Roger A. Pryor, was arraigned before Justice Ford, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, to answer to...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Major L.B. Williams, Third Artillery, stationed at West Troy, N.Y., has been ordered to temporary duty at the National Armory, Springfield, Mass. Lieut.-Col. D.W. Flagler. Ordnance Department, has been ordered from Rock Island Arsenal to Phoenixville, Penn., to inspect...

The Inman steamship City of Chicago, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday, brought as passengers the crew of the American schooner Reuben S. Hunt, Capt. Barnard, which was abandoned in a waterlogged and dismasted condition on Dec. 8 in latitude 39 and longitude 72 .

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8.--Recent rumors about President Cleveland's intention to send Gen. Nelson A. Miles to relieve Gen. Crook from the command of the troops who are trying to hunt down the hostile Indians in New-Mexico and Arizona have been revived, and it is now again asserted that the change will surely be made.
Emily Edwards, tall, dark eyed, brown haired, and about 26 years of age, has been missing from No. 52 East Thirtieth-street since Wednesday night of last week.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 8.--A fire broke out this afternoon in the wholesale grocery house of T.G. Bush Co., Nos. 46, 48, 50, and 52 Commerce-street.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 8.--An interesting case has just been dedided by the Probate Judge of Elbert County. Richard Burton, who recently died in this county, was a citizen of Tennessee.
Timothy Shea, who said that he was a laborer and lived in Ninety-seventh-street, near Second-avenue, was arraigned yesterday at the Tombs Police Court on charges of passing forged checks.
ISHPEMING, Mich., Jan. 8.--D.F. Wadsworth, formerly a banker, has been convicted, on his second trial, of embezzlement in the sum of $60,000. Sentence has been deferred.

There will be fun at the FourteenthStreet Theatre next Friday night. The Produce Exchange is going to descend on "Evangeline" 400 or 500 strong, and the brokers will try to make full amends for the drowsiness of their recent Christmas jollification.

The main topic of conversation in Paterson yesterday was the tragedy enacted the night before, when George Holford shot his wife and then himself, leaving seven, children to mourn the loss of a devoted, respected mother.

The production of "Orpheus" at the Academy of Music yesterday evening was an interesting event for musical students and for people to whom the history of music is an attractive study. Very many years have gone by since the opera was sung in this city--
NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 8.--John Hully, of Philadelphia, arrived in Newburg to-day in search of his sister, Miss Anna Hully, who has been missing since Dec. 1 last.
By the death of Mr. W.H. Guion, Jr., on Thursday night, the firm of Guion Co., of New-York, the successors of the old house of Williams Guion, will terminate.

MANCHESTER, Jan. 8.--The Guardian in its commercial article says: "The market is unchanged. The sales of cloth have been moderate. Orders of any magnitude are infeasible. owing to the firmness of prices, especially for India and China goods, though there is a fair inquiry at below the current rates. Yarns are quiet."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8.--A solemn high mass was celebrated recently in the Catholic Cathedral in Yokohama for the repose of the soul of King Alfonso. All the dignitaries of the State and the imperial household were present. The ceremony was remarkable from the fact that it was the first one attended by high Japanese officials since the time of St. Francis Xavier, 300 years ago.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 8.--Buffalo's new Mayor, Philip Becker, is determined that there shall be a reform in certain branches of the City Government.

Gov. David B. Hill's smooth bald head shone resplendent under the brilliant glare of seven electric lights in Delmonico's banquet hall last night. Cheers, vigorous and enthusiastic, repeatedly rose from 250 good Democratic throats to attest the esteem in which the Governor is held by the business men and politicians whose guest he was.
As Mrs. Elizabeth Godfrey, of No. 3 Mitchell-place, was going down the Tombs steps after leaving the Court of Special Sessions yesterday, she was violently pushed by Susan Barron.

Two men in Harlem started out early yesterday morning to buy a goat. It was not an ordinary goat that they wanted, but a savage, tree-destroying, Lawson N. Fuller sort of goat; one with a very hard head. After scouring the vacant lots with small success the men found what appeared to be a promising goat in the stable of the widow O'Toole, in East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street.

DETROIT, Jan. 8.--Another terrible crime was discovered this afternoon in the heart of the city of Battle Creek, in this State. The neighbors having noticed for the past day or two the absence of any signs of life about the residence of Dr. Martin White, were induced this afternoon to make an investigation.

James Collins, who was arrested Dec. 7 on a charge of burning his own liquor store at North Sixth and Fifth streets, Brooklyn, Eastern District, made a full confession before Justice Naeher yesterday.

A curious and somewhat important case has recently come before and been passed upon by a branch of the English High Court of Justice. It was that of a native Indian Prince, who came over to England and there married an Englishwoman according to the rites of the Mohammedan religion.

Mr. Bright has never been put to any outlay in connection with his candidature for Birmingham, and already a fund has been raised voluntarily to meet the amount now incurred.
Who does not remember the wonderful art displayed by M. Solon at the Centennial Exhibition in his pale sur pate decoration? It was the highest expression of fictile work.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10.--A joint meeting of the Parnell Committee and the Municipal Council of the Irish National League was held last night, John F. Finerty presided and John Markey acted as Secretary.
"Isn't it against the rules to touch the animals at the menagerie, ma?" asked Bobby.
Her Majesty is exceedingly angry that any members of the royal family should have presumed to attend a theatre when the Court is not merely officially, but also privately, in mourning.
The annual meeting of the Board of Directors of the Hebrew Technical Institute was held yesterday morning in the rooms of the Young Men's Hebrew Association, No. 721 Lexington-avenue.

There was old-fashioned Congregational singing in Plymouth Church yesterday. Owing to the cold weather the water engine used to pump the organ gave out, and consequently there was no instrumental music.

No sailing vessels arrived at this port yesterday. It is probable that a number of these vessels have been blown off the coast by the violent westerly winds of Saturday night and yesterday. Several steamships which arrived yesterday bore evidence of having passed an extremely cold and stormy night off the coast.
MATTOON, Ill., Jan. 10.--Joseph C. Litzelman, of Newton, Jasper County, has disappeared, leaving behind him forged paper aggregating $10,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 10.--The organization of the Senate is already made up, in advance of the opening of the session, Senator Nichols, who hoped to be made President, concedes the election now of Senator Griggs, of Passaic.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 10.--Mr. Jay Gould's yacht Atalanta sailed from here to-day or Nassau.

CAIRO, Ill., Jan. 10.--To-day the fire bells were rung, calling the citizens together to institute a search from house to house for Annie McKeon, who disappeared mysteriously from school at the convent here last Thursday. The search proved fruitless, no trace of the girl being found.

LONDON, Jan. 10.--Discount "was easy at 2 for three months' bills and 1 for short sight bills. Dealings on the Stock Exchange since the beginning of the year have diminished, and the tendency is weaker. The changes, however, are not important.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 10.--Paddy Ryan's mother died this evening at her residence in West Troy. Owing to her death the arrangements for the fight between Ryan and Sullivan will be necessarily delayed for some time.

From the time of the summary cutting off by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company of the facilities for passenger traffic granted by it to its great rival, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, all attempts at patching up a lasting peace among the trunk lines proved abortive until the settlement of the NewYork Central-West Shore difficulties, a few months ago.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union a letter was received from a silkweaver stating that the weavers in the upper part of the city were so poorly paid for their work that they could hardly live on their earnings. The matter was referred to the Organization Committee.

WADESBOROUGH, N.C., Jan. 10.--A sensation has been created here by the confession of S.W. Henley, editor of the Intelligencer, that he is not the man he seemed to be, but that he is somebody else.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 10.--The snowstorm that has prevailed since Friday night, accompanied by high winds and intensely cold weather, is likely to greatly interfere with, if not wholly disarrange, the programme that had been made for the inaugural ceremonies to-morrow. To-night a stiff wind is blowing from the west and a fine snow is falling.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10.--The Junior appointments for the Yale Class of '87 have been given out. Of 154 men in the class 94 get appointments and 53 are entitled to recite for the Junior exhibition. The men receiving the highest places are:

CHICAGO, Jan. 10.--Outside of Col. McCaull's "Mikado" company at the Chicago Opera House there has been nothing of any special worth at the leading Chicago theatres during the past week. Frank Bangs's "Silver King" company at McVicker's has done a fair business, and Mr. and Mrs. George S. Knight have done well at Hooley's with "Over the Garden Wall."

CHICAGO, Jan. 10.--It was rumored to-night in theatrical circles that John H. Haverly had failed and had surrendered his lease of Hershey Hall, which he converted last Fall into a home for his local minstrel company, to Hannah and Hogg, ...
QUEENSTOWN, Jan. 10.--The White Star Line steamship Germanic, Capt. Kennedy, from New-York Jan. 1, arr. here at 9 o'clock this morning.
HAWLEY, Penn., Jan. 10.--The abandonment of the Pennsylvania Coal Company's gravity railroad between this place and Pittston, leaves 1,500 coal cars useless on the hands of the company.
LONDON, Jan. 10.--The Greek Government has made overtures to the Government of Montenegro looking to the formation of an alliance, both offensive and defensive, against the Porte.

WAYNESBOROUGH, Ga., Jan. 10.--A special guard has just returned from the swamp on the Savannah River with Jerry Tarber, one of the escaped prisoners, who was badly wounded in the effort to capture him.

Intending visitors to France would do well to provide themselves with a passport, and to have it properly vise, to judge from the experience of Mr. Stanley Weyman and his brother near Pau.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 10.--All hope that Col. Wright or Jabez Balmforth escaped death under the falling walls of their business house on West Main-street on Saturday night has been given up.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 10.--Governor-elect Larrabee, who expected to arrive on Thursday, has got as far as West Liberty, and will reach Des Moines early in the morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10.--The body of the late John B. Raymond, ex-Delegate from Dakota, arrived in this city to-night, and will be temporarily placed by the side of that of his wife in the vault at Rock Creek Cemetery tomorrow.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 10.--Shortly after 9 o'clock last night fire was discovered in the basement of St. James Episcopal Church on the corner of Penn-avenue and Seventeenth-street.

The Jeffersonians were out in full glory last night at Tammany Hall, and the resplendent diamond in ex-Alderman Sheils's shirt front was only excelled by the calcium light which made Fourteenth-street as bright as day.

An admirable representation of "Die Meistersinger" was given at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening in presence of an a semblage that filled the spacious auditorium.

Lew Bernard, of Cincinnati, was upon the floor of the House before the session began to-day busily "mixing" among Democratic members of the Indiana delegation in an effort to get their indorsements, in addition to those of his Ohio friends, to his application for the place ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11, 1886. Notwithstanding the large number of bills in troduced during the last call of States in the House, the call to-day brought forward 650 additional propositions, which increases to nearly 4,000 the number of measures now awaiting action by the House committees.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 11.--Old Washington people will remember Hudson Taylor, who, during the war and for years previous, was first chief clerk and then proprietor of a bookstore in Pennsylvania-avenue, in the capital of the Nation. During the war he was a bosom friend of Edwin M. Stanton, the then Secretary of War.

From the report of the Fire Department for 1885, which was transmitted to the Mayor yesterday, it appears that the fire-extinguishing force numbers 941 and the employes at headquarters and bureaus 182, making a total of 1,123. The number of fire companies is 71.

The mysterious disappearance of George R. Brown, a lawyer in the Morse Building, at No. 140 Nassau-street, has caused great alarm to his family and much inconvenience to his clients. Mr. Brown returned from Buffalo, whither he had gone on legal business for John Lafarge,

A blockade that lasted fully 20 minutes occurred on the Third-avenue elevated railroad at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning. The trouble arose when the cylinder pan of a train bound down town fell out of its place at One Hundred and Nineteenth-street.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 11.--The Knights of Labor announce that the strike at the Clerk Lennox morocco factory has been adjusted to the satisfaction of both parties.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11.--This morning, just after dawn, the Rev. Father Betts preached a funeral sermon over the remains of the suicide, the Rev. Father Henry Jardine. Friends of the deceased had come from Kansas City for the body, but Father Betts was determined not to ...
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 11.--The Hon. Robert L. Taylor, of Knoxville, in a card published to-day, announces his willingness to accept the Democratic nomination for Governor.

ALBANY, Jan. 11.--The official list of the mertality at the penitentiary since the typhus fever broke out, which was made public this afternoon, shows 21 deaths since Dec. 1, of which 17 were from typhus fever.

LONDON, Jan. 11.--Mr. Gladstone held a reception at Carlton-terrace this evening. Earl Granville, Sir William V. Harcourt, Lord Hartington, Sir Charles Dilke, and Mr. Chamberlain were conspicuous by their absence. The meeting of the Liberal Party has been postponed until the day before that on which the Queen's speech is to be delivered.

On the front row of seats in the Surrogate's Court yesterday sat a line of relatives of the wife of Isaac Marcus, who during his life kept a fancy store in East Broadway, and lived in Ludlow-street. They were light haired and some of them were affected with a brogue.

The Anti-Monopoly League, of which William A.A. Carsey and John W. Keogh are the leading members, met last night in the court room of the Sixth Civil District Court, at Eighteenth-street and Fourth-avenue.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 11.--The furnacemen at the Edgar Thompson Steel Works have not yet accepted the proposition of the firm, and as the men in the converting department refuse to work the steel made by the new hands the entire mill will close down for an indefinite period on Wednesday next, throwing out of employment nearly 3,000 men.
Ward, Ewing, O'Rourke, Gerhardt, and Richardson have signed contracts with the NewYork Club for next season. The others will follow their example shortly.

The regular nominations for officers of the Union League Club to serve during the current year are as follows: President-Chauncey M. Depew; Vice-Presidents--Le Grand B. Cannon, Cornelius N. Bliss, William Dowd, Jacob D. Vermilye, Henry Bergh, Levi P. Morton,
The following additional sums from the Hospital Saturday and Sunday collection were received yesterday by Mr. Charles Lanier, General Treasurer, No. 26 Nassau-street:

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 11.--George Black, conductor of the Wilmington and Northern Railroad train which was shattered to pieces in Saturday's collision, died from his injuries shortly before noon to-day. His wounds were frightful and intensely painful.
"Nobody's Claim," a drama of the "M'liss" order, was produced at the ThirdAvenue Theatre under marked disadvantages last evening.

TAPPAN, N.Y., Jan. 11.--The fence surrounding the Andre monument, which was damaged by the recent explosion, was taken down to-day and shipped to the Composite Iron Works to be repaired. From what information could be gained Mr. Field will soon replace the stone in proper shape.
TRENTON, Jan. 11.--A Coroner's inquest was held to-day touching the mysterious murder of Thomas Moran, near Bordentown, on Tuesday last.
TRENTON, Jan. 11.--The funeral of John G. Stevens, the President of the United Railroad Companies of New-Jersey, who shot himself here several days ago, was held here at 1:30 this afternoon.

TRENTON, JAN. 11.--Trenton is crowded with Jersey statesmen to-night. Everybody in any way connected with the State Government is here except the Chief Executive, and he is conspicuous by his absence.
"Any news?" was asked of a leading druggist yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11.--North Haven, a quiet village six miles from this city, is excited over the appearance of a ghost. It is described as about 3 feet in height, and wears a velvet suit and hat. Oliver McNulty, a laborer in Shears's brickyard, with four of his companions, ran across the ghost a night or two ago, when they followed up a moving light.

BUFFALO, Jan. 11.--The movement to supply Buffalo with natural gas from the gas fields of Pennsylvania has taken definite shape. The Buffalo Natural Gas Fuel Company filed its certificate of incorporation to-day.

The request of the drivers and conductors of the Third-avenue horse cars for a diminution of their hours of work was presented to the Directors at their meeting yesterday afternoon, and referred to a subcommittee consisting of President Lyon, Superintendent Robertson, and Dr. Hall, a member of the Executive Committee.

SANTIAGO DE CHILI, Jan. 11, via Galveston.--The Senate convened in special session yesterday to discuss the law of taxes that had been approved by the Chamber of Deputies, and it was passed by a vote of 17 to 11.

There was patriotic eloquence, exultation, and jollity at the meeting of the General Committee of the Irish Parliamentary fund in the Hoffman House last night. The reports of the various subcommittaes showed that more than $4,000 had been subscribed to the fund since the last previous meeting of the committee.

A funny anecdote connected with the Hon. Joe Blackburn's first race for Congress was told to me the other day. Joe happened to be passing through Owenton, the county seat of Owen County, on the occasion of the hanging of a noted criminal.

Chief Engineer and Superintendent Culyer, of Brooklyn, announces that the Prospect Park lake will probably be thrown open to skaters to-morrow or Thursday. The south slide on Lookout Hill, from the crest to the edge of the lake, has been leveled and is set apart for toboggan parties, a large number of which have already patronized it. The sport promises to become popular among residents of the upper wards of Brooklyn.

NEW-HAVEN, Jan. 11.--Mrs. Margaret Degnan, a woman about 50 years old, fell dead in Orange-street, this city, to-day. An autopsy showed that death was due to heart disease. Her husband, a veteran of the late war, is supposed to be in the Soldiers' Home at Dayton, Ohio.
Large forces of men were busy all day yesterday clearing the snow from the principal streets south of Canal, and by 6 o'clock they had removed much of that which had been shoveled from the sidewalk.

John Degeilh, a French shoemaker, 42 years of age, of No. 197 Greene-street, despondent from long sickness and inability to work, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the left breast. He leaves a widow and a son 14 years old.

CENTRALIA, Ill., Jan. 3.--A few days ago, while an old gray-haired man was sitting in one of our hotels, a stranger got off a train which had just arrived and passed through the waiting room. He eyed the old man closely, and over the face of the latter there flashed a look of recognition.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 11.--The Knights of Labor Assembly of District 101 began their first annual session in this city this morning. About 150 delegates are in the city.

Mr. George R. Gibson, a banker at No. 49 Broadway, and who lives at the Rutland flats, Broadway and Fifty-seventh-street, called at Police Headquarters last night and reported the disappearance of his nephew, Henry C. Hinckle, a student at the University Medical College in Twenty-sixth-street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11.--John A. Logan and those Senators who have followed his lead in opposing the confirmation of Civil Service Commissioner Eaton made their final plea for his rejection in the Senate to-day, and then that body confirmed Mr. Eaton by a decisive majority.
The English steamship agents have received instructions by cable to increase their prepaid steerage rates.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 11.--O'Leary left the track at 10:10 o'clock this evening, with 1,418 miles and 2 laps to his credit, while Weston continued walking until 10:30 o'clock and completed 1,386 miles. The attendance was not large. The track is 9 laps to the mile.

When the New-York Presbytery met yesterday afternoon in the Scotch church, on West Fourteenth-street, a petition was read from the mission chapel of the Madison-Square Presbyterian Church, signed by over 250 members, asking that the mission be organized in an independent church under direction of the Presbytery.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 11.--A sad death, which occurred under peculiarly mysterious circumstances, came to light here to-day. The victim was Miss Flora Brown, a Greene County lady, who came to this city the day before Christmas.

About 40 gentlemen, representing Protestant Episcopal churches of the city, met last evening in Annex Hall, at No. 16 Fourth-avenue, to perfect the organization of a general church temperance society for the city, to be known as the Metropolitan Temperance Board of the City of New-York.

From early morning yesterday until after midnight sleigh bells jingled through the Park. The daylight hours belonged essentially to the ladies. Some of them drove out in merry pairs and trios and bowled over the snow as dexterously as practiced reinsmen.

ROME, Ga., Jan. 11.--While Ben H. Allman was sitting at the breakfast table this morning he drew a pistol and, placing the muzzle to his heart, fired. Mental depression over debts drove him to the act.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 11.--Gov. Bate to-day commuted to five years the sentence of William Spence, who was sent to the penitentiary last year to serve a life term for the murder of his son-in-law, Col. Edward S. Wheat, exUnited States Marshal.
During the storm Saturday morning the schooner Sea Bird, Capt. Haskell, of Ellsworth, Me., was wrecked off Gull Island, in the Sound.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 11.--The body of Capt. Conwell, of the schooner Mary G. Farr, which was wrecked on this coast Friday night, will be sent to his home in Milton, Del.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 11.--The frosty atmosphere and the cutting western wind did not deter the military and civic organizations, as well as the political clubs from all parts of the State, from parading in honor of the inauguration of Gov. Foraker.

The talent of the newly knighted painter, Sir Oswald W. Brierly, is very much better known in royal than in artistic circles.
Judge Nathaniel Shipman, of Hartford, is at the Murray Hill Hotel.

NEWBURG, Jan. 11.--On Saturday two detectives from Jersey City, with Deputy Sheriff Price, arrested M.B. Smith at Mount Hope, Orange County, on the charge of bigamy, preferred against him by a woman in Jersey City who claims to be his legal wife.

The clever authors of the original German schwank from which "A Night Off" is taken recently added a sequel to their popular farce, and this work was made known at the Thalia Theatre last evening for the benefit of a large and hilarious assemblage.

Fire broke out on the third floor of the five-story marble building at No. 4 Great Jonesstreet at about 1 o'clock this morning. When the fire was discovered the whole floor, which was occupied by J.F. Tapley, bookbinder, and the North American Metalline Company, was in flames.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11.--The shareholders of the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad Company held their annual meeting to-day. The yearly report did not make a favorable showing, the deficiency in meeting fixed charges being $171,865.
Mr. Joseffy plays Rubinstein's D minor concerto No. 4 in this evening's popular concert at the Academy of Music.

A well dressed gentleman, apparently about 65 years of age, stepped into the narrow elevator car in the National Park Bank Building, No. 214 Broadway, a few minutes before 12 o'clock yesterday. The car was just about starting on its ascent from the first to the fifth floor.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 11.--Louis Hammondi, formerly head cutter of ladies' garments at L.P. Hollander Co.'s, on Washington-street, is wanted in Montreal for larceny from the firm of Henry Morgan Co.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11.--The president sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: J. Gideon Harris to be Register of the Land Office at Montgomery, Ala.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 11.--The joint Democratic caucus was held this evening for the purpose of placing in nomination a candidate for United States Senator. The meeting organized by calling Senator Sullivan to the chair, and Representative Butterfield, of Hamilton County, was made Secretary.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 11.--Joseph V. Rivers, colored, ex-Postmaster at Ladies' Island, S.C., was to-day convicted of embezzling Government funds.

MONTREAL, Jan. 11.--Dr. Orton, member of Parliament, arrived in this city to-day from Winnipeg. He states that there is danger of a rising among the Bloods, Blackfeet, and Piegans in the western portion of the Territories.
CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 11, via Galveston.-- The prices of imported goods are being advanced by the merchants is consequence of the continued depreciation of silver.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11.--Hugh Riddle, who was elected Arbitrator of the east-bound freight pools of the Western connections of the trunk lines by the managers of the Chicago east-bound roads, intends to accept the position. He says that while he refused to accept the position of Commissioner, he is willing to decide and arbitrate questions of dispute, , and if the position tendered him requires no other duties from him he will accept the place.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 11.--A valuable sale of thoroughbreds was made here to-day by Frank Harper, owner of Longfellow and Ten Broeck, to Green B. Morris, owner of Bersan. They were Con Cregan, 3 years old, full brother to Drake Carter, and Ermine, bay filly, 2 years old, full sister to the famous Bersan. The price for the two was $10,000.

It was decided yesterday at a meeting of the Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge to increase the pay of all policemen, conductors, and toll takers who have been employed on the bridge for one year or more.

When Mr. Robert B. Roosevelt opened his mail yesterday morning he found among other letters one from President Cleveland. In it he was asked if his appointment as Assistant Treasurer of the United States at New-York would be agreeable.

Fifty members and about the same number of guests sat down to the one hundred and sixteenth anniversary dinner of the New-York Marine Society, at No. 32 Lafayette-place, last evening. Prior to the dinner the society reelected Capt. Ambrose Snow President; E.G. Tinker and William H. Allen, Vice-Presidents;

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11.--The report of the Senate Committee on Territories, to accompany the bill for the admission of Dakota into the Union and the organization of the Territory of Lincoln, reported by Senator Harrison to-day, covers more than 100 pages of manuscript, in addition to its voluminous printed ...
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 11.--Miss Annie L. Ihmsen, of Pittsburg, an heiress to $60,000, has been declared an incurable lunatic by a commission de lunatico appointed by the court.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES has been gradually extending its sphere of usefulness, and it now counts among its readers men of all nationalities, creeds, and conditions of life. Without lowering in any way its high standard of literary excellence it has become popular with the masses.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 11.--A young man, known as John Mullen, alias John McDonald, who says he comes from Chicago, was arrested on Saturday at Jamaica Plain on suspicion of being a counterfeiter.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11.--East-bound passenger affairs are getting more complicated every day. So strained are the relations between the various roads that it is found impossible to get up another meeting of the Chicago East-bound Passenger Committee.

The American Opera Company gave a performance of Goetz's "Taming of the Shrew" in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening before an audience that filled the house to its utmost capacity, and was at once brilliant and appreciative.

MADRID, Jan. 11.--A party of rebels has seized Fort St. Julian, in Carthagena, and wounded the Military Governor. The commotion attracted the attention of troops in the vicinity and they hastened to the scene of disturbance. On their approach the rebels fled.
SING SING, Jan. 11.--Last Saturday Thomas Wright, of Amawalk, in the town of Yorktown, Westchester County, was called by business to Boston.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 11.--The residence of the widow or Dr. G.S. Miles, one mile from Jordan Station, Ky., was burned at 4 o'clock this morning.

For an hour yesterday forenoon a woman walked up and down the ladies' waiting room at the Third-street station in her efforts to hush the screams and yells of a child about 2 years old.
Sol Smith Russell and company began a week's engagemeut at the Grand Opera House last evening, and a large audience applauded and laughed at the performers.

The General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday affirmed the conviction of John Carpenter, who murdered his wife in Third-avenue about two years ago.
SOURABAYA, Java, Jan. 11.--The American ship Sacramento, Capt. Nelson, from NewYork June 6, for Shanghai, has been wrecked on Brill Reef. The crew were saved.

LONDON, Jan. 11.--Intelligence has been received here that Germay has seized the island of Samoa, in the Pacific Ocean. The King and his chiefs were insulted and finally fled. MALONE, N.Y., Jan. 13.--At 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon John S. Gillett, 32 years old, of this place, a traveling salesman for Wisner, Lohman Co., wholesale grocers, of NewYork, entered a drug store here and going to the back room swallowed the contents of a 60grain bottle of morphine.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 13.--After a season of 52 weeks the Hammersly Opera Company has disbanded, because of continued bad business. Several of the company left for NewYork this evening and the balance will depart to-morrow. The report that salaries were in arrears is denied by the management.

There was a block of the cars on the Brooklyn Bridge last evening about 6:45 o'clock, caused by a train slipping the cable on the Brooklyn approach and being unable to catch it again. Hundreds of persons who had been waiting to ride walked across the bridge because of a groundless rumor that no more trains were to be run until to-day. In 15 minutes the trouble was over and trains were running as usual.

General Passenger Agent Lord, of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, yesterday received word from his Western passenger agent to the effect that the Pennsylvania Road proposed to meet the Baltimore and Ohio's Western rate by cutting its east-bound rate from Chicago to Baltimore and Washington to $13, the present rate by both routes being $17.
Sixty gentlemen, who were either born in or had had something to do with Ohio, met last evening in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel and accomplished the permanent organization of the Ohio Society.

LONDON, Jan. 13.--There was a crush of members offering themselves to take the oath on the meeting of the House of Commons today. They were sworn in in batches. Among the crowd was Mr. Bradlaugh, who cordially shook hands with the Speaker.
CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 14, via Galveston. --The editors of several newspapers have been imprisoned for making libelous attacks on the authorities.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 14.--The continued cold weather has made splendid skating on the river at all points between Tarrytown and Coxsackie, and great crowds of skaters were seen everywhere this afternoon.

All the cigarmakers who were employed in the factory of Levy Brothers, in Avenue C, near Thirteenth-street, who were members of the Cigarmakers' International Union, went out on strike yesterday morning to resist the reduction of wages which had been decided upon by the Cigar Manufacturers' Association.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 14.--A week ago Painter, Tongue Co., dry goods and notion dealers, made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors, and William H. Rose was arrested, charged with having embezzled $15,000 from the firm.
The New-York Ferry Company recently reorganized under the title of the Brooklyn and New-York Ferry Company.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14.--At a meeting of Harvard football men this afternoon William Allen Brooks, '87, of Haverhill, was elected Captain of the university eleven for the season of 1836.

CHARLOTTE N.C., Jan. 14.--Yesterday evening a party of five persons at Salisbury started out to hunt rabbits. One was run into a hole in a stump two miles from town. Tom Mowery sat his gun down to help the dogs, and either himself or another of the party knocked it over. It exploded as it fell and shot Mowery's head nearly off. He died instantly. He leaves a widow and two children.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 14.--News has been received of the capture of six convicts by the unaided efforts of an old farmer.

George R. Blanchard, formerly VicePresident of the Erie Railway, has consented to take the Commissionership of the east-bound freight pool, and has signified his readiness to enter on his duties at once.

MOUNT ORAB, Ohio, Jan. 14.--Last evening Marshal McGraw attempted to arrest a farmer named Clayton Brooks, who was intoxicated. Brooks made a show of resistance, and McGraw shot and killed him. McGraw was hastily taken to the county seat to avoid lynching.

ELIZABETHPORT, N.J., Jan. 14.--As a coal train on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad was passing here, about 2 o'clock this afternoon, an axle broke and 11 loaded cars were wrecked. No one was injured. Travel was delayed about two hours. Loss, $2,000.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 14.--Wiley B. Bryan, who was indicted for sending obscene writing through the mails to Miss Fanny Doiman and attempting to abduct her for evil purposes, was to-day round guilty and sentenced to three years' imprisonment in the penitentiary. Bryan received the verdict with composure. A motion for a new trial was entered and will shortly be argued.
LONDON, Ontario, Jan. 14.--Word has been received from Dakota of the death of George McCabe, who was tried here a year ago on a charge of poisoning his wife at the Dewdrop Inn, London, South.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14.--Stephen McPherson, a negro, was to-day tried before Judge Thayer for assault and battery with intent to kill on Robert J. Cook, the famous athlete and business manager of the Press Company. Capt. look testified that McPherson was employed as janitor at the Press Building.

The revival of Shakespeare's comedy of "The Merry Wives of Windsor" was effected at Daly's Theatre last evening with results which, if they were not brilliant, were at least pleasing. JAMAICA, Long Island, Jan. 14.--It is reported from Matinecock Point that the steamer Greenwich, with freight, from New-York for Oyster Bay, ran ashore on Fox Island yesterday afternoon and bad a hole stove in her side by the ice. The crew are safe.
PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 14.--The ice in the Passaic River gorged just above Straight-Street Bridge early this morning and for a time threatened considerable damage to property in the lower part of town.
NEWMARKET, Ontario, Jan. 14.--Frank Tundy, foreman in Cane Co.'s pail and tub manufactory, while reaching under a saw today was caught by the mandrel and his head was severed from his body.
The return of the children sent from Newark to Paris to be inoculated for hydrophobia ought to mark the close of a particularly foolish and mischievous sensation.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 14--A certified copy of the Supreme Court order granting a stay of proceedings in the Milton Weston case was received from Philadelphia this morning. Mr. Weston appeared in court, and, after renewing his bond of $15,000, was released. He will leave for New-York at once to arrange his business affairs and will return for sentence during the latter part of the week.

The special committee appointed by the Republican County Committee to investigate the charges of political crookedness against some of the Republicad district leaders expects to make its report at the regular meeting of the County Committee next Tuesday evening.

It has long been evident that the Quarantine establishment at this port sorely needs overhauling. The abuses which have sprung up are due in part to the system of permitting public officials to collect fees and to pocket them as compensation for their services, and in part to the practice of treating the offices connected with the establishment as purely political.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 14.--William Friede, a young man of 20, with no home and without work, entered a hardware store at No. 650 Lorain-street at 5 o'clock this evening and asked to be shown some revolvers. He was permitted to examine a 32-calibre Smith Wesson, and when the clerk's back was turned he fired a cartridge, with which he had loaded it, into his body just above his heart. He will recover.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14.--Investigations made periodically by the city police, private detectives, and other persons commissioned to the work, have disclosed that the anarchists of this city have been engaged in manufacturing dynamite bombs, and in experimenting with other infornal machines for the purpose, as they declare, of destroying the militia, and blowing up the large public buildings when the "great revolution" begins.

Marston claims to have written a play called "Walton's Home" for the actors, for which they were to pay him $3,000. They put up $200 as an advance, but concluded not to present the play when they got it.

A comittee of the Hudson County Board of Chosen Freeholders heard charges yesterday against three of the under keepers of the county penitentiary at Snake Hill. The keepers were John Smith, William Dolan, and Patrick Carroll. Three female prisoners who had been looked up in a "dark cell" accused the keepers of taking them out of the cell at midnight and assaulting them. Smith was dismissed. The charges against the other keepers were not proved.

The House Committee on Public Lands agreed to-day to report favorably to the House Mr. Payson's bill declaring forfeited certain grants of lands made to the States of Mississippi, Alabama, and Louisiana in aid of the construction of railroads, with an amendment excluding the Gulf and Ship island grant from the operation of the act.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 14.--The weather moderated considerably during the day, and is now nearly normal. The rise of temperature has been very gradual for two days, with a cloudy sky, which is very favorable, as it reduces the damage inflicted by the cold upon the orange trees to a minimum.

A verdict for the Government was rendered yesterday in a case tried before Judge Shipman and a jury in the United States Circuit Court on a question of the forfeiture of imported goods for fraudulent undervaluation.

ALBANY, Jan. 14.--No victims of the rag disinfecting company being in sight, Dr. Allegany Smith came down from the lookout at Quarantine yesterday long enough to take a flying trip to Albany. His son Frank was also in town.
TROY, N.Y., Jan. 14.--About a year ago, after the death of her mother, Emma Burke, aged 9 years, was placed by her father in the care of his brother, Edward Burke, of Grafton.

Many friends of the Training School for Nurses attached to Bellevue Hospital were gathered in the Nurses' Home, No. 426 East Twenty-sixth-street, last evening, to attend the annual meeting and see the graduates.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 14.--Yesterday's session of the Texas Live Stock Association was taken up with the consideration of the report submitted by the Committee on Public Lands. After some modifications the report was finally adopted by a close vote.
Delegates from all sections of the country met yesterday at the Hotel Brunswick to take part in the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Morocco Manufacturers' National Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--While the Republican Senators are fretting about the evasive reports of Cabinet officers to inquiries for information about removals and suspensions, and talking rashly about summoning the heads of departments and even the President to give their reasons, it does not appear that they have yet made any attempt to obtain the President's reasons by applying to him.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 14.--This city is in the midst of a genuine water famine. The residents of only the lowest portions of the city were able to obtain enough water to finish the preparation of their noonday meals to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 14.--The strike at the New-Haven Wire Mills was practically ended to-day, as 20 of the men returned to work at the wages offered by the company last July, when the men went out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--The proceedings in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day were as follows: No. 58--John Patch, plaintiff in error, vs. E. E. White.--Reargument concluded by Calderon Carise for the plaintiff in error.

BOSTON, Jan. 14.--The "Sullivan and Jacques of Boston" reported by cable as having arrived in Paris to submit themselves to M. Pasteur's treatment for the prevention of hydrophobia are a substantial farmer of Groton and his hired man.

William Cummings, of Stapleton, Staten Island, charged with causing the death of his wife, Elizabeth, about two months ago, after a long examination before Justice Cornell, at Clifton, was committed to the county jail, at Richmond, Staten Island, last evening to await the action of the Grand Jury.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14.--The statement that President Cleveland has determined that no answers shall be given to requests from the Senate for information as to the reasons for removals or suspensions from office is authoritatively denied.
The members of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association were in a very pleasant frame of mind yesterday. Secretary Dooley's mental condition might be described as hilarious.

BOSTON, Jan. 14.--A private dispatch announces the death, in Sonora, Cal., to-day of Capt. Charles C. Morton, aged 76 years. Capt. Morton was a native of Nantucket and was master of the bark John W. Coffin, which sailed from Boston Dec. 8, 1848, being the first vessel to leave Boston for California after the discovery of gold.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 15.--Orders were received last night by the West Shore agent to cut rates on lumber from Buffalo as follows: To New-York, 16 cents per 100; Boston, 19 cents; Philadelphia, 14 cents; Albany, 12 cents. This is a cut of from 2 to 3 cents.

Ward B. Smith, of Jersey City, who was convicted of bigamy, was yesterday sentenced to the State prison for five years. Smith was married to Miss Alice Legatt, of South Brooklyn, in 1880, and abandoned her to marry Nettle F. Rettinger, of New-York, in 1884. Both of his wives appeared against him in court.

The Chicago managers' committee completed its meeting at the Windsor Hotel yesterday by virtually agreeing upon the terms of an east-bound pooling arrangement. All the roads leading out of Chicago were represented at the meeting, and the pooling arrangement now awaits only the signature of President Jewett, of the Chicago and Atlantic road. He took the agreement home with him for study, and his decision will be announced at the next meeting at Chicago.

LONDON, Jan. 15.--The St. James's Gazette denies the rumors published in the News this morning that the Government meditates a coup d'etat in Ireland, and says: "The Government must and will take precautions against disorder in Ireland."

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 15.--J. O'Hearn, manager of the Carbondale Opera House, says that the reports recently published to the effect that he had assaulted George Miln, the Chicago preacher-tragedian, were distorted and exaggerated.
The alleged Socialist conspiracy which has its headquarters in Chicago is probably very much magnified in the reports which have been sent out from that centre of "sensations."

It is expected that the dog pound for the indiscriminate destruction of dogs in Newark will be opened on next Wednesday. The keepers have been appointed and $500 was appropriated last night by the Common Council to carry out the plan.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 15.--Special reports to the American Rural Home, of this city, from over 5,000 correspondents in all parts of the country, indicate that the snowstorm with the recent intense cold has protected the wheat from all harm.

A handful of dry chestnuts rattled down upon the stage of the Fourteenth-Street Theatre last night when John A. Mackay and George Fortescue began to bombard one another with some of the old, old puns that adorn the dialogue of "Evangeline."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 15.--This has been a day of excitement, danger, and apprehension in Cleveland, followed by an evening of relief. The announcement in the morning papers that it might be two weeks before water would again be drawn through the lake tunnel created great fear and consequent hurrying from one end of the city to the other.

TROY, Jan. 15.--Bradford C. Vaughn, an extensive manufacturer of vitriol, has left the city within a few days. A mortgage for $65,000 on real estate owned by him was recorded in favor of his mother-in-law to-day.

Controller Loew is after the Broadway railway people. He said yesterday that the company did not give the city the benefit of its percentage of fares collected from passengers above Fourteenth-street, although many of these passengers ride on lower Broadway and even to Bowling Green.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 15.--The gang of burglars which has been operating in Fairfield County towns seems to have concentrated its efforts on Danbury. Two cases were reported to-day of burglaries on Wednesday night.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 15.--There was a drizzling rain here all day, yesterday, until nightfall, when a steady rain set in, which continued until this morning.
UTICA, Jan. 15.--Ex-Collector James Armstrong will publish a card to-morrow in reference to the allegations that he sought to retain office by claiming that he supported Mr. Cleveland.

OGDEN, Utah, Jan. 15.--The bodies of six of the thirteen victims of the coal mine explosion at Almy, Wyoming, which occurred Tuesday night, have been recovered from the mine. They were found on the seventh level. The men were killed by suffocation.

Sheriff John Mitchell, of Queens County, who has been in office but two weeks, has disgusted sporting men by giving emphatic notice that he will not permit any violation of the law regarding prize fighting, cock fighting, or dog fighting within the county. The Sheriff broke up a cock fight at Woodside, Long Island, a few nights ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--First Lieut. J.S. Pettit, First Infantry, has been granted three months' leave of absence, to take effect after the close of Indian hostilities in Arizona.

If a more perfect day for skating ever existed than yesterday the most ancient inhabitant could not recall it. The sky was bright, and the sun shone with such effect that it produced a mild, mellow atmosphere, which permitted even the frailest and youngest of children to find rare enjoyment.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15.--Before the Chicago and Pacific Railroad was leased to the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, which event occurred April 2, 1880, H.A.W. Tabor obtained judgment against the road for $3,490.
OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 15.--A man named James Patrick, while walking on the railroad track last night, saw a train coming toward him, to avoid which he stepped on another track.

Bills have been introduced in both houses of Congress for the repeal of the civil service law. Neither of them will pass the House in which it originated. If such a bill could pass both houses it would encounter the veto of the President, which would be fatal.

HAVANA, Jan. 15.--A large number of laborers have left the island recently for the Isthmus of Panama in the hope of obtaining more remunerative wages by securing work on the Panama Canal. The newspapers here contain daily warnings to workingmen not to leave their present employment in the expectation of bettering their condition to Panama, where, the papers say, they will experience nothing but misery. The opinions expressed by the newspapers are commonly indorsed.

RONDOUT, Jan. 15.--A special to the Freeman form Sangerties, N.Y., says that the Hon. W.F. Russell has declined the Sub-Treasuryship tendered him by President Cleveland. Mr. Russell celebrated his seventy-fourth birthday to-day, and thinks it best at his time of life to decline the honor.

The men asked that vouchers should be attached to all hats sized in the "fair" make shops, so that the finishers might know that hats sized only by "fair" men were being finished by them. The public rehearsal prefatory to the third concert of the Symphony Society took place yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, which was filled by a large and generously appreciative audience. The programme was Admirable in respect of variety and intrinsic worth.

ALBANY, Jan. 15.--The return on behalf of the State Board of Equalization to the writ of certiorari brought by the city of New-York, was filed with the Clerk of Albany County today by the Attorney General. Arguments upon the writ and return will be had at the General Term of the Supreme Court on the 26th inst.

The New-York Historical Society is dissatisfied with its present accommodations. They are not on a scale commensurate with the needs of the society and are inconveniently located for a majority of the members.
CALAIS, Jan. 15.--M. Sagot, a banker of this city, has suspended. His liabilities are $2,000,000.
The series of meetings which have been hold at Plymouth Church every evening during the present week was finished last night with a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Bradford, of Montclair, N.J.
The floating ice fields are causing considerable trouble in the Lower Bay. A number of channel buoys nave been set adrift, and the Southwest Spit buoy has been carried away.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 15.--Judges Simonton and McPherson to-day handed down opinions in the motion to continue the preliminary injunction restraining the sale of the South Pennsylvania Railroad to the Pennsylvania Railroad Company.

The details of the belligerent demonstration made by Commander WEBER at Apia do not greatly alter its character as at first reported. His intervention was certainly decisive, as King MALIETOA has no force with which to fight a war ship whose landing party is covered by its guns.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15.--In the Supreme Court this morning counsel for Milton Weston, the Chicago millionaire, who has been convicted in the Allegheny County Court as an accessory to a murder, made a motion for the further relief of that gentleman.
RICHMOND, Jan. 15.--The Richmond Whig, which suspended publication last month, will be reissued in a few days.

BUFFALO, Jan. 15.--At the end of to-day's walk the score stood: O'Leary, 1,605 miles, 7 laps; Weston, 1,578 miles, 3 laps, showing a gain for Weston of 1 mile and 3 laps. The men are in good condition.

The 14 firms of the United Cigar Manufacturers' Association whose hands were still at work came yesterday to the assistance of two of their number whose workmen had struck, by ordering a lockout in all the factories, to take effect on Wednesday morning.

NASHVILLE, Jan. 15.--Mrs. Mary Humphreys, formerly of Indiana, was arrested near Tullahoma, to-day, by a United States detective, and bound over for trial on the charge of defrauding the Government. She is accused of having drawn a pension for fifteen years, although she afterward married, and her second husband is still living. She will be taken to Indiana for trial.

COTULLA, Texas, Jan. 15.--Jose Maria Mendiola was hanged to-day at 2:10 for the murder of G.M. Rodges. He was accompanied to the scaffold by a priest, who made a short talk for him, saying that the criminal was sorry for his act and hoped to go to heaven.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 15.--A tenement house on the premises of Capt. W.T.R. Bell, at King's Fountain, was destroyed by fire before daylight yesterday morning. Three colored persons, Gertrude Rendleman, Julia Earle, and Julia's 18-months-old child were burned to death. The fire originated accidentally from a fireplace.

The Germania Assembly Rooms, in the Bowery, were crowded last evening by sporting men of all calibres. Horse owners, jockeys, poolsellers, pedestrians, fighters, oarsmen, marksmen, ball-players, and, in fact, all sorts of professional sports were in attendance.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 15.--Two more games were drawn in the checker championship match to-day. The score is: Heffner, 0; Barker, 0; drawn, 10.

William Walter, 25 years old, who was employed as a clerk in the office of the exporting firm of J.W. Wilson at No. 102 Front-street, attempted to commit suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the left breast with a revolver.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 15.--George W. Ristine, the new manager of the Erie Consolidated Fast Freight Lines, has been in this city for a day or two consulting with his predecessor, T.A. Lewis.

ALBANY, Jan. 15.--Typhus fever has cliamed for its victim the resident physician at the penitentiary, Dr. Joseph W. Reilly, who died at his home, in West Troy, this morning after two weeks' illness. He was assiduous in his care of the sick convicts until prostrated with the fever. He was 25 years old, and had held his position about a year. The plague among the prisoners is abating rapidly.
The steamship The Queen, of the National Line, which sailed for London yesterday afternoon, grounded in the ship channel near the Hospital Islands, in the Lower Bay.

SAVANNAH, Jan. 15.--James A. Brall, a cotton broker and member of the New-York Cotton Exchange, committed suicide at Albany to-day by shooting through the heart with a revolver. Unlucky speculation is believed to have prompted the deed. He leaves a wife and two sons in New-York. The father of Mr. Brall won heavy cotton suits against the Government after the war.

READING, Penn., Jan. 15.--The furnace and puddling mill of S. Seyfert, near Gibraltar, closed last evening because of a disagreement between the men and the firm. Forty puddlers and helpers left the mill and sent a committee to the firm stating that they would not go back to work until they were furnished with better iron. Some of the employes were paid and other were discharged. The rolling mill is still in operation.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 15.--Some time ago Joe Flowers, a negro, living in Bienville Parish, La., was attacked by a party of white men and severely beaten.

A jury in the City Court decided yesterday that Alexander H. Strouse was too big for a pair of trousers his tailors sought to impose on him, and that therefore he should not be compelled to pay for them.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 15.--There is every prospect that the ice gorges above Nashville, when they break, will do considerable damage.

BUFFALO, Jan. 15.--A warrant was issued this afternoon for the arrest of Prof. O.S. Fowler, the famed phrenologist, on a charge of practicing medicine without a license.

MANCHESTER, Jan. 15.--The Guardian in its commercial article says: "The market is quiet. Prices are steady. There is increased inquiry for China staples. Few offers for any large quantity are accepted. The India business has been small owing to the low prices offered. Yarns are inactive. Prices of the finer numbers are hardening."
The public rehearsal prefatory to the third concert given by the Philharmonic Society of Brooklyn this season took place at the Academy of Music, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

ANTIGO, Wis., Jan. 15.--The preliminary examination of Mrs. Chadek, who is charged with the murder of her husband, the late Postmaster at Deer Brook, began to-day.
MONTREAL, Jan. 15.--L.E. Morin, an oil merchant here, has made an assignment. His liabilities are $20,000. The principal creditors are the Producers' Oil Company of Petrolia and the Bank Nationale.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 15.--Several weeks ago Frank Knoch, his wife, and their two children were murdered and their bodies burned in their home. Within a short time the relatives of the murdered family began to dispute over the little property that had been left.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 15.--At the annual meeting, to-day, of the American Statistical Association, the following officers were elected: President--Gen. Francis A. Walker; Vice-Presidents--George C. Shattuck and Hamilton A. Hill; Recording Secretary--Edward Atkinson; Corresponding Secretary--Carroll D. Wright; Treasurer--Lyman Mason; Librarian--Julius L. Clark, with the old Board of Councilors and other officers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15.--Judge Blodgett today sentenced B.T.O. Hubbard, the ex-Cashier of the First National Bank of Monmouth, who embezzled about $110,000, to seven years' imprisonment at Joliet. The motion for a new trial was overruled without argument. Hubbard will go to prison in 10 days.
HAVERHILL, Mass., Jan. 15.--J.C. Hardy's coal office was entered by burglars at an early hour this morning. The safe was blown open and wrecked.

COLUMBUS, Jan. 15.--Just after the election last October, Thomas Cogan, of Cincinnati, McLean's Chairman of the Democratic State Executive Committee, was a visitor to Columbus and other towns where the vote for legislative candidates was uncomfortably close.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15.--The officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company deny the report that they are about to meet the cut in west-bound passenger rates from New-York made by the Baltimore and Ohio.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Jan. 6.--A speciall from Leaky, in Edwards County, tells of the discovery of a paying gold mine. The ore yields from $68 to $300 per ton. Prospectors are pouring in and many claims have been staked off. A complete mining outfit will be erected at once.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 16.--Col. Charles S. Cotter, Superintendent of the State House and ground's under Gov. Hoadly, was found dead in bed this morning. He retired about midnight in apparently good health.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 16.--A stationary boiler in Walter's flouring mill at Butler, Penn., exploded this afternoon, wrecking the structure and seriously injuring two small boys who were in the mill at the time.
