CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--John Boppin, a single man, residing at No. 2,500 Emerald-avenue, developed a case of smallpox this morning, and on recommendation of Dr. Sawyer was sent to the pesthouse.

BERMUDA, Jan. 12.--Bark Idaho, Richardson, 6 ds. from New-York, for Clenfuegos, with general cargo, arr. at this port in tow of tug Gladisfen. Experienced very severe weather and vessel was badly damaged.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--The Trustees of the Grant Monument fund to-day adopted resolutions declaring the money at their disposal insufficient "to erect any appropriate and enduring structure of that nature which will be worthy of the subject or the park where it would be placed.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 16.--A second case of smallpox was discovered in the Jollett family, in Blackstone, Mass., this afternoon, Great excitement prevailed in the village, as a hundred persons were exposed to the first case, and it is thought that other cases will be developed. The local physicians are actively engaged in vaccinating the villagers.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 16.--The operatives in the mills of Messrs. B.B. R. Knight, in Natick, River Point, Arctic, and Hebronville, received notice to-day that the wages of those engaged on piece work would be advanced on Feb. 1 so as to make good the loss in pay occasioned by the 10-hour law. There is considerable rejoicing among the operatives.

Inquiry at the various trunk line offices yesterday showed that the emigrant pool remains intact, despite the reduction to $7 to Chicago. There are no indications whatever of any disruption in the pool, and all the trunk lines are obtaining their full quota of business.
The steamship The Queen, of the National Line, which grounded in the ship channel in the Lower Bay on Friday, remained aground all day yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 16.--For some time past efforts were made to procure a delivery of the mails on Sunday, but the project has failed. A letter from Postmaster-General Vilas to the Postmaster of Baltimore says that it is not done elsewhere, and out of respect to the moral sense or the community it will not be granted. Further, he can see no necessity for a Sunday delivery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--The Treasury Department has given notice to the Collector of Customs at Baltimore that leather jackets or short coats lined throughout with wool flannel are properly classified as wearing apparel in part of wool, and as such are subject to duty at the rate of 40 cents per pound and 35 per cent. ad valorem.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 16.--James Harrison, a switchman in the Delaware division yard at Port Jervis, was killed there about 10 o'clock last night. He was riding on an engine and jumped off in front of it. Both arms were cut off and his head was cut badly. He lived one hour. His age was 30 years.
Bluff Capt. Nathaniel Keeney, of the fishing smack Stephen Woolsey, was a happy man yesterday.

The Executive Committee of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association held a meeting at No. 20 Nassau-street yesterday afternoon and selected Gen. James R. O'Beirne and Major John Byrne as speakers for the association meeting at the Hoffman House on Monday evening.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Jan. 16.--This morning's TIMES contained an account of the sudden death of Samuel England in this county.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--Up to 3 o'clock to-day the Washington Park Club had received 528 entries to its 16 stakes, closing Jan. 15. The club is reasonably sure of l,100 entries. Among the entries to the All Age Stakes is the mare Fallen Leaf, owned by E.J. Baldwin, of California, by Grinstead, out of Molly McCarthy.

Commissioner Atkins cut down the number of traders at each agency from four to two when he assumed charge of the office of Indian Affairs, but afterward, under pressure, restored the old order of things.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 16.--C.A.J. Quickberner and George D. Phillips, of New-York, who announced yesterday their intention of skating on the Hudson River from Tarrytown to this city, arrived here about 1:30 o'clock this afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 16.--In accordance with a previous notice the Fund Commission of Jefferson City, Mo., received bids until noon yesterday for the purchase of $650,000 of State funding 5-20 bonds.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 16.--It is rumored here that Sir John Macdonald, upon his return to Canada, will grant full and unconditional pardon to all political prisoners now undergoing sentence in the North west for connection with the recent rebellion in that country.

Nothing more was learned in Wall-street yesterday about the affairs of the bankrupt banking and brokerage firm of Brown Anderton. Mr. Anderton's resignation as a member of the Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange has been accepted.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 16.--An effort is being made to obtain an extension of the Lifesaving Service between Point Judith, R.I., and Watch Hill by connecting the two stations. The coast, owing to tidal currents, is a dangerous one.

STAUNTON, Va., Jan. 16.--Several inches of snow fell here to-day, but the weather is moderate this evening. Reports from surrounding sections state that there has been a fearful destruction of game birds, thousands of partridges, pheasants, and doves having perished from the cold. The extermination of these birds is feared.
LONDON, Jan. 16.--The London Chamber of Commerce has petitioned the Indian Office to facilitate the establishing of railroad communication between Burmah and China.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 16.--C.E. Hershey, for many years the Cashier of the First National Bank of Owosso, and a reputed wealthy and efficient business man, left town Thursday, ostensibly on business, but really for parts unknown, and it is said took with him several thousand dollars in ready money.

A dinner was given by the Lotos Club last evening to Major A.W. Greely, the arctic explorer. In the absence of the President of the club, Whitelaw Reid, Gen. Horace Porter presided.

TOMS RIVER, N.Y., Jan. 16.--There was tremendous excitement for a time is this place yesterday afternoon. S.W. Warren's dynamite packing house is situated about three miles from the town. Three thousand tons of dynamite are kept stored in the building.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 16.--An Attica (Ind.) special reports the killing at that place this afternoon of Henry Loddi by John Reinhardt.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 16.--J. Thompson, of Birmingham, had a narrow escape from death to-night. He has been troubled with varicose veins, and as he was drawing an electric stocking over one of his feet a vein burst. Before a physician could reach the sufferer's home he had lost a quart of blood, and with all the doctor's skill Thompson was just saved from bleeding to death.

VINCENNES, Ind., Jan. 16.--A masked mob appeared at the jail this morning, in which Hally Epps, the negro who killed Farmer Dobson, is confined and demanded the keys from the jailer.
John Kelly, the invalid ex-leader of Tammany Hall, is not so alarmingly ill as has been reported. His physician says that he has had no relapse and is improving.

NASHVILLE, Jan. 16.--The Supreme Court to-day decided that the making of bets and selling of pools on races run, paced, or trotted in another State is unlawful. Burkholtz, a saloon keeper, and a number of other men were arrested last Fall for selling and buying pools on races in other States, and were fined by the Criminal Court.

Military and social expectation is proper regarding the Old Guard ball at the Metropolitan Opera. House on Thursday evening. The committees have had their final meetings, the work of management has been assigned, and Treasurer Faris has no boxes unengaged.
MONTREAL, Jan. 16.--News was received in this city to-day that Mr. George Stephen, President of the Canadian Pacific Railway, had been knighted by the Queen.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Jan. 16.--The death of Mrs. C.V. Carson, at Canonsburg, occurred to-day. More than three years ago she was stricken with paralysis, and has not walked a step since.

PARIS, Jan. 16.--M. de Freycinet, the Prime Minister, and Minister of Foreign Affairs, to-day made a declaration in the Chamber of Deputies of the policy the new Cabinet would follow. He said that its colonial policy would be less adventurous than that of its recent predecessors.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 16.--The National Convention of Journeymen Bakers adjourned to-day after electing Charles Bloch, of NewYork, National Secretary and adopting a resolution to boycott the proprietors who refuse to reduce the hours of labor to 12 hours per day. The next convention is to be held in Chicago, Jan. 15, 1887.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 16.--The effect of the Washington decision is still apparent on Bell Telephone stock, which to-day was down to 158 at the noon board. The sales were not heavy, comprising in all 300 shares.

QUINCY, Ill., Jan. 16.--H.J. Bruning, the proprietor of a cigar factory in this place, was found dead in his office this morning with a bullet hole in his head. The cause of his death is supposed to be suicide, caused by trouble with the internal revenue officers, who took charge of the factory this afternoon.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 16.--Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Bannett, of Horseheads, N.Y., while crossing a railroad track two miles from Elmira to-day, were struck by a train on the Lehigh Valley Railroad. Mr. Bennett was instantly killed and Mrs. Bennett will probably die.

The jury in the suit of Julia Foy against Buchanan Lyall for damages for the loss of three fingers brought in a verdict yesterday for the plaintiff in the sum of $2,000. The plaintiff was cleaning a machine in motion, and her fingers were caught in the spokes of a wheel.
The familiar representation of "Die Meistersinger" was offered once more at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 16.--John Heeseman, a merchant here for 40 years, died suddenly on Jan. 4. It was found to-day that he had forged notes on banks here for $10,000 and was a defaulter to that amount.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 16.--The Times of this morning gives reports from nearly 500 points as to the crop of corn and hogs in the Northwest and Southwest. It appears that the yield of corn has been overestimated and its quality ranked too high. Ohio and Indiana farmers have sold more freely than those in other States.

An audience that quite filled the Academy of Music assembled yesterday afternoon to listen to the third performance of Gluck's "Orpheus" by the American opera company. The large gathering paid close attention to the music, and was, for a matinee audience, unusually prolific in applause.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 16.--The tunnel on the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad, near this city, which caved in last Wednesday, will be repaired, and trains resume running on Monday night.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 16.--Five prisoners escaped from the county jail at Poplar Bluff, Mo., Thursday, through the negligence of the colored janitor, who thonghtlessly left a key in a door. While he was out of doors Nancy Crow liberated four male prisoners and fled with the gang.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--The box office people at the Chicago Opera House estimate that over 600 persons who wanted to see Col. McCaull's "Mikado" company this afternoon went away disappointed, being unable to get seats. The house was sold at 1 o'clock.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 16.--The preliminary investigation into the case of the Rev. Dr. I.C. Pershing, President of the Pittsburg Methodist Episcopal Female College, is to begin on Tuesday, and will continue a week or perhaps longer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--A meeting of the Pacific slope Congressional delegations had been arranged for to-night to agree upon a uniform policy in the treatment of matters affecting that section likely to come up before Congress during the present session.

READING, Penn., Jan. 16.--Reading Typographical Union, No. 89, celebrated the one hundred and eighty-sixth anniversary of Franklin's birthday by a grand banquet at Hertwig's Family Park this evening. Nearly every newspaper and printing office in this city was represented. There were recitations, toasts, speeches, and music.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 16.--Dr. Weber, County Inspector of Diseased Cattle, visited the herd of Joseph D. Ginder, near Mastersonville, yesterday afternoon, as it was reported that the cattle there were affected with pleuro-pneumonia.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 16.--The statement of the condition of the chartered banks doing business in Canada at the end of 1885 shows a slight expansion of business during the year. There has bean an increase of $12,000,000 in aggregate assets, and a like increase in liabilities.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 16.--A.H. Norton, dress goods dealer, made an assignment yesterday. His liabilities are about $10,000. Eastern creditors hold the principal claims against him.

Dennier, in which the defendant was charged with failing to report a case of smallpox in the family of James Flynn, which he was called to attend. Dr. Dennier was held to await the action of the Grand Jury under $200 bonds.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 16.--Robert M. Gourdin, a young son of the late Dr. Peter G. Gourdin, was killed while hunting in Santee Swamp yesterday. When found he was lying on his back, with a bullet hole in his forehead. He is supposed to have been shot accidentally by some hunter, although none could be found in the vicinity.

HAZLETON, Penn., Jan. 16.--Henry Fear, age 76 years, went to his home at Black Ridge to-day, kissed his wife, and then drew a dagger from his pocket and stabbed himself in the left breast, inflicting a wound which resulted in his death several minutes later. Melancholy is the only motive attributed by his friends for the commission of the act.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.--Susan Whelan, late housekeeper and matron of the Calumet Club, one of the most aristocratic organizations of its kind in the city, to-day began a libel suit for $25,000 against the publishers of the Chicago Mail and several of its employes.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16.--Isaac Steelman, manager of the Philadelphia branch of the Colby Washing Machine Company, of Boston, was today arrested and committed in default of bail for a hearing on the charge of embezzling $500 and papers valued at $3,000, of the property of the company. Steelman admits taking the property, but claims that he is merely holding it as security for $1,500 which the company owes him.

The annual statistical report of Bellevue Hospital for 1885 shows that during the year 11,864 patients were treated in that institution. Of that number 1,106 died.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 16.--The customs officials have forwarded to the Secretary of the Treasury a report concerning the collision between the revenue cutter Dexter and the Fall River steamer Pilgrim, in which the blame is put entirely upon the Dexter. The Pilgrim's damage was slight, as was also that to the cutter, but it is thought that an investigation is to be made.

The New-York Travelers' Association met last night at the Morton House. President John. F. Henry occupying the chair. Vice-President John De Witt spoke of the growth of the association throughout the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--The leave of absence of Lient.-Col. Alexander Chambers, Twenty-first Infantry, has been further extended three months on account of disability.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Jan. 16.--Katie Rooney, the actress and daughter of Pat Rooney the comedian, is in jail here. She had some difficulty with her father while the company was playing in Peoria and left to go to Baltimore, where she has relatives. Her father intercepted her here by telegraph, and she was arrested on the east-bound train.

WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 17.--John Tucker, a prominent business man in this city and a large property owner, and who was one of the proprietors of a large flouring mill in this city, has made an assignment. The liabilities are $50,699: his real estate assets alone have been appraised at $65,000.

JOLIET, Ill., Jan. 18.--Glanders in a malignant form has broken out among the horses in the vicinity of Lisbon, 15 miles west of Joliet. Four diseased horses belonging to one man were ordered shot to-day. An epidemic is feared.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18.--In the City Court to-day a case came up which is of great interest to New-Haven people. Sherman Guernsey, a Bethany farmer, sold a diseased cow to Vogt Co., butchers, of this city, and the animal's flesh was used in the manufacture of sausage.

A faded oil portrait of Benjamin Franklin, painted in Paris when the great printer was the American ambassador to France, hung on the wall in Delmonico's large banquet hall last night, and was cheered by the 200 members of the New-York Typothetae who had assembled to eat their annual dinner.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 18.--This morning the Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club sailed their annual 15-mile race for the Commodore's pennant. A fair breeze was blowing, and although the ice was rough good time was made. The yacht Grover Cleveland won in 37:00. The Dreadnaught was a few minutes behind. The two had a great race, but the Dreadnaught was fairly outsailed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The resignation of First Lieut. M.J. Jenkins, Fourth Cavalry, has been accepted by the President, to take effect March 1.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 18.--The situation with the blockaded railroads is serious. One train from the East over the Santa Fe Road succeeded in reaching Pueblo at midnight Saturday. It was the first since Thursday. Three others arrived here yesterday.

TROY, N.Y., Jan 18.--Some gossip has been created by the clandestine marriage of Charles Seaman, a writer employed in Sinsabaugh's fashionable restaurant, to Minnie Quackenbush, a niece and adopted daughter of Mr. Sinsabaugh.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 18.--The barns of a farmer named Houck, in Glenville, this county, were set on fire by a discharged employe on Saturday night, and, with their contents, were entirely destroyed. The incendiary was discovered, and, on being pursued, ran to the Mohawk River, which be attempted to cross on the ice. When near the middle of the stream he ran into an opening in the ice and was drowned.

A splendid specimen of the Italian brunette, by name Glutana di Stefano, staggered into the room adjoining her own at No. 65 Mulberry-street, at 12:25 yesterday morning and fell dead. She had been shot through the breast by Andrea Depolido, an old Italian, with whom she had been living for some months past. The murder was premeditated and had long been expected by the neighborhood.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18.--The Trades and Labor Assembly of this city has mailed to every manufacturer and employer of labor in Chicago a circular in regard to the movement to make eight hours a day's work.

At the annual meeting of the Congregational Club of New-York last night at Clark's restaurant, in West Twenty-third-street, the subject of national aid to popular education was discussed as an after-dinner topic.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 18.--At 7.30 o'clock this morning the boilers on the towboat Modoc exploded, killing Pilot Joseph Davey and injuring several others, and making as complete a wreck of the craft as was ever witnessed on the local waters.

The trial of George Ogle, who is charged with stabbing and killing James A. Brown is a saloon on Eighth-avenue, in November, 1882 was continued in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, before Recorder Smyth, yesterday. The court room and corridors were crowded with friends of the prisoner.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 18.--The trouble between the cigarmakers and large manufacturers of this city seems to increase. The men are becoming more obstinate every day on account of the backing they are receiving from New-York unions and the International Union.

DEVIL'S LAKE, Dakota, Jan. 18.--The Bank of Devil's Lake, the pioneer bank here, has suspended, local bank depositors issuing writs of attachment for $8,000. A.M. Ferris is President; H.G. Stone, Vice-President, and O.B. Corsett, Cashier.

During the services at Plymouth Church on Sunday morning, a tall, wild-looking man in the gallery stood up in his seat and cried out: "Jesus Christ is a liar." Very few people beyond a radius of 20 feet heard him, but after the services W.H. Hudson, a pewholder, had him arrested.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 18.--Daniel G. Sperry died at his home in South Windsor yesterday. Early in December he had a premonition that he was to die, bought his coffin, and said good-bye to his friends. His premonition proved correct.

AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 18.--Matthew Hickey, a life convict from Monroe County, died in Auburn Prison this morning. He had served four years for murder.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 18.--Eliphas B. Page, of Batavia, well known throughout Western New-York as a musician, is a prisoner in the Genesee County Jail.

LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 18.--At an early hour this morning a pleasant looking gentleman of medium height, dressed plainly, but neatly, in a suit of black broadcloth, with high standing collar, and wearing a tall silk hat, walked up to the clerk's desk at Hurst's Hotel. "I haven't seen you for quite a while," said he to the clerk, Major Dean, at the same time extending a long, slender hand in the clerk's direction.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18.--Frank S. Fiske, at one time a member of the late firm of Fiske Kellogg, brokers of this city, was brought to New-Haven to-day from Staffordville, Conn., charged with embezzlement.

NASSAU, New-Providence, Jan. 12.--On the 9th inst. Charles T. Sands, a white man, shot and killed a black policeman on Bay-street. An angry mob endeavored to lynch Sands, but after a severe struggle the officers landed him at the station. For several hours the colored population were greatly excited, and fears of a riot were entertained. Quiet was restored, however, without calling out the troops, which at one time was thought unavoidable.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18.--While Lewis Allen, a woodbridge wood chopper, was at work, a day or two ago, he was struck on the face by a limb of a tree, which bounded up from the ground. His left eye was gouged out. Allen is now lying seriously ill at his home. It is probable that he will lose the sight of the uninjured eye.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 18.--More pleuropneumonia is reported; this time from the lower end of the county. A message reached Dr. S.E. Weber, County Inspector, this afternoon that the disease had attacked a herd of cattle belonging to W.W. Bickwell, of Wakefield, and that five had already died.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 18.--A new departure has been taken in the Boettger-Ratterman contested election case. The case was regularly brought before Judge Buchwalter last Thursday, and after due consideration the Judge determined that he had proper jurisdiction, and that he would try the case.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18.--Thirty-five grinders employed by the Shelton Silver Plate and Cutlery Company, of Shelton, went out on a strike to-day. They demand an increase of 10 per cent. in wages.

Surrogate Rollins yesterday denied a motion, that Commissioners be appointed to take testimony in the contest over the will of James Griffiths Henry, made in behalf of Evan J. Henry, who wishes his son's will annulled.
TROY, N.Y., Jan. 18.--A written confession of Bradford C. Vaughn, the missing vitriol manufacturer, is in the possession of his brotherin-law.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 18.--Seward Applegate, a boy or 6 years, residing with his parents, between Rhode Hall and Spottswood, N.J., was bitten by a mad dog three weeks ago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18.--The Rev. J.O. Foster presented some statistics to the Chicago Methodist ministers to-day in a paper on "Church Benevolence." Among other things it was shown that every conversion effected in the Rock River Conference last year cost $431.

There was a conference yesterday afternoon at the Grand Union Hotel between the Cigar Manufacturers' Association and a committee of the tenement house cigarmakers, and a compromise was attempted by which the 700 families of tenement house cigarmakers might return to work for the nine firms of the association who employ such labor.

Quarantine Commissioner PLATT very much mistakes the nature of the charges against him and his associates if he supposes that they can be successfully met and disposed of by his unsupported denial in a newspaper letter.

ORANGEVILLE, Ontario, Jan. 18.--A dynamite cartridge was exploded at the door of the residence of Police Magistrate Monroe yesterday, causing great damage to the building. None of the inmates was injured. This is the second occurrence of the sort at Mr. Monroe's house. He bas been imposing fines for violations of the Scott Temperance act.

ALBANY, Jan. 18.--The Common Council to-night, by a vote of 15 to 2, passed over the Mayor's veto a resolution adopting the driven well system of water supply in place of the river supply, now in use. The question was decided in a secret meeting previous to the open session of the Council.

MONTREAL, Jan. 18.--The libel suit of the Hon. Toussaint Antoine R. Laflamme, exMinister of Justice and Attorney-General, against the Toronto Mail, was concluded today. The jury awarded the plaintiff $10,000 damages, the full amount asked. The Mail charged Mr. Lafiamme with having tampered with the ballot box.
CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 18, via Galveston. --The second Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which has been in session for several days in this city, adjourned to-day.

ASHLAND, Penn., Jan. 18.--A cave-in occurred at the Tunnel colliery to-day, completely closing the fan way. As the miners had not entered the mine at the time no one was injured. It will take four months to repair the damage. Over 300 men are thrown out of employment.

Charles H. Bertrand committed suicide yesterday afternoon in Frederick Otten's saloon, at No. 348 Fulton-street, Brooklyn. He was a lawyer, about 55 years of age, and has been in trouble for several years.

Mrs. D.W. Lee, wife of a wealthy retired New-York merchant living on Ridgewood road, South Orange, put on her hat yesterday morning to go to the Post Office. Her husband kissed her affectionately as she started.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 18.--The body of Miss Bayard reached this city by the Congressional express this evening. Secretary Bayard, with his two younger sons and his private secretary, and Senator Gray accompanied the remains.

LONDON, Jan. 18.--The Queen to-day sent her private secretary, Sir H.F. Ponsonby, to Mr. Gladstone with a letter on the Irish situation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--In their search for political points against the Administration the Republican Senators have taken up the agreement entered into between the United States and Great Britain to continue temporarily the terms of the fisheries convention between the two Governments which was terminated last July.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18.--The Mapleson Opera Company opened to-night at the Academy of Music with "Carmen" before a very large and fashionable audience. Minnie Hauk, Del Puente, and Ravelli were recalled frequently before the certain. The entire parformance was a great success, and the audience was very enthusiastic.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19.--In an interview last night Patrick Egan, President of the Irish National League of America, said that he would ask the Executive Committee at its meeting on Wednesday to relieve him of his duties as President of the League and select some other man to take his place.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 19.--A special from Overton County, Tenn., says: "William Eldridge, a boy 14 years old, killed his brotherin-law, Bige Wallingford, because the later abused his wife, the sister of Eldridge."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19.--The bill authorizing the Staten Island Railroad bridge across the Arthur Kill, and by means of which the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad proposes to enter New-York Harbor, made another step toward its passage to-day.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Jan. 19.--A rare and remarkable surgical operation was performed in the Evansville City Hospital yesterday afternoon. Joseph Whye, of Warwick County, this State, had his left kidney taken out, it being rendered useless by an abscess and filled with bloody pus. He had been in the hospital 10 months without relief. He endured the operation well and seems to have a chance for recovery.

The Court of Appeals has affirmed the decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court, which released Harvey M. Munsell, of this city, from prison, where he was committed for contempt of court by Judge Van Brunt.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 19.--A committee of Wheeling nail manufacturers passed through this city to-day on their way to Boston to inspect an automatic nail machine, a recent invention, and to report upon its ability to do the work claimed. If it be available large orders will at once be given by the Wheeling manufacturers, who hope that it will solve the wage problem and do away with strikes forever.

We learn from undoubted authority that the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company will carry out this year its long-talked-of plan for a through route to Saratoga over its own lines by way of Schenectady. The New-York Central will be utilized to that city and thence a new air line road will be constructed to the Springs.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 19.--The vote for United States Senator in the Maryland Legislature resulted to-day: In the Senate--For A. P. Gorman, (Dem.,) 21 votes; for Louis E. McComas, (Rep.,) 4 votes; in the House--For A.P. Gorman, 79 votes; for Louis E. McComas, 10 votes.

Victor Hugo's masterpiece, "Marion Delorme," is to be produced on Tuesday at the Porte St. Martin, with Mme. Bernhardt as the heroine, in the very theatre where, 50 years ago, it gained its great success. The whole play was written in 11 days.

While a gang of laborers was blasting rock in one of the Guttenberg (N.J.) quarries yesterday a fuse attached to a keg of powder which was secreted under the rocks became prematurely ignited and the powder exploded with terrific force. Charles Kessner, foreman, was thrown over the rocks a distance of 40 feet, and fell with great violence.
VICTORIA, British Columbia, Jan. 19.--It is reported that three Chinamen were found starving to death in a tent at Port Henry yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19.--The members of the Dakota delegation, headed by Judges Edger ton and Moody, called on the President this afternoon by appointment and formally presented the claims of that Territory for admission into the Union of States with a view of securing his aid and co-operation in attaining that end.

Conductor John A. Brown, of the Missouri Pacific train which was snowbound near Council Grove, did a most heroic act in carrying John Tallman to Council Grove, a distance of a mile a half, on last Thursday night, with the thermometer at 22 below zero.
A memorial in honor of the late Prof. John C. Draper was read at a meeting of the Board of Trustees of the College of the City of New-York yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19.--By direction of the President Capt. William Mitchell, Third Infantry, has been ordered to appear before the Army Retiring Board at Governor's Island, New-York, when summoned for examination for retirement.

ALBANY, Jan. 19.--The Forestry Commission met here to-day, and discussed the reports received from their agents, who have been investigating the condition of the State lands in the northern part of the State, prior to making their annual report to the Legislature.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 19.--Charles Sears and E.W. Wilson, experts under State Dairy Commissioner Brown, inspected butter and cheese at 50 Newburg stores last evening and this morning. There was a very large attendance at the meeting of the Municipal Council of the Irish National League last night, and the proceedings throughout were characterized by a degree of harmony and unity very encouraging to the local leaders of the league.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19.--For the last month Gen. W.R. Rowley, Gen. Grant's old military secretary, has been lying ill at the residence of his son-in-law, J.C. Gienat, in this city. He is not expected to recover, and the physicians give very little encouragement. To-night he was very low, but it was said at the house that there was no danger of his dying during the night.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 19.--Dr. N.G. Holmes, late of Buffalo, N.Y., was killed by a runaway accident in the Twelfth District of Coffee County to-day. The deceased, the whereabouts of whose relatives are unknown, had on his person money and notes valued at $1,600.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 19.--Work was not resumed at the Edgar Thomson Steel Works to-day. The furnacemen refused to abide by the action of last night's meeting, claiming that it was packed by uninterested parties.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 19.--Tobias Epstein, a dry goods merchant, was to-day committed for trial on a charge of defrauding his creditors of $10,000 worth of goods, and was admitted to bail in $30,000. Neither his bookkeeper nor his ledger can be found.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19.--The stockholders of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company held their annual meeting to-day.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 19.--The mutilated remains discovered last night near Hell's Half Acre, one of the worst localities in the city, have not yet been identified. Two thousand people inspected the body to-day, gazing with great interest on the mangled heap of humanity which lay in a rude box.

The Court of Appeals yesterday sustained Judge Cullen in sentencing Patrick Kiernan to death in November, 1884. Kiernan is confined in the Queens County Jail, Long Island City. He was a saloon keeper in Borden-avenue, Long Island City, and Peter McCormick was his landlord.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Jan. 19.--The cigarmakers' strike, which has been in progress here for six months, is practically ended. The Cigar Manufacturers' Association dissolved to-day, and the members are filling their shops with union men.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 19.--On Sunday, Feb. 24, 1884, the safe in the jewelry store of E. Marks Son, on River-street in this city, was blown open, and diamonds and jewelry valued at $30,000 were stolen.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19.--Articles of incorporation were filed to-day by the following companies: Buffalo and Geneva Railroad Company; capital stock, $1,000,000. CHICAGO, Jan. 19.--A bold attempt to defraud the Government by means of the undervaluation of imported goods has been discovered by the Customs authorities here.

NANTICOKE, Penn., Jan. 19.--To-morrow a Board of Arbitrators, composed of several intelligent and practical miners selected by the relatives of the men and boys entombed in No. 1 slope, will meet here to make a personal inspection of the mine and to decide if the efforts which the company are making to recover the bodies are proper ones.
The Executive Committee of the Society for the Relief of the Destitute Blind has just completed its seventeenth annual report.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19.--It is the opinion of more than one Senator that the peculiar situation of affairs in the Senate regarding the nominations sent in by the President will ultimately result in a discussion in open Senate of the whole subject of the rights and duties of that body and of the President in the premises.

Gov. Foraker has taken the correct position in regard to the canals of the State. He is against any scheme which will sell them out and turn them into railroads.
The trial of William A. Slaughter, dentist, for attempting to kill his wife was continued yesterday before Judge Moore, in Brooklyn.

Richard Millward, a laborer, 40 years old, of King's Bridge, while walking on the railroad track at Spuyten Duyyil crossing last evening has struck by the locomotive of a southbound train on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad and was instantly killed.

VINCENNES, Ind., Jan. 19.--The body of Holly Epps, who was hanged by a mob yesterday morning, dangled from the limb of a tree in the Court House yard until 8 o'clock.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Jan. 19.-- Premier Sullivan and Provincial Secretary Ferguson, of Prince Edward Island, have been appointed delegates bp the Island Government to proceed to England to support the petition recently forwarded praying that the terms of union with Canada, regarding Winter communication with the mainland, be carried out.

Upon the theory that it does not pay to sell poor materials Mr. C.C. Shayne, the fur dealer, has built up a reputation that is bringing to him a fast increasing prosperity. SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 19.--Jacob W. Beyer, a hatter, of this city, made an assignment to-day to William H. Peckham. His assets are $5,000. There are preferred claims of $2,352. The amount of liabilities is not known.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 19.--The mule spinners employed in the cotton mills voted in mas meeting to-night that the state of trade warranted a demand for the restoration of the scale of wages of a year ago, which was about 11 per cent, higher than present prices. About 250 mule spinners are employed in New-Bedford, and three-quarters of them were present at the meeting.
A severe blow was dealt the Cigar Manufacturers' Association yesterday by the withdrawal of D. Hirsch Co., whose factory is on Forty-first-street, between Second and Third avenues.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 19.--Proceedings in the Legislature would have been dull enough to-day but for a little brush in the Senate between Senators Nichols and Herring.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 19.--It is stated that the mail bag containing the registered letters on the mail car of the Portland and Boston night express was cut open some time yesterday morning between Boston and Portland and three packages of letters stolen. The value of the letters is not known.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19.--The Supreme Court of this State to-day announced that a majority of its members had affirmed the decision of the lower court, deciding that the Chicago election law adopted by the Legislature last Winter, and accepted by the people at the polls last Fall, is constitutional.

John Mahon held a candle over an ice bin in his saloon, at No. 42 Washington-street, last evening, and revealed to a TIMES reporter his brindle bulldog, Nell, coiled up cozily in the straw with a litter of blind pups around her.
The Thingvalla Steamship Line has reduced its prepaid steerage rates about $5. Passage tickets from Copenhagen are now $22, and from other Scandinavian ports $20.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 19.--The strike in the coke regions is assuming alarming proportions. The Governor has been asked by the Sheriff of Westmoreland County for troops. Company I, Tenth Regiment, at Greensburg, is holding itself in readiness to move at a moment's notice.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 19.--The event of the season on the river will be the race between yachts of the Poughkeepsie and Hudson River Ice Yacht Clubs for the ice yacht challenge pennant of America, which may be sailed any day this week.
The third of the series of matinees of orchestral music given this season under the auspices of the Philharmonic Society of Brooklyn took place at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 20.--Last Summer B. Frank Phillips, a young clerk, met Miss Daisy McCay at Mount Washington.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 20.--The Board of Directors of the new Richmond Whig Company to-day completed their organization by electing Mr. Abner Anderson, of Danville, business manager: Judge A.W.C, Nowlin, of Washington, chief editor, and Peter J. Burton, of Richmond, city editor. The new paper will be issued next Wednesday, the sixty-second anniversary of the first publication of the Whig.

ALBANY, Jan. 20.--Sterling's, the gin-sell ing friend of the Governor, was displayed in the Senate this morning along with nine other appointments, none of any special importance, except for the amount of small politics which is involved in their original selection.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 20.--It appears today as though the recent mysterious disappearance of William B. Beakes, owner of the West Cornwall Driving Park, is not on account of any trouble with his secret enemy and that foul play has not been done him.
READING, Penn., Jan. 20.--The State Horticultural Association, comprising many of the most successful fruit growers in this State held its twenty-seventh annual meeting in this city to-day.

TRENTON, Jan. 20.--The New-Jersey Temperance Alliance held its annual meeting here to-day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20.--The employes of Maxwell Brothers arrived as usual this morning escorted by a large detail of police from the West Twelfth-street station.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 20.--On the morning of Jan. 6, the body of an unknown man was found by the roadside in Looneyville, a village 15 miles east of here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 20.--David P. Mish, son of J.S. Mish, the well known proprietor of the principal retail millinery establishment in this city, was shot and killed by Dr. J. H. McDonald last night as he was fleeing from the latter's house, No. 155. New Montgomerystreet, where he had been discovered in the room of the physician's wife. Dr. McDonald surrendered to the police and is now in jail.

Developments in reference to the scheme to give the Western Union Telegraph Company, through a "straw" company organized under the direction of Maurice B. Flynn and others, control of the scheme to put the wires under ground continue to come to light.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 20.--The annual meeting of the New-York State Cider and Cider Vinegar Makers' Association opened here at 2 P.M. to-day, and will continue till to-morrow evening.
SHAMOKIN, Penn., Jan. 20.--The last of the collieries flooded in this region by the recent heavy rainstorm resumed work to-day.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 20.--The new City Clerk appointed by the Aldermen is a Democrat, He has recently announced his appointments, all new men.
Kate Romer is but 16 years old, but during the past year she has earned quite a record for herself. Her father is a short, stout German, who lives at No. 237 East Ninety-thirdstreet.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 20.--The Western Export Association, (whisky pool,) at a special meeting here last evening, filed the basis of production at 28 per cent. of the pool capacity. The basis heretofore was 33 per cent. The members all signed a written agreement at the meeting to abstain from cutting prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20.--A scene was witnessed this afternoon in the House of Representatives which would be described if it had happened in the Assembly at Albany, as the first charge for the session of the black horse cavalry.
The inspectors who are investigating the management of the Custom House spent the greater part of yesterday in the warehouse department.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 20.--Intelligence from Tiffin, Ohio, announces the greatest strike yet made in the Ohio gas fields.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 20.--The Yale Juniors to-day elected these editors of the Yale Literary Magazine: Adrew F. Gates, Lebanon; William Kent, San Rafael. Cal.; Charles H. Luddington, Jr., New-York City; William L. Phelps, New-Haven; John N. Pomeroy, San Francisco, Cal. Mr. Pomeroy will be the Chairman of the board. He received 125 votes out of 140.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 20, via Galveston. --A telegram from Colima has been received by the Government, stating that on the morning of Friday, the l5th inst., another eruption of the volcano occurred, preceded, as before, by loud detonations. Enormous stones were thrown to a great height, and were plainly visible from Colima, which is 25 miles distant.
The bills for the protection of children which have been introduced at Albany by Senator COMSTOCK are aimed at certain abuses that seem to demand additional legislation.

TRENTON, Jan. 20.--The Assembly held a short session this morning and then adjourned for the week. The first bill passed in that branch of the Legislature was passed before the House rose.

Charles Gunderdorf is a locksmith, who lives at Third-street and Avenue B. Monday night he drank beer in Willett-street, and in paying for it he changed a five-dollar bill.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--Charles H. Reed, of New-York, this morning presented to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania a printed brief petitioning for a rehearing and reargument in the case of Milton Weston, now under sentence of four years' imprisonment for voluntary manslaughter.

Miss Hattie A. Lang was married last evening to Mr. Elton Waterbury Clark. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph F. Elder, of the Church of the Epiphany, at the residence of the bride's father, Mr. Peter Lang, No. 126 East Fifty-sixth-street.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 20.--President Allen, of the Sanior Class of Union College, has appointed the following committees for Commencement: Class Day-Masher, Skinner, Ostrander; Reception-Cole, Veeder, Dorwin; Ball --Jackson, Foote, Dorwin; Music--Woodbrdge, Lawler. The father of David Williamson Lee. who committed suicide on the 18th inst. while in a state of mental aberration superinduced by prolonged illness, was Gideon Lee, who half a century ago was the leading leather merchant of America.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 20.--The last game in the first series in the Hudson River Polo League was played here to-night by the Hudson team of Hudson, and the Casinos of this city. These clubs were a tie on the previous record, and there was a big attendance and no little excitement at to-night's game. The Casinos won the first, third, and fourth goals and with them the game and the series.

Emperor WILLIAM'S recent expression of confidence, before the Prussian Diet, that "the peace of Europe is sure to continue," scarcely finds a reflection in existing facts on the Balkan peninsula. Greece refuses to disarm without assurances of territorial extension.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 20.--The Legislature to-day in joint convention elected the Hon. Henry Lloyd to be Governor of Maryland for the term for which Gov. Robert M. McLane was elected by the people. The two houses also confirmed the election of the Hon. A.P. Gorman as United States Senator for six years from the 4th of March, 1887.
MADRID, Jan. 20.--Senior Ruiz Gomez has refused the office of Spanish Minister at Washington.
PONCA, Neb., Jan. 20.--A feud of long standing between the families of W.W. Westbrook and Anson Gibson, living one mile north of Ponca, has finally come to a bloody climax.

The President resumed his public receptions this afternoon, and shook hands with nearly 250 persons in the East Room. Prior to this he had received the delegates to the Western Waterways Convention and the members of the American Colonization Society.
SEAFORTH, Ontario, Jan. 20.--Kidd Son, proprietors of a general store, have made an assignment. Their liabilities are $40,000, and their assets $30,000.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 20.--The Legislature in joint session to-day compared and verified the vote cast by each house yesterday for United States Senators, as required by the Constitution, and Messrs. Walthall and George were officially declared elected.

Detective Price, with a squad of police, made a raid on Tuesday night on what was reported to be a "poker" game at No. 489 Sixthavenue, and arrested Thomas McGarrity, the alleged proprietor, and 18 young men who were found in the room.

Capt. William Schultz, of the Grand Central Station, has for several weeks received complaints from parents and employers of lads and young men in the pay of the Union News Company that they were encouraged to gamble in William Marrin's liquor saloon, No.107 East Forty-fourth-street.

At a meeting of the Young Men's Philomathean Society, at No. 44 Court-street, Brooklyn, last evening, the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Hall spoke on the influence of the negro on the white population in this country.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 20.--The State Editorial Association held its annual Winter meeting here to-day. J.K. Bogert, of the Wilkesbarre. Union-Leader, was chosen President; R.H. Thomas, of Mechanicsburg, Secretary, and H.C. Dern, of Altoona, Corresponding Secretary. The next excursion of the association will probably embrace the Catskills.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20.--A meeting of the shareholders of the Montreal, Portland and Boston Railway was held here to-day and a new Board of Directors elected, but this only serves to still further complicate matters, for it is alleged they were elected by an illegal vote.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20.--Gov. Hill entertained at dinner at the Executive Mansion this evening United States Judges Wallace and Cole, Chief-Judge Ruger, of the Court of Appeals, and Judges Hand and Learned.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 20.--The stockholders of the Big Sandy Railway met here today and leased all the property of the road to the Newport News and Mississippi Valley Railway Company, thus consolidating all the roads between Newport News and New-Orleans.

Mr. Kaufmann, of Franklin Township, N.J., who went to Paris and was treated by M. Pasteur for a bite inflicted by a dog supposed to be mad, arrived yesterday on the steamship Labrador, of the French Line.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 20.--The recent developments regarding ex-Collector Armstrong's alleged letter and his denial have set the Democratic politicians to talking, especially when the names of Attorney-General O'Brien and Roswell P. Flower are mentioned in connection with them.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 20.--A special meeting of the Spinners' Union to consider the proposition to demand an advance in wages will be held Friday night.

An exhibition of billiards will be given at the Press Club at 3:30 P.M. to-day. Messrs. Vignaux, Schaefer, Daly, Sexton, Heiser, and other knights of the cue have signified their intention of being present.
CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 20.--A daring robbery was committed last evening at Severin Brothers' retail jewelry store, No. 775 West Madisonstreet.

John Brown, of No. 321 East Twentyfourth-street, was held in $500 bail by Justice White, in the Yorkville court yesterday, for abusing his children, two boys, 10 and 7 years old. Brown came home drunk, and, lifting the older boy out of bed by his ears, threw him on the floor and kicked him.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 20.--There was a lively skirmish in the Senate this afternoon, growing out of the new rules adopted by that body just before Lieut.-Gov. kennedy, the presiding officer, took the oath of office.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--An important meeting of the Eastern Pig Iron Association was held to-day at the office of the Andover Iron Company, on South Fourth-street, to hear the report of the Committee on Legislation, which visited Washington a few days ago.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 20.--After innumerable delays the trial of ex-Controller James S. White on a charge of embezzling eight city bonds of the value of $8,000 has been commenced in the Circuit Court.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--Fire broke out about 5 o'clock this evening in one of a nest of oil warehouses on Arch-street, above Front, which at first threatened to be an extensive conflagration.

LONDON, Jan. 20.--The Queen's speech was read at the Ministerial dinner to-day. Referring to Ireland, the speech says in substance that, although in some respects there are favorable indications of progress toward order in that country, yet at present Ireland is disturbed by an increasing tendency to a resort to unlawful practices and a disposition to set the law at naught.

A blind old fireman, William McLaughlin by name, who lost his sight by an explosion at a fire 18 years ago, was arrested last week by Agent Wilson, of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, for employing a boy named Frederick Reynolds under 16 years of age, to lead him around in his occupation of selling lead pencils, by which he gains a scanty livelihood.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 20.--The situation in the coke region has assumed an alarming phase. This morning 300 strikers of Mount Pleasant, armed with bars, coke forks, and revolvers, started on a march and drove the men from work at the Alice Mines, and charged upon Warden's coke yard.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20--The "bobbers" are holding high carnival to-night. In Albany the bob sled has probably--reached its greatest development. Built on a series of hills the city is naturally adapted for coasting, but before last Winter the sport was not openly permitted by the authorities.

He offers Beach, of Australia, $1,000 as expenses to come to America and row him.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21.--While George Micado, of Birmingham, was smoking a cigar this morning, it exploded, completely blinding him, burning off his mustache and eyebrows, and loosening his front teeth. The cigar was purchased at one of the drug stores, in which worked a friend of the young man, and it is surmised that the explosion was the result of a practical joke.

The British bark Stanfield, which arrived from Java late Wednesday evening, has had an unfortunate time since she left Sunderland, England, last Spring. On the first day out from Sunderland, William Allen, the cook, became insane, cut his throat, and died soon afterward.

"A Dying Gladiator," in bronze, adorned Judge Shipman's desk in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, and down in front was a "David before the Combat" and a "Mozart."
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 21.--At 9:50 o'clock this morning a terrific boiler explosion occurred in the distillery of Fairbanks Duneweg, at Terre Haute. Frank McNellis and George Otterman were killed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 21.--In the Court of Appeals to-day at Frankfort the case of J.J. Cornellison, the lawyer who cowhided Judge Richard Reid, of the Superior Court, over a year ago, causing Reid to commit suicide at Mount Sterling, was argued to-day.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 21.--Georgia Belle Lyons, 17 years old, died suddenly last night from heart disease, superinduced by starvation and exposure to cold weather. The family are poor, and for several days were without fuel and suffered intensely. Their wants have been relieved.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y, Jan. 21.--Miss Mary Morgan, aged 46 years, committed suicide to-day by hanging herself to a stair rail by a clothes line. The act is attributed to mental derangement caused by deep religious study, ill health, and dearness. She was connected with a family of good position.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 21.--The annual report of State Controller Alfred C. Chapin has just been submitted to the Legislature, with the apology that its delay was caused by the extraordinary labor necessitated by the State tax sale. CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 21.--Detectives arrested here to-day J.F. Hale, who is charged with committing a number of forgeries on Illinois and Iowa banks by means of forged drafts on Chicago banks. In his valise was found drafts on 65 different banks. He is said to have served two terms in a New-York State Prison, where he was known as Robert Bowman, alias J. C. Hogan.

VANDALIA, Mo., Jan. 21.--This city has for some time been in a state of excitement caused by the presence of mad dogs. Recently a dog supposed to be afflicted with the rabies bit several others, and these still others, until a large number had been bitten. Yesterday these animals, 37 in all, were brought to the Public Square and shot, each by his own master.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 21.--The convention of striking miners and coke drawers at Dunbar this afternoon was attended by over 1,000 delegates from all parts of the coke region. The gathering was enthusiastic but orderly, and the sentiment was unanimously in favor of a continuance of the struggle.

RED FORK, Indian Territory, Jan. 21.-- Col. V.B. Haine, General Manager of the Saginaw Cattle Company, which has the Sac and Fox Indian reservation under pasture lease, said today that he was at the company's ranch throughout the recent intense cold weather.

NAHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 21.--Charles Debow shot and mortally wounded Dr. W.B. Cummings, his father-in-law, at Sparta this afternoon. Two shots were fired, both bullets taking effect. Dr. Cummings was unarmed. The cause of the shooting was not learned.

ALBANY, Jan. 21.--The third annual report of the Bureau of Statistics of Labor, by Commissioner Charles F. Peck, which was submitted to the Legislature to-day, is filled with valuable information and suggestions in regard to the important labor problems of the State.

A detective from this city visited the little village of Hastings-on-the-Hudson yesterday to discover the masked burglars who robbed the residence of Miss Sophia M.T. Cooke on Wednesday morning. The victim of the robbery is a maiden lady over 70 years of age.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21.--The proceedings in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day were as follows: Nos. 369 and 370--Henry Childs et al., plaintiffs in error, vs. the First National Bank of Peterborough, N.H.--In error to the Superior Court of Franklin County, Mass.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 21.--It was generally expected that the conflict between the Republicans and Democrats in the Senate, which created no small sensation yesterday, would be reopened this morning when the motion to discuss the resolution of Mr. Pavey came up.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21.--While two boys, Willie Anderson and Fred Hubbell, were coasting in Shelton to-day, their sleds collided, and both boys were picked up in an insensible condition. Anderson had several bones broken, and Hubbell was badly cut up.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 21--A night train Wednesday on the Nickel Plate Road ran over a man lying on the track eight miles west of Tiffin and cut his head off. The man proved to be one Feasel, of Linden, supposed to be insane. He had a large butcher's knife and 3 cents on his person. The engineer saw him, but could not stop the train.

The meeting of the General Committee of the German-American Independent Citizens' Association was packed last evening, as it afterward proved to be, by friends of the delegation headed by Edward Grosse.

Charles Paine, Second Vice-President of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company, yesterday tendered his resignation to the Board of Directors, and it was accepted, to take effect on Jan. 31.

As a pageant, the opening of Parliament by the Queen in person is no doubt worth seeing. At the same time, the general interest and curiosity it seems to have awakened are chiefly due to its novelty, since Queen VICTORIA has not opened Parliament before since the death of Lord BEACONSFIELD.

The House Committee on Banking and Currency to-day considered the bill introduced by Mr. Wilkins and generally known as the McPherson bill of last session, and after prolonged discussion agreed to report it favorably to the House by a vote of 7 to 4.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20.--The largest and most important organization of merchants in this city is likely to be drawn into the contests of the rival railroads seeking the trade and privileges of the city.

BOSTON, Jan. 21.--Information has been received in this city that the ship Frank N. Thayer, 592 tons, bound from Manila to NewYork with a cargo of hemp, has been burned at sea. The vessel was valued at $60,000, the freight at $15,000 and the cargo at $250,000. The loss on the vessel and cargo is probably covered by insurance.

The second assembly at Delmonico's, last evening, was as enjoyable as the opening ball before the holidays given by the same ladies. Placques of lilies and other flowers adorned the walls, the orchestra in the balcony was hidden behind palms and Southern plants, and in the reception rooms were vases of roses.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 21.--Considerable excitement was caused here to-day by the issue of a notice from the Police Department ordering all stores generally open for a few hours Sunday morning to be closed on Sunday hereafter. The order is aimed especially at groceries with barrooms attached, but will probably be enforced against all kinds of stores excepting those of druggists.

The Memorial Chapel of the MadisonSquare Presbyterian Church was organized last evening as an independent church, under the title of the Adams Memorial. The organization services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst, Pastor of the parent church.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 21.--A large number of the men employed in the Union Pacific shops probably 300, were discharged yesterday in order to cut down expenses.

The Secretary of the Treasury has sent to the House of Representatives a long letter, with a large number of accompanying documents, on the subject of "protests, appeals, and suits against the exaction of duties."
The Executive Committee of the Citizens' League met in the Hamilton Building, in Court-street, Brooklyn, last evening and discussed four laws which are to be presented to the Legislature next week.

Coroner Mitchell, of Yonkers, held an inquest yesterday in the case of Many Odell, of Yonkers, who died at about 9 o'clock yesterday morning from the result of a wound received by the accidental discharge of a rifle on Wednesday afternoon.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 21.--The determination of the Cotton Spinners' Union to make a demand for an advance of 10 per cent. in wages has been the cause of considerable trouble in several of the large cotton factories here, and already operatives in four of the mills have quit work for various causes.

CENTRALIA, Ill., Jan. 21.--The report circulated that J.W. Turley, the missing Land Commissioner of the Illinois Central Railroad, had turned up on a towboat on the Mississippi River, has proved to be untrue, and the affair is envelope in deeper mystery than ever.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 21.--In deference to the wishes of the relatives of the doomed men in the mine at Nanticoke, the officials have concluded to drill a hole from the surface to the chamber where the men are supposed to be.

LONDON, Jan. 21.--In both its physical and its political aspects the pageant of the Queen opening Parliament to-day was disappointing. There was a tremendous crowd out. George H. Young, of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, appeared at the Essex Market Police Court yesterday and took possession of Mrs. Fannie London, who is not yet 16, and who was found in a disorderly house at No. 78 Delancey-street.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 21.--Gov. Hill keeps the State Trades Assembly well under his control. It passed a resolution to-day thanking him for the interest he has shown in its behalf, and to-night, by special invitation of the Governor, the representatives of the workingmen had dinner at the Executive Mansion.

During the year just closed the attendance at the West Presbyterian Church has increased with such rapidity that the Pastor and a large proportion of the people have had no opportunity of becoming acquainted with each each other.
TROY, N.Y., Jan. 21.--When Bedford C. Vaughan, the absconding vitriol manufacturer, left Troy he was indebted to T.S. Wotkyns, a coal dealer, in the sum of $9,500 for money borrowed.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 21.--The National Society, as represented in the Fourteenth Ward of this city, is said to have recently received 2,000 Winchester repeating rifles, with which they are daily drilling, to be in readiness to join the general Socialistic uprising booked for May 1, which is to sweep over the country and reduce all classes to one financial level.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 21.--Since the first day of this month not less than 5,000 laborers, white and colored, have left this State, going South in search of better wages and more liberal and protective laws.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21.--E.F. Shelton, President of the Derby Silver Company, of Shelton, whose employes have been on a strike for nine weeks, received to-day a letter from John W. Hayes, one of the Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor, stating that a boycott would be at once declared against the company.
DAWSON, Penn., Jan. 21.--A sad skating accident resulting in the drowning of two persons occurred near here last night. A party of young folks were enjoying themselves on the ice ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 21.--The mill of Brown, Bonnet Co., at Youngstown, was the scene of a serious explosion of molten metal at noon to-day. Several holes were torn in the roof of the building, pieces of which were hurled, 400 yards away.

Robert Bowman, a New-York "crook," one of the most expert and daring swindlers in the country, is under arrest in Chicago, where he was caught masquerading under the name of J.F. Hale. Bowman's career has been a most remarkable one, and he has already served two terms in the Clinton Prison, in this State.

A sale of oil paintings was begun at George A. Leavitt Co.'s auction rooms last night, and there was included the Assignee's sale of the paintings belonging to the late firm of Paulding, Kemble Co., of which Charles J. Nourse, Jr., is Assignee.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 21.--Oscar R. Taylor, traveling salesman for Voorhies, Miller Rupel, clothiers, of Cincinnati, who arrived here on Dec. 30, has mysteriously disappeared.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 21.--The fishing schooner Georgiana, of Greenpoint, Long Island, is ashore half a mile south of Absecom Light. The crew was safely landed. The vessel will probably be a total wreck.

MONTREAL, Jan. 21.--The Customs authorities have discovered that an Englishman named Dearden, who has appeared to be an invalid and who has been a frequent traveler on the Halifax and Quebec trains, has for a number of years been engaged in smuggling English jewelry into the Dominion. Officers made a descent on his rooms in this city recently and seized $20,000 worth of goods which had not passed through the Custom House.

Alexander H. Ward, who was arrested for abandonment on Monday and then held for bigamy, was taken into Justice Walsh's court, in Brooklyn, yesterday, and confronted by his two wives, each with a baby in her arms.

The billiard exhibition at the rooms of the New-York Press Club yesterday afternoon drew an audience that filled the spacious billiard hall so full that the experts at times were scarcely able to handle their cues.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 22.--The Palmer House races were trotted this afternoon on the ice on the Hudson River, opposite Catskill. A race for double teams was won by Peter Conover's br. m. Carrie May and blk m. Lulu. Two heats were trotted and the time was 2:48 and 2:49, respectively.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22.--Ira Peck, an old resident of Southington, went into a neighbor's house yesterday, lay down on the floor, and cut his throat with a dull knife. It is his second attempt at suicide and will probably prove successful.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 22.--The will of Francis F. Parker gives to the Boston Athenseum, $5,000; to Harvard College, portraits of Prof. Farrar and his father, and the residue of his estate after leaving $125,000 to relatives and irlends, is to be divided among the Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard College, and the Boston Provident Association.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 22.--The ice in the bay continues to embarrass navigation. Little or no change is reported, and vessels experience the greatest difficulty in getting up or down.

All yesterday afternoon was spent by the Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Company in discussing plans for building one or more branch roads and issuing new securities. There was not a unanimity of sentiment in everything, and the meeting finally adjourned without accomplishing anything. They meet again at 1 P.M. to-day.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 22.--J. P. Coats, of Philadelphia, the celebrated thread manufacturers, have purchased land on the Augusta canal, on which they will build a yarn facory at an early day. They already own a small mill here. The new factory will run 10,000 spindles.

MONTREAL, Jan. 22.--The employes of the Grand Trunk Railway have been notified that a reduction of force will be made on Feb. 1. Thereafter no overtime will be allowed, and the hours of labor will be shortened.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 22.--Mine Inspectors J.E. Roderick, of the Fourth District; Hugh McDonald, of the Second District, and Patrick Blewett, of the Lackawanna district, together with a number of other inspectors, left for Nanticoke this morning.

Myers was flitting about the Chamber, acting as director of the Democratic forces.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 22.--one of the malt hoppers in Weiss's South Side Brewery became choked this afternoon and George Fisher, an employe of the brewery, entered a lower room under the huge tank to clear it out.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22.--In the Police Court to-day Kate Doughan, the "Queen of the Italians," was charged with drunkenness and carrying concealed weapons, and she was sent to jail for 120 days. The woman is a beauty and has complete control over one of the Italian colonies. She has the longest police record in the city, and has attempted to commit suicide on a dozen occasions.

Ex-Assemblyman Frank Burns, of Glens Falls, wrote to the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association yesterday: "I hope you will live to see the day Ireland will have home rule."

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Jan. 22.--The mercury here is 12 to 15 below zero and still falling. The railroads are blockaded worse than at any previous time this Winter. No trains on the Illinois Central west of here to Sioux City were moving to-day.
Timothy Desmond and his brother-inlaw, James Burns, both steam fitters, living at No. 133 Thompson-street, became engaged in a quarrel at midnight on Thursday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 22.--Henry S. Reinstein Co., cloth importers, of No. 516 Market-street, have failed. Their liabilities are $14,000 and their actual assets about $5,300. Among the principal creditors are Stein Co., of New-York, $4,300, and Miller, Schamm Co., of New-York, $3,100.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 22.--A number of Chinese have begun a suit in the United States Circuit Court against the city of Eureka for $132,000 damages, alleged to have been sustained by them from loss of property at the time of their expulsion from that place in February last.

The extent of the calamity which befell it yesterday in the explosion at the Orrell mine is not fully realized, nor will it be until the bodies of the imprisoned miners are brought to the surface.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22.--A restless dog saved two lives in Westville, a suburb of this city, this morning.

Warner. It was understood by W.B. Hornblower, counsel for Receiver Davies, of Grant Ward, that the several claimants against Warner had put in their evidence and had rested.

CHICAGO, Ill. Jan. 22.--A fearful tragedy was enected at No. 441 South Clark-street at an early hour this morning in a house of ill repute. Charles A. Clowes, Secretary of the Riverton Alcohol Works, a wealthy and handsome young married man, murdered his mistress Blanche Gray, and then shot himself, both dying almost instantly. There were no witnesses to the horrible deed.

The Long Island City police last night successfully raided a gambling house at Front and Third streets, Long Island City, and arrested its nineteen inmates. The place raided is rented by "Larry" Casey, a well-known sporting man.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 22.--Political circles here are worked up over the action of the President in the case of ex-Gov. Crittenden. Senators Vest and Cockrell, before they left here, promised friends of Crittenden to secure the appointment of the latter to a foreign mission, and the two Senators called on the President and asked him to grant them that favor.

CLIFFORD, Mich., Jan. 22.--John R. Moore, a wealthy farmer, whose home is near here, during a temporary fit of insanity yesterday, removed the cover from a large wood stove and jumped head first in on the hot fire. Although he was dragged out almost immediately he was terribly burned about the head and upper portion of his body, and recovery is doubtful.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 25.--A daring and desperate escape from jail occurred at Seguin last Friday evening, in which eight prisoners regained their liberty. Five were subsequently recaptured. The three still at large are Willis Jackson, a negro, who was held for murder; a white man charged with complicity in a railway station safe robbery, and an unknown man. Officers are in pursuit of the fugitives.

NEWMARKET, Ontario, Jan. 25.--A collision occurred between a passenger train and an engine on the Northern Railway near here this afternoon. Both engines were wrecked and one fireman was killed. The other fireman and one of the engineers were badly injured. Several passengers were slightly injured.

NASHUA, N.H., Jan. 25.--Herbert Nichols, a brakeman on the Nashua and Worcester Railroad, was arrested at his boarding place in Worcester last evening on a charge of robbing a train of a six-hundred-dollar package on Friday evening, and was bound over in the Police Court this morning in the sum of $10,000. QUEBEC, Jan. 25.--The steamer Brooklyn, ashore at Anticosti, has broken up. Only a small piece of her stern is now visible above the water.
