NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 25.--The steamship City of Dallas, Capt. Read, from Puerto Cortez, via Livingston and Belize, Honduras, with a cargo of tropical products, arrived this noon.

The florid face and snow-white locks and portly form of the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher attracted attention to the middle stage box on the right-hand side in the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon between the hours of 1 o'clock and 5.
An English melodrama called "The Hoop of Gold" was put on the stage for a week's run in the Third-Avenue Theatre last night.

The second-class traveler on English railways is gradually being improved out of existence, or, to put it more accurately, third-class traveling has been made so exceedingly comfortable, snug, and expeditious that it is rapidly monopolizing all the business.

There was not a vacant chair in the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association, which has a seating capacity of 1,250, when President Hoppin rose to open the thirty-third anniversary meeting last evening.

The stick of oak from which the keel for probably the fastest yacht ever built in this country is to be made was towed to Lawley Son's yard, South Boston, Friday last, and next week workmen will begin hewing it into shape.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25.--Two young men, whose names are not written down in any accessible records, drifted into Jeff Hankin's gambling rooms at No. 125 South Clarkstreet yesterday morning.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 25.--The office of W.L. Foulk's Son Co.'s advertising agency on Fifth-avenue is in a state of siege. Col. Foulk is a retired army officer.

Dr. William A. Hammond discussed "Hydrophobia and Its Prevention" at a fully attended meeting of the Clinical Society of the New-York Postgraduate Medical School, at No. 226 East Twentieth-street, last evening.
"Well, Mr. Williams," said THE TIMES'S reporter to the Mets' Secretary yesterday, "did James Roseman sign a contract with you today?"

After supper last night John Starhn went to a bureau in his rooms in the rear of No. 84 Elizabeth-street to get some money for a friend. He had $120 in the drawer, the savings of a year by his wife and himself.
Capt. Paul Boyton's "Ship," on Twentyninth-street, was completely dismantled yesterday. Everything went, and at good prices, too, from the buffet and relics within to the flags and binnacle without.

QUEBEC, Jan. 25.--Alfred Ross, an Italian, has been arrested here on a charge of counterfeiting fifty-cent pieces. A die and a large quantity of counterfeit coins were found in the prisoner's lodging.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25.--The annual election for Directors of the Corn and Flour Exchange took place to-day, and the following were elected: Edson M. Schryver, Henry A. Parr, Robert S. Fowler, George T. Kenty, Samuel E. George, Hirman G. Dudley, George W. Titlow, Charles D. Reid, Joseph R. Foard, Edwin Reese, A. Henry Nelker, Edward C. Heald, Alexander J. Godby, George Frame, John H. Girvin.

William Livingstone, searcher of water grants in the Department of Docks since 1876, has been allowed to resign under something of a cloud. The documents in regard to the case, as they appear in the department files, consist of four papers.

LONDON, Jan. 25.--The Greek Government, in reply to the note of the Marquis of Salisbury, says that the representations of England infringe on international and diplomatic observance, and declares that Greece reserves perfect freedom of action.

HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 25.--Cadby Son, piano and music dealers, of this city, are financially embarrassed. Their store has been closed by the Sheriff. Their liabilities are understood to be large, and their assets small. The firm has branch stores at Kingston, Newburg, and other places on the river, and has done an extensive business.
President Simmons, of the Stock Exchange, bought a new overcoat a week or two ago. The cloth was costly, the fit was perfect; the wearer was the envy of every man on the floors of the Stock Exchange.

KEOKUK, Iowa, Jan. 25.--To-day Judge Love, of the United States Circuit Court, remanded the saloon case of Hall and others against Muggenstrum and others from Des Moines County back to the State courts.
Mr. and Mrs. John T. Farish, of No. 70 Park-avenue, gave a dinner last night in honor of their nephew, Mr. Robert Greer Munroe.
We learn from a consular report dealing with Sicily in the year 1884 that coral fishing was completely forbidden on the Sicilian coast on account of the outbreak of cholera in September of last year.

BOSTON, Jan. 25.--The condition of Mr. Lawrence Barrett was reported this evening as being somewhat improved, and the indications are favorable for his appearance at the Globe Theatre on Wednesday evening.
BUFFALO, Jan. 25.--A motion was made in the Supreme Court to-day for the removal of the Receiver of the Tonawanda Valley and Cuba Railroad Company.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 25.--Five years ago Rumsey, Johnson Co., engaged in mercantile and lumbering operations here, failed, with liabilities of $80,000 and assets of $60,000.
One by one the surface roads of the city are accepting the principle that 12 hours constitute a good day's work for the conductors and drivers in their employ.

Mr. Mortimer Hendricks, a well known Hebrew, who lives at Long Branch and does business as a broker at No. 51 Exchange-place, appeared at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to answer a summons for assault obtained by his son, Elmer Hendricks, a young man of 20, cashier for his uncle, Mr. Monteflore Isaacs, a broker at No. 42 Broad-street.
METROPOLITAN OPERA HOUSE. The performance of "Faust," first of fered at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday of last week, was repeated there last evening in presence of a crowded auditorium.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--Capt. Michael Cooney, Ninth Cavalry, now on leave of absence at Leavenworth, Kan., has been ordered to Nashville, Tenn., to take charge of a recruiting rendezvous.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 25.--Yesterday afternoon Officer A.M. Harrington, in arresting William Mullone, who was intoxicated, kicked him about the body, and afterward had him locked up in a cell, where he was found dead this morning. The Coroner's jury returned a verdict of death from ill treatment by Harrington.

MORSSTON, N.Y., Jan. 25.--Not less than 120 foxes have been killed in this portion of Sullivan County during the past three weeks. No one remembers when foxes were so numerous in this region as they have been for a month or so.

It was a noose of purely circumstantial evidence that Prosecuting Attorney Fitzgerald drew closer and closer around the Kohout brothers, charged with arson and homicide, before Recorder Smyth yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25.--The American Iron and Steel Association has received from the manufacturers full and detailed statistics of the production of pig iron in the United States in 1885, with statistics of the stocks of unsold pig iron at the close of the year.
BERLIN, Jan. 25.--The German-Americans on the Island of Foehr, whose expulsion from Germany was recently ordered, have petitioned the Government to allow them to remain until April 1.

John Roach, the ship builder, was one of the most conspicuous figures at the meeting of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association at the Hoffman House last evening. He contributed $100 to the fund as "an old and veteran skilled mechanic."
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 25.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20 to 17 cents; telegraphic 25 to 22 cents.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 25.--The question of religious services in the public schools is causing trouble in Chartiers Borough, and may result in legal proceedings.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 25.--Leroy Adams, counsel for Herman, the condemned Buffalo wife murderer, this afternoon asked Gov. Hill to commute the condemned man's sentence to imprisonment for life.
The performance of "Lohengrin" by the American Opera Company at the Academy of Music last eveing was attended by an audince of fair size and no great tendency to de monstrativeness.
The bill originally known as the Edmunds bill, of which Senator HOAR now has charge, is again before the Senate, and has encountered criticism and opposition from an unexpected source.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 25.--The Wabash shops at this place have again been shut down in pursuance of an order promulgated by the Receivers for the purpose, it is alleged, of enabling ...

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 25.--In the examination to-day of N.V. Jones and Frank Treseder, charged with bribing Deputy Marshal Franks to notify Mormons of process against them, the facts as heretofore given were substantiated, and, further, that Treseder told Franks that he had the whole Mormon Church at his back, and could control all the money needed.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25.--In the course of the hearing to-day on one of the wills of the late Wilbur F. Storey, A.S. Trude, Mr. Storey's lawyer, was examined.

Eleven houses standing empty and "to be let" in Portland-place! Surely this is a portent, indeed, for, after all, in these days of "avenues" and "gardens," flats of all orders and "mansions" of no order at all, there is ever an odor of simplicity and grandeur about Portlandplace.
William Cunningham was arrested in Chicago about six months ago on a charge of shooting a man during the street car riots.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 25.--Baltimore gave to-night at its magnificent Academy of Music a charity ball, which proved the greatest social event in this city for many a long year.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Jan. 25.--The snowslides on the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company's line, between the Dalles and Multnomah Falls, were much heavier than was at first supposed, as earth, trees, and rocks were brought down with the snow. Plows cannot beat through the obstruction, and it must be removed with picks and shovels. It is probable that the track will not be cleared for three days.
The lively musical farce called "A Bunch of Keys" was presented before a hilarious assemblage at the Theatre Comique in Harlem last night.

The statistics of the number of suicides which have taken place in the Department of the Seine during 1885 show that a very large percentage of the inhabitants of the ville lumiere find life an insupportable burden.

LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 25.--Pleuro-pneumonia, which was stamped out in York County by a wholesale slaughter of the affected cattle, has made its appearance again in that region, and the work is all to be done over again.
AT 1 o'clock yesterday morning the flagman's box on the Harlem Railroad at One Hundred and Thirty-seventh-street and Fourthavenue was discovered to be on fire.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 26.--Gen. Lew Wallace publishes a card to-day saying that many telegrams published in the Commercial Gazette's Washington correspondence are new to him and tend to relieve Gen. Halleck from ...

The best temperance drink is milk. This, the Americans have discovered, and they consume it largely at their meals. Here, this would be regarded as "odd." I was at a hotel the other day and drank milk with my dinner; the waiters and the guests stared at me as though I were a calf. Those who find milk indigestible should put a little lime water in it.

LONDON, Jan. 26.--A violent anonymous pamphlet has been published at Zurich in relation to the Duke of Edinburgh and the throne of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha. It inveighs against the Duke's succession to the throne and says: "We must at least be ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 26.--A petition signed by the most prominent American residents of Apia, Samoa, under date of Dec. 9, 1885, has been forwarded to Secretary of State Bayard, at Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--The executive communication which the Senate yesterday sent to Attorney-General Garland, calling for an account of the administration of the office of the District Attorney for the Southern District of Alabama at the time George M. Duskin was suspended and John D. Burnett appointed to his place, was to-day laid before the Cabinet by Mr. Garland, who regarded it as a communication to the President, although addressed to one ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--The Supreme Court of the United states transacted the following business to-day:

A woman at No. 154 First-avenue saw an unusual glare through the windows of the third floor of old Primary School No. 22, Nos. 143 to 152 First-avenue last night, and informed the janitor, Albert Kunne, who, with his family, was in the lower part of the building.

It is not every college alumni association that can bunch five Bishops at its annual dinner, but this was precisely the number that lifted their glasses to the toast of "Old Trinity" at the feast of the New-York Alumni Association of Trinity College, Hartford, last night. Within hand-shaking distance were Assistant Bishop Henry C. Potter, of New-York; Bishops Niles, of New-Hampshire; Paddock, of Massachusetts; ...

There was a large gathering of Grand Army of the Republic men last evening at the Hotel Brunswick to witness the installation of officers of George Washington Post, No. 103, G.A.R. The large ballroom of the Brunswick was brilliant with uniforms after the ceremonies had been completed. Gilmore's Band discoursed martial airs from the balcony.
Mr. Sam Franko gives a concert at Steinway Hall this evening. Mozart's "Magic Flute" will be brought out to-night at the Academy of Music.

NORWICH, Conn., Jan. 26.--Samuel Bingham, Cashier of the Windham National Bank at Willimantic, Conn., was brought before United States Commissioner Tenney, of this city, by United States District Attorney Stanton to-day charged with taking heavy commissions on paper bought of James D. Fish, late President of the Marine Bank of New-York.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 26.--The principal producers of and dealers in California wines yesterday decided to advance the prices of sweet wines 20 per cent. and of dry wines in proportion. This action was taken in consequence of the shortness of the crop and the increased cost of production.

GRIFFIN, Ga., Jan. 26.--About a month ago George Daniel, accompanied by a woman, passing as his wife, went to Mr. Bob Freeman's, three miles above town, and rented a house. Nothing occurred to ripple the even tenor of their ways until last Saturday, when another ...
ST. Louis, Mo., Jan. 26.--The Supreme Court of the State of Missouri to-day rendered a decision which prohibits the Circuit Court from trying the contested city election cases.
More than 100 free traders met last night at the Clarendon' Hotel, Brooklyn, at the annual dinner of the Revenue Reform Club, of that city.

WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 26.--The divorce case of Willard Perkins against Mary E. Perkins was decided by Judge Andrews in the Superior Court to-day in favor of the plaintiff, on the grounds of intolerable cruelty. Perkins weighs nearly 300 pounds.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Jan. 26.--The City Government to-night adopted a resolution declaring that "we urgently remonstrate against the appointment of any international convention to consider the matter, or any diplomatic ...

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 26.--Andrew William Smith died at his residence in Ballston yesterday, at the age of 75, of physical debility. Besides his widow the deceased leaves four sons. Before the war Mr. Smith and his brother Samuel composed the banking firm of S. A.W. Smith, doing business in--New-Orleans, La., but with the ...
The international billiard match between Maurice Vignaux, of Paris, and Jacob Schaefer, of this city, began last evening in the Cosmopolitan Rink, at Broadway and Fortyfirst-street.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 26.--I. Lighthall, the quack doctor and patent medicine vendor, who was stricken with smallpox Friday evening, and with a number of others was quarantined by the authorities, died last night.
Mr. Thomas C. Platt, President of the Board of Commissioners of Quarantine, says, in a letter to the Tribune:

The scientific gentleman who fathered the importation of English sparrows to this country for the purpose of turning them loose on the canker worms which infested the trees and thence dropped casually down the citizen's back lived long enough to regret his miserable ignorance.

The hall of the Young Men's Christian Association was crowded to the doors last night with an assemblage composed of representative New-York citizens, gathered to celebrate the twelfth anniversary of the New-York Society for the Suppression of Vice.

OTTAWA, Jan. 26.--It is stated that owing to the unsatisfactory state of the public finances, the Canadian Government have decided to introduce a measure at the coming session of Parliament canceling all subsidies granted in aid of railways which have not thus far been availed of or where the conditions of such grants have not been complied with by any chartered railway companies.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 26.--Detective Nelson, of Indianapolis, captured last night a fugitive merchant named Brown, from Terre Haute, Ind., and left with him this morning for Indiana. Last year Brown was a member of a firm in Terra Haute. About Christmas his partner left Terre Haute to go to Chicago to buy goods.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 26.--The Board of Revenue Commissioners to-day issued a circular giving a list of articles taxable under the tax law passed last Winter, measures to contest which have been taken in various counties.

DURANGO, Col., Jan. 26.--Another snow slide tragedy is reported from the extreme southwestern part of the State. Leonard Sutton, who has been at work in the Silver Lake basin in the La Plata Mountains, reached Durango last night with the account of a slide which wrecked the cabin at the Daylight mine on Tuesday last.

When Herman Lange, who keeps a small cabinet workshop at No. 155 Avenue C, returned from his lunch yesterday, he was surprised to find the door locked. He knocked loudly, but there was no response, and he broke open the door.

DEPOSIT, N.Y., Jan. 26.--A terrible boiler explosion, by which two persons were killed and one fatally injured, occurred on the farm of Palmer Newton, in Sherburne, this county, on Saturday. Mr. Newton was absent in the West with one of his sons, and Russell Palmer, a prominent farmer of the town, was superintending ...
STOCKTON, Cal., Jan. 26.--The San Joaquin River has been gradually rising for the past week. On Sunday a portion of this city, comprising about one-fifth of its area, was covered with water.

The extreme unwillingness of the Bell Telephone Company to have its rights put to the test in the suit proposed by the United States Government naturally suggests the suspicion that it feels the weakness of its case as it would be tried in such a suit.

Lawson N. Fuller told between 300 and 400 persons, in the public hall of the Masonic Temple last night, what he knew "about the Broadway Street railroad steal." He said that he took an active part 35 years ago in agitating the question of a street railroad in Broadway.
MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Jan. 26.--A shocking accident happened at Congressman Scott's mines at Green Ridge this morning. A young man named McCaulis started out to make an inspection of the machinery.

Mrs. Minnie J. Cole was arraigned before Judge Gildersleeve yesterday charged with bigamy. In May, 1882, she was married to Arthur E. Cole, of No. 511 West Sixty-first-street. She lived with him for a short time, when the couple separated.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--Mrs. Charles Burke, a slender woman, who would be pretty were her face not covered with bruises, told Justice Meech to-day what kind of a man her husband, a bartender, is. Burke, she said, was paid good wages, but refused to give her even enough to eat. He, himself, patronized a restaurant, and often did not come home for days. Last Saturday night he returned drunk, and when she ...
The Amateur Baseball League is the name of a new organization formed from some of the most prominent athletic and baseball clubs in this city and Brooklyn at a meeting on Monday night.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 26.--Miss Lillie Todd was found dead at her home in New-Castle yesterday. She was 105 years old and lived alone in a small house adjoining the Knights of Pythias Hall.

Catherine Collyer, in the Circuit Court, in Jersey City, yesterday got a verdict of $1,200 against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. Mrs. Collyer's husband, while in the employ of the company as a night watchman, was severely injured by an iron door falling on him.
Nobody will dispute the good faith of Senator COMSTOCK in respect to investigating the charge that the franchise for the Broadway Railroad was obtained by bribery.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26.--John Muller was arrested here to-day by Post Office Inspector Barrett upon the charge of fraudulently obtaining a registered letter. Muller had lived in Livingston-street, Brooklyn, and on Nov. 23 last he received a registered letter postmarked Bremerhaven, containing $170 from Henry Muller.

Berlin is going to strike out in a new direction in the field of public exhibitions. Various capitalists intend to do for the human family what zoological gardens do for the animal kingdom in general.

The Lexington Flats are several apartment houses on the northwest corner of Thirdavenue and Forty-ninth-street, and in what is known as the "second house" live four families, among them those of Mrs. E. Merry on the second floor and Mr. Thomas Godwin, assistant auditor at the Grand Central Station, on the fourth floor.

The General Passenger Agents and Controllers of the trunk lines met yesterday and discussed the present situation of affairs especially concerning the emigrant pool agency and the methods of accounting to be pursued in the proposed emigrant clearing house.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26.--The Receivers of the Reading Railroad Company have decided to remit $5,000 per day out of the earnings of the Jersey Central Railroad to the general officers of that company in New-York.

The trial of Freeholders Thomas McGowan, Edward L. Conklin, D.H. Boughner, Philip Kuhn, and Dr. D.M. Dill, the Lunatic Asylum Committee of the Essex County Board of Freeholders, and of Dr. L.D. Hinkley, Superintendent, and Edward J. Heustis, steward, of the asylum, on a charge of nonfeasance in office, was begun before Judge Depue, in the Essex County Court of Oyer, at Newark, yesterday morning.
Mary Lipnow, a 4-year-old girl, fell from the fire escape on the fourth floor of No. 4 Albany-street yesterday, and was killed.

BOSTON, Jan. 26.--The annual meeting and dinner of the Yale Alumni Association of Boston and vicinity occurred at the Parker House this evening. The announcement that Dr. Porter and Chauncey M. Depew, President of the New-York Association of Yale Alumni, would probably be present served as an incentive to make the members respond in force.

The first annual report of Commissioner Squire, of the Department of Public Works, was sent to Mayor Grace yesterday. The expenditures during the year amounted to $3,791,288 10, or less by $852,258 19 than the expenditures for 1884, and less by $933,855 80 than the expenditures for 1883.

Lippman Ahrensberg was tried before Judge Moore, in the Sessions Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday, for selling oleomargarine for butter. It is a test case, and is to be carried to the Court of Appeals. Ahrensberg was defended by F.R. Coudert, Wheeler H. Peckham, and John M. Lewis.

TRENTON, Jan. 26.--An interesting wedding took place at half-past 5 o'clock this afternoon at the residence of Mrs. Samuel D. Southard, No. 137 East Hanover-street. The contracting parties were Miss Mary E. Southard, her daughter, and Frank S. Voorhies, of New-York.
The Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association celebrated its thirty-second anniversary last evening in Association Hall, on Fulton-street. President Packard read the annual report.

NYACK, Jan. 26.--The Board of Underderwriters of Rockland County have resolved to enter upon a new order of things in the county, and on Monday next a regular schedule of tariff rates will again go in force, being the first time in many years.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 26.--Two small trunks full of watches, brooches, rings, and silverware, belonging to an English smuggler named Deardon, were seized at a hotel here to-day by the customs authorities. A similar lot of valuables brought here on board the Sarmatian were also seized. All the goods are of fine quality.

CHARLESTON, Jan. 26.--When Jay Gould recently hurried down here by rail to go on board his yacht for a Winter's sail through Southern waters he brought, besides his family and his doctor, another guest, a man of retiring manner, who was never seen with the excursionists, but who was, for all that, in Mr. Gould's estimation, an important member of the traveling party.

Wylie H. Tinsel, who represented himself as a collector for the Grant Monument Association, and was arrested at Williamsport, Penn., on Monday on a suspicion that his representations were fraudulent, was not authorized by the association to collect money for it, and its officers have no knowledge of him.

Alderman De Lacy, at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen, introduced a resolution calling attention to the inadequate faci1ities for travel to and from the New-York entrance to Brooklyn Bridge.

There was a very large attendance yesterday at the hearing before the Commissioners for the appraisement of lands taken for parks and parkways in the annexed district. Franklin Bartlett appeared as counsel for the city.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 26.--Correspondents of the Freeman at a number of points in Ulster and Greene Counties write to-day that they felt a slight earthquake shock in their respective localities last Sunday evening and again early Monday morning.

Elliott J. Arthur, a lawyer of this city, and formerly a Lieutenant in the United States Navy, died yesterday at Burlington, Vt. Lieut. Arthur was born at Burlington in 1850. He entered the Naval Academy in 1865 and was graduated in 1869.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--The subcommittees of the Senate and House Committees on Commerce were addressed to-day by representatives of those interested in the construction of a railroad bridge across the Arthur Kill from the New-Jersey shore to that of Staten Island. The opponents of the plans of the Baltimore and Ohio Company were first heard.

MONTREAL, Jan. 26.--A train on the Canada and Atlantic Railway was thrown off the track near Coteau Station to-day by the spreading of the rails. The train ran 150 yards on the ties, cutting them in two and throwing the rails out of place. The tender was completely wrecked. Some of the passengers were slightly injured.
The latest move of the Republican Senators in their one-sided contest over removals from office does not strengthen their case.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan, 26.--About a year ago a married man named Butler, a member of a well known family residing at Pendleton, a small village 20 miles from here, died and was buried. Last week when the family visited the grave they found it open and the body gone. The robbery bad been committed during the week previous. No trace of the thieves has been discovered.
ALBANY, Jan. 26.--The 13 Republican Senators held another caucus this afternoon to arrange for the joint caucus to be held to-morrow night. Senator Sloan was selected to preside to-morrow night.
MADRID, Jan.26.--A party of rebels made an attempt to-day to destroy the railroad crossing the mountains in the Province of Jaen. They were dispersed by troops.
The Society of Amateur Photographers sat in its rooms, No. 1,260 Broadway, last night and was photographed by magnesium light. After a short exposure the cap was placed over the lens by D.C. Hooker.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--Jacob Barth, the teamster employed by Maxwell Brothers, who was shot yesterday morning in an affray with strikers, died to-day at the County Hospital. His death was quite unexpected, as reports from the hospital received early this morning were to the effect that he was in no immediate danger of death, but he suddenly grew worse and expired.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 26.--There is a decidedly panicky feeling prevailing to-night, and many strangers throng the hotels and places of public resort.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 26.--A fire at 11 o'clock to-night did about $15,000 damage to the buildings Nos. 8 and 10 Chartres and No. 87 Canal street, New-Orleans. The sufferers were T.E. Larne, tea and coffee, No. 8 Chartres; S.F. Ohlsen, Davis sewing machine agency, No. 10 Chartres, and S.T. Blessing, pictures and frames, No. 87 Canal street. The buildings belonged to Leon Godchaux and were insured, mostly in local companies.

The gilded veil of tradition which has hung over the face of Mexico for many years was temporarily blown aside in the hall of the Long Island Historical Society, in Brooklyn, last evening by David A. Wells, who has recently returned from a tour through the Southern republic with the idea that Mexico is one of the poorest and most wretched countries on the face of the globe.

TRENTON, Jan. 26.--It was expected that the resolution against the construction of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad bridge across Staten Island Sound would be reported to-day, and a large lobby was in attendance upon the House.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 26.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20 to 17 . Drafts on NewYork, telegraphic, 25 to 22 .

ALBANY, Jan. 26.--The Trustees of Union College were in secret session here for three hours this afternoon, and adjourned without electing a President of the institution. The condition of the college, its prospects, and the fitness of several candidates named for the Presi-- dency were fully discussed.

The International Union has set aside $10,325 this week for the support of cigarmakers locked out and on strike. The workpeople in eight shops received their strike benefit yesterday at No. 94 Ludlow-street, and the remainder will be paid to-day. The Progressives have appropriated $800 to the tenement house workers and packers for the present week.

Judge Barrett yesterday afternoon denied the motion of Gen. Shaler's counsel to direct the Oyer and Terminer jury to bring in a verdict of acquittal of the crime of accepting a bribe, with which he stands charged, before any evidence for the defense is put in.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 26.--James B. Weaver, owner of the Shrewsbury ice yacht Scud, arrived to-night from Red Bank with T. S. Hubbard, J.C. Doughty, and R.D. Chandler. Capt. Weaver says his boat will be here in the ...

KINGSTON, Ontario, Jan. 26.--Harry Horsey to-day was found guilty of setting fire to the premises of Robertson Brothers on Friday night, and was sentenced to imprisonment for 14 years in the penitentiary. The Judge lectured the prisoner sharply and said he intended the sentence to be severe.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 26.--Fred L. Fullam, the lumber merchant, who mysteriously disappeared from this city two months ago, has returned to his father's, at North Brookfield. He gives no reason for his singular conduct except financial difficulties. He has been in California, and during his absence of eight weeks has had not had a change of clothing.

Mr. Michael Banner, the violin virtuoso whose performances have often claimed cordial commendation in this place, not merely as the wonderful efforts of a very youthful artist, but as the ripe and solid achievements of a gifted and skilled player, gave a concert at Steinway Hall yesterday evening.
ALBANY, Jan. 26.--A bill was introduced in the Assembly by Mr. McClelland, of Yonkers, to-day, which certainly suggests the idea that the cable railroad people have begun legislative operations.

BUFFALO, Jan. 26.--Cornelius Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew, J.H. Harden, and J.M. Toucey, of the New-York Central; Dr. Seward Webb, of the New-York Central Sleeping Car Company, and General Manager Layng, of the West Shore, arrived here this morning.

All the memorials and bills relating to the establishment of a free public library in this city will be presented to the Legislature to-day. Adolph L. Sanger, who started the project, yesterday obtained the signatures of Mayor Grace, Corporation Counsel Lacombe, and the members of the special Aldermanic committee having the matter in charge, and left here for Albany last night to submit the matter to the Senate and Assembly.

In obedience to a summons issued on Sunday by Justice Duffy, Dr. Charles H. Nichols, the Medical Superintendent of the Bloomingdale Lunatic Asylum, yesterday appeared at the Jefferson Market Police Court to answer a complaint made by Col. Albert H. Rogers that the doctors had illegally detained at the asylum property belonging to him.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 26.--The Rev. Charles J. Baldwin, for the past 12 years Pastor of the First Baptist Church here, resigned to-day. Mr. Baldwin is well known throughout the State as a very eloquent and successful preacher, and his resignation was entirely unexpected.

MUSCATINE, Iowa, Jan. 26.--A passenger train for Chicago on the Rock Island Road left here at 6:30 o'clock this morning, and about 25 minutes later a construction train pulled out, going in the same direction.

The mystery surrounding the sick man at Staten Island knows as "Sig. No. 17, S.E.," has been in a measure solved. Last night a Frenchman was found who said, after hearing a description of the man: "Yes, I know him.

There was lately presented to Mrs. Grant and also to the Grant Monument Association a bronze memorial of Gen. Grant, of a unique design, by J.M. Kershaw, of St. Louis. It is 13 inches long, 10 inches wide, and 2 inches deep. The sides and ends slope outward.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 26.--The fivestory brick building Nos. 715, 717 and 719 Archstreet, was discovered to be on fire at 12:35 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26, 1886. Assistant Secretary Fairchild has instructed the Collector of Customs at New-York to admit free of duty a portrait of the late Gen. Grant painted in Paris by Mr. Healy, an American artist, and imported by Mrs. U.S. Grant.

In a lecture before the Farmers' Club, in Clinton Hall, yesterday afternoon, Kanute Forsbere, a German park engineer of 42 years' experience, said that the Park Commissioners of this city had a great deal to learn concerning the proper care and drainage of parks.

BOSTON, Jan. 26.--The Williams College Alumni Association of Boston held its annual dinner at the Parker House this evening. R. G. Fitch, of the Boston Post, presided. Prof. R.M. Rice, for the Faculty, made a plea for the further extension of the elective work, and said that new library facilities were needed; that the ...

A mortgage for $3,000,000 has been filed in Salem, Mass., and it is the largest mortgage ever filed in that city. It was given by the Commercial Cable Company to Dr. Ernst Werner Siemens, of No. 94 Markgrafen-strasse, Berlin, and Johann Carl Ludwig Loeffler, of No. 12 ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 26.--At 10 o'clock this morning, before Justice Williams, was commenced the trial of the action brought by creditors against Alfred and J. Forman Wilkinson, the bankers, who made an assignment on Dec. 10, 1884.

Rumors were current in Newark yesterday that Mayor Haynes contemplated a strategic move to gain possession and control of the Police Department. The trouble is over the non-partisan Fire and Police Commission act.

TRENTON, Jan. 26.--The annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Historical Society was held here to-day. The following officers were elected: President--Samuel M. Hamill, Lawrenceville; Vice-Presidents--Judge John T. Nixon, Trenton; John Clement, Haddonfield, and ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--Mr. L.R. Erskine, a member of the Board of Trade, lives at Austin, a suburban village on the line of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad. Last night he could find no seat in the train, and refused to give up his ticket until furnished with a place to sit down.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 26.--A party of local capitalists have been quietly boring for natural gas at the foot of Lookout Mountain. To-night, at a depth of 340 feet, they struck gas in such quantities that work was necessarily suspended. The gas is thought to be plentiful in this coal region, but this is the first ever discovered.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 26.--At a meeting of the Merchants' Exchange to-day Mr. S.F. Sherman offered the following resolution, which will be considered on Thursday:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26.--One of the most fashionable weddings that New-Haven has ever seen took place this afternoon, when Miss Emelie Eliza Trowbridge, daughter of the Hon. Thomas R. Trowbridge, was married to George Bliss Ropers, of Boston, at the home of the bride's parents, on Elm-street.
The jurymen called upon to determine the guilt or innocence of the Kohout brothers are in a quandary over the Bohemian testimony that reaches them though the interpreters.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 26.--A local paper publishes this morning the following article: "There has been a good deal of suppressed excitement among men in Chicago during the past few days over reports received from the agent of a syndicate of Americans searching for gold in Honduras.

The railroad members of the Board of Aldermen looked aghast yesterday when Alderman Van Rensselaer introduced a resolution which proposed to regulate the giving of consent by the Common Council to the construction of street surface railroads in this city.

ALBANY, N.Y , Jan. 26.--This evening the Fort Orange Club gave their annual reception to the Legislature and State officers. Among the guests were Gov. Hill, Lieut.-Gov. Jones, other State officers, members of the Legislature, and prominent citizens from this and other States. The decorations and menu were elaborate, and the festivities were continued to a late hour.
ATHENS, Jan. 26.--A Cabinet council, with the King presiding, was held to-day to discuss the political situation. New regiments are being rapidly formed for active service.
Whenever "A Friend of the Cause" sends a word of cheer to the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association he accompanies it with something tangible in order to prove that he has a right to the appellation.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 26.--Advance sheets of the Massachusetts Railroad Commissioners' annual report contain a charge against the veracity of ex-Senator Barnum, President of the Housatonic Railroad Company. By way of retaliation, says the commission, "the railroad company compelled the Lee merchants to pay for freight on delivery.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 26.--A Sergeant, two detectives, and two members of the police force returned to the city at 3 o'clock this morning, having in custody Bill Brown and Bob McLin, colored, who are charged with murder.

Argument was heard by Judge Van Brunt, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, in cases affecting the sale of liquors at balls in the Academy of Music and the Metropolitan Opera House. Albert S. Leroy, who keeps a cafe at No. 1,425 Broadway, in the Metropolitan Opera House Building, recently procured an injunction restraining the Excise Board and the police from interfering with him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--Second Lieut. E.E. Benjamin, First Infantry, has been transferred from Company H to Company L of that regiment, and will join the latter company at once. Acting Assistant Surgeon Robert Finlay has been granted one month's leave of absence, with permission to apply for one month's extension without pay. The leave of absence to Second Lieut. John H. Beacom, Third Infantry, has been extended two months.

In the upper end of Central Park, standing on a commanding elevation, is the new Mount St. Vincent Hotel, a resort that has become one of the attractive features of the main drive through the Park. Scores of merry sleighing parties have enjoyed the warmth and good cheer that prevail within its hospitable walls during the past few days.

The Court of Appeals yesterday made decisions in two of the suits which are well known in all the courts and to lawyers as the Abendroth cases. These actions have been pending in the courts with varied fortunes for 12 years.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 26.--The high license liquor law of Nebraska, which has been declared constitutional in the State Supreme Court, is to be tested further as to its constitutionality in the United States Supreme Court by a St. Louis liquor firm, who two years ago sold a large bill of goods to D.L. McGucken, of this city.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--The Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul and the Rock Island Railroads locked horns to-day over the question of the St. Paul business in a meeting of the Missouri River Association, and succeeded in preventing, for the time being at least, a renewal of the life of the association.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 26.--The recent murder of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse C. Wickersham, near Cloverdale, Sonoma County, by their Chinese cook, has again thoroughly aroused the anti-Chinese sentiment throughout the Pacific coast.
Alarming stories of John Kelly's condition continue to be circulated. He is no better and no worse than he has been for some time. He has had no relapse, and it is not expected that he will have one.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 26.--Frederick M. Ott, a prominent and popular young lawyer of this city, was accidentally shot in the right side of the abdomen to-day by a constable from Lebanon County named Fred Fink, who was a witness in a case in which Mr. Ott was concerned as an attorney.

The second Patriarchs' ball of this season was given last evening in the assembly rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House. The floral decorations, by Klunder, were confined almost entirely to the supper room, which adjoins the ballroom on the west. The supper was served by Pinard. The cotillion, which embraced about 100 couples, was led by J. Ridgeway Moore.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26.--A special meeting of the Clay Telephone stockholders was held at No. 1,017 Chestnut-street this afternoon. President John C. Scott recited the circumstances under which Secretary Lamar had been led to investigate the charges against the alleged inventor.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 26.--While the the south-bound mail train on the Illinois Central Railroad was crossing the trestle work over the Tallahatchie River last night the engine struck an obstruction, evidently placed there by miscreants, and was thrown from the bridge, ...
ALBANY, N.Y., 26.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following decisions were handed down:
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 26.--The Post Dispatch to-day publishes interviews giving the opinions of over 200 leading employers and manufacturers relative to the eight-hour system.

GALVESTON, Jan. 26.--Among the passengers on the steamship Harlan, from Vera Cruz, to-day, was Capt. J. Lawrence, of the British bark Silica. He brings information that his vessel was lost on the Mexican coast, 55 miles east of Manatitlan, on the 14th of last December.

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 26.--The case of the Rev. G.R. Bristor came before the Grand Jury of Rockland County this morning and occupied all day. A vote was taken this evening, and it is reported that an indictment was found against the Pastor, which will be officially announced to the court to-morrow morning.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 26.--When Representative James P. Pigott, of New-Haven, famous as the man who made things generally uncomfortable for the last Assembly by talking about its weaknesses for railroad passes, came to Hartford to-day and walked up the hill to the Capitol, he carried a bill which he hopes will make a big change in the way his city is governed.

MONTREAL, Jan. 26.--Mr. Deardon, the Englishman whose jewelry was seized recently, has deposited $20,000 with the Collector of Customs, being the full value of the goods, pending the decision of the authorities at Ottawa.

Somewhat to the surprise and apparently to the disappointment of as many men as could crowd into the Council Chamber at Rahway, N.J., last night there was no blood spilled by the municipal legislators, nor did the latter proceed to greater extremities than to question each other's veracity in rather pointed fashion.

HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 26.--The embarrassed firm of Cadby Son has made an assignment to W. Frank Holsapple for the benefit of creditors. Among the preferred claims are salaries due employes, the Farmers' National Bank, of this city, for paper discounted, and Napoleon J. Haines, of New-York. The liabilities are contingently large, but the amount cannot be learned until an examination shall have been made.

MONTREAL, Jan. 26.--Four additional officers attached to the Customs Department here have been suspended by an order from Ottawa for conniving with the arm of Bresseau Lisabelle, the absconding brokers, in huge swindles on the revenue.

Miss Sadie J. Young, a daughter of Mrs. Charles L. Young, was married last evening at the residence of her mother, No. 33 West Thirtyeighth-street, to Mr. O.D. Baldwin, the President of the Fourth National Bank.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26.--The statement of the business of all lines of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company east of Pittsburg and Erie for December, 1885, as compared with the same month of 1884, shows: An increase in gross earnings of $277,354, an increase in expenses of $14,383, an increase in net earnings of $262,971. The year 1885, as compared with 1884, shows: A ...

David H. Ross, of No. 511 East Eightyninth-street, was sent to Sing Sing for two years by Recorder Smyth yesterday. Ross was convicted of perjury. On Dec. 17, 1884, he was sued by William D. Woods before Judge Browne, in the City Court, to recover $119.40, and a verdict was given in favor of the plaintiff.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 26.--Peter C. Graham, colored, sued David Fennessey, President of St. Mary's College, a Catholic institution in Marion County, Ky., for $30,000 in the United States court here to-day.

LONDON, Jan. 26.--Sir Michael HicksBeach, Conservative leader, gave notice in the House of Commons this afternoon that the Government would introduce on Thursday a bill to suppress the Irish National League and other dangerous societies, to prevent intimidation, to protect life and property, and to maintain public order in Ireland.

BOSTON, Jan. 26.--The subject of leasing the New-York and New-England Railroad to the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Company was discussed at a meeting to-day of the Directors of the former company.
The Tory Government has been overthrown, and Mr. GLADSTONE is face to face with the greatest problem and the grandest opportunity of his public life.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 26.--There is no change in the situation of affairs at King Philip mill. No looms are running and the striking weavers are still out. Unless a compromise is effected the entire mill will shut down at the close of the week.

Mr. "Pete" McCoy, John L. Sullivan's trusted lieutenant, and Mr. "Alf." Power, of Brooklyn, were announced to take part in a glove fight in Odd Fellows' Hall, Hoboken, last night. Power refused to go on the stage, saying that the crowd was not large enough, and left the hall. McCoy offered $25 to any one who would face him, and "Paddy" Crowley, the collar and elbow wrestler, boxed with him for four uninteresting rounds.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 26.--The creditors of Henry B. Wells, dry goods, who failed recently with liabilities of about $18,000, have accepted 50 cents on the dollar.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Jan. 26.--From reports received to-day from every locality where peaches are grown in Ulster County and along the Hudson Valley generally it appears that the cold weather was too much for the buds.

Mary Graham lived for a number of years on West Thirty-sixth-street, in the same house with her niece and nephews. After her death on June 18 a will was found, which was made 25 years ago, disposing of her estate, valued at $40,000.

Gray-haired Andrew Anderson, who has been Collector of Taxes in the township of West Hoboken, N.J., for the last 17 years, was arrested yesterday on a bench warrant issued by Judge McGill, of the Hudson County Court of General Sessions. An indictment for embezzlement has been found against him.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26.--News was received in New-Haven to-night that Minnie E. Cramer, sister of the ill-fated Jennie Cramer whose body was round on the West Haven beach nearly five years ago, died this morning in Brooklyn, N.Y., to which city the family removed soon after the trial of James and Walter Malley, who were accused of murdering Jennie Cramer. Minnie was 18 years old.

POCAHONTAS, Ark., Jan. 26.--On Sunday night, as Special Constable Stove Dame was bringing here a negro prisoner, Sam Evans, alias Sam Patch, whom he had under arrest, when within about one mile of town the negro broke for the woods, and the officer fired, killing his man as he ran.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 26.--At 2 o'clock this afternoon Milton Weston, convicted of being an accessory to the murder of Obadiah Haymaker, who was killed during the Murraysville riots, appeared in the Sheriff's office with his bondsmen and gave himself up.

The programme of last evening's concert at the Academy of Music was made up of numbers chosen from the repertoire of Mr. Thomas's orchestra by frequenters of the entertainments given under his direction.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 26.--A serving girl in the employ of George E. Sparrow, of Watkins, a dealer in railroad supplies, while sweeping the kitchen a day or two since, came across two flat little pieces of iron. She supposed they were rubbish of some kind and threw them into the stove with the sweepings.

The contest in the Ohio Senate over the right of the sitting members from Hamilton County to their seats is one of those deplorable struggles that are almost inevitable when an effort is made to undo the results of political fraud in the face of a majority constituted by the fraud itself.
Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities at auction at the Liberty-Street Real Estate Exchange yesterday, the bidding on some lots being very active:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 27.--A smoothfaced, well dressed young man to-day presented a check for $372 at the German-American Bank with Secretary of State Cook's signature attached. The Cashier suspected the check was a forgery.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 27.--During the past three weeks the Kentucky Assembly has been trying to ratify the action of the Penitentiary Commissioners in dismissing Warden South upon charges connected with the escape of Desperado Alsop and others nearly two years ago, upon which occasion several persons were killed.

CHICAGO, Jan.27.--S.M. Nickerson, L.F. Gage, and other officers and stockholders of the First National Bank of this city to-day flied an answer to the suit brought by Henry Clews, of New-York, and other persons in the East, to set aside the reorganization of the bank in April, 1882, and to compel an accounting.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 27.--The Catholic Universe will say in its issue of to-morrow: "From reliable information received from home we feel justified in saying that the Holy Father has determined in the near future to create the Most Rev. James Gibbons, Archbishop of Baltimore, a Cardinal.
The American Ornithologists' Union has recently been giving attention to the destruction of birds for uses prescribed by fashion, and has decided to take steps to prevent its spread.

The Aqueduct Commissioners decided yesterday to construct the Sodom Dam and reservoir at an estimated cost of $1,100,000. Any written communication in reference to the construction of the Quaker Bridge Dam and reservoir will be received up to March 1.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 27.--The establishment of Sullivan Burke, boot and shoe dealers of Newport, have been closed by creditors. Writs of arrest for fraud were served at the suit of Brayman Trafford, of this city, and both Sullivan and Burke were held in bail.

The proposed reorganization scheme of the Louisville, Evansville and St. Louis Railroad Company seems now to be an assured success. A majority of the first mortgage bondholders have already made deposits in its favor with the reorganization Trustee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27, 1886. The President will give a state dinner to the members of the United States Supreme Court on Thursday evening, Feb. 4.
It is stated with much impressiveness that a Western dramatist is about to construct a play in which he will introduce left motifs after the manner of WAGNER.

A brief telegram in yesterday's TIMES announced the arrest, at Norwich, Conn., of Cashier Samuel Bingham, of the Windham National Bank of Willimantic. The charge against Mr. Bingham is brought under the national bank act, and is based on the taking by him of heavy and unlawful commissions on paper ...
TORONTO, Jan. 27.--Peter Ryan, who recently purchased the Joseph Hall Manufacturing Works at Oshawa, has failed, with liabilities of $100,000.

LONDON, Jan. 27.--The business in the House of Commons began last night with ingenious attempts of the Government to postpone the discussion of Mr. Collings's amendment on compulsory allotments until to-morrow, when, as Sir Michael Hicks-Beach had previously announced, new measures of coercion ...

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 27.--Coleman Freeman, of Windsor, Ontario, on the opposite side of the river from this city, better known as "Dad," died last night at the great age of 120 years. He was born in Virginia, and for many years was a slave. Given his liberty by a kind master, he came North by slow stages and settled in Windsor over 40 years ago.

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 27.--Charles A. Wilson, an attorney in this city, has been summoned, and Hattle A. Engley has been arrested on a suit brought against them by Levi W. Wilson for false imprisonment, with damages laid at $15,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--The House Committee on Military Affairs to-day instructed Mr. Viele to report favorably the bill introduced by Mr. Dowdney for the erection of a monument in New-York City to the memory of Gen. Grant.

TRENTON, Jan. 27.--When the Legislature of New-Jersey first met Mr. R. Wayne Parker, of Newark, determined to take the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad by tha horns and drop it into Staten Island Sound by offering a resolution enthusiastically protesting against the kill Von Kull bridge and committing the State against permitting its erection there.

Mrs. Juliette Thourault, a Frenchwoman of 60, has been missing from her home, No. 1,217 Third-avenue, since Monday, and her relatives believe that she has committed suicide. The family is very poor and consists of Prosper Thourault, the husband of the missing woman, and a daughter Felice, a girl of 17, who is in poor health.
The usual Thomas Popular Concert may be attended this afternoon at the Academy of Music.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 27--Intelligence from vermillion, on the Lake Shore Road, west of Cleveland, announces the narrow escape of a resident of that place from lynching yesterday afternoon. John Horn, a mechanic, living at the hamlet or Birmingham, was arrested fot indecently assaulting his daughter Alice, aged 14.

It is difficult to assign any worthy motive for the conduct of the seven Republican Senators who have been standing aloof from their associates and threatening a division in the Senate which may prove embarrassing to the work of the session.

A representation of "The Magic Flute" that did not differ in interest or quality from the performances supplied during the past fortnight by the company of English-speaking artists now occupying the Academy of Music was offered there last evening to the manifest satisfaction of a large audience.

TRENTON, Jan 27.--The ninety-ninth annual communication of the Masonic Grand Lodge of this State was began in the new Masonic Temple here to-day. Several hundred prominent members of the order attended.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 27.--The Dutchess County Medical Society met in extraordinary session to-day to consider charges of conspicuous advertising against Dr. Samuel Wimpleberg.

Mr. P.D. Armour, Partner Plankinton, and other Western Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Company have left New-York, and President Mitchell was kept busy all day yesterday answering leading questions from Wall-street men anxious to know what business really had been transacted at the daily meetings of the week past.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27.--Congressman Boutelle to-day sought, but failed to obtain, leave to lay formally before the House and to have printed in the Record certain citations from official documents is support of his statement in relation to the destruction of the dry dock at Portsmouth, Va. Congressman Wise, of Virginia, had declared that the dry dock had never been destroyed.
The Senate Committee on Territories advises the Senate that the time has come for the creation of a State in Washington Territory.

There is an air of indirection that closely approaches bad faith about the conduct of the Republican Senators in the matter of removals and appointments.
