NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 31.--While coasting on Hedge's Alley to-day John Kennedy, a boy of 12, and living at No. 62 Hoyt-street, ran under the feet of two horses which were attached to a coach being driven rapidly by the end of the alley. One of the horses stepped on his breast and the wheels of the carriage passed over him. He was taken to his home, and his injuries are pronounced fatal.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 31.--Before Judge Don A. Pardee, in the United States Circuit Court, to-morrow, will be heard the application filed by the Bell Telephone Company for an injunction to issue against the National Telephone Company.

--Mr. Ralph Disraeli has just published in London another volume of his brother's (Lord Beaconsfield's) letters. They were addressed to his sister during the earlier years of his social and political career and contain accounts of interviews with Louis Philippe, Prince Albert, and other leading men of that time.
The steamship Servia, of the Cunard Line, which was in collision with the Red Star steamship Noordland in the North River on Saturday, proceeded to sea at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

THE TIMES'S reporter who visited No. 314 Madison-street presented himself to Mrs. Wilcox, who is a sister of the comedian Frank Bush and the mother of Mrs. Augustus J. Bruno, who is well known in traveling theatrical companies. Oscar Wilcox has never seen his father.
TROY, N.Y., Jan. 31.--An interesting struggle between the Knights of Labor and the Fuller Warren Company, owners of the Clinton foundry in this city was developed yesterday afternoon.
The United Labor Exchange, of Brooklyn, gave an instrumental concert yesterday afternoon, in the Brooklyn Theatre, for the benefit of the Exchange.

A neatly dressed young man walked into the Mulberry-street police station at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, and walking up to the desk said: "Sergeant, I've come to give myself up. I stabbed my brothor-in-law last night and he's dead."

The bill recently passed in the Brazilian Legislature for the gradual abolition of slavery decrees that all slaves over 60 years of age shall be free. Those remaining are to be divided into classes according to age and value.

Year by year the results of the business with the fire underwriters become less and less favorable, and it is rapidly becoming, as the former Superintendent of Insurance, Mr. McCall, said a few weeks ago, merely a question of the survival of the fittest.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 31.--Lawyers John Hackett and John H. Milard have asked Judge Barnard to discharge Sarah L. Raphael from the Hudson River State Hospital, on the ground that she is not insane.

February does not fail to present objects of interest to lovers of the stars. The three planets, Venus, Jupiter, and Saturn, play prominent parts on its starry records. Venus, after her superb career as evening star, disappears from the western sky only to reappear before the month closes "under the opening eyelids of the morn."

DENVER, Col., Jan. 31.--At Telluride, Col., on Wednesday morning last, a snowslide demolished four cabins at the Sheridan mine, burying 22 men under 17 feet of snow. David Overstreet, Sims Bree, William Harford, and Michael Mitchell were killed; William Delaney and Richard Evans were fatally injured, and John Churchill and John Hanna badly injured.

Several well known physicians and surgeons yesterday met casually in a down-town drugstore, and naturally the conversation centred upon topics that most closely interest the members of this profession. Each had his little story of phenomenal cures of supposed fatal injuries or sickness.

The recently submitted reports of Labor Commissioner PECK, of this State, and Labor Commissioner HADLEY, of Connecticut, deal with the subject of immigration from one point of view, and the annual report of the New-York State Board of Charities deals with it from another.

The several organizations of firemen and brakemen in the service of the Pennsylvania Railroad held meetings yesterday morning in their respective halls to take action upon the new compulsory system of insurance the company proposes to enforce against it employes.

The Humane Society has decided to warn George Day and Thomas Russell, the Rubicon farmers, not to cut the horns off any more cattle. Farmers in other parts of the State are resorting to the same practice, and the society will try to stop it.

A rumor, which appears to have originated in Boston, was prevalent in some quarters last night to the effect that Mr. Parnell had been assassinated.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31.--Henry Lambert, in the employ of a German farmer, living near Squires Mills, on the Housatonic, got up early one morning recently and went to the barn to feed his stock.

Peter Dwyer's West Side Mission, on West Thirty-fifth-street, near Ninth-avenue, was not open for service yesterday, and the neighborhood was busy with gossip over the reformer's absence, which has now been protracted beyond a week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1.--With the activity that is possible to a rich and confident monoply the Bell Telephone people are kicking up a great cloud of dust in the capital, promoting talk about the alleged scandalous actions of high public officers, stimulating their partisans to belittle and misrepresent the motives of Secretary Lamar and the other officers...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 1.--At Lebanon today Judge R.A. Burton and Samuel Averett, Directors in a bank, quarreled over matters pertaining to the institution, when Averett declared that Burton was a liar.
The remarkably ingenious application of the cat to theatrical advertising, recently made in Chicago, opens up a field of usefulness for that hitherto impracticable domestic animal.

HUNTINGTON, Penn., Feb. 1.--During the temporary absence from home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Westbrook to-day their residence was broken open and robbed of $4,500 in gold and many valuable papers. The old couple had been saving the money for 15 years, and instead of depositing in a bank had secreted it in an old trunk up stairs.

At the annual meeting of the Dry Goods Importers' Association of New-York yesterday V. Mumford Moore was elected President, James McCreery Vice-President, Henry W. Curtiss Secretary, and William E. Iselin Treasurer.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 1.--Frank Hiscock opened the trial of the Wilkinson cases to-day by submitting in evidence the will of John Wilkinson, father of the defendants. The will was admitted to probate Sept. 29, 1862.
The Directors of the Cunard Steamship Company have decided to place on their line between Boston and Liverpool the steamships Oregon, Gallia, Bothnia, and Scythia, and to retire the Cephalonia.

WILMINGTON, Feb. 1.--The remains of the wife of Secretary Bayard will be deposited in the family vault in the cemetery of the old Swedish church to-morrow afternoon by the side of her daughter, whose body was laid to rest in the ancient burying ground just a fortnight to-morrow.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 1.--The Common Council of this city met to-night. Alderman Peter Atkinson, who was elected City Treasurer Jan. 25, refused to accept that position.

The Treasury statement for the month of January, which we print this morning, shows a reduction of the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, of $8,672,553 81, making a total reduction since the present Administration took office of $46,204,030 35.

The annual statement of the Norfolk and Western Railroad Company shows that the gross earnings for 1885 were $2,771,120, an increase of $59,967 over 1884.

ALBANY, Feb. 1.--Senator Murphy presented a resolution to the Senate to-night calling for an investigation of the New-York Emigration Bureau. It was tabled, on motion of Senator Sloan, until further opportunity was afforded. It was as follows:
Miss May A. Lewis was married to Thomas W. Lindsay, Commander of Cushing Post, No. 231, G.A.R., last evening at the Sixth-Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1, 1886. Congressman Belmont has appointed Harry Spofford, son of Librarian Spofford, to be Clerk of the Foreign Affairs Committee. Mr. Spofford held this place when Mr. S.S. Cox was Chairman of the committee.
LONDON, Feb. 1.--Mr. Gladstone left London this morning for Osborne in response to the command of the Queen.
Mrs. Alexander Henderson, otherwise known to the playgoing public as Miss Lydia Thompson, returned to this city on Sunday morning last from Washington and registered at the Westminster Hotel.

While Chairman Kelly and the Secretaries of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association were counting out the contributions for Parnell that were showered upon the table in the Hoffman House parlor last evening Mayor Grace walked up to the table and drew from his wallet a check for $500.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1.--Officers of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company say that already more than half the men in the service of the company have applied for the benefits of the relief department.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 1.--President Adams returned yesterday from an important trip to Washington, where he went to appear before the Committee on Agriculture in the interest of a bill now before Congress, which, if passed, will greatly strengthen the Agricultural Department in the Cornell University.

MAHANOY CITY, Penn., Feb. 1.--What on Saturday night seemed a very plain case of fratricide becomes more mysteriously involved the further it is officially investigated, and Franz Mayer, the suspected murderer of his brother, has been released from custody, though he is still kept in sight.

The drivers and conductors on 46 cars of the Fourth-Avenue Railroad making trips between the Post Office and Eighty-sixth-street are dissatisfied with the new time table which went into effect yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 1.--The first serious movement toward the building of a bridge across the river at this point is now going on. M. Bollen, a well known civil engineer, arrived this morning and at once entered upon the work of making surveys and gathering all needed data to determine the cost.

The special committee of twenty-one appointed by the Union League Club to consider the advisability of constructing the proposed Quaker Bridge Dam in connection with the new aqueduct, and to report upon the best system of storing the water of the Croton shed for the use of the city, made its report to the Commissioners of the new aqueduct on Saturday last.

AURORA, Ill., Feb. 1.--Clifford C. Stevens, a well known and respected citizen, entered his store last evening to arrange the fires for the night. On entering he was surprised to find a young man named Charles H. Ross behind the counter filling bags with nuts and confectionery.

The steamship Philadelphia, which arrived yesterday from La Guayra and other Venezuelan ports, brought as passengers Capt. McGough, Mate McGough, and three seamen of the British bark Robert Porter, which was recently lost in the Gulf of Maracaibo.

The new Commissioners appointed by Mayor Whitney took possession of their several departments in Brooklyn early yesterday morning. Corporation Counsel Jenks sat down in John A. Taylor's chair and announced William T. Gilbert...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1.--Her Majesty's Opera Company opened their season in Washington this evening with "Fra Diavolo," at Albaugh's Grand Opera House, and met with a warm reception. Mlle. Alma Fohstrom made her debut as Zerlina, and Signor Ravelli appeared as Fra Diavolo.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 1.--The Free Press Grand Haven special says: "Fire broke out at l0 o'clock to-night in the Detroit, Grand Haven and Milwaukee freight house, and within a few minutes nearly half of that immense structure, which stretches nearly three squares from south to north, was on fire.

At the monthly meeting of the Trustees of Columbia College yesterday Charles M. Da Costa was elected a Trustee. Dr. Edward R.A. Seligman made a donation of $150 per annum for five years as a prize for the best essay on political economy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1.--The Public Lands Committee of the Senate reconsidered this morning its bill making a revision of the general land laws, and having finally perfected the details directed Mr. Dolph to report it to the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1.--An examination into the case of Fisher Rubican, who was brought home insensible in a carriage last night and died shortly afterward, reveals the fact that the man's real name was Frank Fisher. The police say that early yesterday morning he was brought to the station drunk.
The annual meeting of the Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club was held yesterday afternoon in the Directors' room of the Maritime Exchange.
The Norwegian bark Tordenskjold, Capt. Gundersen, which arrived last evening from Bahia, brought the crew of the British brig Elizabeth, which was abandoned in a sinking condition on Jan. 23.

Kitty Doyle, who disappeared from Morristown last Friday with, it was thought, a young man, was found on Broad-street, Newark, last night, and was taken to Police Headquarters. She makes no explanation or her leaving home.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 1.--The Senior Class decided at a meeting this afternoon to accept the generous offer of Mr. Hayes, instructor in elocution, to produce "A Midsummer's Night Dream," ...

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 1.--J.J. Waters, the Postmaster at Quincy, a small settlement in Newton County, has been driven away by his neighbors on account of grievances personal in nature, growing out of the dislike of his manner of treating persons having business at that office.

TRENTON, Feb. 1.--Mrs. Minnie Schaefer, who accused Keeper Laverty of adultery with her while she was serving a term in the State prison, and who was indicted for perjury, pleaded not guilty to the charge to-day, and her trial was set down for next Monday.

The House took a very sensible course yesterday in adopting without dissent Mr. HANBACK'S resolution empowering the Committee on Expenditures in the Department of Justice to inquire into "any expenditure on the part of the Government relative to the rights of the Bell and Pan Electric Telephone Companies."
With an uncertain tread and downcast eyes Rollin Misguided Squire, Brevet Commissioner of Public Works, walked into his office yesterday, and sought seclusion for over an hour.
The bequest of $100,000 made by William H. Vanderbilt to the Moravian Church, NewDorp, Staten Island, was paid last Friday by the Executors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1.--The Electoral Count bill was again taken up in the Senate to-day, when Mr. Hoar moved the amendment of which he had previously given notice.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 1.--During a meeting of associated ministers here to-day a resolution was adopted urging the State Assembly to pass an act making gambling a felony in Kentucky. Such a bill is now being considered by the Legislature, and the entire ministry of the State is lending it a helping hand.

"Are you going to protest against President McKnight's decision in the Burch case?" was the question propounded by a TIMES reporter yesterday to Major George F. Williams, the Secretary of the Metropolitan Baseball Club.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 1.--The most magnificent street pageant ever seen in the Northwest was witnessed here to-day. It was preliminary to the formal dedication of the Ice Palace to the Winter carnival.

The Baptist ministers yesterday were entertained and instructed in regard to prison reform. William M.F. Round related his experiences and conclusions as a delegate to the recent convention of prison associations at Rome.
MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 1.--James Hunter, the leading shipper of this port and of Pascagoula, Miss., died last night under very peculiar circumstances.
PANAMA, Jan. 24.--One of the most diabolical plots ever planned to overthrow a Government has just been discovered in Guatemala, the most thriving republic in Central America.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 1.--J.B. Snell, a decidedly good-looking young man, was arrested to-day on a charge of obtaining money on false pretence. He recently advertised for lady pupils to learn water-color painting.

Decisions were rendered by the United States Supreme Court yesterday in four cases involving the validity of the legislation by which the State of Virginia has attempted to avoid its obligation to receive the coupons of bonds issued under authority of the act of 187l in payment of taxes.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1.--James W. Sherman, a special broker on the Chicago Board of Trade, committed suicide at his home in Waukesha, Wis., early yesterday morning by inhaling chloroform.

Mr. Lawrence Barrett, after a year's absence from New-York, returned to the stage of the Star Theatre last evening, appearing in "Hernani" amid brilliantly attractive surroundings, to be greeted with manifestations of esteem, emphatically expressed, by one of the most remarkable audiences of the present dramatic season.

LIVERPOOL, Feb. 1.--A mutiny occurred to-day among the lads on the reformatory ship Clarence, which is lying in the Mersey. At a preconcerted signal the lads in a body attacked the officers with belaying pins, firearms, and other weapons.
Julius Reinmann, a boy of 16, of No. 217 Scholes-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, was found yesterday afternoon lying dangerously wounded by the roadside in Middle Village, Long Island.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1.--Two fatal accidents occurred in this city to-day. John Kenney, of No. 117 View-street, a brakeman on the Hartford Division of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad, was almost instantly killed at Tin Bridge, in this city, his morning.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1.--John G. Jones, a colored man, recently addressed a letter to exPresident Hayes in reference to the Slater fund, of which Mr. Hayes is a Trustee.
The Uniformed Veteran Corps of the Seventh Regiment held their twelfth annual meeting at Mazzetti's last evening.

Michael Duffy was in the Legislature, some years ago, he brought forward a famous bill to "attack the rocks" of Harlem, and it was through his engineering that the marshy wastes of that region were reclaimed and the cliffs, frowning with their batteries of goats, were hewn down and blasted.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 1.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20 to 17 . Drafts on New York, telegraphic, 25 to 22 .

OSWEGO, N.Y., Feb. 1.--W.F. Ahern, an express messenger of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad and a resident of this city, has fallen heir to $115,000 by the death of an uncle, who was a London banker.
The first annual ball of the Brooklyn Volunteer Firemen's Association was held last evening at the Academy of Music, in that city.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 1.--The all-engrossing topic of conversation here to-day has been the butchery of yesterday. The Coroner's investigation began at 10:30 o'clock this morning and lasted until 5 o'clock this evening.

Anna Littman, the servant girl whose mother had complained against Mrs. D.C. Potter, of No. 120 Second-avenue, charging that the latter would not let the girl go home, was taken to the Essex Market Police Court yesterday afternoon by Agent Young, of the...

BALTIMORE, Feb. 1.--The Times, an evening newspaper, which was started last Fall as a Gorman Democratic organ, has given up the ghost, and an assignment was made to-day to the typefounders, John A. Ryan Co.
The latest development in telegraphy-- that of sending and receiving messages on a moving train--was successfully tested yesterday on the Staten Island Railroad.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 1.--The initiatory step is being taken to-night to wipe out all lottery franchises and all branches of such schemes in this State. The people declare all legislative franchises unconstitutional that tend to recognize the swindles, and the object is to get such legislation as will wipe them out of existence.

Mr. JACOB SHARP has decided, it appears, that it would be a breach of decorum for him to vindicate himself against the charge of having bribed the Board of Aldermen until he has secured the consent of the Court of Appeals.

Isaacs, Vought Co., of No. 56 Wallstreet, are Custom House brokers, who do an extensive business. Samuel Craemer is an 18year-old lad who works for the firm.

COLUMBUS, Ohio Feb. 1.--The Senate will convene to-morrow afternoon and by agreement adjourn over until Wednesday. Little information can be gained from the subcommittee of the Senate as to what progress has been...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1.--Post Chaplain M.N. Adams has been relieved from duty in the Department of the Platte and will proceed to St. Paul and await retirement.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 1.--Recently information was received from a detective agency in New-Mexico to the effect that John Connors, who murdered Supervisor Casey in this city a number of years ago, was located in that Territory.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 1.--A sensation was created here to-day by the discovery of an attempt to blow up the passenger ferryboat Pearl with dynamite.
Commissioner Edmund Stephenson has sent a letter to President Henry A. Hurlbut, of the Emigration Board, declining to continue as a member after the expiration of his term on the 11th inst.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 1.--The Rev. Dr. C. L. Goodell, Pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, had an attack of apoplexy at about midnight last night.
WARSAW, Ind., Feb. 1.--W.W. Mikles, of Barbour, Ind., and V.J. Card, of this place, have been arrested on a charge of forging several thousand dollars' worth of notes against...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1.--The Supreme Court of the United States to-day rendered the following decisions:
SING SING, N.Y., Feb. 1.--The earnings at Sing Sing Prison for the month of January were $21,498 06 and the expenditures $15,495 89, making the profit for the month $6,002 17.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 1.--At Chester, Va., on Sunday night, while Sheriff Hood was in the jail in the discharge of his duties, he was attacked by three colored prisoners who succeeded in getting the keys of the jail and a pistol away from him. A scuffle ensued, in which the pistol dropped to the floor. The Sheriff regained possession of it and shot one prisoner dead, after which the other two surrendered.
In the case of Thomas A. Dowling, on trial at Paterson for shooting Z.M. Ward, of that city, yesterday was occupied in presenting the case to the jury by the counsel and the court.
PARIS, Feb. 1.--The Temps states that France has not thus far joined the other powers in coercing Greece.

GRAND HAVEN, Mich., Feb. 1.--The large freight house of the Detroit, Grand Haven and Milwaukee Railroad is now on fire. The station is threatened, and the elevator and new warehouses will probably go, making nearly a mile of flames. The steamers have withdrawn to a place of safety.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1.--It will not be the fault of Senator Edmunds, the leader of the intensely partisan portion of the Republican Senators, if the public is not treated to a lively debate on the rights of the Senate and the powers of the Executive.

The decision of Judge J.F. Daly that the city bonds or stock in the possession of the Sinking Fund Commissioners yet represent an existing valid indebtedness of the city was affirmed by the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.

A.D. Juilliard, Receiver of Hoyt, Spragues Co., is paying a dividend of 2 per cent. to the creditors whose claims have been allowed. The magnitude of the failure can be judged when 2 per cent. of the allowed claims amounts to $200,000.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1.--The Directors of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company met this afternoon for the purpose of considering the proposals of the New-York and NewEngland Company to lease that road to the former corporation.
Louis Spengermann, of East One Hundred and Fifth-street, was engaged two weeks ago to attend the lunch counter at Carl Goerwitz's saloon, No. 194 Third-avenue.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1.--The Baxter Wrecking Company has raised the schooner lost with all hands off Milford three weeks ago. The vessel proves to be the Henry C. Gibbs, of St. George, Me. No bodies can be found, and it is certain that the crew were washed out of the rigging. The Gibbs must have been scudding before the gale when she sank. She will be unloaded where she now lies.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 1.--Edward Bowman, charged with complicity in the murder of Emory Thayer in Livingston County last October, was arrested at Johnstown, Penn., by Detective Kavanagh, of this city, and brought here Saturday night.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1.--The last sale of securities belonging to the broken Townsend Savings Bank took place to-day.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1.--Prof. Thompson, of the University of Pennsylvania, has been engaged by Yale College as an additional lecturer on political economy.
BOSTON, Feb. 1.--The New-York and New-England bond sale question appeared in a new form in the Legislature to-day.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1.--The Chicago, St. Louis and Missouri River Passenger Association finally went to pieces to-day over the question of the Northwestern business.

Two messenger boys, Harry Cashman, of No. 29 Allen-street, and Isaac Landig, of No. 36 Essex-street, took a message to Mrs. Custer, widow of Gen. Custer, at her apartments, No. 148 East Eighteenth-street, on Sunday afternoon.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 1.--There was a trial with very unusual results in the Waterbury Police Court to-day. Valentine Bohl, who keeps the largest meat market in the city, was accused of having offered for sale three partridges after Jan. 1, contrary to the State statutes.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 1.--Gen. J.C. Rowley, who for the past three or four years has been seriously ill at the residence of his son-in-law in this city, is sinking rapidly again. In the early part of last week he began to gain strength, and for a few days surprised his physicians, but the rally did not prove lasting, and dissolution now seems probable at any time.
PARIS, Feb. 1--The text of the treaty between France and Madagascar has been submitted to the Chamber of Deputies. The document consists of 19 articles of agreement.

The following letter was received yesterday by the Grant Monument Association: "Inclosed find $13.75 as a contribution to the Grant National Monument fund of New-York City from the committee of letter carriers of the United States of the late eight-hundred-dollar class, being the unexpended balance of a testimonial fund."

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 1.--It is said to-day that the Canadian syndicate, representatives of which made an inspection trip over the Cincinnati, Wabash and Michigan Railroad last week, is already the owner of the property.

ALBANY, Feb. 1.--In the Court of Appeals today, the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following business was transacted: No. 500--John Braun, respondent, vs. Charles J. Freygang, appellant.--Dismissed, without costs, under rule 21.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 1.--The aftermath of the season of bank failures of 1885 was reaped to-day, when it was announced that the banking firm of Ritzinger Co., composed of Frank L. and Augustus W. Ritzinger, had made an assignment to George B. Yandes as Trustee for their creditors.
GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 1.--The local Executive Board of the Knights of Labor-to-day promulgated the following order:
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 1.--Mayers McQueen, dry goods, made an assignment this afternoon. There are preferences to the amount of $12,000. The liabilities are said to considerably exceed the assets.
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 1.--John Ralston, foreman of the Journal job office for 20 years, committed suicide this morning by cutting his throat with a razor.

Delegates from the Progressive aad Central Labor Unions dashed the hopes of the United Cigar Manufacturers, yesterday, by informing Secretary Oppenheimer that the offer to compromise on an increase of 25 cents per 1,000 on the new schedule had been voted upon by the men and was declined.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 1.--The funeral of the late Henry P. Kidder took place here to-day. Private services were held at the residence of the family, and public services at 11 o'clock in the South Congregational Church, which was thronged with mourners. The Rev. Mrs. E.E. Hale and John H. Morrison officiated.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 1.--Every Evening will to-morrow, upon the most reliable authority, publish a contradiction of the report telegraphed from Washington yesterday to the effect that Secretary Bayard would resign his Cabinet portfolio, retire from public life, and go to Europe for a few months.

Believers in organized charity gathered in goodly numbers in Association Hall last night and listened to the reports of the Charity Organization Society of this city, at its fifth annual meeting. What they heard was encouraging.

The Grand Jury for the month of February was sworn in by Judge Cowing yesterday. Mr. Oliver K. King, a broker, of No. 53 Wallstreet, was selected as foreman. "If men would only cease from committing crimes," said the Judge in making his charge, ...
Mayor Haynes, of Newark, yesterday morning refused to sign the monthly pay warrants of the Police and Fire Departments, and as a result 275 men are without their pay.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Feb. 1.--At the meeting of manufacturers this afternoon the demand of the spinners for an advance in wages of 10 per cent. was discussed.

The Tarrytown burglars were out on the war path again Sunday night, when they paid a visit to J. Alexander See's residence. Mr. See is one of the Trustees of North Tarrytown, and his home is No. 34 Chestnut-street.

The organization of the new Metropolitan Board of the Church Temperance Society was completed in Grace Chapel last evening by the election of officers for the coming year. The meeting was presided over by the Rev. Dr. Henry Y. Satterlee.

Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Goelet gave a ball last night at their residence, No. 608 Fifth-avenue. There was the usual elaborate floral decoration, novel features of which were two floral peacocks, upon which the favors for the german were hung.

DANVILLE, Va., Feb. 2.--The Tobacco Association reports the sales of leaf tobacco for last month at 1,640,000 pounds at an average of 10.79 cents, against 5,596,000 pounds at an average of 13.13 cents for the preceding January.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2.--The representatives of the roads in the Missouri River Passenger Association to-day reorganized the association, so as to include all the lines in the old organization except the Chicago and Northwestern and Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul.
PARIS, Feb. 2.--The American colony here have gone into mourning over the death of Mrs. Bayard. Minister McLane has canceled the arrangements for the reception he had announced for next Friday.

The military features of the Century are of unusual importance this month. Gen. Grant's article--the last of his series, it is understood to be--has already been quoted from. The Lincoln incidents in it are singularly interesting.
The thirty-seventh annual report of the Astor Library contains much interesting information in regard to the condition and usefulnces of the institution.
The merely personal feature in the unfortunate controversy between Gen. SHERMAN and Gen. FRY is of minor public importance. It is a pity that it was not settled privately and with less acrimony.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 2.--A recent telegram to THE TIMES from Atlanta, regarding the depreciation of values here as a result of the recent prohibition election has stirred up the Prohibitionists here. Prompted by J.N. Stearns of New-York, the preachers, who are responsible for the passage of the law, met and denounced the statements made.

The Police Commissioners were in secret session yesterday investigating charges against Detective James Moran, of the Fourteenth Precinct, for levying tribute upon Harry Hill and incidentally reflecting upon the commandant of the precinct, Capt. Michael Murphy.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 2.--Frank Staub, a tailor, aged about 30 years, living with his parents in this city, Started to go to work this morning, but as he went out of the rear door of his home he drew a razor across his throat. He was picked up unconscious, and died in a few minutes. The only reason assigned for the act is sickness. His parents are German and unable to speak English.

Mr. W.S. GILBERT produced among those who met him in this country the conviction that a man may write very amusing librettos for comic operas without being a particularly estimable or agreeable person. This belief Mr. GILBERT has now taken the pains to diffuse...

The positions of the Senators of the two parties respectively touching the question of removals and appointments are supposed to be defined by the resolutions introduced in the Senate yesterday by Mr. RIDDLEBERGER On the one hand and by Mr. PUGH on the other.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2.--A dispatch from Washington says that a writ of error has been granted by the United States Supreme Court as against the decision of the Illinois Supreme Court in the case of the defaulting cashier of the old banking firm of Preston, Kean Co., Frederick M. Kerr.

The General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines were in session yesterday at Commissioner Fink's office and adopted a schedule rate for emigrants to Buffalo, and also considered the matter of fixing excursion rates to Niagara Falls as soon as the ice bridge over the river shall have been formed.

PLAQUEMINE, La., Feb. 2.--William Smith and Bernie Anselm, two young men of this place, to-day armed themselves and prepared to settle a difficulty between them. They met near a shingle mill, and after exchanging some words opened fire upon each other. Smith received four wounds, all of them painful, but not necessarily dangerous. Eight shots were fired. Anselm was uninjured.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 2.--General Manager Oakes, of the Northern Pacific, in an interview on the affairs of that company, said, in reference to the proposed big land sale east of the Missouri River, that negotiations were still pending, and the prospects were that the sale would be made.
"Lohengrin" will be the opera at the Academy of Music this evening. Mr. John E. Owens, who has been ill for a long time, is slowly recovering.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2.--The mercury is descending rapidly here to-night, and has reached 15 below. Dispatches from outside note extremely cold weather at points. In Sycamore, Ill., the thermometer this morning marked 18 below, and Galena, Ill., reports 20 below.

The Franch chef who donned a dress suit last night, and with a most interesting lisp informed all comers to the French Cooks' Ball how they should find their way through the Metropolitan Opera House without getting lost, was very tired at 1 o'clock this morning.

The first "Novelty Concert" given by Mr. Van der Stucken this season took place at Steinway Hall last evening. The programme was a brief one, its interpretation only occupying one hour and a half. It opened with Gernsheim's overture to "Waldmeister's Brautfahrt" and included...

The Ihpetonga, a social organization in Brooklyn similar in character to the Patriarchs of New-York, held a very successful reception and ball at the Assembly Roomus, in Brooklyn, last evening. The society is composed ef 50 gentlemen living on Brooklyn Heights.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2.--Post Office Inspector Metcalf to-day received a telegram from the Postmaster at Rapid City, Dakota, giving an account of a mail robbery on the stage route between Deadwood and Rapid City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2.--In the debate on the Electoral Count bill in the Senate to-day Mr. Evarts favored the recommittal of the measure to the committee. OTTAWA, Feb. 2.--A.A. Dickson, of Montreal, manufacturer of electrical instruments, has filed an application with the Minister of Agriculture with a view of testing the validity of the patent for the Blake transmitter held by the Bell Telephone Company.

Patrick S. Gilmore and his band, and the other musicians who will assist at the concert to be given at Madison-Square Garden, in aid of the Irish Parliamentary fund, are not likely to lack an audience. Although the concert will not be given until Sunday, Feb. 14, a...
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 2.--Chancellor Runyon this morning decided that the lease of the Central Railroad Company of New-Jersey to the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad should be terminated.

The twentieth anniversary of the NewYork City Church Extension and Missionary Society was held in St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, at Fourth-avenue and Twenty-secondstreet, last evening. The newly elected President, Bowles Colgate, made the opening address.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 2.--An interesting feature in the increase of real estate values is shown in Sandersville, a town of 3,000 inhabitants. While the increase for the year of the property of the whites was 16 2/8 per cent. that of the colored people was 36 per cent.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 2.--The annual report of the State Assessors for 1885 was submitted to the Legislature to-day. The report, which is comprehensive and thorough, shows that the assessed valuation of real estate has increased $802,000,000 over 1875, while the personalty...
MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 2.--Carewell and Simmons arrived at Pensacola from Wood's Holl with 500,000 young codfish Monday morning.

DES MONIES, Iowa, Feb. 2.--The House proceedings were enlivened last evening by a brisk debate upon the proposed impeachment of Walter I. Hayes, Judge of the Seventh Judical District. The movement to impeach is based upon resolutions passed by Prohibitionists at Muscatine...
The New-York Suburban Railway Company yesterday applied to the Board of Aldermen for permission to construct a railroad in the principal streets in the annexed district.
The Court of Chancery at Trenton, N.J., yesterday set aside the decision of Judge McCarter, in the Essex County Orphans' Court, in the Dietz will case.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 2.--The great strike in the coke regions is likely to cause a coke famine. The Tariff Association held a meeting yesterday to consider a question that has been agitating insurance circles for some time. Prior to 1882 no discrimination was made by underwriters in rating risks in the dry goods district in which manufacturing was carried on.
